TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Guide
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

PETITION.PARA: 1.We are opposed to the sex guide endorsed by Ms Lawrence, Minister for Health in the Keating Government, and published in the December issue of Cleo.
2.We believe that the sex guide encourages dangerous sexual practices which could have serious medical and moral effects.

PARA.TAB: We request the Senate to call on Ms Lawrence to withdraw her endorsement of this sex guide and for the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, to indicate his disapproval.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Brownhill (from 60 citizens) and Senator Herron (from 2,403 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Census
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned shows:
That the current practice of destroying the Census is denying future generations an invaluable and irreplaceable resource of data on medical, historical, social, scientific, and demographic factors.
Your Petitioners request that the Senate should:

Request the Government to review its current policy of destroying the Census; and support a proposal to retain the census forms for release for specific research purposes in either 70 or 100 years time.

PETITION.TITLE: East Timor
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned expresses our concern over the issue of East Timor.
Your petitioners therefore ask the Senate to:

PETITION.PARA: 1.reverse the decision of the Australian recognition of Indonesia as ruler of East Timor,

2.support the involvement of East Timor in the dialogue between Indonesia and Portugal under the UN auspices aimed at finding a comprehensive and internationally acceptable solution to the question of East Timor,
3.appeal for the release of Xanana Gusmao, and other East Timorese political prisoners, and
4.condemn the continuing violations of human rights taking place in East Timor.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned draw to the attention of the Senate:
We are proud to fly the Australian Flag and will oppose any changes to it.
We support the Constitutional Monarchy and will oppose any moves to turn Australia into a Republic.
We believe in loyalty to the Crown and Nation, pride in the National Anthem and respect for our existing Australian National Flag.
And your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Widows Allowance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned requests that the Widow Allowance be made available to women over 50 who were widowed, separated or divorced after they turned 40 years of age; that the allowance be paid at the Age Pension rate; and that the allowance attract the same concessions and benefits as the Age Pension.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SHORT

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I present to the Senate the following petition, from 386 citizens, which is not in conformity with the Standing Orders as it is not in the correct form:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens showeth.
Based on Australia's record and standing in the international arena in reference to the defence of fundamental human and political rights.

We who are assembled here on the steps of Parliament House, Victoria on this day the 26th of March, 1995 hereby request that the Australian Parliament (Senate), take into consideration the following points with reference to the plight of the majority Albanian population in Kosova, which was formerly one of the eight constituent federal units of Yugoslavia prior to the disintegration of the old Yugoslav Federal Republic.

On May 24, 1992, more than 80% of citizens of the Republic of Kosova, voted in free and fair multi-party elections, under the supervision of many international observers and journalists, and directly elected Dr Ibrahim Rugova as Kosova's President and also elected 130 parliamentary deputies to the Parliament of the Republic of Kosova.

As a sign of protest regarding the woeful human rights situation which characterizes daily life in Kosova for the 2 million Albanian inhabitants as a result of Serbian aggression and occupation, we are appealing for understanding and support for the peaceful path which the Albanians of Kosova have chosen in order to realise their independence, whilst also respecting the political will and legitimate right for self-determination that the overwhelming majority of the citizens of Kosova
have expressed in both popular elections and a referendum which was held in 1991.

Kosova, which declared its independence in September 1990 through the legitimate organs of the Parliamentary Assembly of Kosova, and then once again confirmed through the overwhelming participation of the majority of Kosova's citizens in the successful organization of the statewide referendum in September 1991 and the multiparty elections in May 1992 and which has consistently strived to attain its political independence through peaceful and democratic means, now endures a classic system of occupation from the Serbian authorities who rule with an iron hand. Whilst acknowledging that Kosova which has more than two million citizens,

92% of whom are ethnically Albanian, after the disintegration of Yugoslavia had the legitimate right as a formerly constitutive element in the old federation to declare independence, just like the republics of Slovenia or Macedonia.
Therefore the petitioners hereby duly request the Senate to:

PARA.TAB: 1. Recognition of the right to self-determination for the two million Albanians of Kosova.
2. Demand that the Serbian authorities immediately put an end to the systematic repression of the Albanian population in Kosova.
3. Stop the campaign of "quiet ethnic cleansing" and the forced colonization of Kosova with Serbian refugees from the former war zones of Croatia and Bosnia-Hercegovina.

4. Call on the United Nations to use preventative diplomacy to ensure that there is no outbreak of the conflict into Kosova, which includes requesting the Serbian government to demilitarise Kosova as well as supporting the deployment of some sort of international presence in Kosova to reduce the level of repression and human rights violations.

SPEECH.PARA: And your petitioners shall as in duty bound forever pray.

Attentive senators may have realised that I actually proposed a different motion earlier in this program. I was anxious about it for the reason that I did not particularly want to blow out the timetable for our last day of sitting nor gag legitimate debate which is appropriate when it is as serious as a censure motion.

PARA.TAB: I was also a little anxious that by putting it in this place rather than in the House of Representatives I would have been denying natural justice in the form of an immediate rely, even though I am sure the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) would have been quite capable of making the reply in his own chamber in due course. So, firstly, I realised there were problems in putting it on the program and proceeding to request formality for it. The second reason why I have chosen not to put it is that some Aboriginal people made contact with me expressing distress and urging me not to criticise Mr Campbell, as he listens to and supports them and is one of the few who do.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is he the only one?

—No. In fact, they named a couple of others and I was a bit embarrassed because they also named me. He is one of the people who listen to and support them. Even though they do not agree that he should disclose the name of a young person who had been charged, they pointed out how frequently this happens to their own young people and how ashamed, concerned and perturbed they are that they have not had anybody else stand up in parliament and censure those members of parliament who have disclosed the names of their young people. So that should be mentioned at this time.
—Give us a few examples of that being done.

—These people mentioned their own children and I do not wish to proceed down that track. I gave them my guarantee that when I made the censure of Mr Campbell I would state that on the public record. I feel I need to fulfil that commitment even though I am not proceeding with the formal motion. My third point is that I have decided to withdraw the motion and replace it with the one which is on the program now because it sets a precedent and I do not want to pre-empt any action which we should rightfully recognise as the responsibility of the House of Representatives to discipline its own members.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, I present the following report: Report No. 335—Finance minutes tabled in 1994, and I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I have just a few remarks. Report 335 contains copies of the two finance minutes received by the committee during the 1994 calendar year. Each of the finance minutes contained in this report has already been tabled separately, but they are reproduced now in an annual consolidation for ease of future reference. The finance minutes deal with the committee's reports on an inquiry into the Australian Taxation Office and its reviews of Auditor-General's reports tabled in the period May 1991 to September 1992.

PARA.TAB: The finance minute on report 326, an assessment of tax, was tabled in parliament on 20 October 1994, together with comments by the committee. Report 326 was the result of the first major public examination of the administration of taxation laws in Australia since the enactment of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936. In its report the committee sought to introduce balance to a system which it saw as having grown to ignore the people it serves.

When tabling the finance minute on report 326 in October last year, I noted that the vast majority of the 88 administrative recommendations had been accepted and were being implemented. I can now advise the Senate that, since that date, the committee has continued its interest and involvement in the reform process generated by report 326.

Amongst other things, the committee announced a watching brief over the work of the tax law improvement project. The improvement project was established by the government in response to one of the key recommendations in report 326—that being that the Income Tax Assessment Act be re-written and simplified.

The improvement project has already produced impressive results with its vastly simplified rewrite of the substantiation provisions of the tax law. The Joint Committee of Public Accounts will be paying close attention to the work of the improvement project over the next 12 months or so.

The second finance minute reproduced in the report I have just tabled is in relation to report 330, Review of the Auditor-General's reports, May 1991 to September 1992. Report 330 contained the results of the committee's review of the 72 audit reports tabled from May 1991 to September 1992. The committee is pleased to note that 10 of the 12 recommendations contained in the report have been accepted or accepted in principle by the relevant agencies.

One issue of concern to the committee arising from report 330 is an apparent inconsistency between information provided by the Department of Human Services and Health in response to a recommendation about the validation of nursing home funding, information provided by the same department in response to the Senate community affairs committee's recent report on nursing home funding and the findings of the recent audit report on the same subject. The committee has sought an explanation from the secretary of the department and will consider his response closely. I thank the Senate for enabling me to make these brief remarks.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present a discussion paper prepared by the Legal and Constitutional References Committee entitled Treaties and external affairs power. I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a discussion paper which relates to the reference to the Legal and Constitutional References Committee of matters dealing with the external affairs power of the Commonwealth as contained in section 51 of the constitution. This discussion paper does not in any way represent the views of the committee but is intended as an aid for those people who would wish to make a submission in relation to this reference. The deadline for submissions has now been extended to 21 April, and I am pleased to say that to date there has been a very good response to the advertising of this matter. There is obviously a keen interest in the community in this question of the external affairs power of the Commonwealth and the treaty making provisions which are related thereto. I commend the document to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would be appropriate for me, coming from one of the smaller states in the Commonwealth, to say that recently there has been an abuse of the external affairs power by the government. As a result, the division between the legislative capacity of state and federal governments has become very blurred. Indeed, the federal government has obtained a considerable dominance. It is, therefore, appropriate that this matter as outlined by Senator Ellison be given serious consideration by all people who are genuinely concerned and interested in the democratic fabric of the Australian body politic.

PARA.TAB: Clearly, this issue is of greater significance than the other constitutional issues that have been thrown around by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), such as the republic debate, because this issue ultimately affects the lives and capacities of the people in the various states of the Commonwealth to determine their own future. I recommend the discussion paper to all Australians for their consideration, look forward to the submissions that the committee will receive and trust that an appropriate framework can be developed as a result of the committee's decision making process to ensure that the blurring of the legislative competency between state and federal governments is cleared up and to ensure that the states retain a proper and appropriate role within our federal system of government.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson Sen A.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present an issues paper prepared by the Economics References Committee entitled Telecommunications developments to the year 2000 and beyond, and move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The issues paper which I have just tabled is intended to stimulate public debate in the coming months about Australia's future communications requirements and how we are best able to meet those requirements in light of the rapid—in fact, explosive—changes in telecommunications technology which have taken place. Like other physical infrastructures—roads, ports and the like—our future communications network will serve as a platform supporting social interaction, education, health, government services, business activities and our communication with the world.

PARA.TAB: Many in the community are looking to the government and to their elected representatives to play a leadership role in the new information and technology environment. Accordingly, the paper discusses a number of topical issues such as whether we should go with optical fibre technology in preference to the current hybrid coaxial cable, what sort of national information and research data we should develop and whether existing consumer safeguards are adequate given the regulatory framework we currently have. But, rather than seeking a blueprint for Australia's communications future, the paper provides a starting point and framework through which a common understanding of the key issues can be gained.

The timing of the issues paper is also important. The government is currently reviewing the duopoly arrangements with a view to introducing greater competition in telecommunications post-1997. I understand that the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Mr Lee) will make some major announcements before the budget and will introduce new legislation into this parliament before the end of the year.

It is the committee's intention to review the outcomes of the government's own telecommunications review to allow interested groups to have their say regarding the changes the government proposes to make. By doing this, we hope that we will have in place a telecommunications infrastructure and model which best suits our unique requirements and ensures that the changes in telecommunications are managed sensitively and that they are consistent with our social, economic and cultural goals. The committee looks forward to responses to the paper and will be looking further into these issues when the government announces its policy at the time of the 1995-96 budget. I commend the paper to all senators.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson Sen A.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present an issues paper prepared by the Economics References Committee entitled Issues of small business taxation: An issues paper on improving the tax treatment of small business, and move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The issues paper on small business taxation that I have just tabled sets out the concerns of the business community about its taxation responsibilities. The paper describes the various taxes and how they are applied as well as provides a sample of comments about them based on evidence received to date.

PARA.TAB: This inquiry commenced in October 1994 and had a report date of 30 March 1995. The Senate has now agreed to extend that date to 29 June 1995. The business community was very concerned that the committee's original timetable did not allow it sufficient time to consider the issues and prepare submissions. The committee has been told clearly that this inquiry is essential and that, because of the complexity of the issues, it should not be hurried.

To date, the committee has received 60 submissions. In April and May the committee will conduct hearings in Brisbane, Adelaide, Sydney, Melbourne and Canberra. The committee wants to give the business community the greatest possible opportunity to contribute to the inquiry. The aim of the issues paper is to stimulate further interest based on the information received to date to ensure that, by the time the committee comes to deliberate on its report, it is fully aware of the concerns of business.

The tax issues of concern to business include: opposition to the revised company tax lodgment and payment schedules which were due to commence in respect of the 1994-95 year and subsequent years of income, reservations about the current provisional taxation regime, complaints regarding compliance costs associated with, for example, FBT and capital gains tax, the timing of tax payments and the 10 per cent provisional tax uplift factor.

The paper will be circulated widely to the business community and to those who have already contributed to the inquiry. I look forward to the response of business to this paper. I believe that this process will assist the committee during the hearings and deliberations upon the report. I commend the issues paper to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT (DROUGHT RELIEF MEASURES) BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Crowley) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill contains the drought investment allowance and enhancements of the farm management bond scheme. These measures were first announced by the Prime Minister and Minister for Primary Industries and Energy on 8 December 1994.

The five year drought investment allowance is a 10% deduction of capital expenditure incurred on investment in fodder storage, or livestock water storage, or minimum tillage equipment or all water transport facilities. There is a cap on deductions of $5,000 per taxpayer per income year.

Farm management bonds have been made more concessional. That measure increases the "default" investment component of farm management bonds to 100%, increases the maximum holding of farm management bonds to $150,000 for each farmer, eliminates withholding tax on withdrawal of farm management bonds, and brings the treatment of farm management bonds where a farmer ceases to be engaged in primary production into line with other repayments unrelated to serious financial difficulties.

It was originally intended that the measures should come into effect on 1 July 1995. However, the Government brought them forward after representations from the National Farmers Federation and the Caucus Primary Industries and Resources Committee. The Treasurer announced this on 23 March 1995.

The drought investment allowance is now to take effect for capital expenditure incurred after 23 March 1995, the day announced in the more recent Press Release. This will give those primary producers who can incur such expenditure this financial year the opportunity to do so.

The changed arrangements for farm management bonds will now take effect on Royal Assent. The Government is seeking to speed the consideration of this bill, so that those primary producers who can make deposits of farm management bonds this financial year may have the opportunity to do so to the maximum level.
I turn now to a more detailed discussion of these measures.

The drought investment allowance provides an incentive for primary producers to invest in items that will increase their drought preparedness. It applies to capital expenditure incurred after 23 March 1995 and the items of property to which it applies must be first used to produce assessable primary production income, or installed ready for such use, by 30 June 2001. The allowance, deductible in the year the item of property is first used, will be at a rate of 10 per cent and will be additional to depreciation.

The drought investment allowance will operate similarly to the general investment allowance that ceased application at the end of June last year. To qualify, the items of property must be fodder storage facilities, or livestock water storage facilities, or minimum tillage equipment, or facilities for the transport of water. The taxpayer may incur expenditure on any one or more of these items but cannot incur expenditure in excess of $50,000 on items first used or installed ready for use in a particular year of income and claim the full allowance for all of it. The items of property must be for use in Australia to produce primary production assessable income.

The property must be retained by the primary producer for at least 12 months and must not, in that period, be made available for use by other persons. The allowance can be withdrawn at any time if property is acquired or constructed by the primary producer with the intention of dealing with it in a disqualifying manner even after the first 12 months.

The drought investment allowance will be available to leasing companies if lessees contract to use the property for not less that four years. Leasing companies will have the option to transfer some or all of their entitlement to the allowance to the lessee of the property.

Those primary producers who wish to claim the drought investment allowance on the installation of water storage facilities and water transport facilities must have an approved water conservation plan in place to be eligible for the allowance.

The purpose of such a plan is to help the primary producer in preparing the farm to survive drought better in ways that minimise any adverse effects that the installation of water storage and water transport facilities might have both on the primary producer's farm and on the environment of which the farm is a part. A plan ensures there are no significant adverse effects on water quality or availability off the farm.

As a consequence of the amendments to the Loan (Income Equalization Deposits) Act 1976, farm management bonds will become more attractive to farmers. Farm management bonds provide a greater return if they are repaid to meet certain sources of serious financial difficulties including commodity price collapse and drought.

These amendments increase the proportion of the deposit which attracts interest to 100 per cent, farmers will be able to hold up to $150,000 in farm management bonds, and the 20 per cent withholding tax that was imposed on withdrawals of farm management bonds has been removed.

When farm management bonds are not repaid because of serious financial difficulties caused by a commodity price collapse or by drought, disease, fire, flood or the like, they are repaid only as ordinary income equalization deposits. Deposits made after these changes may be repaid on the retirement of the primary producer from primary production only as though those deposits were income equalization deposits and so will have earned a lower level of interest. This brings the treatment of repayment of farm management bonds on the retirement from primary production of a primary producer into line with repayment of farm management bonds in other situations where there is no collapse of commodity prices or other disaster.
Full details of the amendments are contained in the explanatory memorandum circulated to honourable senators.
I commend the bill to the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that further consideration of the second reading of this bill be adjourned until the first day of sitting of the winter sittings, in accordance with the order agreed to on 29 November 1994.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Herron)—I present an application for funds from the Advance to the President of the Senate 1994-95 for the Department of the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Legal and Constitutional References Committee on the protection afforded to the various words and symbols associated with Sydney 2000 Olympics, together with the transcript of evidence, submissions and documents received by the committee.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: This report came about as a result of Sydney gaining the 2000 Olympics. It will come as no surprise to the Senate that the estimated cost of the Olympic Games will be somewhere in the region of $1.7 billion. Of that, the Commonwealth contribution will be $150 million and the contribution by the New South Wales government will be $30 million. Revenue from the games is estimated at $454 million. This does not include television rights. What we are dealing with is a great deal of money. In fact, there is an aspect of risk in this in that if the games would fail it could well be the taxpayer who bears the brunt of that.

PARA.TAB: There was some concern expressed in relation to the protection of Olympic words and symbols. If investors are to be attracted to invest in the Sydney Olympics, they must be given some form of security that their investment will be safe and that it will not be subject to someone else ambushing the market, so to speak. That is why it is terribly important that in 1995 we look ahead to the year 2000 and make plans for adequate legislation to protect us.

There is an obligation of an international nature on the host city to protect the olympic symbol. Former Olympic Games have had the protection and assurance from host cities that the symbols, such as the olympic rings, will not be copied and used by any unauthorised person. It is terribly important that we strike a balance in relation to the protection to be afforded to this one-off event.

I would not normally advocate regulation of this nature in the marketplace. I much prefer a free market. In this case, we have an unusual situation involving one event that is of great moment and cost. Therefore, it has to be looked at very carefully.

The committee received 35 submissions in relation to its inquiry. It took evidence at public hearings in Sydney on 12 September last year. Submissions were received from a range of interested parties, including the Sydney Olympic Games Organising Committee and the New South Wales government. The central issue was whether the Commonwealth should provide additional protection to the organisers of the Sydney 2000 games for the olympic words and symbols.

A significant problem facing the Olympics organisers is ambush marketing. Ambush marketing refers to the unauthorised association by businesses of their products for the marketing of a sporting event without paying for those rights. It goes without saying that the Sydney Olympics would be a prime target for such ambush marketing. I refer to the action between Visa and American Express over the Albertville Winter Olympics in 1992. Visa had the sponsorship of the games, and it was alleged that American Express tried to encroach on it and unfairly advertise in relation to that event. So legislation was needed in that instance to protect the substantial investment by Visa.

The other side of the coin is the question of balance. A sporting or charitable group might in a harmless way use something which could be associated with the games. It, too, might suffer some legal sanction. I refer to page 94 of the report, which stated that recipients of letters from the Canadian Olympic Trust, which was entrusted with protecting the olympic words and symbols, included a men's amateur hockey team at Scarborough in Ontario and a Toronto bicycle shop for using stick-man logos similar to the official olympic symbols. Similarly, the Muscular Dystrophy Association of Canada was forced to drop the stick person symbol it had used for over six years. That could well be an example of where this can go too far. That is where we really need to strike a balance.

One problem that the committee heard of was a system for gaining injunctive relief to stop someone using improperly an olympic word or symbol. At the moment, I suggest that there is some convoluted process in relation to such an application. It was submitted that there should be legislation which can afford quick release so that one can stop unauthorised advertising in its tracks and seek corrective advertising.

The committee was convinced that existing laws are inadequate to meet the special circumstances of the games. This opinion is based on the legal advice the committee received in relation to current legislation. In all, the committee has made 17 recommendations on the additional measures which it believes should be taken to protect olympic words and symbols. The committee has recommended specific purpose legislation to protect olympic related expressions.

The committee is of the view that, without additional measures, there is a likelihood that not only will ambush marketing of the Sydney games occur on an unprecedented scale but also that this will be to the detriment of the game's organisers' budget and, in turn, could have ramifications for the taxpayers of Australia. The committee also recommended that specific purpose legislative measures be introduced to facilitate the Olympic organisers' abilities to seek and obtain urgent injunctions and also that there be corrective advertising. If someone does transgress the provisions of this legislation, then they would have to place corrective advertising in order to remedy the situation.

Next to the report there is a schedule dealing with those expressions which would be considered as impinging on the phrase `Olympic words and symbols'. For instance, it stated that the words `Olympic' and `Olympics' should not be used in conjunction with the words `games' `gold', `medals', `millennium' or `summer'. If you have a combination of those words, they could well represent an association with the Olympic Games. On their own there might not be any trouble with them, but once you get them combined you have this representation that they are associated with the Olympic Games.

I also add that there are some businesses presently which use the word `Olympic'. I refer to Olympic Tyres and the Olympic Coffee Cafe. It is intended that they should remain. There should be no interference with the use of that word in those cases. Those businesses have been using those words for some time, and the running of their business should not be disrupted.

I would like to thank the witnesses who appeared before the committee. I would like to thank the chair of the former committee—the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs—Senator Cooney. In particular, I would like to thank the committee secretariat for its efforts on this reference and putting together a report which I believe will be of great value.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to say a few words, although Senator Ellison has covered the issues raised in this report very well. I would like to take the opportunity of paying tribute to Senator Ellison. This is the first report that he has brought in as Chairman of the Senate Legal and Constitutional References Committee. The result, as indicated in this report, shows the skill, the learning and the patience that he displayed as chairman in bringing this report to the parliament.

PARA.TAB: The committee system works very well, but a lot depends on the chairman. Sometimes the system falls away from working less than perfect. When a committee does perform as it should, proper tribute should be paid to the chairman. I simply acknowledge my respect and my thanks for the way Senator Ellison has chaired this committee and brought this report forward.

I also join with Senator Ellison in thanking the secretariat. In that context, I pay tribute to Anne Twomey, because I think it was her first reference committee report. She displayed the energy and the learning that was displayed by her predecessor, Paul Griffiths. I would like to put that on the record. Of course, the other members of the secretariat—Peter Thomson, Steven Bull, Marina Ellis and Lois Carroll—are a mighty asset that Anne Twomey has available to her.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak very briefly to this report of the Senate Legal and Constitutional References Committee. I endorse the comments made by my colleague Senator Cooney about the chair of the committee, Senator Ellison. During the short time that Senator Ellison has been chair of the committee, he has made an enormous contribution to the work of the committee.

PARA.TAB: I also want to pay a huge tribute to the committee's secretariat. This committee, along with its sister committee—the Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee—is probably the hardest working committee of the Senate. We continually get references from the Senate to look at legislation, with very tight guidelines which we are not always able to meet. The secretariat does a phenomenal job in assisting the members of the committee and in assisting the committee as a whole to meet their obligations to the Senate. Due credit to those people must be put on the record for the amount of work they do and for the extraordinary hours that they put in so that the committee can meet its obligations to the chamber.

The matter of the Olympic symbols, and the protection of them, is of deep interest to the city of Sydney and to the state of New South Wales. As a Western Australian senator, and as a member of the committee, I felt that there was a broader interest in this matter. Whilst we have not accepted all of the suggestions that came from SOGOC, the planning committee for the games, my mind has been perhaps influenced to a certain extent by the fact that there is an Australian investment in those games, not just a Sydney or a state of New South Wales investment. Indeed, the Commonwealth government has pledged $150 million to assist the games. I do believe that each state, in particular the outlying states—Queensland, the Northern Territory and Western Australia—ought to be in a position to benefit from the games, but they ought not to be in any way intrusive of, and interfering in, the marketing that must go on to raise the enormous amount of money that is required to ensure that the games are a success.

I think the 17 recommendations that the committee has put forward have been very well considered and that they will fit the bill. I expect there will be some disappointment and complaints from some quarters that perhaps we have not gone far enough and have not met each and every one of the suggestions that we have put forward to the committee. Nonetheless, I think we have reached a happy medium and a good balance in the recommendations that we have put forward. We put forward those recommendations in an environment in which there is a strong push to deregulate. We are suggesting and recommending to the parliament, and will be suggesting later to the government, that we increase regulation. We are doing that for a very good reason.

TALK.START.PARA: —A bit of orderly marketing.

—Senator Boswell has said for `a bit of orderly marketing'. I feel it is a very good reason. I am personally in favour of regulation, but I am prepared to listen to arguments about deregulation and give them consideration. I think this is a case where regulation is required. The evidence that was put to the committee showed that individuals and companies throughout the world have, in the past, sought to exploit and jump on the bandwagon of previous Olympic Games—not only the summer games, which Sydney is going to host, but also the winter games.

PARA.TAB: I have a somewhat personal interest in the Paralympics. I have found out in the last couple of weeks that this building of ours and indeed the airports of Australia are not really sympathetic to people who are not completely and fully fit. The Paralympics will be another important event, which is not to be overlooked as we approach the summer games. I think the report is a well considered document. I hope that it will be given the due consideration it deserves. Indeed, the detractors from the recommendations in the report will understand that the committee has approached this with a very open mind as to what is required to ensure that the 2000 Sydney Olympics are a success.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to address the report of the Legal and Constitutional References Committee as a member of the committee who did not participate in the hearings and did not participate in the preparation of the report. My colleagues on the committee know the reason for that. I disqualified myself from sitting on that committee for the purposes of this hearing so as to ensure that there could be no allegation of conflict of interest. The reason being that the sporting discipline I have represented this country in for a number of years and will continue to represent this country in is subject to consideration by the IOC for return to the Winter Olympics either in 1998 or 2002. I did not want it seen in any way that my participation in this inquiry could influence the AOC in how it is going to deal with that matter when it comes before the IOC.

PARA.TAB: As an athlete, I feel it is appropriate to make a few comments in relation to the recommendations. Again, I wish to make those comments not with the intention of swaying the AOC but merely to put a few concerns that I have on the record. I congratulate the members of the committee who did participate in the inquiry and, in particular, I would also like to thank my colleague Senator McGauran for sitting in on the inquiry on my behalf. That was much appreciated as far as I am concerned.

I note that in recommendation No. 6, one of the 16 very well prepared recommendations, the committee recommends protection of words combined with other words—that is, for instance, a word out of list A combined with a word out of list B. For example, olympic city, millennium paralympics, millennium paralympian or millennium olympian would be protected. I do not think many people would have concerns about that. The question is exactly how the combination of words should be defined. Is it simply one word followed by another—for example, olympic city or olympic sponsor—or would that protection be drafted so widely as to catch, say, a phrase like sponsor of our olympic athlete X.

That is my concern. The difficulty for young athletes in this country is getting sponsorship to meet their training requirements. The cost of training and competing these days is increasingly expensive. The difficulty for young athletes is that they have to hold out a light at the end of the tunnel for the sponsor and say, `I may only be competing in the Australian age championships now, but in four or five years time I could well be on my way to the Olympics.' That is the dilemma.

If you preclude a sponsor from using a loose grouping of words—for example, sponsor of olympic athlete X—at any point in the future, then what you do is preclude the opportunities for young athletes to get the sponsorship which will get them through the next three, four or five years and make them an athlete of olympic quality. I think it is important that consideration be given to that matter otherwise all we will do is cheat our young athletes out of the opportunity to properly develop and we will cheat our country out of gold medals in the year 2000 as well as having unintended consequences on Winter Olympic athletes in 1998 and 2002.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport References Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport References Committee entitled Impact of assets test on farming families' access to Social Security and Austudy, together with the transcript of evidence.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Senators will recall that in August last year the Senate agreed that the Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport References Committee should inquire into and report upon the impact of assets tests on farming families' access to social security payments and Austudy. It was basically at the instigation of Senator Woodley and Senator Boswell, who had been pushing for something to be done about this for quite some time, albeit a lot of other people were concerned about what was happening.

PARA.TAB: The first report deals with Austudy assets tests and farming families—a matter that attracted considerable comment in submissions to the inquiry. The committee's report reviews Austudy provisions—including the assets tests—examines its impact on farming families and notes specific concerns raised in evidence.

For the amount of information that we received and the amount of work that was done, we should pay a special tribute to the secretariat of John O'Keefe, Ms Hawkins, Mrs Migus, Neil Bessell, and particularly Peter Hallahan, who did most of the work on this inquiry.

In order to be eligible for Austudy, a student must jump two hurdles. The first is the assets test—the limit for which is currently $369,350. Do not forget that that is not the students' assets; it is the parents' assets. Farms and businesses receive what the Department of Employment, Education and Training describes as a 50 per cent discount. In effect, this means that the value of the assets for farmers is $738,700—double the standard limit.

The second test that applies is the income test. Under this test, maximum benefits are available for taxable incomes up to $21,300 and then on a sliding scale to approximately $40,000 taxable income per annum. The living allowances available under Austudy depend on the status of the student. A dependent student aged 16 to 17 years receives $3,449, whereas an independent student married with a child receives $6,917.

Based on the evidence presented by DEET, it would be very easy to draw the conclusion that the assets test has a minimal impact on access to education, particularly for farming families. The department advised the committee that, in relation to unsuccessful Austudy applications from rural areas in 1994, only one per cent failed on the basis of the assets test, while 72 per cent failed on the basis of the income test. However, as the department itself recognised, the statistics reflect only those students who submitted applications for assistance. Also, the department's statistics relate to applications from rural areas but do not show those exclusively for farming families.

The committee, therefore, was interested to receive, and has included as an appendix to its report, unpublished data from the Department of Primary Industries and Energy which shows the impact of the Austudy assets test on farming families regardless of whether or not they applied for assistance. DPIE advised the committee that, if the assets test excluded farm assets while retaining a test on off-farm assets—I stress that point: it would retain a test on off-farm assets—an additional 5,400 students from farming families would be eligible for Austudy. In simple terms, this means that 5,400 students from farming families who meet the income test for Austudy are being denied assistance for their education solely on the basis of parental assets.

There is no doubt that the data provided by DPIE is in stark contrast to the Treasury's view that the assets test is a generous test as it has removed only the wealthiest families from Austudy. Not only does the evidence of DPIE call into question the economically rational pronouncements from Treasury, but the overwhelming opinion expressed in the 260 submissions lodged with the committee is that the Austudy assets test is a blunt policy instrument which effectively denies a sector of the Australian community access to education opportunities.

The evidence maintains that the assets test is not an appropriate indicator of a family's immediate ability to meet the costs of educating their children. This is because farming is a capital intensive industry in which most assets are fixed and cannot be readily liquidated without diminishing the viability of the industry. I think there are many cases where you can say that farmers are asset rich but income poor. If we look at broadacre farms at the moment, we will see that the average income is something like minus $17,500. If we look at the assets of those farms, they might sound rich but they cannot just sell off the back paddock very easily.

The majority report considers the Austudy assets test as not only a blunt instrument but also an inappropriate instrument which determines farming families' access to educational opportunities. Accordingly, the committee has recommended that farm assets should be excluded from the Austudy assets test. This recommendation is based on several considerations which are noted in the report.

It is my strong personal view, which I am pleased is reflected in the committee's report, that it is important in the national interest that farming families have access to educational opportunities in order for this protective sector to remain competitive and technologically innovative. In our rural adjustment scheme report we made recommendations to the effect that if we are going to have a better farming community we have to have a better educated farming community and for people to have a better chance of readjusting off the farm they need to be able to go to universities.

In saying what I have just said, neither I nor the farming sector expect special treatment. What I believe is essential and what the farming community asks for is a fair go—something they are not getting because of the Austudy assets test. Basically, my position and the position of the committee is that education is a right, not a privilege.

In making the recommendation, the committee was mindful of budget implications. We were advised that it would cost a maximum of $15 million to have the farm assets removed from the Austudy assets test. This may seem a lot of money but, after all, we are dealing with the future of young Australians. I suspect that $15 million would represent about one per cent of the overall budget for student financial assistance. In terms of the bigger picture, I would also suspect that some of the 5,400 students who have been identified by the DPIE as having been excluded from Austudy may well receive more costly yet less enriching government assistance through other programs and services, for example, jobsearch or jobstart.

It is difficult for anyone on these committees to divorce themselves from strong political or economic considerations. In relation to this report, I must admit that as the chairman I had no such difficulties. The fundamental consideration in this report is equitable access to educational opportunities. As I said, education is a right, not a privilege. Equity needs to be extended to farming families. I commend the report to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to say that I am delighted to be able to contribute to the discussion on this latest report of the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport References Committee. This report deals with the impact of the assets test on the access of farming families to Austudy. As all senators in this place will be aware, this is an issue that the Australian Democrats have been pursuing for over four years.

PARA.TAB: In December 1990 my colleague Senator Lees moved an amendment to a social security bill to exempt the value of the family farm from the assets test which applied to the family allowance supplement. On at least eight further occasions since that amendment of Senator Lees the Democrats have attempted to exempt farm tools of trade from the Austudy and social security assets tests.

The most recent instance of this was an amendment I moved on behalf of the Democrats to the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1994. That amendment sought to exempt the family farm from the assets tests which apply to the basic and additional family payments. It was in response to my amendment that this committee of inquiry was originally established. Soon after submissions were called for to that inquiry it became obvious that the committee needed to look beyond just those assets tests on the family payment and to consider all social security payments as well as the student assistance payment, Austudy.

So the terms of reference for the committee's inquiry were subsequently broadened by a notice of motion moved by the Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Meg Lees. Following the incorporation of Senator Lees's motion into the terms of reference, the committee was required to inquire into and report on the impact of the assets test on farming families' access to all social security payments and to Austudy.

Given our record, senators will understand when I say the Democrats feel not only a sense of having been vindicated by the major recommendation of this report but also a sense of frustration that it has taken so long for the Senate to realise what the Democrats have known for years. The recommendation which appears on page 22 of this report is straightforward. It simply states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee recommends that farm assets be excluded from the AUSTUDY assets test.
We are pleased, I must say, to see this recommendation put to the government and we feel and hope that the government will accept it. It would be remiss not to do so.

PARA.TAB: I would like to extend my thanks to the committee for the marvellous job that it did on this report. The great concern in the community over the issue of the access of farm families to Austudy and social security payments was clearly reflected in the fact that the committee received over 250 submissions. These included various rural counselling groups, the Independent Schools Parents Council of South Australia Inc., the Western Australia Minister for Community Development and the Family, Australian Women in Agriculture and a large number of church groups, including the Australian Conference of Leaders of Religious Institutes and the National Anglican Caring Organisations Network.

The majority of the submissions were highly critical of the current assets test as it affects farming families and a large proportion of the submissions made extensive reference to the Austudy assets test. The Australian Cane Farmers submitted:

SPEECH.PARA: AUSTUDY is the benefit that most farmers resent being excluded from. Perhaps this is because they see education as a means of their children being able to get out of the economic uncertainty they have grown up with.
In submission No. 209 Mr And Mrs Blake said:
The assets test means our kids work most weekends and holidays—for no pay, seldom have the pleasures of urban children, and are well used to hand me downs.
In submission No. 215 the Woodhouse Woolgrowers Group said:
Tertiary education is the greatest strain of all because rural children simply have no choice but to board away from home if they wish to pursue higher educational opportunities.

I could read from many other submissions and I have a number of other quotes, but I am aware of the pressure of time. Time does not allow me to place any more quotations on the record. Senators who are interested in rural Australia should read these submissions. They would meet face to face the real suffering of rural people. Access to education is a basic right and children from farming families must have the same opportunities that other children receive and government encouragement to continue their studies.

PARA.TAB: I want to leave the Senate with the words of Mr and Mrs Blake, a farming couple from Shelford in Victoria who saw the issue of Austudy assets test in a broader context and that is whether or not the government has any commitment to the maintenance of rural communities. They said:

SPEECH.PARA: Senators I believe that Australians must make decisions very soon as to whether they want a viable rural community—to continue to have family farms with people who love and care for their land or if they want to see young people leaving for the much easier more comfortable life offered by urban dwelling.

The Democrats are strongly committed to the maintenance of Australian rural communities. We see better access to Austudy as a small but very important part of the campaign needed to save our farming communities.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would also like to comment on the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport References Committee report on the impact of the assets test on farming families and their access to social security and Austudy. As Senator Brownhill has pointed out, this aspect of the report deals with the provision of Austudy. The nature of farm assets in themselves means that farmers are usually asset rich and income poor, given the fluctuating nature of their income, particularly over the last four years in Australia which have seen probably the worst ever drought. Urban families do not have to put so much capital into their assets in the sense that the family home is exempted from the assets test and the home in the city or in the town is often where capital is used. So it is possible to have an extremely expensive home—in the sense that a lot of capital has been invested in it—yet still be eligible for Austudy. On the other hand, farming families who possess broadacres of land are ruled out of being eligible for Austudy because of the nature of their assets. Farm families use their capital to build up the productive nature of their assets. If they are to retain their farm and use it for the benefit of future generations, they must plough their capital back into their land. They are penalised for that.

PARA.TAB: As Senator Brownhill said, the net value of the assets that apply to farming families to determine eligibility for Austudy is $738,700. In Victoria in particular, which is my home state, many productive farms have land worth much more than this, because Victorian land values are higher than other states and you do not need to have a very big farm to have farming land worth over that amount. Even in the drought many of the farming areas in Victoria are not eligible for the drought relief payment because they are not considered to be within the negative rainfall criteria given by the government to access the DRP. So farmers are neither eligible for that nor eligible for other welfare payments.

I understand that representatives of the rural adjustment scheme have made only two visits to Victoria, both to irrigation areas. They have not even been to look at whether other farming areas in Victoria should be considered for drought relief payments. So those farmers are not considered to be affected by the drought when in fact they are.

However, I do not wish to dwell on the negative side of this in so far as how many farmers we should possibly get onto welfare payments or social security. I would like to look at the positive aspect of providing education to equip children for the challenges of the 21st century. Education, as Senator Woodley has correctly outlined, should be a right for children. It is an undeniable fact that children of farming families do not go on to tertiary education in the same numbers as children from cities and towns. We need a well trained, well educated work force for the future not only for the many farm children who go on to other areas of employment away from the farm but also for those employed on the farm itself.

Farmers themselves need to be better educated to cope with the challenges of a technological farming future. Australia's farm managers and farm owners are an ageing group. As a group in their past lives they have not had access to tertiary education and, in many cases, to a higher secondary education. Many of them, and I have spoken to them about this, would like to see a much brighter future for their children in so far as they want their children to be better educated to have better farms in the future. We need to provide Austudy for those children so that they can move away from their farm environment and go on to tertiary studies.

The best form of welfare is a job. Education will lead to this, even if the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) does not believe it. The Department of Primary Industries and Energy estimated that, if farm assets were excluded from the assets test but off farm assets were retained, as Senator Brownhill said, an additional 5,400 children would be eligible. Even if one child were to be eligible because of the removal of the assets test, it would give that child—or the 5,400 children—a better chance of attaining an education. This is not taking into account those students who did not apply.

The committee also received a deal of evidence to lead us to believe that confusion abounds among rural families as to the exact nature of the assets test. Many families do not know whether or not they are eligible to receive Austudy. There is also a lack of information about Austudy provided through government information outlets. There are complex application procedures which mean that many people are put off applying. Farmers and their families, from the evidence we received, are often ruled in to receive Austudy for one year of their child's studies and in the next year, because of better commodity prices being obtained from what they produce, are then ruled out.

We cannot let a student embark on a tertiary degree course for three or four years without knowing whether that child will receive Austudy for the entire three or four years of a course. Students need to know that they will be receiving it for the three or four years. They do not need to have Austudy for one year, be ruled out the next year, and so on. That leads to enormous economic uncertainty not only for the students but also for their families.

The way in which Austudy is provided is not the only factor that works against rural participation in tertiary education. I realise that some of these are endemic because of the fact that rural people do live a long way away from capital cities. These factors include travelling costs. Also, there are living away from home costs for tertiary students. To reside in a university residential college for one academic year entails a cost of around about $9,000. For students who want to reside in private rental accommodation, the cost is even greater—starting, I would estimate, at around about $10,500. We need to provide these students with the wherewithal to at least go to the cities, gain their tertiary education, even if they have to supplement Austudy with a part-time job.

The cost will no doubt be touted by the government as a factor against implementing what we have recommended in the report—which is, to remove the assets test. The Department of Employment, Education and Training estimated that the cost of excluding farm assets would be $15 million. When we consider some of the other items of government expenditure that are perceived by the Prime Minister and the cabinet as being absolutely essential, such as the refurbishment of the Prime Minister's private plane—and I note a report in this morning's papers of a plan by Mr Bilney to send journalists overseas on further education at government expense, and we are talking about private sector journalists here—I do not feel that $15 million is too much to pay for the cost of giving rural students access to tertiary education, a right that is enjoyed by every other student in this nation.

If our recommendation to remove the assets test were to be implemented, it would be an acknowledgment by the government of the difficulties being faced by rural families in the present environment. It would also be an acknowledgment by this government that all Australians are to be treated equally, regardless of where they live or what their aspirations are in life. Therefore, I commend the report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just rise to indicate that there is a dissenting report by the government members of the committee. In view of the time constraints, I will not elaborate further but just draw the Senate's attention to the government's position on this matter, which is outlined in the dissenting report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen A.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too would like to comment on this report of the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport References Committee. I have agreed to keep my contribution short because of pressures of business. It is tragic that when reports such as this inevitably come down in this place we find ourselves pressured to such a point that they cannot be given proper attention, but I know there will be other opportunities. I want to reinforce some of the points that have been made by my colleagues about the impact of the assets test on farming families. I am a recent convert—I confess—to the position adopted by my colleagues. I also recognise the position adopted by the government members of the committee. Senator Forshaw just rose to his feet to make the point that there was a dissenting report. The government members, as well, recognise in their recommendations that there is a problem with the assets test, although they were not prepared to take the quantum leap of recommending it be abolished. I hope they follow it through and get some action on the problem.

PARA.TAB: Some 5,400 potential farming families students are affected by the assets test. A total cost of some $15 million would be needed to overcome it out of the total budget of $1.4 billion which is currently spent, as I understand it, on Austudy. Something most people do not understand is that the problem of being income poor and asset rich is not easily overcome. There is no way you can go out and sell the back paddock. You cannot sell your income earning resource, whether it be sheep, cattle or a tractor because, once you do that, you are on the road to oblivion. So you have to look at it somewhat differently to other aspects of assets testing.

The sum of $738,000 of net assets might seem like a lot of money, and to a lot of people it is a lot of money, but the problem is the way assessments are made by financial institutions to determine whether you can borrow against that net asset. To endeavour to put it in simple terms, you can have a property that has a gross value of $1.5 million—just to pick a figure out—and you can have debt of $500,000, which means you have net assets of $1 million. The problem is that when financial institutions assess the capacity of people to borrow against that, they take a stress value of two-thirds, which immediately means that the stress value of that property is $1 million. They then look at the $500,000 debt against that and totally rule out any capacity to borrow money against that for the education of farming families' children.

The scenario I have put is fairly common. It does not matter much whether you use the $1.5 million or a $2 million gross value, you seem to find that the debt level is between 33 or 34 per cent and 40 per cent. But for borrowings for personal requirements the test from the financial institutions is much harder. So as a consequence you have this relatively small group of people who are ruled out of being able, when they are income poor, to get the money required to educate their children. That is an anomaly, an unintended consequence, of the assets test and where it sits. It disadvantages a small group of people significantly. It also runs in the eye of the thrust, which I believe most if not all people support, in the farm sector that we need to have better educated young people remaining in the industry.

Against the $15 million we mentioned before and the research that was done through DPIE and others there will be a significant offset of young people who receive social security. We have not got a figure for that but certainly in some areas—I can nominate some areas in Western Australia; however, it is probably better from the point of view of the districts concerned that I don't—where over 50 per cent of the rural youth receive some social assistance because their families have no money to pay them, there are no jobs in the area and there is little point in their heading for the city because with their level of education they have little or no hope of getting a job. So it is an enormous social problem.
I also draw the Senate's attention to paragraph 107. I will read it into the record. It states:

It must be understood that, in keeping with its terms of reference, the Committee's conclusions and recommendations are confined to farming families. Therefore, the Committee has not addressed more general issues such as the application of the AUSTUDY assets test to businesses other than farms. Nevertheless, the Committee anticipates that this issue will be addressed by the Senate Employment, Education and Training References Committee in its broader inquiry into AUSTUDY.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason I draw attention to that is that I think it is important that that other group of people out there who have the same problem with periods of being income poor but relatively asset rich know they have not been ignored by this report—it was just that they were not included in the terms of reference—and the issue will be addressed.

PARA.TAB: It is interesting to note some figures we were given in terms of that group. If the assets test were removed for those who would qualify, the additional cost would be about $5 million. So we are not talking about a lot of money, but we are talking about a group of young people who I believe are being severely disadvantaged in terms of access to quality education.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Select Committee on ABC Management and Operations, together with submissions, Hansard transcript of evidence, supplementary material and minutes of proceedings.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: In the ten minutes available to me and indeed to other speakers, it is not possible to do justice to what I think is a very comprehensive and important document that has been tabled in the Senate today.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Chapman)—Senator Alston, I interrupt you to point out that there are only six minutes in total left for debate of committee reports.

TALK.START.PARA: —Initially, I seek leave to enable each of the three representatives of the parties—perhaps four—to speak for ten minutes each, as I think was agreed between us all. We were all led to believe that there would be ample opportunity for that to occur without needing leave. But, nonetheless, to ensure that all parties—particularly, the government senator or senators, who would be last in the queue—are given the same opportunity—
—What do you mean `last in the queue'?
—If Senator Carr does not realise that he is speaking after me and Senator Bourne, I am informing him now.

—Before leave is granted, I make the comment that the agreement is that the extension be 30 minutes—10 minutes for each speaker. Our two speakers will split the remaining 10 minutes between them. The other two speakers and our senators will make up the 30 minutes, so we agree to extend the debate for 30 minutes. Might I just say this: upon agreeing to an extension of 30 minutes, we then expect a great deal of cooperation to get the rest of the legislation through.
—I am sure harmony will break out all over.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a very important report. It is not possible to do justice in the time available to the detail of the report, so I simply want to make some general comments and elaborate at a later point on its precise contents. I begin by thanking the committee secretariat: Peter Keele, committee secretary; Robert King, who was secretary in the initial stages; Janice Paull, principal research officer; Sarah Bachelard, senior research officer; Dr Pippa Carron, principal research officer; Christine Tieu, executive assistant; and Winifred Jurcevic, the executive assistant.

PARA.TAB: There is no doubt that they worked well beyond the call of duty. Indeed, in many respects they are probably much more exhausted than we are, the highlight of that being that they worked until 4 a.m. the other day in order to meet the Senate imposed deadline. I pay public tribute to their efforts. I found them to be extraordinarily cooperative and enthusiastic. I hope they enjoyed the exercise as much as we did.

I make mention of another matter that is of particular concern. All members of the Senate committee are appalled at an article which appeared in the Australian today which referred to a suggestion that senior ABC managers had acted dishonestly in their dismissal of Pamela Bornhorst. That is factually incorrect. I think we all want to make it very clear that we take it very seriously that some person or persons presumably provided that information to a journalist on whatever basis. We want to utterly dissociate ourselves from those remarks.

The coalition has a very strong commitment to the ABC as one of Australia's vital national cultural institutions. I have no doubt that it will continue to deserve the support of all Australians. The ABC has had a special place in the hearts of the community now for more than 60 years. It is a long and honourable history and it is vitally important that the ABC remains as an independent quality alternative to the commercial radio and television networks in the decade ahead. Australia certainly needs a fearlessly fair, impartial and independent ABC.
Of course, the forces of darkness are constantly at hand, whether in the form of political interference, board stacking, or commer

SPEECH.PARA: cial interest wanting a free, or indeed a paid, run. Therefore, the ABC must be constantly on its guard to protect itself against threats to its independence and impartiality. Where necessary, the parliament, which currently provides $515 million on behalf of the taxpayers each year, must be equally vigilant to ensure that the ABC does not compromise itself and that it maintains its independence and integrity.

PARA.TAB: This Senate committee comprised members of all political parties. It is the first major public inquiry into the activities of the ABC since the Dix report of some 14 years ago. The inquiry came about as a direct result of Channel 9's Sunday program of 18 September last year. Indeed, it is fair to say that even in the period of little over six months since that time, a virtual torrent of water has flowed under the bridge with the departure of the managing director, the director of television, with two reports from Mr George Palmer QC, with the decision taken to scrap infotainment programs and with the appointment of Mr Ian Macphee to the board, undoubtedly a token Liberal counterbalance to the very gross board stacking that we have seen in recent times.

I think it is fair to say that even in the time the committee has been sitting, it has certainly achieved a considerable amount. I pay tribute to: my fellow committee members, particularly my colleagues Senators Tierney and Chapman but also Senators Bourne and Chamarette and Senators Carr and Forshaw; the printing office and the Sound and Vision Office; and the ABC for not only providing us with detailed submissions and supplementary submissions but also answering innumerable questions and providing us with the information that is necessary in order to ensure as best one can that the report truly reflects the facts and circumstances of the ABC.

A number of aspects of the ABC's operations are touched on in the report. I think it is fair to say that the common thread that runs through the report is the impact of commercialisation and commercial activities. In many respects it can be said that that relates to the budget pressures that have been on the ABC and, of course, on a number of other publicly funded institutions. It is a function of pushing the barriers to engage in a number of new commercial activities, which often have taken the ABC into unchartered waters, and the compromises and pressures that are always there on a public broadcaster.

We have canvassed not only Australian television and pay television but also the continuing gravitation towards Sydney as the centre of Australia. We have expressed concern that the ABC should, under its charter, reflect cultural diversity and, as much as possible, regional representations so that we do not have just one view of the world. Much as we would all like our own views to prevail, the fact remains that they will not. Therefore, it is very important in a democratic society to have a diversity of views and opinions.

We have touched on staff-management relations. We think there is considerable scope for improvement there. We are mindful of the fact that only those with grievances come before a public committee. Nonetheless, that in itself was a courageous act in a number of respects. It certainly reflects a level of discontent that needs to be addressed by management. I have already commented on the stacked nature of the board, which at one stage saw six out of nine members with past or present ALP affiliations. We are therefore very supportive of the ABC, but we believe that there is scope for a number of changes to ensure that it remains vital and strong in the years ahead.

I conclude by referring to the minority report incorporated in the document in the names of Senator Carr and Senator Forshaw, which has only come to my attention this morning. I have not had an opportunity to read it in any detail. Chapter 4 refers to the chairman's initial draft report. I also see a statement in the second paragraph that the chairman completely rewrote the entire report and its recommendations. Not only is that absolutely and manifestly untrue; it would seem to me that that is a clear breach of privilege.

Senators who have been in this place for more than five minutes know that a private meeting of a committee is just that and that it is normal practice for committees to consider draft documents. Indeed, the chairman's draft is the common term used in that process. It is then on the table for all members of the committee to contribute to it. They have an opportunity to correct any inaccuracies and to add to it. But to refer to what is a private process in that way seems to me on the face of it to be a very clear breach. I am simply giving notice that I will be pursuing this matter further.

I have no reason to think Senator Forshaw is the prime mover in this little effort. I expect Senator Carr to apologise for the utterly untrue statement that the entire report and its recommendations were rewritten at the 11th hour. I also call on Senator Carr to explain why a reference to what occurred in private session is not a breach of privilege. I also find it offensive in the extreme to read:

SPEECH.PARA: We do not believe that the report reflects the true views of the Opposition in relation to the ABC and its role as the national broadcaster.

There is not a skerrick of evidence to support the proposition. It is simply put in the report in stark print. It seems to me to show the desperation of some people to politicise and discredit by whatever means are available to them and to resort to whatever tactics, however dubious, to effect that end. I look forward to both an apology and an explanation. I give notice that I will be taking advice about the reference of this matter to the privileges committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —I note that this morning a report was dealt with shortly before ours concerning the operation of the Legal and Constitutional References Committee and Senator Ellison's behaviour in particular. I noted the manner in which that report was presented. I noted the comments by my colleagues. It is a great pity that the same level of cooperation and harmony could not be exhibited on this committee. I am very sorry to see that.

PARA.TAB: Senator Forshaw and I agreed to participate in this select committee in the full knowledge that it was a kangaroo court set up to condemn the ABC. We did so because we believe that it is part of our responsibilities as senators to defend citizens and institutions targeted for such a witch-hunt.
