In the opposition's view, the corporation's crime is very straightforward: it is competing too effectively with the private media cartels not only in traditional areas such as radio and television but also in areas such as pay TV and the wire services. The ABC has increased its radio audience by 62 per cent and its television audience by 26 per cent since the late 1980s. It has done so through quality programming with more Australian content than ever.

At the same time, it has launched Australia Television International to offer a satellite service into Asia and Broadcast News Australia to offer a news wire service to subscribers around Australia in direct competition with AAP. These successes are putting pressure on private networks, and they do not like it. Sure, there is something that the champions of the free enterprise system in this country could do about that, and they have. Members of the Liberal Party have run a campaign of smear and disinformation to create the impression that the ABC is in crisis. They have used their own propaganda as the pretext for a Senate inquiry and to make a series of recommendations that would render the corporation totally uncompetitive.

The government agreed to be part of this committee only on the basis that it felt a responsibility to keep the bastards honest, and that is exactly what we have done. Given the way things started, I have to confess that we were not all that optimistic about our chances of getting justice in the end. But this inquiry was politically motivated from the outset. The opposition was quite clearly prepared to sacrifice the ABC's reputation in the pursuit of some chimerical political advantage.

There is no question that the opposition members of the committee had already made up their minds about the issues they were purporting to investigate before the inquiry began. Senator Alston has been enriching the public record for some years with his diatribes against the ABC and its former managing director. He clearly saw this inquiry as a heaven-sent opportunity to vent his hostility towards the corporation. This is why the opposition was so keen to stack the committee, which had only two government members out of the seven on this committee.

Members of the opposition were furnishing themselves with utterly scandalous terms of reference which took it for granted that the ABC was marked by `failure', `controversy' and `conflict' and that these were symptomatic of some `dysfunction', some `deep-seated problem', that was causing universal `concern'. This is why members opposite flouted the standing orders, with Senator Alston careering around like a loose cannon and acting without the committee's authority. That is why those opposite made one outrageous demand on the ABC after another, blithely requesting truckloads of documents they never intended to read about events they had no intention of ever investigating.

That is why those opposite extended the deadline for submissions when it became clear that no-one was taking much interest in their antics. That is why they went around on the inquisitorial equivalent of the gutter crawl, trying to solicit submissions from anyone they could think of who had a grudge against the ABC. That is why those opposite allowed the committee's time to be wasted on peripheral matters like the dismissal of television presenter Pamela Bornhorst—matters that would have been more appropriately dealt with in the letters pages of TV Week rather than the Australian Senate.

That is why those opposite accepted submissions and testimonies that had absolutely nothing to do with the terms of reference. That is why they consistently flaunted the provisions of the Senate parliamentary privileges resolutions relating to adverse evidence. That is why they gave witnesses with personal axes to grind free rein to vent themselves on the ABC. That is why they allowed the disgruntled and vindictive to make unsubstantiated and often highly slanderous accusations about individuals under parliament privilege. That is why they gave the victims of these attacks no opportunity to respond and allow their side of the story to be heard.

However, as witch-hunts go, this one has been a real dud. Despite the fact that the whole inquiry has been predicated on the presumption of the ABC's guilt, not one of the allegations found in the terms of reference has been proven. The ringleaders of this inquiry may have failed in their primary objective of bringing the ABC into public disrepute, but they have succeeded in making the Senate and its committee system the object of ridicule and contempt.

The government members of this committee want to put on record our complete lack of confidence in this sham inquiry and our support for the ABC, its staff, its management and its board. Our faith in the ABC is shared by the government as a whole, which has demonstrated its commitment by giving the corporation triennial funding since 1988, by steadily increasing its funding in real terms since 1988-89, by earmarking $1.5 billion for ABC activities over the next three years to 30 June 1997, and by providing additional funds when required for special initiatives such as Australia Television International and ABC Pay TV.

Let us compare this with the opposition's threat before the last election to slash the corporation's budget by $50 million a year. The stable funding and policy environment created by the government has given the ABC the confidence to develop new services, experiment with new formats and pioneer new technologies.

The ABC is a stronger, more innovative and more dynamic organisation in 1995 than it was in 1985. However, one thing has not changed: its commitment, enshrined in the ABC's charter, to nurture and to protect Australian culture, both here and abroad. Australians have every reason to be confident in their national broadcaster. The ABC is one of our most important cultural institutions. It has survived war, depression and the worst excesses of Tory philistinism. It certainly will survive Senator Alston.

TALK.START.PARA: —It may be a cliche, but the ABC is a vital national institution. It consistently puts quality Australian content on our radios and on our televisions. It provides leading news and current affairs coverage which cannot be manipulated by any powerful media baron. Without the ABC, Australian culture and Australian democracy would be the poorer. But, like any large organisation, problems do arise. This report deals with some serious allegations. They concern commercial influences on the ABC, the adequacy of its funding, relations between management and staff, centralisation of ABC management and programming and political appointments to the board.

PARA.TAB: The inquiry cast a very wide net; but, as the report says, the central issue was commercialisation. This was not an inquiry in which the ABC's critics hid their lights under bushels. Robust allegations were made. I believe the committee did examine them thoroughly. The picture that emerged was of an ABC that is sound and is providing a diverse and vibrant service. But it is clear that commercial influences have compromised the ABC's editorial integrity at the margins, particularly in the area of co-production. That problem has already been tackled by the board and by management. The committee believes that further changes to the ABC's editorial policies are warranted, along with a regular audit of external funding.

The report also foreshadows the possible need for greater public funding of the ABC's pay television operation to keep the commercial wolves at bay. In my view, that is a critical recommendation. Underfunding of pay TV has forced the ABC to accept equity from Fairfax and from Cox Communications, at a time when the future ownership of Fairfax is in considerable doubt. I believe this recommendation is not enough by itself. I have proposed further measures to maintain the ABC's relevance and integrity in the cable era. That is the era that is coming up.

The ABC should be guaranteed lanes on the FOXTEL and Optus Vision cable networks, subject to a fair price being negotiated. It is essential that any editorial leverage which the cable providers might have over the ABC's service be removed before it gets there. The fact that FOXTEL and Optus Vision will be `closed access' networks until at least 1997 gives them potential editorial influence which dwarfs anything that we have seen so far on free-to-air.

The ABC's pay service is extremely important—in fact, more important than is generally understood. But inadequate funding has exposed it to commercial pressures it could well do without. I have great faith in Kim Williams upholding the ABC's integrity, but I would be far happier if the potential for compromise was eliminated right now, or at least substantially reduced.

I am pleased that the report strongly endorses the ABC's Asian TV service—Australian Television International. I am even more pleased that it accepts that increased core funding may be needed to ensure that ATV builds on its impressive success to date. I would go further and remove sponsorship from ATV altogether, but I am pleased that the committee has endorsed a measure which would at least reduce the commercial pressures on that service.

Given that the committee did find problems, the question then arises as to who should take responsibility. As we know, the ABC chairman yesterday announced that the director of television had accepted responsibility and had resigned from that position. This has happened just three months short of Mr Conroy's retirement. It would be most unfair if the manner of his departure were to obscure his contribution to a very productive period in the ABC's history. Of the hundreds and hundreds of co-productions under his leadership, problems were discovered in only a handful, and serious breaches were discovered in, at the most, three. There is room for concern that some complacency had crept into editorial content of co-productions, but I do not believe that responsibility rests solely with Paddy Conroy.

In the last 10 years, the ABC has come under unprecedented pressure to become more commercial and to stretch its limited budget further. I think it is important that we remind ourselves that greed was good in the 1980s, and the ethos of public broadcasting was widely regarded in this place to be old-fashioned and out of date. It is very easy for us to go tut-tut and to wag our fingers at the ABC for allowing commercial influence to creep into programming decisions, but the fact is that, until very recently, the two major parties were strong advocates of that trend.

Just look at the some of the things they said. When Michael Duffy was communications minister he urged the ABC `to make greater use of commercial opportunities in the marketplace'. John Howard said that commercial sponsorship on the ABC was inevitable and that people who rejected it would be sticking their heads in the sand. The pressure on the ABC reached the point where the chairman, Bob Somervaille, issued a press release expressing concern at the policies of the major parties in the lead-up to the 1990 election. He criticised Labor for failing to commit itself to a further funding agreement and for refusing to rule out corporate sponsorship. He criticised the coalition for threatening funding cuts and advocating sponsorship.

It was in that context that the ABC cut its work force by about 1,000 and started looking aggressively for external sources of income. It is now clear that the pendulum swung too far, but that is with the benefit of hindsight. The two major parties showed no concern about that until it became impossible to ignore. My main criticism of the report is that Labor and the coalition did not acknowledge that their policies were wrong too.

We will be hearing strong criticisms again from the Labor members of the committee about the process by which this report was produced. I will make a couple of observations on that issue. It is normal for the chairman to produce a draft report for the committee's consideration. Senator Alston did that, and we strongly disagreed with the draft. Negotiations began as usual. That is what happens. The report was changed to better reflect the views of the committee. Senator Alston willingly engaged in a constructive process and I believe that produced a good report.

Senator Carr and Senator Forshaw decided that they could not support the initial draft—that is understandable, I could not either. But there is much in the final version that I believe they could agree with. They have refused to consider giving any support to the majority findings. They are more intent on exposing what they see as flaws in the committee system. I find that a matter for regret.

Something which occurred this morning, however, is much more than a matter for regret. In fact, it is an outrage that the Australian has given great prominence to an alleged finding by this committee that a member of the ABC management acted—and I use the term it used—dishonestly in the reasons he gave to Ms Pamela Bornhorst for putting her on probation. The committee did not draw that conclusion as Senator Alston has said. That word does not appear in this report. It is a matter of deep distress that yet again a person's reputation has been falsely maligned by the actions of someone in this place with a particular view of this matter. It is equally distressing that the Australian chose to publish that.

The upshot of this exercise is that a contempt of the Senate may have been committed, the Australian may have left itself open to legal challenge and this controversy has been reignited on false grounds—a proud moment indeed for somebody! The Democrats believe that this matter must be investigated by the Privileges Committee.

I believe the treatment of Ms Bornhorst's dismissal in the report is balanced. The committee was unable to find evidence of any political interference in the decision to dismiss her. It found that there were real problems with her relations with her colleagues, but that the problems had been poorly handled by management over many years. Whatever might be said about Mr Chubb's actions, he did at least take actions where others had feared to tread.

It seems to me that there are some lessons for the committee system. Firstly, the chairman in the first draft should really strive to reflect the majority view. Secondly, all parties should do as much as possible to negotiate an agreed outcome. Thirdly, and most importantly, all parties should set aside politics and draw conclusions which are consistent with the available evidence rather than bending the facts to fit a predetermined stance and running a political agenda.

I appeal to the media to concentrate more on the findings of this report than on the long-running personality feud between two members of this committee. It is old news, it is tired news and we have heard it before. The real news is that both major parties have recognised that adequate public funding is the key to public broadcasting. At last we have an acknowledgment that you cannot keep hacking away at the ABC's resources without paying an unacceptable price.

I conclude by thanking the members of the committee secretariat for their excellent work. They were caught in the crossfire. They were asked to do far more than was reasonable. They did it with great ability and with great good humour and they deserve a glass of champagne and a good rest. I will be pleased to help them out with the first.

I love the ABC dearly—it is my ABC. I listen to ABC radio and I watch ABC television. I believe the ABC is now far more relevant to Australia and to all Australians than it was ten years ago. I look forward to continuing my rewarding relationship with the ABC for a very long time to come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw Sen M.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no doubt that from the outset this was a politically motivated inquiry. The original terms of reference were a hotchpotch of biased conclusions cobbled together in search of supporting arguments, and the amended terms of reference were no better. That is clearly illustrated by paragraph 1(b) of the terms of reference, which referred to:

SPEECH.PARA: controversial proposals to abolish regional Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) TV News, advocated with great vigour by ABC Management and rejected by the ABC Board—

That term of reference was totally incorrect. It was without any foundation whatsoever. Yet before and during the inquiry the management and board of the ABC were attacked for even daring to consider proposals regarding its news and current affairs broadcasts on television. This false term of reference was put to rest only when it was outlined clearly to the committee that management had never advocated the abolition of ABC regional news, but had put a proposal to the board which would have extended the amount of coverage of ABC news on television.

PARA.TAB: In any event, the proposal was rejected by the board. ABC retained its 7 p.m. news based upon regional and national news, followed by its current affairs report at 7.30. This is a clear example of the board doing its job. It considered proposals brought to it by management and made a decision on those proposals. That term of reference is a clear illustration of the entire process in this report and the reason why government senators on the committee could not, in the end, agree with the majority. From the very outset, the inquiry was loaded to focus on negative, pessimistic views about the ABC.

Clearly, the board's action on that occasion and its actions since in respect of the Palmer report—which was commissioned by the board to look at the issue of co-productions—demonstrate that the board is doing its job. It does not need a Senate committee of inquiry to go on witch-hunts and fishing expeditions to enable it to do its job.

I will mention one other episode referred briefly to by Senator Bourne—that is, the Bornhorst affair. The committee spent 1 1/2 days out of seven inquiring into the position of a single employee who ultimately left the ABC. As Senator Carr so rightly pointed out, in the process a range of people were very maliciously slandered on the public record. We on the government side believe that those people—particularly Janine Walker—deserve an apology.

Interestingly enough, the majority report suggests that the proposals on news broadcasts demonstrated some centralisation in Sydney. This committee held hearings only in Sydney and Canberra, except when it went to Brisbane to deal with the Bornhorst affair.

In the remaining time available to me—and I no doubt will have further opportunity to address the report—I want to say that I support everything that Senator Bourne said about the ABC in her concluding remarks. The public love the ABC. That is clear by the recognition that is given to the broad range of ABC services that are provided and its audience reach. It produces first-class drama. Australian content on ABC television is significantly in advance of what it was 10 years ago.

We have a first-class, internationally renowned ABC news and current affairs service regarded as one of the best in the world. The ABC is a leader in children's programming. It has created a dynamic youth broadcasting network through Triple J. The ABC has excellent educational and open learning services. It is a leader in developing Australian comedy, and, of course, it continues its great role in promoting and developing culture and the arts through the orchestras and other programs on ABC television.

It is a creative organisation of over 5,500 employees who do a great job for one of the great public broadcasters in the world and, I might say, one of the few public broadcasters in the world that rely almost entirely on budgeted funding, unlike other national public broadcasters that do accept advertising overseas or, like the BBC, have a licence fee system to sustain them. Whilst we acknowledge that the ABC will have its faults—in any creative organisation of this size that is to be expected—we believe that these mistakes when they do occur, and some have occurred as George Palmer QC found, will be appropriately dealt with by the board and by the management. We have seen that evidence in the last couple of days.

We reject the negative, pessimistic tone of the majority report that suggests that the ABC should not look to the future, should not look necessarily to being involved in things like pay TV or ATV because of a fear it might get it wrong. We want an ABC that is dynamic, that moves with the changes in technology and continues to be, as I said, one of the great broadcasters in the world today.

I believe, as the public has shown through its great support of ABC open days, it is the public's ABC—and I note the report is entitled Our ABC. It is not the Senate's and it is not the preserve of a few journalists who want to continually criticise it and look at negative aspects; it is the public's, who I believe support very strongly the ABC. Aunty is doing a great job and I think it is about time we, in the parliament, recognised the great job it is doing. We should give it the support that it needs to continue that job rather than look for opportunities and ways to attack it and bring it down.

In conclusion, and hopefully I will have another opportunity to make some further remarks, I thank the secretariat staff. They did a stirling job under what were clearly trying circumstances, particularly in this last week with the time constraints upon them. I support the minority report as put forward by Senator Carr and me.
Debate (on motion by Senator Tierney) adjourned.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

This debate has now moved forward and Senator Ian Macdonald, who is handling this matter for the coalition, has agreement to amend Senator Woodley's motion. I think it would probably be appropriate if Senator Macdonald spoke now on this motion. I seek leave to continue my remarks after Senator Macdonald has spoken.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —By arrangement with Senator Woodley, I have drafted some amendments which have been circulated and I want to explain them briefly. The first amendment seeks to substitute the reporting date from the date mentioned in Senator Woodley's motion to 28 September 1995. The reason is that the committee which this is being referred to has two fairly large references before it already. The committee is a very expert one and very well chaired by Senator Ferguson, but it is going to have difficulty because of the work it already has. So that is the reason for that one.

PARA.TAB: The reason for the second amendment to, paragraph (1)(d), is that we do not see that there is any real need to mention `instead of expanding the consumption of coal generated electricity'. TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise a couple of issues on this matter. The Eastlink issue has been a long, involved process. It has caused major concern, particularly along the proposed route that the high voltage line is to go through. I have received a number of representations from people right throughout the rural areas of Queensland who have asked me to support a Senate inquiry that will allow them to express their concerns in a public manner.

PARA.TAB: Today we have seen, after a fairly long process, the Senate accept a joint put forward firstly by Senator Woodley and amended by Senator Ian MacDonald. The amendment makes the motion slightly better and easier to understand. I am very pleased that the Senate committee, chaired by Senator Woodley, will be able to investigate the proposed powerline and some of the fears—including the impact on health, rural productivity, environment and lifestyle—that people are so concerned about. I know that there will be a great deal of happiness tonight in Allora, Warwick, Toowoomba, Gatton and all those places that the powerline will go through because the people have seen some response by parliament to their concerns.

I also say to them that I do not believe the Senate inquiry will be a panacea for all their problems, but it will nevertheless give them some access to an inquiry that will allow them to put their concerns on the public record. I am very grateful that the Senate, the coalition and the Democrats have allowed this to go through. Of course, with the Democrat and coalition support, the Senate inquiry becomes a fact of life as from today.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats agree with the amendment moved by the coalition. I want to assure people that I do not think it limits any submissions people would want to make. They are still able to canvass the issues that they want to raise. I agree that we certainly needed to limit the last part of the reference in the way in which it has been done. The last thing I want to do is to remind governments that consultation is not pacification and that consultation is a two-way street. If governments use that word simply to mean that we are going to deliver decisions which have already been taken and expect people to accept them, then that is not consultation. This gives people the opportunity to raise their concerns in a proper manner.

Debate resumed from 29 March, on motion by Senator Schacht:
That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry Sen The Hon N.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Cook was dealing with this matter and he had been asked—
—He was responding to a number of issues which had been raised during the second reading stage.

—Yes, I have at least one of the issues here that Senator Cook was responding to. It is something that Senator Watson had raised. It was: can the project be completed in its three-year time frame? That is the issue I am to deal with.

PARA.TAB: The tax law improvement project team believes that, within three years, it will have broken the back of the task and shown very clearly the community benefits to be won from this project. With such a vast amount of law to review and with the public consultation and parliamentary process necessary to complete the task, it may well be that a little longer is needed before all the ends are tied up. But having such a schedule will help to maintain a momentum and allow the benefits to be delivered to the public as soon as possible.

There were some other matters too. Senator Watson, I understand, has claimed that, on page 55 of the bill, there is the highlighting of a major problem in the underlying policy. It contains an example which states:

SPEECH.PARA: If you fly to Los Angeles for the sole purpose of attending a seven day conference, but you don't record the conference in your travel record, you cannot deduct the cost of the airfare. This is so even if you have written evidence that you paid the fare (eg a receipt), as required by Division 5.

That is the point Senator Watson made. We do not see this as a major problem. Just because a person has a receipt for a trip does not mean that they have engaged in business activities for some or all of the time that they were away. They could have attended a conference for one day and then spent several weeks on holiday. A record of their business activities while away on a long trip is required to establish a connection between their income earning activities and the expense. All they have to do is make a written record of their business activities while away. This is a very easy requirement, especially given the high costs which can be involved in long overseas trips.

PARA.TAB: The next issue that has been raised is the urgency of the bill and why it should be passed as soon as possible. The bill eases the substantiation rules in numerous ways which benefit taxpayers. These benefits are so great it was decided that the bill should be backdated to 1 July 1994 to enable taxpayers to take advantage of these benefits as soon as possible. Tax Pack, which outlines taxpayers' rights and responsibilities, is about to go to the printers. If the bill is not passed soon, it will not be possible for these new laws to be put into Tax Pack and into effect.

If this bill is not passed now, taxpayers will have deductions denied on the basis of rules which are unnecessary, out of step with commercial reality and so complicated in some areas that we suspect that no-one fully complies with them. For example, under this bill taxpayers can claim up to $150 for laundry expenses without receipts. Under the current law, taxpayers will be denied such claims unless they have receipts for their electricity, water and power costs and carefully calculated costs of how much each wash costs them. That does seem a bit ludicrous.

Under this bill taxpayers can use the cents per kilometre method even if they travel more than 5,000 business kilometres. Under the current law they cannot. Under this bill taxpayers do not have to sign logbooks and diary entries. Under the current law they will be denied claims if they do not sign such entries. Under this bill taxpayers can annotate receipts which do not adequately describe what they have purchased and can rely on an invoice plus a bank statement to support a declaration. Under the current law you cannot do this.

These are only a handful of the benefits for taxpayers contained in this bill. These changes have been widely welcomed. No taxpayer will be disadvantaged by the backdating of the bill. If the bill is not passed now, taxpayers will have rules applied to them which they know will not apply in the future. Taxpayers will be totally confused as to what they must do to substantiate their deductions.

Senator Watson raised his concern about a situation where someone goes to a show, pays $10 to go through the gate—it must be one of the shows we have been going to recently, Senator Watson—and then must pass the ticket in so that there is no record of expenditure. Section 5(7) of schedule 2B allows taxpayers to use a diary entry or similar record if the Commissioner considers it unreasonable to expect them to have gotten written evidence in any other way. So all those shows we are going to, Senator Watson, I presume are in your diary and mine.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's right. No doubt about that.

—Good. The expense may be more than $10 and there is no monetary limit on the amount which can be substantiated in this way. Other examples of this type of situation include tollway fees and parking metre expenses. I think Senator Watson was also concerned about uncertainty as to whether the Commissioner will exercise this discretion. I am informed that the Commissioner will be happy to issue a tax ruling or tax determination on the situation that Senator Watson is concerned about and in relation to other similar circumstances which may be raised.

PARA.TAB: Senator Lees had a concern. She argued this bill does not benefit ordinary taxpayers. All of the benefits in this bill apply to ordinary wage and salary earners. Some of the examples that I have referred to would clearly illustrate that. Seven out of ten taxpayers are affected by the substantiation rules and will benefit from the easing of the rules by this bill. For example, some $3.5 million taxpayers claim deductions for protective clothing or deductible uniforms. Almost all of them will benefit from the changes, which will enable them to claim up to $150 of laundry expenses without substantiation. Sixteen per cent of salary and wage earners, more than one million people, claim deductions for car expenses and will benefit from the greater access to the cents per kilometre method and the much simpler logbook rules.

Just as well I am here for this one. I understand that Senator Harradine raised a question with respect to my comments during a debate where I was alleged to have misled the Senate. I was not here when Senator Harradine raised the issue so I am not clear what the precise—

TALK.START.PARA: —I made it clear that what you said was `on advice'.

—Again on advice, I did not mislead the Senate. That act contained measures relating to children's income provisions of the income tax law. Comments on these provisions were made by several people. Some comments directed only to non-government senators were made on the expected evening of the Senate debate because the debate was a few days earlier. Senators sought comment from the government on these various comments.

PARA.TAB: The government provided written notes on each of the matters raised. It also provided copies of the explanatory material from the introduction of the child income provisions, division 6AA, Income Tax Assessment Act 1936. The original intention of the parliament was stated clearly in those notes and in that material, as were the government's views on the amendments it proposed. I stated to the Senate the government's view on particular aspects of the amendments. Senator Harradine challenged that. Reasons for the government's views were set out in the material that the government gave to interested senators and different views were set out in various materials also received by interested senators.

After the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) was passed, Dr Dwyer and Ms Dwyer raised a further argument against the government's view that new subsection 102AG(2)(a) was a restatement of the existing law. This new argument was not raised in the written material on which senators sought a response from the government before or during the debate. Dr Dwyer and Ms Dwyer published their views in the Butterworths Weekly Tax Bulletin of 10 January 1995. They claimed that the Senate had been misled. Mr Hood, a senior tax counsel of the Australian Tax Office, replied in the same issue of the tax bulletin.

The Law Council has now raised the question of whether or not the Senate was misled, relying on the views of the Dwyers. The government does not agree with the views expressed by Dr Dwyer and Ms Dwyer. I was correct to express the government's view and did not mislead the Senate in doing so. I was responding to clear statements by Senator Harradine of a different view, and both of us gave reasons for our views. Those different views form part of the material the Senate considered in deciding to pass the bill. Further arguments for and against one of these views do not make statements made to the Senate misleading and they were not intended to be so.

Senator Harradine raised concerns over the operation of the rule in Sanders v. Vortore. I understand that after the debate Senator Harradine accepted advice and those concerns were allayed. Dr Dwyer and Ms Dwyer seem to have accepted the same advice in their views published in Butterworths.

I did not seek to mislead the Senate when these concerns were genuinely held. The fact that those concerns were misplaced does not mean the Senate was misled, and nor were they intended to. I did not mislead the Senate as to the government's view of the formal law. The government still holds the view that I expressed. It is true that some aspects of the view are disputed. That dispute was a matter of record in the Senate debate. The government and certainly I did not mislead the Senate by stating our views any more than Senator Harradine would mislead the Senate by stating his own view.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek clarification of the term `expense' used in the new substantiation provisions. I wish to have an assurance that the plain English substantiation provision does not override section 51 in the sense of a matter maybe having to be paid as opposed to being incurred. I remind the Senate of section 51 of the Income Tax Assessment Act. That is the general provision in relation to an expense being incurred. These substantiation provisions could affect a doctor who brings income to account on a cash or accrual basis. For example, if the doctor gets a phone bill on 29 June, under section 51 he would be able to claim the expense for the phone bill because the expense was incurred in respect of phone calls up to, say, 3 June. He received the bill on 29 June and, according to section 51 of the act, he would be entitled to a deduction.

PARA.TAB: The words there are quite specific. I refer to the general provisions of section 51. All section 51 really states is that an expense has to be incurred. The inference I gain on reading the substantiation provisions is that it must be paid. If that is the case, this really introduces a new dimension.

I am not sure whether we really need a definition with the way it is written in plain English. This is one of the problems we are incurring because we are changing to a plain English style. Is it intended under this plain English version that the amount must actually have been paid before 30 June or can we still rely on the older provisions not yet written in plain English which provide that the expense has to be incurred? Using this new format is essentially going to deny quite substantially the availability of deductions for many professional people who come within the ambit of section 51.

I want to make sure that these new substantiation provisions are not going to change the law. We have been assured that there are no changes, but by virtue of the plain English style and the emphasis on meaning, it appears to me that there could well be a change. If the judges, for example, believe the law is clear, then the assurances we get in the second reading speeches or during the committee stage are to no avail. I think we should at least ask the question because it is most important that in the way this is written—I go along with the plain English version of using examples because examples do help to explain the law—there has not been a change in terms of what is required under section 51 of the act. We are supposed to be bringing about a greater element of certainty. I want to make sure that in what I say now and in terms of later presentations I will make, particularly in relation to section 5, we do have a position that is absolutely certain.

I also use this opportunity to respond to the parliamentary secretary's summing up of the second reading speeches. I thank him very much for the assurance he has given that in terms of section 5(7) of the act there will be some examples by way of adding to the list I have given as typical of where a number of people could run into trouble. I think parliamentarians are very much in this category. Their expenditure patterns are such that an allowance is given for certain activities or expenses incurred in connection with their parliamentary business for which it is very difficult to get receipts.

I had a major problem with the $200 limit. I wanted it increased. The parliamentary secretary has agreed with the compromise of issuing a ruling. The problem with rulings is that they can be withdrawn without the assent of the parliament. While it is a second-best option, I appreciate the parliamentary secretary's assent to issuing a concept of a ruling to clarify 5(7).

I am not sure whether the ruling can be linked into section 5(7). In order to trigger section 5(7), you actually must be subject to an audit, which means that taxpayers who are over the $200 limit and have genuinely expended such moneys—they can prove it by virtue of their travel itineraries or their diaries or whatever it is, but actually do not have a ticket from the show society or the ethnic organisation or the Red Cross or whoever it might be—may run into trouble.

In order to trigger that, a taxpayer must be subject to an audit. How many taxpayers are going to subject themselves to fighting the commissioner having to rely on a discretion on a particular ruling'? Basically, it will be forcing these taxpayers to go to their tax agents, who will charge them $100 or $200, to get a deduction of $100. That scenario is not on. So who wins? Most taxpayers will not test the process.

My third point is that the parliamentary secretary did not respond to another issue raised by the Taxation Institute. It is concerned that the process will inhibit the response of ordinary taxpayers, such as blue collar workers, who are really frightened of being called before tax auditors.

The parliamentary secretary was not present during my speech on the second reading; in fact, one of his colleagues was handling the matter. I draw the parliamentary secretary's attention to a fundamental issue that we have to address very early in this whole tax law improvement program. The Tax Institute acknowledges that a `move to a simpler legislative framework with a less legalistic structure is clearly a preferable approach to the future direction of the tax laws'. I agree. However, the changing language used in the legislation is not of itself sufficient to materially reduce the compliance burdens on taxpayers in complying with the substantiated provisions.

While I welcome the concept of a tax ruling as it applies to section 5(7), somehow I would like that tax ruling to be related to section 5(6), if possible. In order to get to section 5(7), the process itself is convoluted because the onus is on the individual to prove on audit. Until people get audited, they are effectively sitting on the edge of their seats.

I note that our colleague Senator Margetts will shortly be introducing an amendment to substantially change the compliance rules. I will restrict my comments to that point. I might take this opportunity, in addressing the title and the matters raised in the second reading debate, to refer to section 82A of the act.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps we could deal with a couple of the issues you have already raised. That approach would assist me, because I am not quite as well across the tax act as you are. You have a very impressive knowledge. I would like to try to deal with a couple of the matters you have raised so far.
—Thank you.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I can state for the record that there has been no intention for this bill to change the timing of deductions. We do not believe that this bill will have that effect.
—You say you did not believe. Can you give an assurance?

—I can give you an assurance that, if your fear arose and there was some change, we would seek to amend it to change it back again. But we do not believe it is going to happen. Another issue you raised is the referral under 5(7) to the tax commissioner. You believe that you have to be under audit. Apparently, you do not. Under 5(7) anyone can refer to the tax commissioner. You do not have to be under an audit for a referral to take place.
—Who's going to do it?

—In the case of the issue you have raised—in fact, it has been raised here before—it would be sent to the tax commissioner by the department, I suppose. They would then seek a ruling on the matter and bring it back to you.

—I raise the issue of whether expenses will be incurred in order to get the deduction under the so-called section 51 or other sections. It has been a matter of some considerable debate between the tax office and members of the tax liaison group. There have been concerns at that level. However, I am not sure how strong the assurances have been. I thought it was appropriate that in this parliamentary forum we tease out the issue a little more in the interests of certainty.

PARA.TAB: I come back to the concept that certainty is one of the problems of self-assessment. We are supposed to be trying to make our laws so clear as to remove the ambiguities and fears that a lot of people have in dealing with the tax office. It is not an easy process for an ordinary worker to write into the tax office and to understand the nature of the response. The whole purpose of this tax law improvement program is to make it very simple. That is why I sought a clarification. I thank you that there has been no change and that, if events turn out to the contrary, you will change the law. I do not think I can go further than that.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I deal with the other issue that Senator Watson raised. A ruling would not be appropriate under section 5(6) in the example you gave, Senator Watson. Clearly, if the show ticket is less than $10 and total expenses do not exceed $200, then section 5(6) will apply.

—The problem does not arise until you exceed your $200. Section 5(6) quite adequately deals with items under $200. What we are concerned about are the 5(7) provisions where you have exceeded $200. It is the process that the tax institute is so concerned about. I am a little bit unhappy about the inference that you have to write in and ask the tax commissioner once you have exceeded that limit before you get to an audit. Again, this is adding quite substantially to compliance costs.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The earlier answer I gave in respect of 5(7) and the access to the commissioner would cover your concern in accessing under 5(7) should you go over that $200 limit.

—What I am really asking is: can the ruling be written in such a way that it does not really require the taxpayer to write to the tax commissioner before audit or having to be subject to an audit and therefore creating a degree of uncertainty?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Taxpayers would not have to write in for it. It will be a general ruling that will be published and circulated as widely as possible to tax advisers, accountants, et cetera. That would be the normal process. I am not sure what else you can do to inform the public beyond that. It would be in the tax pack.

—It is really a question of how wide an application you are going to give to your proposed ruling. I am very happy about the concept of the ruling—as the second best option. However, I would have preferred the clarification in the legislation. Since the government wants the legislation quickly, the coalition is trying to accommodate that request by not pressing amendments. This is the first piece of legislation that has come through the good offices of the tax law improvement team. It covers a very narrow field of work-related expenses. I ask why the existing provision, section 82A, covering self-education expenses. As I understand it, section 82A concerns work-related expenses. Therefore, the inconsistency is that not all work-related expenses have been included in this substantiation legislation. It is my understanding that an undertaking was given in April 1994, in a meeting of the occupational rulings committee with the various accounting bodies, that this issue would be addressed in this legislation.

PARA.TAB: Under section 82A, if an individual taxpayer incurs self-education expenses, he is not entitled to deduct the first $250. If a company pays that educational expense on behalf of an employee, that company gets an outright tax deduction—whereas an individual only can claim the excess over $250.

Furthermore, under the Fringe Benefits Tax Act, self-education or education to benefit an employee are exempt from its provisions. The first question is: why was that assurance of the meeting between the occupational rulings committee and the accounting bodies broken or not proceeded with? The second question is: as this was the first attempt to cover work-related expenses, why was the very important item of self-education omitted, in terms of denying a taxpayer the entitlement to deduct the first $250? Why was the undertaking not honoured? The third question is: isn't it reasonable that taxpayers' should be allowed the whole amount, just as the company or the employer is entitled to a deduction as from the first dollar spent? This is especially so in view of the fact that, for fringe benefit tax purposes, we do not regard self-education as a fringe benefit.

Again, the government is hurting the little people. You might recall some comments that were made during the second reading speeches, which I think Senator Margetts will be attempting to address. I must say at this stage that I do have some problems with the wording, although I endorse 100 per cent the thrust of what the senator is trying to achieve. I ask the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Sherry) why this very important item of self-education was deliberately omitted from this bill when the whole intention was to focus on work-related expenses.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 82A, which relates to the deduction provisions, is not part of the substantial area. I am informed that the self-education provisions as part of the deduction provisions are being looked at at the moment. They will be part of the next bill. In relation to the assurance you were given, the advisers indicate that they are not aware of the detail of when that assurance was given or how it was given. Therefore, I cannot respond now to your claim that an assurance was given. I will check on that and find out how and what was said and who gave that assurance.
—Can you give an assurance that it is going to be addressed in the next tranche of tax law improvement legislation?
—Yes, I can give that assurance.

—Can you also give us the timetable of when it is likely that the parliament will be receiving the next set of amendments to the tax law improvement legislation? Can you indicate whether you are meeting the timetable and commitment you gave in your concluding remarks in the second reading debate?
—I can give you an indication that it is likely to be November this year.

—I want to get clear in my mind a matter that Senator Watson raised and Senator Sherry responded to. It relates to the question of whether or not a deduction can be claimed for an expense that was incurred. Am I correct that the current law has not changed; that is, even if the actual cheque has not been written out by 30 June but the expenditure has been incurred during that period it would be a legitimate deduction?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just taken over so I am coming up to speed on this bill. I am advised that there has been no change to the law and its operation, but if that proves not to be the case the government will then give a commitment that it will make appropriate changes to overcome that situation.

—My understanding of the issue raised by Senator Watson is that, if a medical practitioner receives an account for telephone expenses incurred up until, say, 3 June—and I think that was the example, Senator Watson?
—Yes.

—Up to 3 June. If the telephone account comes on 30 June and the taxpayer writes out a cheque the next week, the taxpayer could claim a deduction for the telephone expenses incurred to 3 June, notwithstanding that he or she had not written the cheque until mid-July. Am I correct?
—For a medical service, I am advised that that is the case. They can claim the expense.
—So only for a medical service?
—Any professional.
—That is what I am saying. We are talking about taxpayers. Is it limited in some cases?

—I might help clarify this issue. These particular provisions relate only to individuals. As soon as you get into a business, you come under a different set of substantiation requirements which are fairly detailed in terms of what a business has to comply with. The minimum requirements are set down in section 262A of the Income Tax Assessment Act.

PARA.TAB: The point is that these provisions apply to sole practitioners and employees. I just used the example of a doctor. It could have been an architect practising on his own, an accountant practising on his own or a shopkeeper practising as a sole trader. It is basically the professional people, because a different set of criteria applies for businesses. As a general rule, once you start to employ people, you are generally regarded as a business.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that. I was raising the point of the individual taxpayer who had incurred an expense prior to the end of the financial year but had not actually paid the money until mid-July. Having paid the—
—Wait for the explanation.

—I am waiting for the explanation. In that case, the taxpayer has a legitimate expense that relates to the earning of that taxpayer's income. I simply ask this: if that individual taxpayer incurred the expense prior to the end of the financial year but had not paid for it, does it still mean that that individual taxpayer can claim the deduction in the year the expense was incurred?

TALK.START.PARA: —As I indicated, I am pleased to get the minister's clarification; however, I am disappointed that the government has not proceeded with a form of speech in the form that it was. SPEECH.PARA: These additional amendments to the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill No. 3 (PIELAB) meet concerns that the RAS may not be implemented in full consultation with the States. They put in place a requirement for all Commonwealth RAS assistance to be the subject of Commonwealth/State Agreements, including regional initiatives.

The amendments retain provision for, subject to Commonwealth/State agreement, payments to be made directly to beneficiaries, for payments to entities other than farmers under all elements of RAS and for flexible cost sharing arrangements under all elements of RAS. However, as has been stated before, the assistance would be provided within the framework of a Commonwealth/State agreement.

Whilst I am certainly reading from a draft that was made available to us yesterday, it must be reiterated that they were the important issues that we certainly wanted to see reinforced and which the presented government amendments address. We were intending to propose amendments ourselves which would have met those very requirements, but I understand that, by negotiation between Mr Anderson's office and Senator Collins's office, those issues were comprehensively picked up in the 12 amendments that have now been placed by the government.

PARA.TAB: The coalition's original decision to send this bill to the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee resulted from the lack of information about how RAS regional plans would work, how they would be funded and whether they would be constitutionally acceptable. These concerns have been borne out by the committee's report, which was also tabled in the Senate.

While the committee recommended the bill be passed without amendments, it recorded at that time its concerns that the explanatory memorandum and, in particular, the second reading speech did not contain detailed information on the proposed amendments to the Rural Adjustment Act 1992. Even the Attorney-General's Department said:

SPEECH.PARA: The administrative arrangements to be undertaken by the Commonwealth in relation to the new non-state-based component of the RAS are not clear from the available material. It is this lack of information which appears to be of concern to the Parliamentary Research Service. In the absence of that information, it is not possible to form a view whether the proposed administrative arrangements would be valid.

The committee concluded that the Department of Primary Industries and Energy and the minister must provide information that will allow the parliament to make informed judgments when considering legislation. During the inquiry, representatives from the Department of Primary Industries and Energy said that refunding for RAS regional plans would come from `the underspends' of each state. The coalition is concerned.

PARA.TAB: Mr Malcolm Smith, from the Rural Finance Corporation of Victoria, said that the federal government wanted to impose a levy on states on top of the underspends which would create a larger pot of money. Mr Smith correctly pointed out that the Victorian government would not be happy to provide finance for a regional restructuring plan in Queensland. Quite rightly, any state that puts money into a scheme must receive the benefit for its citizens.

The coalition is aware that the regional restructuring area in Queensland appears to be welcomed by the people of that area because it was sought by the local people. It is a grassroots request. It is not a decision made at the top being imposed on the locals. For this reason the coalition is pleased that the government is now proposing amendments in line with the Senate committee's dissenting report which states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . as a minimum, the legislation should be amended to require the Commonwealth to consult with the States on regional adjustment initiatives, fully recognising that the States have the responsibility for land management.

The government's amendments ensure that a regional restructuring program cannot go ahead without agreement of the particular state or territory. We would also like an assurance from the minister that any regional reconstruction scheme will be as a result of initiatives of the local community and will not be foisted on the community from a federal Labor government.

PARA.TAB: I am sure that Senator Crane and Senator Brownhill will address this issue and ask for additional information, as both participated in the Senate inquiry in this area. We are concerned that in parts of New South Wales the government is trying desperately to have its restructuring plans look like they are the idea of the locals when in fact it is being forced upon them. The coalition has no objection to the government amendments put forward.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen The Hon C.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have 3 1/2 pages of notes explaining those further amendments as requested. I have not had a chance to show Senator Tambling a copy of them. I seek leave to incorporate them in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: These further amendments to the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill No.3 seek to do three main things:
retain a regional component to the Rural Adjustment Scheme (RAS)
retain the flexibility in relation to the provision of support for regional and other elements of RAS; and
to make it an explicit requirement for Commonwealth support under all elements of RAS to be subject to Commonwealth/states agreement.

Proposed amendments to the Rural Adjustment Act 1992 were initially considered by the Senate on 9 February 1995 as part of the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill No.3 (PIELAB). The proposed amendments were referred to the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee for further consideration.
In considering the proposed amendments, the Committee generally supported a regional approach to the RAS, but raised a number of concerns, in particular:
the constitutional validity of the amendments;
administrative arrangements to be established to implement the regional approach to the RAS; and
consultation with the States in developing the regional approach to the RAS.

The Committee's report in its deliberations made a number of useful observations on the proposed amendments. The further amendments now proposed respond positively to the Committee's report and accommodate the Committee's substantive concerns.

The Attorney-General's Department has provided clear advice that the proposed amendments are constitutionally valid and that this validity is not affected by any administrative arrangements that may be put into place.
The Commonwealth's ability to enter into agreements with persons other than states; and to make direct or indirect payments to farmers and persons other than farmers, for the
purposes of rural adjustment; is supported by the appropriations power in s81 and the incidental power in s51(xxxix) of the constitution.

In a regional context, the Commonwealth funding is intended to be provided for community based activities relating to rural adjustment. The activities would be driven and undertaken by the States, local government, community and industry, with the Commonwealth in addition to a funding role, monitoring the expenditure of such funding ensuring that it is spent for the purpose for which it was allocated. A role which Attorney-General's Department advises is within the Commonwealth's constitutional powers.

With respect to the Committee's concerns as to the lack of clarity on administrative arrangements, on 3 March the Agriculture and Resource Management Council of Australia and New Zealand (ARMCANZ) endorsed in principle the implementation of integrated and community based regional approaches involving the linked implementation of rural programs such as the RAS, National Landcare, Agribusiness programs, and Rural Communities Access Program.

ARMCANZ also agreed in principle to the early implementation of a Rural Partnership Program (RPP) based on a model incorporating input from the Case Studies Report undertaken by SCARM which focussed on South West Queensland and Sunraysia.

The framework supported by ARMCANZ involves a competitive bidding process, extensive community consultation, and joint development of regional strategies with the States and the community. The suggested approach is consistent with that developed by the Rural Adjustment Scheme Advisory Council (RASAC), and discussed between Commonwealth and State RAS Officers in May 1994.

The South West Queensland Regional Strategy is a pilot project for the development of a regional approach to rural adjustment. The strategy is generally consistent with the ARMCANZ approach, incorporating an integrated package of adjustment measures, including RAS, Landcare, and Rural Counselling. The strategy was initially proposed by community based organisations which recognised the need for rural adjustment within the SWQ region, and is a real partnership between the community and governments at local, state, and Commonwealth levels.

It has always been my intention that within the broad framework discussed with the States, the detailed administrative arrangements under a regional approach would be developed in consultation with the States on a case by case basis and with their full cooperation and consultation. A successful regional initiative can only be effectively and most efficiently implemented with the full cooperation of all parties, Commonwealth, State and local governments community and industry.

The states were consulted on the proposed approach to a regional component to the RAS including on the nature of each of the proposed amendments to the Act, at a meeting of State/Commonwealth RAS Officers in May 1994. The States have been consulted in detail on these additional amendments and support the approach proposed.

These additional amendments to the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill No.3 (PIELAB) meet concerns that the RAS may not be implemented in full consultation with the states. They put in place a requirement for all Commonwealth RAS assistance to be the subject of Commonwealth/State Agreements, including regional initiatives.

The amendments retain provision for, subject to Commonwealth/State agreement, payments to be made directly to beneficiaries, for payments to entities other than farmers under all elements of RAS and for flexible cost sharing arrangements under all elements of RAS. However, as has been stated before, the assistance would be provided within the framework of a Commonwealth/State agreement.

The ability to make direct payments and payments to organisations and groups will allow greater efficiency and effectiveness in program delivery. It will allow for example, one cheque to be paid directly to a training course facilitator, rather than multiple cheques being paid to individual farmers that attend. It will also allow closer linkages to other programs with direct payment elements such as Rural Counselling, Landcare, and Agribusiness.

The flexible cost sharing arrangements allow provision for states or the Commonwealth to make greater funding contributions to regional projects should they so wish. This flexibility is essential to permit RAS assistance to be tailored to regional and community needs.
I commend the amendments to honourable senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen A.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would also like to make some comments with regard to this legislation, particularly the amendments that have been brought before us, which satisfy the concerns that we had. I am talking about the initial concerns that Senator Brownhill and I and others raised in this chamber when the original legislation was here and then what came through in the committee and in the dissenting report.

PARA.TAB: The next point that I want to make causes me enormous concern. One must ask the question how we got legislation brought into this place when it does not reflect the minister's second reading speech. I believe that somebody needs to answer the question as to where the legislation came from. Was it the fault of the department or was it the fault of the minister? It is very serious when legislation which is at such divergence from the second reading speech is brought into this place. It was not a little mistake; it was a huge mistake.

The second reading speech related to regional agreements. This legislation should facilitate those agreements, whereas under examination—getting the information was like drawing teeth—we find that the legislation would have given the Commonwealth power to override every aspect of rural adjustment as we know it. The flow-on from that, relative to the management of land title and aspects of that, is quite enormous and horrendous.

When that legislation was brought in there was certainly a move to change the face of land management and rural agriculture in pastoral Australia as we know it. It is something that I was very upset about.

In the speeches following the second reading speech a number of us raised these particular issues and put down a series of questions for which we wanted answers. Yet, when the committee met to discuss this particular legislation, the department did not come up with a statement or responses to any of those questions. I am very critical of the department for that. It is not its normal form, in my experience. Once again, I pose the question why, in this case, having raised all these issues in this place, the questions were not addressed?

In effect, it meant that the committee's work and the time we spent there was extended significantly. At the end of the day we got the information out, even though, as I said, it was like drawing teeth. I would like some explanation as to why the department behaved in this way towards the committee when these particular issues were raised.

In particular, I pay tribute to the work of Neil Bessell, the secretary of the committee. We always felt we could smell a rat, but it took a while to put our finger on it as we had to look at constitutional aspects and various conventions.

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister can jump up and down all he likes. It does not worry me very much. When we look at all the aspects of it, at the end of the day we got those particular aspects drawn out. The important amendment amongst these—all the amendments are important—relates to 20AA(1) and 20AA(2), concerning the memorandum of understanding about section 20A powers, where it says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister may only enter into an agreement under section 20A that relates, in whole or in part, to an activity carried on, or proposed to be carried on, in a particular State if a memorandum of understanding with that State is in force under subsection (1).

If it had not been for the work of the committee and the people on this side of the chamber, that would not be in this legislation at this particular time. That amendment is absolutely crucial, if this concept of regional schemes is going to work. I support the concept, but it has to be done under the proper guidelines. It has to be driven from the ground upwards and it has to have the full cooperation of the states. Otherwise, it will just turn into a messy conflict.

PARA.TAB: Having made those comments, I am pleased to note that the minister has come forward with these particular amendments, but I leave on the table the question of why, in getting the information, the department was so difficult.

PARA.TAB: Right from the start, as Senator Crane has said, we were concerned that there was going to be an overriding of the present act. People should realise what the current RAS act does.
