PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Constitutional Basis for Proposed Amendments

For a Commonwealth law to be valid it must come within at least one of the Commonwealth powers enumerated in, or capable of being implied from, the Australian Constitution. The law or proposed law must have a constitutional basis.

Only rarely will a Bills Digest call into question the constitutional validity of a piece of legislation or a particular aspect of a Bill. In most cases it will be simply unnecessary to do so. In the present instance however, the proposed amendments which allow for direct payments from the Commonwealth to individuals raise a number of interesting constitutional issues.
(a) The Legislative Process

In the normal course of preparing legislation, the initiating Department or agency will, where any doubt exists, seek advice from the Attorney-General's Department as to the constitutional validity of the proposals being developed. That advice is neither binding nor definitive but is invariably well considered and the product of many years of accumulated wisdom within the Attorney-General's Department. In many cases, proposals are recast to take account of Attorney-General's advice and consequently questions of constitutional validity are mostly answered before legislation is introduced.

On the other hand, the Attorney-General's Department's advice may or may not be clear cut. Moreover, it is for the sponsoring Department to determine whether it wishes to proceed with its legislative package to final consideration by the Legislative Committee of Cabinet before bringing the legislation into the Parliament. Bills sometimes "fall over" because the Government collectively determines that the risk of provoking a successful High Court challenge is too great, but there are also occasions where the Government either deliberately seeks to test the limits of its constitutional powers or else the policy imperative "driving" the legislation cannot be resisted.

Legislation may be introduced without reference to the Constitutional head(s) of power relied on. Legislation may, but need not, recite the relevant sources of Commonwealth power, nor are those sponsoring legislation required to advise the Parliament—through the Explanatory Memorandum or the Second Reading Speech—as to constitutional basis of the measures proposed. Given the opportunity, it is of course quite appropriate for Members and Senators to test those responsible for the legislation on the issue of validity, particularly where the relevant legal basis has not been volunteered. Indeed, what follows are no more than the arguments for raising just these sort of questions in the context of the current proposals affecting RAS.
(b) Constitutional Limitations

It is not uncommon for the Commonwealth to involve itself in activities which are not on their face Commonwealth areas of responsibility under the Constitution. This can be achieved by a variety of means, through:

PARA.TAB: .an existing head of constitutional power being given a broad meaning by the High Court;

.the use of broad "purposive" powers which do not relate to any particular activity but whose subject matter is determined by the object to be achieved [eg. the purposes of "constitutional corporations"—see section 51, placitum (xx)];
.a combination of taxation and grants powers;

.reliance on a range of ancillary powers including the incidental power [section 51, placitum (xxxix)] and the executive power (section 61) and implied powers derived from the Constitution and Australia's status as a national polity;
.the referral of power from the States to the Commonwealth;
.co-operative arrangements between the States and the Commonwealth; and
.reliance on technically invalid legislation which is yet to be ruled to be unconstitutional by the High Court.

SPEECH.PARA: Hence, the Commonwealth is involved in the promotion and regulation of a whole range of activities, for example: sport, education, research and business ventures which are not specifically mentioned in the Constitution but which are commonly accepted as legitimate areas of Commonwealth interest.
As has already been noted, however, there are limits to Commonwealth power.

The limits to the Commonwealth's activities are determined by the High Court on a case by case basis. However, as each case is decided on different facts (and not infrequently by different judges), it is not possible to know precisely or be able safely to predict the limits of the Commonwealth's powers.

Where a controversial matter has not been litigated, where the Court is divided, or where the relevant decisions of the Court do not lay down general principles, there will remain some residual doubts as to the validity of legislative provisions which do not fall squarely within the established meaning of an enumerated head of legislative power. Reliance on an implied or inherent power is by definition problematic.
(c) Validity of Amendments to RAS

Some doubts exist as to the constitutional underpinnings of the amendments being proposed to the Rural Adjustment Act 1992 (RAS Act). This is not because there is any inherent objection to the Commonwealth involving itself in the process of rural adjustment, but because the method chosen here to deliver that assistance may not be within the Commonwealth's power. (At the risk of oversimplifying, the question of constitutional validity frequently turns not on what is to be done, but on how it is to be done.)

The Commonwealth is not specifically empowered to make laws with respect to rural adjustment. Any scheme which provides for Commonwealth involvement in rural adjustment must therefore rely on some other power or powers. So for example, the Commonwealth can (and has) enacted legislation which, through grants to the States, supports a range of measures to assist rural reconstruction as well as other forms of assistance to primary industry. Other strategies such as those involving taxation concessions would also be valid by virtue of being laws with respect to taxation which is an explicit area of Commonwealth legislative competence [eg. section 51, placitum (ii)].

By contrast, there is some doubt as to whether, and the means by which, the Commonwealth may provide direct financial assistance to individuals. In some areas there is no uncertainty because the Constitution clearly provides that the Commonwealth may provide direct assistance. For example, section 51 (xxiiiA) allows for the Commonwealth to make payments in the form of maternity allowances, widow's pensions, child endowment, unemployment, pharmaceutical, sickness and hospital benefits etc. However, as already noted, no such power exists in relation to rural adjustment or payments for drought relief. Likewise, for the most part, the Commonwealth's use of the appropriation power (sections 81 and 83) is uncontroversial. Most Commonwealth appropriations are for programs which have a clear constitutional authority. For example, the Jobsearch and Newstart allowances are clearly authorised by a combination of sections 81, 83 and 51, placitum (xxiiiA).

Other Commonwealth payments to individuals, specifically those for purposes or activities not enumerated in the Constitution, have been a source of legal controversy and have been tested in the High Court. Moreover, despite those cases it would be somewhat adventurous to suggest that those controversies have been safely put to rest.

The potential sources of constitutional difficulty for direct grants are twofold. Firstly, the grant itself may be invalid. This will be the case where the funds expended have not been validly appropriated. Secondly, the scheme devised to administer the grant may also be beyond power—legislation establishing a scheme may be outside the power of Parliament to enact laws (principally section 51) or an administratively based scheme may be beyond the scope of the executive power of the Commonwealth (section 61).
The key elements of the proposed non-State component of the RAS would appear to be:

PARA.TAB: .appropriations to be made by the Parliament (sections 81 and 83 of the Constitution)
.legislation designed to facilitate the payment of direct grants to individuals [potentially supported by the incidental power—section 51, placitum (xxxix)]
.an as yet not fully disclosed set of administrative arrangements for distributing the funds appropriated by the Parliament under the executive power (section 61).

SPEECH.PARA: In the case of the proposed non State-based component of RAS, each of these aspects of the scheme must be within power for the scheme to be constitutionally valid.
(d) Appropriations

It would appear that the non State-based component of RAS is to be funded by an appropriation from the Consolidated Revenue Fund either as a separate measure or through the annual Appropriation Bills. The relevant constitutional provisions here are sections 81 and 83.
Section 83 of the Constitution provides:
No money shall be drawn from the Treasury of the Commonwealth except under appropriation made by law.
Section 81 of the Constitution provides:

All revenues or moneys raised or received by the Executive Government of the Commonwealth shall form one Consolidated Revenue Fund, to be appropriated for the purposes of the Commonwealth in the manner and subject to the charges and liabilities imposed by this Constitution.

For the most part, the Commonwealth's use of the appropriations power is uncontroversial. Most Commonwealth appropriations are for programs which have a clear constitutional authority. Commonly, there are two pieces of legislation, an Appropriations Act, and an Act like the Social Security Act 1991 which regulates the program. Two Acts are required because an appropriation of itself is only a financial measure. In the words of Mason J in Victoria v. Commonwealth (AAP Case) the act of appropriating funds:
does not supply legal authority for the Commonwealth's engagement in the activities in connection with which the monies are to be spent.

It is now generally accepted that an appropriation may be made for any purpose and need not be confined to purposes or activities assigned to the Commonwealth under the Constitution. This view was accepted by three of the five judges who addressed this issue in the AAP Case.

The AAP Case concerned the constitutional validity of executive action taken in support of an appropriation. The Australian Assistance Plan was a scheme established by executive action within the Department of Social Security, and supported by an appropriation. Under the plan, regional councils for social development were to be established at a non-governmental level throughout Australia to identify local social welfare projects which could be supported by a Commonwealth grant. Victoria sought a declaration that the appropriation was invalid and an injunction to restrain the Commonwealth from spending any of the money for purposes of the plan. The Court dismissed the action.

Although this decision did not settle the scope of the appropriation power, the better view would appear to be that appropriations can be made for any purpose—not just matters by reference to heads of legislative power identified under the constitution.
For those interested, the different approaches taken by the High Court in the AAP Case on the scope of section 81 have been summarised by Zines as follows:

1.The appropriation power is a power to appropriate for any purpose. The executive power enables the Commonwealth to carry out that purpose (McTiernan and Murphy J) and section 51 (xxxix) provides a legislative source of power: Murphy J.

2."Purposes of the Commonwealth" in section 81 refer to legislative and executive purposes to be ascertained by examining the specific powers of the Commonwealth and its inherent power as a nation: Barwick CJ and Gibbs J.

3.Section 81 permits appropriations for any purpose but does not permit the Commonwealth to engage in activities unless those activities come within section 61. The scope of section 61 is to be ascertained as in (2) above: Mason J.
Accordingly, there would appear to be little doubt that the Commonwealth can draw funds from the Consolidated Revenue Fund to provide assistance under the proposed amendments to RAS.
(e) Legislative Power

To the extent that legislation is employed to underpin the operations of a scheme of the sort proposed under this Bill, that legislation must come within a head of legislative power enumerated in the Constitution.

Amongst the heads of legislative power commonly relied on is the incidental power [section 51, placitum (xxxix)] which provides that the Parliament may legislate with respect to any matter that is incidental to the execution of a power (including the executive power and the appropriations power) by the Parliament.

The amendments to the RAS Act proposed in the current Bill appear to come within the scope of the incidental power in that they relate directly to the creation of administrative machinery designed to provide grants to persons under the non State-based component of the RAS Act. The Commonwealth's proposed purpose in appropriating any funds under the present proposal may also provide a basis for the use of the incidental power.
(f) Executive Power
Section 61 of the Constitution provides:

The executive power of the Commonwealth is vested in the Queen and is exercisable by the Governor-General as the Queen's representative, and extends to the execution and maintenance of this Constitution, and of the laws of the Commonwealth.

The practical effect of section 61 is to enable the government administration to undertake many administrative activities without prior authorisation from an Act of Parliament. This view is supported by the AAP Case and Davis v. The Commonwealth. McMillan provides a number of examples of executive actions undertaken without the support of legislation, including:

PARA.TAB: .entering into contracts;
.conducting research and inquiries;
.engaging in public relations;
.conducting negotiations with and entering into agreements with other countries;
.incorporation of bodies to carry out governmental activities; and
.the administration of schemes for national awards and celebrations.

SPEECH.PARA: There is, however, considerable doubt as to whether the executive power can be relied on where a Commonwealth proposal does not come within a substantive head of legislative power. Put another way, the executive power is confined to areas of Commonwealth legislative competence.

In both the AAP Case and Davis, members of the High Court (including the present Chief Justice) took the view that executive action which was unsupported by a head of legislative power and intruded into an area of State responsibility was invalid.

The question of whether the executive action "intrudes" into the activities of a State will be one of degree, partly dependent on the nature of the administrative arrangements developed to facilitate and monitor the expenditure of funds appropriated. A complex scheme involving, for example, the creation of a separate Commonwealth Agency is more likely to "intrude" than a system of simply making out cheques according to a list of names compiled by a Department or in the Minister's office. As McMillan has noted:

At one extreme, the Parliament can simply authorise payment of a cheque. For example, to establish an AAP-type scheme the Parliament could make a number of individual grants to organisations to run family day care, parent education, and the like. Alternatively, the Parliament could make a block grant to a private organisation like the Consumers' Health Forum, to be distributed by it to individual projects like family day care.

In either instance the Parliament could then pass allied legislation to ensure the financial accountability of the organisations (for example, providing that each recipient of Commonwealth funds had to acquit to the Commonwealth, and had to use the money for the purpose specified in the grant). The constitutional basis for such legislation would be a s51(39), which provides that the Parliament may legislate with respect to any matter that is incidental to the execution of a power (namely, the appropriations power) by the Parliament. Informal influence could also be exerted by the appointment of a Commonwealth representative to the committee of a private body—an executive action that could be justified as safeguarding legitimate Commonwealth interests in health, welfare, and financial accountability.

Even so, the administrative activity could not develop to the point (as it did in the AAP Case) that the executive was effectively engaging in the activities that were not Commonwealth responsibilities.

The position is further complicated where there is a valid appropriation and the Commonwealth seeks to rely on a combination of the executive power and the incidental power to put into effect a scheme which is not directly related to a substantive head of constitutional power.
(g) Concluding Comments

This digest has discussed at length the Constitutional limitations on the power of the Commonwealth to pay money directly to individuals. This discussion was prompted by concerns raised with the authors over the validity of the amendments proposed to the RAS Act.
Our general conclusions are that:

PARA.TAB: .the scheme will require a valid appropriation under sections 81 and 83 of the Constitution;
.the proposed amendments to the RAS Act are supported by a combination of the incidental and executive powers; and

.the validity of the administrative machinery to be developed to run the "regional" component of RAS will depend on the extent to which those, as yet undisclosed administrative arrangements, intrude into spheres regarded as properly the sole responsibility of the States.

SPEECH.PARA: This lengthy exposition may not have been necessary had the relevant detail been provided in the Explanatory Memorandum or in the Second Reading Speech to the Bill.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to make a contribution to the debate on this legislation.
—Spare us, Ron.

—If Senator Schacht would sit down and listen, I will teach him all I know about primary industry, as I have taught him all I know about small business, and it certainly has improved his performance on small business.

PARA.TAB: The Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1994 [1995] formalises the taking of rural adjustment funds out of the hands of farmers, and out of the hands of the states, and putting it somewhere else. Any watering down of this process and any diminishing of the funds of that process concerns me. They could go into all sorts of airy-fairy things, or TAFE colleges or more formal education. DEBATE.TITLE: STATES GRANTS (PRIMARY AND SECONDARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 23 March, on motion by Senator Crowley:
That this bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill 1995 amends the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Act 1992 to give effect to the following budget initiatives: $8.7 million to be provided in 1995 to foster literacy development for children in the early years of schooling and $4 million to be allocated in 1995 to provide grants to school authorities to support the study of 10 priority languages. This program will replace an existing program which supports eight languages in each state and territory.

PARA.TAB: The bill will also give effect to changes to the Commonwealth's new schools policy. Whilst the opposition will not be opposing this bill, we do continue to express concern at the new schools policy of the government and the timetable for the review of this program as recently announced by the minister. To understand many of this bill's implications fully, it is important to have a background understanding of what these measures involve. With regard to the new schools policy, in order to gain provisional approval and, eventually, final approval for general recurrent funding, schools must meet certain eligibility criteria, including an advanced notification requirement and a sufficiently high funding priority.

Under the 1992 act, a school wishing to operate at a new location, amalgamate, provide an additional level of education or separate into two or more schools must give notice two years before 1 March in the year in which the change is proposed. The States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1994 extends this notice period to three years before 31 October for changes proposed on or after 1 January 1997.

Clause 23 of this bill introduces a further notification requirement for changes or proposals intended to occur on or after 1 January 1998. So that notification of a change or proposal to be funded in 1998 will be required by 31 October 1995. We are already a quarter of the way into 1995 and, not only has this bill not been passed, but one must question the ability of schools which have not acted pending the outcome of this bill to give adequate notification by the end of October this year.

The coalition maintains its policy position of the last election, which is to abandon the new schools policy. The Labor Party has always been philosophically opposed to non-government school education. This policy is just one example of this outdated philosophical position. The principal objective of this policy is to make it as difficult as possible for new schools to start. The policy is opposed to real parental choice in schooling, with the post-1992 funding policy effectively pricing non-government schools out of the reach of many parents. The coalition is committed to parental choice in schooling and we believe that this should be an affordable choice. The coalition has long been opposed to the new schools policy. The policy is restrictive, intrusive and designed to restrict true parental choice.

Representatives of non-government schools have repeatedly said to us that the policy significantly retards new schools growth. The ironic aspect of this whole debate is that the government has now virtually conceded that there are problems being caused by this new schools policy. The Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training, Mr Free, announced early this month that a review of the policy would be undertaken. It is quite obvious that this review is no more than an attempt to placate growing anger in the community about the program. That fact is obvious from the timetable for the review which allows for a discussion paper by the middle of this year, but a finalisation of the review itself by March 1996, probably after the next election. We would urge the government to bring about a finalisation of that review by the end of September this year at least.

The concerns we have with this bill have been shown to be legitimate to the extent that even the minister acknowledges the new schools policy, which this bill serves to further restrict, needs further review. Had the government the courage to listen to the opposition in the first place and to abandon this obnoxious policy, the sector would not be in the chaos it is in today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As we have been told by Senator Gibson, the legislation we have before us, the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill 1995, provides $8.7 million for a literacy program concentrating on the early years of schooling and provides additional money for a language program as budget initiatives which have taken until this time to manifest themselves. We also have some non-controversial changes to administrative arrangements under the new schools policy. The Democrats will be supporting and welcoming all of these aspects of the legislation, but that is not to say that there is no controversy to be explored. With Senator Gibson, I believe there are many parts of the new schools policy which can and should be challenged; but perhaps not at this moment, because in this legislation what is being proposed is worth while.

PARA.TAB: Senator Gibson said that the policy of the coalition was to abandon the new schools policy. I wonder whether that means that there will be no policy with regard to new schools from the coalition or whether we can wait in anticipation, as we do with many other coalition policies, for the vacuum to be filled. I will welcome the day when we see some substance there. With regard to the other aspects of the legislation, I take this opportunity to make comment on the provision for education both by the Commonwealth and indirectly by the states, as they are the recipients of money from the Commonwealth to sustain their education systems.

I think it is important for me to state here and now that the 1990s will be remembered as the decade when Australia's economists looked into their crystal balls and decided that the future was far too expensive. While it is trite to say that our future is in our schools, it is becoming even more true as we move to the year 2000 and to a world where those with skills prosper while those without skills struggle even to survive.

In response to this challenge, and in response to the need to position Australia in this new world order where knowledge and education are the sources of wealth, in aiming to achieve their vision of a clever country the leaders we have at the moment and have had over the last few years have overseen the systematic starvation of our school systems. Australia now ranks 13th out of the 16 countries in the OECD in education spending as a percentage of GDP. We are on the way down with a bullet, despite more of our population being of school age than is true of most other developed countries. We remain ahead only of such notable international economic powerhouses as Turkey and Portugal.

In the 1970s we spent nearly six per cent of our GDP on education, and now it is down to only about 4 1/2 per cent. In 1980, 25 per cent of government spending nationwide went on education, and now it is down close to 20 per cent. In Victoria we have witnessed the Kennett government slashing more than $300 million off the education budget, closing 250 schools and sacking thousands of teachers. South Australia has followed that short-sighted lead, as has Tasmania, where the Liberal government has cut education spending for three years in a row by a cumulative 20 per cent. We also see that Mr Goss got rid of 450 teaching positions in 1994. New South Wales faces a shortfall of 2,500 teachers, and New South Wales has the largest class sizes in Australia. It begs the question: when did investing in the future become such an unpopular idea?

All of these cuts have occurred through a period of rising enrolment and rising retention rates, and at a time when the demands of the new information age have meant that more resources are needed to teach children to cope with the technologies of the future. What should be spent on education is being contradicted by what is being spent. I do not want to get into the pointless argument that often goes on in this place about whether it is the responsibility of federal or state governments. The state governments have been cutting spending on schools partly because the general purpose grants to states have been cut by a third by this government, but it is also partly due to their own lack of commitment to public education. I do not want to get into a debate on the pros and cons of the new schools policy. I think there is much in that to explore, but not at this time.

The popular response to the sorts of criticisms that I have just made has been that throwing money at a problem is not the way to solve it. I agree with that; it is not the whole solution. But it is quite foolish to suggest that better qualified teachers, smaller class sizes and better equipped schools can be achieved without money.

The government's own reports—and I start with the Finn review, the Ramsey report and the Swan report—all called for substantial increases in school funding. They all commented on overcrowded classes, inappropriate facilities, outdated equipment and limited access to technology. But instead of heeding those reports, the Commonwealth has introduced this bizarre concept of benchmarking. As I said in a committee the other day, `benchmarking' to me is a gerund. It has been used as a verb by a whole new race of bureaucrats who seem to think that it is more important to invent a whole new vocabulary than to get on and actually address the basic problem that not enough money is being spent.

Anyway, this benchmarking business is based on cost, so all states are now competing to spend the least amount of money per student in order to be assessed as the most efficient. Arguments are expressed in terms of achieving cost reductions, and the usual thing that is quoted is `without sacrificing educational standards'. In fact, what is happening is that we are being pushed towards the lowest common denominator in an inexorable way.

Many of the effects of the considered neglect that is going on in our schools are obvious. We all know of state schools in poorer areas with composite classes. The debate about that is not the debate that we need to have here, but it is a fact that there are more composite classes in schools in poorer areas. In those same areas we have incomplete equipment inventories and facilities. We see a reduction in the numbers of science teachers, and we see teachers doubling up in areas in which they have no training.

Some courses are not offered or schools rely on voluntary fundraising to pay the salaries of the so-called `extras' of music, language or physical education teachers. We know that retention rates are falling, that literacy rates are low and that surveys show people are losing confidence in the government school system. I believe that relates directly to the sorts of things that Senator Gibson was raising. It is alarming to see this process under way.

But there are more insidious effects that are not as obvious. We can see a school system which is beginning to entrench inequality—entrenching a permanent underclass. We are seeing a school system that is being privatised by stealth and by neglect with all the implications for inequality that entails. Because we have so-called voluntary fees, we have the `McDonaldisation' of our education system—we have untrammelled and unregulated corporate sponsorship. We see attempts to keep a check on this process but those attempts are failing because our schools are needing to compete for resources by attracting more students. The aspects of this phenomenon will manifest themselves more clearly as time passes, but I would ask honourable senators to take note of what is happening when they see the sponsorship logos on the gates of our schools.

When they are strapped for cash, the schools all around our country demand extra fees from parents. In South Australia, as I brought to the Senate's attention in a notice of motion just a couple of days ago, if parents do not pay these so-called voluntary fees, the school takes them to the small claims court or it sends around a debt collector to remind the parents of the obligations that they have to the school of several hundred dollars. I do not think that is a funny matter at all, Minister.

In other states we have seen children refused their school report cards. We have seen access to library books denied to students who have not paid these so-called voluntary fees. This has also happened in respect of lockers, excursions, school camps, annual school bike rides, or whatever, welding equipment, trade and craft materials. Inferior or no materials are provided to students whose parents have been unable to pay these so-called voluntary fees.

This insidious trend has gone well past the point where, when you and I were at school, Minister, such a concept was probably $3 or $4, perhaps even $30 or its equivalent in today's terms. Now we see $300 and $400 being the common level of voluntary fees per student per school. In some state systems where education maintenance allowance cheques are provided, we have even seen principals refusing to hand those over until the so-called voluntary fees have been paid.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is illegal I think, isn't it?

—I agree. I am very pleased that the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction (Senator Schacht) has interjected that that is illegal. Parents who were very unsure of their status in this situation will be very pleased that the minister interjected that that is illegal.

PARA.TAB: So much has been written about this issue in the past few years. I remember writing about this in 1992, in one of our leading metropolitan dailies, and being told that the situation was unclear. If the minister has now clarified it by saying that it is illegal—

TALK.START.PARA: —I said that I think it is illegal, and I hope it is.
—I would appreciate it if the minister could clarify his own position eventually—not at this moment.
—I will certainly ask the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Crean) to have a look at it.

—That would help this situation a lot. Jeanette Wilson, writing in the Rationalist, wrote that there is developing within the government school system a two-tier model: the base model which is available free to all students, and the user-pays model with the extras being provided to those who pay voluntary fees. In fact, these fees are no longer for just extras, if ever they were. They are being used to fund basic items such as books, materials, gymnasium equipment, and so on. The president of the Victorian Association of Secondary School Principals has said:

SPEECH.PARA: Schools cannot provide adequate quality education without the voluntary fee.

If the minister is concerned about these matters, perhaps he might take that quote with him and see whether that in fact means a voluntary fee or whether some sort of pressure is being placed on parents.

PARA.TAB: In the ACT primary schools, parent contributions almost equal the government funding of operating budgets. They are used to funding programs offered by schools and the essential equipment for those schools. I think this is simply unfair. Schools in affluent areas can raise money and sustain their programs and schools in poor areas cannot. The difference in school funding can end up being tens of thousands of dollars. Of course, it is immediately apparent that these fees are regressive in the extreme, and that a single income family with four children in high school is looking at having to pay several thousand dollars; $1,400 a year is not unusual in that situation.

I re-state the position of the Democrats that this is the sort of thing that we ought to be very concerned about. We as a party believe that the only fair education system is a free education system. We oppose these fees that I have been speaking about, in any form, and we oppose this idea of introduction by stealth of a user-pays system.

Schools in some states are now funded on the basis of student numbers so that the money they do have to spend on features attractive to success conscious parents are to the detriment of student welfare programs. I have heard reports—I must say that they are informal reports and I cannot verify them at the moment—of parents with children who have behaviour problems approaching schools and being told, `Don't turn up, go somewhere else. Go and pester some other school.' Brian Burdekin has called the public education system's treatment of young people with social disabilities as `an abomination'. That is a quote of his attitude to that. These are the sorts of insidious trends that are a direct result of the way we fund our education system at the moment.

A Smith Family survey showed that our school system is now so inequitable that 60 per cent of children from poorer families are leaving school functionally illiterate. This package of legislation makes some attempt to address that. However, I suggest that that attempt—the spending of $4 million for the priority language program and $8.7 million for an early years literacy program—could easily be seen as wasting money unless the other problems in our education system are addressed. Those problems are the problems that are inherent in the way that we have allowed these insidious voluntary fees to creep up to the extent where they increase inequities.

Australia cannot afford to have an underclass of people that has been denied any position in the world where knowledge and skills are the things that are most important. If we neglect those people to that extent, then we should be condemned. When fees are not immediately extractable from parents, the other place that our school principals go to for money is to the corporate sponsors: McDonalds, Pizza Hut, Hungry Jacks, Mars Bars and Coco Pops. Schools are being funded by the amount of lolly wrappers the children can pick up from the gutter—I am not stretching that point.

We have seen fundraising schemes which involve dollars being returned to a school based on the amount of grocery receipts or lolly wrappers that are collected by the school. Every senator in this place should be familiar with these trends and should be awake to what they mean in the end. If the school needs computers, it must negotiate with IBM or Apple, which have the whip hand over this.

Those companies are determining what ends up being provided for learners in our schools, not the departments of education. That happens in the fortunate instances and not at the end where kids are picking lolly wrappers out of the gutters. We should be deciding what equipment goes into our schools. We should be deciding what is an appropriate learning environment for our children. Teachers in education should be contributing, not corporate marketeers.

The equity aspects should be obvious to anybody who has the capacity to think about this. In instances where it is possible, we should be addressing these matters. Children as young as five years of age are visiting McDonalds outlets in official primary school excursions. A newspaper survey last weekend showed that of 35 McDonalds outlets, 32 said that primary school children had come through their outlets on tours. All that this says is that the gold star that we all strove for as children has been replaced by vouchers to the golden arches.

TALK.START.PARA: —McDonalds is good fun!
—I agree with Senator McGauran's interjection that it is good fun to go to McDonalds, but is it educationally valuable? Is it the pinnacle of educational values that we want our children to pursue?

PARA.TAB: The last point I want to make about the neglect in our schools is the risk that we run for our children if we allow them to be by-passed by the information superhighway. One computer for 20 school children is not enough. Students need individual access. To leave a school bereft of computer skills will, in tomorrow's world, be a sentence to second-class jobs for life. We know that those who have access to a greater amount of cash will have computers at home, but our public schools must be the first staging post. It must be the first place where we gain access to that information superhighway.

We cannot allow the cost of the information and its technology to entrench information inequality. We must ensure that there is equitable access for all the technologies of tomorrow. We have to make sure that those things that are becoming absolutely essential

SPEECH.PARA: to provide our children with a capacity to compete in tomorrow's world are not denied because of our ignorance in this place, ignorance of what is happening in schools and ignorance of the effects that are occurring because of the lack of proper direction and funding. I do not apologise for taking this moment to raise these matters. It is important that it be raised here. However, we do support the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not intend to speak in this debate but, seeing we are at the end of the matter, we cannot let some of the comments made by Senator Bell and, indeed, Senator Schacht, pass, because it leads—
—You interjected, Minister.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator West)—Just address the chair, thank you, Senator Tierney; you might get through this more quickly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Schacht did interject and did seem to have a misleading view of certain aspects of public and private education in this country. Speaking today for the Democrats, Senator Bell has made much of the fact of private sponsorships in schools and the lack of funding for public education. Let us look across a whole range of areas. I have just come from a press conference with his colleague Senator Bourne. She indicated that the problems of the ABC could be fixed with more money. Senator Bell has indicated that the problems of education could be fixed with more money.

PARA.TAB: I look around Australia at the run-down infrastructure; we could certainly fix the roads with more money. Farmers are crying out for drought relief. What do they need? They need more money. The harsh reality in this country, of course, is—and I think today's current account deficit blow-out of almost $3 billion has borne this out—that the days are long gone in this country when we could afford to do everything that was needed: we could build the roads that were needed; we could provide the welfare benefits that were needed; we could provide the funding for schooling that was needed. We have got to look around for some creative solutions to this problem.

Schools are being forced into a range of measures to get hold of extra funding because of lack of funding in the public budget. But there is quite a simple answer to the whole problem in education of lack of funding which this government has overlooked. That is, providing true freedom of choice for parents in schooling in this country. We have a situation where parents pay $1.5 billion at the moment in private school fees. This takes tremendous pressure off the public budget for education. If the government wants to continue taking pressure off, obviously what it can do if parents want to do this—and it is a democracy; we live in a society with freedom of choice—is allow parents to send their children to private schools if they are prepared to pay the fees. My children go to private schools; I am prepared to pay the fees. There are a lot of others out there that are prepared to pay.

This government calls its policy the new schools policy; I prefer to call it the no new schools policy because that policy is there to put a brake on the expansion of private schools in this country. I was chairman of a private school while it was expanding; I felt and the school felt the full effects of this policy. Even though we were established in a suburb that was not expanding, the enrolments of the school were drawn from right across the whole region. We were drawing enrolments from expanding areas. Under this policy, the regional situation is not taken into account.

Last week we had some hearings here in Canberra. We heard from the Steiner school people and they are having exactly the same problem. Because they want to locate a school in an area that does not have rapid growth, they are being prevented from doing this. The government still does not recognise the regional nature of the school system. I think one of the most telling indictments of the government's new schools policy and its approach to private schooling in this country is that the people from the Steiner school movement told us that if they were establishing their entire system in Canberra at this point in time under the government's so-called new schools policy, nothing would start. It would stymie them; the system would not even start. This so-called new schools policy would break it.

So the point I am making very simply is that, if the government is concerned about lack of budget funding for schooling in this country, there is one solution that will not cost the budget anything at all. If people want to set up schools, if they meet the minimum requirements of the school educational authorities, they should be allowed to go ahead and do it. What this would do is allow a gradual expansion of the private school system. We are not going to end up with 70 per cent private schools in this country. That is not going to happen at all. But I would think that it would possibly go up from where it is now—27 per cent perhaps—to something like 35 per cent. If we multiply the dollars that would save the government across the country—as it is now saving $1.5 billion—that could be sufficient to assist public education. That saved budget money could be put back into public education and could allay some of the concerns that Senator Bell has raised.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I seek leave on behalf of Senator Margetts to incorporate Senator Margetts's copious notes in Hansard.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Gibson

TALK.START.PARA: —Could I just make a point about that? Normally the coalition would not agree to this being done without the senator being present but, this being the last day of the session, we will agree on this occasion.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

INTERJECT.PARA: STATES GRANTS (PRIMARY AND SECONDARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1994

This bill makes some amendments to the new schools policy to improve the processes for non government schools to receive government funding. It also clarifies the complicated process of gaining approval for progressively introduced education levels and replaces the Priority Language Incentive Element with funding for 10 priority languages.

The Greens will be voting for this bill as we believe the bill's measures will improve the workability and administration of the New Schools Policy. This does not mean we do not have criticisms of the New Schools Policy, but we do believe these reforms will enhance the workability of the policy pending its review over the next year.

Members of the community have raised their concerns with me about the utter complexity of the New Schools Policy. They question the limits of minimum and maximum numbers of students allowed before a school can open and claim government funding. This places undue inflexibility on new schools who will have fluctuating numbers in their first years. This can actually have a destabilising effect on new schools, whereas the purpose of the policy is to help viable schools get off the ground. The Government's definition of viability is narrow of course—being too caught up with economic viability rather than educational viability.

The other big concern is with differing rules for independent schools versus systems. Schools are forming systems—bodies that run schools, in order to circumvent the very complicated rules that benefit systems. This means that identical schools in different areas can get very different levels of funds which is unfair and inequitable. Schools then get locked into the category of funding they have received in the past although they may be changing their focus, expertise, populations and demographics, but they cannot change their funding to match their needs.

A further community concern expressed to me is on the new priority languages program stipulated in this bill. The Government will give priority to 10 languages. It is assumed that this is a realistic goal to introduce 10 different languages into the school curriculum. However, I understand that it will be very difficult to retrain teachers and change the focus of language teachers so quickly with limited resources.

These are just some of the larger concerns we have in the context of this Bill. We are however supporting this bill because it reintroduces some rather complicated amendments to make the New Schools Policy which requires a lot of rethinking, to work in the interim, before we get something better.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not think it would be necessary to speak on the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill 1995, because I cannot see anyone opposing its measures about the way to improve literacy programs and language programs in our schools and so forth. However, after hearing some of the remarks by members of the opposition, the record just has to be put straight. The government does not oppose the establishment of independent schools—
—Your policy has that effect, Minister.

—We do not oppose the establishment of independent schools. In fact, under this government's policy, the number of enrolments in private schools has increased from 25.8 per cent in 1985 to 28.5 per cent now.
—If you hadn't put a brake on it, it would be even higher.
—We know what your policy is—it is to let anyone who wants to establish a school—
—There should be this minimum requirement.

—Minimum requirement. Well, this is just the minimum to allow anybody to establish them. Then members of the opposition will not provide the funding on a needs basis. They will do it on a per capita basis so that, irrespective of the value of the education or the needs of the individual student, the schools that clearly have a higher socioeconomic background will get the same funding as an independent school in a lower socioeconomic area—a Catholic parish school, and so on. The coalition would give Melbourne Grammar the same funding per student as it would give to a Catholic parish school.
—That is not our policy, never has been and you know it.

—That is basically the bottom line. It would fudge the figures over a period of time in government to ensure that that would happen. In regard to this minimum standard, which is not defined, what we could easily end up with is some of these quite bizarre groups in the community who claim that they want to establish their own schools: members of some of these sects that have been running around in recent times carrying out terrorist acts. There was one recently in Japan and another a couple of years ago in Texas. I suspect these are the sorts of people who, under coalition policy, would be able to get public funding to establish an independent school, because the coalition has not defined in any way what are the minimum requirements. What it is on about is redirecting resources from the public sector, the taxpayers' money—

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator West)—Order!

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition, over time, will allow the rich schools to get richer and the poorer schools in the independent sector to get poorer. That is the bottom line of the coalition policy. It always has been, for two, three or more decades. The Labor Party, since 1967, has supported state aid for independent schools on a needs basis. That is the philosophical approach we take. That will always be the approach we take, and it is the best approach because it is about equity for kids. But the structure of the review that the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Crean) has mentioned has nothing to do with what Senator Tierney and Senator Gibson have attempted to raise here as a standard political red herring.

PARA.TAB: We believe that this bill has got to be supported. The bill raises issues about grants for national projects for literacy, grants for priority languages and grants in relation to conditions. The requirement for non-government schools to notify changes in operations, to vary the periods required for notification, are quite sensible from an administrative point of view. On that basis, the honourable senator is getting up and telling us that we are trying to squeeze the independent sector. This bill is a very good bill and I do know that, because it is a non-controversial bill, that the honourable senators opposite will be voting for it, though they have spent 45 minutes telling us it is the end of the independent school system as we know it. That is utterly wrong.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.
Debate resumed.

DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT (DROUGHT RELIEF MEASURES) BILL 1995

TALK.START.PARA: —On 21 September 1994, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) announced the federal government's drought assistance package, which included tax incentives for farm storage and water facilities to encourage farmers to better prepare for drought. At that time, he also indicated that other, longer-term measures would be taken to cabinet at a later date to deal with such matters as taxation initiatives and income equalisation deposits. These additional measures were announced in December of last year. The package included an enhanced farm management bonds scheme, with additional tax incentive measures to encourage the building up of physical reserves for future drought.

PARA.TAB: In broad terms, the Taxation Laws Amendment (Drought Relief Measures) Bill 1995 amends, firstly, the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 to provide for a drought investment allowance to encourage investment in drought mitigation property; and, secondly, the Loan (Income Equalisation Deposits) Act 1976 to make farm management bonds a more attractive investment vehicle for farmers. The coalition will be supporting this bill. However, there are a number of points that need to be made.

The first is the fact that the government announced these measures in December last year and forecast the drought investment allowance in September last year. It is, therefore, an indictment of the government and the minister that it has taken so long to prepare the legislation. It also needs to be stressed that the government has only now accepted the fact that long overdue drought preparedness measures should be available for the current financial year. The opposition and farming industry leaders have been arguing this point for some time.

In relation to the bill itself, the drought investment allowance will benefit only those farmers who can afford to purchase capital equipment. In addition, the condition that use of water storage and transport facilities must be in accord with an approved water conservation plan is, in effect, forcing farmers to enter into such plans. Secondly, the changes to the farm management bonds scheme will benefit only those farmers who are lucky enough to have earned enough income to set aside as a future insurance against future droughts.

I ask the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction (Senator Schacht) to confirm to the Senate that the definition of `item' in proposed new section 626 of this bill is sufficient to cover a combination of several elements—for example, a water management plan consisting of three small storage dams, reticulation between them and a bore. Can these separate but interrelated elements be aggregated into one item and be eligible for the drought reduction allowance, even if the cost of individual items is under the $3,000 limit but the total cost exceeds $3,000?

We in the opposition have some concerns about this point, and have sought advice from the Taxation Office. Whilst we are satisfied that such a situation would be eligible for the allowance, I would just like the minister's official confirmation of that point on the record.

TALK.START.PARA: —The bill that we are debating, the Taxation Laws Amendment (Drought Relief Measures) Bill 1995, contains those measures that Senator Gibson has already spoken of. It brings forward a tax incentive for drought proofing a farm, which is basically a five-year, 10 per cent allowance for capital expenditure up to $50,000 per annum per taxpayer in livestock, fodder storage, water storage, water transport facilities and minimum tillage equipment; and an enhancement of farm management bond schemes, with investment interest, to go up to 100 per cent.

PARA.TAB: This is in reaction to drought affected farmers, Madam Acting Deputy President; but what the farmers in drought areas need at the present moment is real help, not the would-be help in this bill. This bill may be okay for a time down the track, after farmers recover from the drought effects and get some income. Then they can look forward to planning against the next drought. What they require at the present moment is more low interest loans and that sort of thing.

Of course, it is not only to the drought affected farmers of New South Wales and Queensland who are affected. I have in mind the East Gascoyne region of Western Australia, in drought for four years and totally ignored by this government. What did the government give them after four years of drought? It offered them a $25,000 stewardship grant, subject to various conditions. The minister at the table, the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction (Senator Schacht), should not expect to get this bill through before 2 o'clock, because there are a few points to be made by me and my good colleague Senator Sandy Macdonald.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, well, there's plenty of time.
—We have got to make these points to tell the people of Australia how they are being hoodwinked by this bill if they think it is going to help drought affected farmers this year.
—They're waiting on your words.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator West)—Minister!

TALK.START.PARA: —We have got plenty of time. Let him go, Madam Acting Deputy President. He is all right. I can handle him.
—Address your remarks to the chair and ignore everybody else, thank you.

—Thank you, that is good advice. The stewardship grant made to farmers in the East Gascoyne region of Western Australia was some $25,000 towards landcare and that sort of thing, but one of the things that is mandatory about it is that the owner must live on the station. I suppose that is a fair enough assumption in certain circumstances, but I know one station owner who is 75 years old. He still holds the station. He is battling to get up into a truck or into any sort of heavy vehicle, but to get the grant he has got to be able to live on the place. I suppose he might be able to do that, but he has had a manager—the same manager—for 20 years. That manager has a wife and children. As far as I am concerned, they are working that station on behalf of the owner, so they should be just as eligible for the grant as anyone else.

PARA.TAB: However, the measures contained in this bill only help one section of people in Australia at the present moment: the people who were fortunate enough to be able to have a reasonable crop. They are the ones who may be able to get some help so they can put it into drought bonds, buy some minimum tillage equipment, do landcare, buy water storage and buy storage for fodder. All of those sorts of things those farmers may be able to do, but those who are drought affected will not get one cent out of this bill. Why will they not get any help? Because this bill allows deductibility from taxable income; and, of course, drought affected farmers have no income, so to them the deductibility is of no use whatsoever.

The farmers who are badly drought affected might not be able to get any benefit next year, either, because the losses on this year's drought will carry forward against next year's income. So how can anyone say that this is of help to drought affected farmers? It is totally ridiculous to claim that.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is wasting time.
—I am not wasting time, Senator Faulkner. I am pointing out to the whole of Australia what a sham this bill is, when you are pretending that you are helping drought affected farmers.

PARA.TAB: Debate interrupted.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I inform the Senate that the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, Senator Bolkus, will be absent from question time today, as he will be overseas on official business. He will be visiting the Republic of Korea, the People's Republic of China, Hong Kong, Thailand and Indonesia, undertaking bilateral discussions on immigration matters. His first appointment is with the foreign minister in Seoul tomorrow, requiring him to leave Australia today. His primary purpose in visiting China is, as Senator Bolkus foreshadowed in his answer to Senator Short during question time yesterday, to discuss with Chinese authorities issues concerning the recently arrived Sino-Vietnamese boat people. In Senator Bolkus's absence, Senator Ray will take questions relating to immigration and ethnic affairs and will represent the Minister for Administrative Services, I will represent the Attorney-General and Senator Cook will represent the Minister for Housing and Regional Development.

—My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government. In 1986, when Mr Keating warned that we were heading towards a banana republic, the current account deficit was running at $12 billion, or five per cent of gross domestic product. Now, nine years since the banana republic warning and the recession we had to have, the current account deficit by the government—
—Given the circumstances, it is not the same at all.
—We will give him an opportunity to say that.
—Stop manipulating.

—A journeyman like your good self is in no position to justify the indefensible. Now, nine years since the banana republic warning and the recession we had to have, the current account deficit by the government's own projections is expected to be $26 billion, or nearly six per cent of GDP, for 1994-95.
—You are en economic incompetent.
—We are not in government. Why, after a decade of talking about the current account, has your government done absolutely nothing to solve this problem?

—The economy in 1995 is a very different kettle of fish from that in 1986—and Senator Alston knows that perfectly well—in terms of the growth rates we have been achieving, the inflation rates remarkably low that we have been sustaining, the levels of investment remarkably high that we have been seeing and the associated productivity, the competitiveness gains and the exports that are associated with that and the general shape of the economy. The current account deficit remains a problem, but it is a problem that should be seen in context.

PARA.TAB: The current account deficit fell by $111 million in February from the previous month, due to a strong rise in exports and a fall in the net income deficit. The deficit of $2.165 billion was in fact right down the lower end of market expectations, which ranged on this occasion as high as $2.7 billion.

But more important than the size of the deficit is its composition and the circumstances that have led to its change, including the surge in imports of capital equipment, which is of course part of the general surge in productive investment associated with a very strong economy. Investments are now forecast to grow by an extraordinarily strong 24 per cent in 1994-95. Remember, we said in the last budget it was going to be 14, and those opposite were sort of chortling their heads off at that stage on the ground that that was unobtainable. This of course is sucking in imports of capital equipment.

Capital imports rose 24 per cent in the first eight months of 1994-95 compared with the same period in 1993-94. These imports reflect that the prospects for growth—not just the present growth rate, but its prospects—are excellent, and that of course reflects the economic success of which I spoke.

The unsynchronised nature of world recovery has meant that Australian demand for imports has picked up ahead of world demand for Australian exports. While the US economy has also experienced very strong growth, Germany has thus far experienced only a weak, largely export-led recovery, and Japan is only just emerging from recession.

There has been structural change in the economy, such as the fact that as a result of tariff reform Australia is in a transition phase on the path to greater export diversity, with the initial impact of raising import intensity. Falling world commodity prices have seen Australia's terms of trade decline over the last several decades, making it increasingly hard to balance our trade without structural reform on the export side.There is the drought, which is adversely affecting rural exports still. Although rural exports rose two per cent in seasonally adjusted terms in February, this followed falls of four per cent in January and 11 per cent in December. There is the two per cent rise in world interest rates, which adds to debt servicing costs and the net income deficit. These are all factors affecting the balance as it is presently emerging.

While the $2.4 billion current account deficit in December and the $2.3 billion in January are the highest monthly deficits on record in absolute terms, they are clearly not the highest—and we seem to be past that hump already if the figure for this month is going to be sustained—as a proportion of GDP. Monthly deficits of close to this amount were recorded in January 1990 and December 1989, when nominal GDP was significantly lower. That again creates part of the context against which these figures should be seen.

You talk in terms of increases against GDP, but that is not so; they have been in that sort of territory before. The important thing to appreciate in all of this is that the long-term prognosis is good. Manufactured exports continue to respond well to the improved economic environment and as these other international factors of which I spoke a moment ago come back into the kinds of parameters that we are anticipating, they will have their own positive effects, too. The crucial thing is this underlying increase in Australian competitiveness, now nearly 40 per cent since the early 1980s, low inflation, low wage rises, strong productivity growth and maintaining that. We have seen exports particularly strong in the area of elaborately transformed manufactures, growing by 16 per cent last year and by 19 per cent over the year to date. These are all signs of an economy that is flourishing. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Defence. I ask: has the minister's attention been drawn to comments made by the Premier of Victoria Mr Kennett doubting the Defence processes in awarding a contract to a company offering a foreign product? Can the minister indicate to the Senate why this decision was made?

—I am aware of the comments by the Victorian Premier and other reports in the media regarding Defence's decision to award a contract for supplying Italian forklift trucks to the army. The adverse comments that surfaced yesterday follow an unfortunate trend by losing tenderers to question the Defence processes and cry foul. I can assure the Senate that the Defence tendering processes are rigorous and are carried out with the utmost propriety. They have to be because we are dealing with very large sums of money across a diverse range of equipment and facilities in defence. It must be, however, said that the defence processes do sit in rather stark contrast to the rather quaint tendering processes that occur in the state of Victoria these days. But I might give an airing to those matters at a later time.

PARA.TAB: I would like to make some specific comments about the forklift truck project and the assertions made. The tender for this project involved three companies, namely, Domino Mining, Caterpillar Australia and Tutts. The first two contenders offered an overseas product with a through life support for the equipment, essentially locally based. The Tutts product is an Australian made forklift with some imported components, mainly the engine and transmission. With equipment such as this, army undertakes a comprehensive test program to examine the capabilities of each machine. It should be appreciated that this forklift is required to operate in the field under a variety of conditions.

With respect to the Tutts forklift, it was found that its large size made operations in confined spaces very difficult, the high boom severely restricted the vision of the operator—a significant safety factor—preparation for transport by air was far less easy than the other two competitors, and the machine did not have a separate inching and creeping function, as required in the specifications. In addition, in comparison to the preferred tenderer, the operator had to stop the machine to change gear on gradients, the wheels were so large that they required two people to change them, and the boom cylinder mounting brackets were underdesigned. I am also informed that the claim made by Tutts that it was the only machine to have passed all the trials is incorrect. In fact, all machines incurred some damage or partial failure during the trials.
Clearly I would be delighted, and I always am delighted as an economic Australian chauvinist—

TALK.START.PARA: —Spare parts—when is the time to get them?

—Senator Panizza raises a good point. I thank him for his assistance. The Tutts project is a prototype. The other two are in working order. There was no proper through life support offered through the Tutts program, so Senator Panizza is right to raise spare parts and reinforces the very point I am making.

PARA.TAB: I was saying in conclusion before I answered Senator Panizza's interjection that I am an economic nationalist—I like to see Australian firms win—but I will not respond to pleas by the Premier of Victoria to interfere in the tender process to award a contract to someone who has put in a higher price for a product that is rated lower in quality and ability. To do so would really, I think, pervert the whole tender process. I have no intention of importing to the Commonwealth tendering processes those that the current Victorian government is implementing. If I did, I would be rightly criticised not only by the Auditor-General, but also by the estimates committee and by this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, who is also the minister responsible for ASIS. I ask: why, a few days before receipt by the government of the Samuels report into the Australian Security and Intelligence Service, did the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security resign? Why was the deputy director-general of ASIS transferred to the Department of Defence? Is this just an extraordinary coincidence, or is it yet again another attempt to pass the buck to public servants rather than accept the responsibility of government?

—As to the movement of the senior officer to Defence, or the reported movement, in keeping with the practice of successive Australian governments I cannot confirm or deny questions relating to security matters, which include matters relating to personnel of this kind. It should be noted, however, if I can make a general comment, that the movement of senior officers within the intelligence community for career development purposes is not unusual.

PARA.TAB: I am certainly not going to speculate on any possible recommendations of the ASIS judicial inquiry. I have no idea what those recommendations will be. I cannot believe that there has been any leakage from the commission such as would give any foundation to the kinds of rumours that Senator Hill seems to be basing his question on, one or two of which have surfaced in columns of people like Mr Toohey. I do not know what the ASIS inquiry is going to say. We will need to find out when it brings down its report, which is due quite soon—the end of this month or early April.

Similarly with the retirement of Mr Holdich from the position of Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security, that is a decision that Mr Holdich made some months ago. So far as I am aware, it is utterly unconnected with the course of events so far as this inquiry is concerned. It is a personal decision made by Mr Holdich for reasons of his own. I think he has done a good job in his position as IGIS, and I am sure his successor will do an equally good job.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the minister: will he release as much as is possible of the Samuels report to the public, in particular that part which deals with the treatment of former staff of ASIS, which treatment was the responsibility of the minister?

—We expect there to be a publicly releaseable version of the Samuels commission report. I am sure the Samuels commission is very conscious of the need, so far as it possibly can, to alleviate such remaining public concerns as there are on this matter. I certainly have no intention to do other than put some of the stuff into the public domain. The government will be reporting to parliament in due course on the outcome of its deliberations. Whether we will do so before or after the public release is a matter for determination by us when we see the report.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Minister, you would be aware that statements were made in this place yesterday that the federal government is ignoring the plight of farmers in drought stricken areas in the Hunter. Just how accurate are these comments?
—Before we get too heavily into interjections, we should catch up with what the New South Wales Farmers Association representatives said this morning—
—Boring.

—It is not boring for farmers in New South Wales, Senator, let me assure you. I was not in the chamber when Senator Tierney was carrying on with more of this nonsense yesterday. It is totally untrue. It has in fact been the former Fahey government's position that has ignored the plight of its own farmers in the Upper Hunter.
—People have no money.

—It takes some basic understanding of the process for exceptional circumstances applications by the federal government to understand why. Senator Tierney either fails to realise or chooses to completely ignore the process that in fact does—
—I have been talking to the people up there. Why don't you?

—Mad Dog Tierney—he does not understand it, or chooses to ignore it. There is a clear agreement between the Commonwealth and all states and territories that requests for exceptional circumstances are initiated by state governments. The criteria were in fact endorsed again at the last ARMCANZ meeting that was held just a short time ago in Canberra. The requests are then referred to an independent advisory committee, RASAC, for consideration against criteria that have been agreed by all states.

PARA.TAB: It has been open to Senator Tierney's mates, the former government of New South Wales, to make an application to me on this. For the record, Senator Tierney, I have not received an application for drought assistance from New South Wales since December last year. It has been open to Senator Tierney's mates, the former discredited government of New South Wales, to do it. With all the crocodile tears in here from the now opposition's representative, Senator Tierney, there has been not a single application.

TALK.START.PARA: —You go up there. If you are game, go up there.

—Understand the process, Senator Tierney. I have to act on an application from the government in New South Wales. That is how it works. It is little wonder that a New South Wales Farmers Association representative said on radio today that the farmers of New South Wales hoped the new state government of New South Wales would take a different approach to drought relief for farmers than the former discredited Fahey government—your mates, Senator Tierney—which had not made an application to me since December last year. It is now April.

PARA.TAB: I would welcome a fresh submission from the new government of New South Wales seeking a re-examination of drought assistance for farmers in New South Wales, just as I have initiated a review of the Victorian drought situation having received the necessary application from Bill McGrath, the Victorian minister. I will do exactly the same with New South Wales.

A question New South Wales farmers are all asking, clearly from the radio today, is: despite all the crocodile tears that Senator Tierney has been carrying on with in here on behalf of his mates in New South Wales, why has the New South Wales government—and it well understands the process—made no application to me, as is required under the process, for drought assistance for those farmers for four months?

The New South Wales Farmers Association representative said this morning that he hoped the new Labor government in New South Wales would have a different approach to the problems of farmers. I say again that, should that prove to be the case, I welcome a fresh application for drought assistance from New South Wales.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, on a point of order: I draw your attention to the volume which we continually get from that minister to the extent that it is an occupational health and safety matter. I ask whether you would be prepared to ask the sound and vision people to turn Senator Collins's microphone down permanently.

—Mr President, on the point of order: I would normally be happy to support Senator Newman, and I have asked Bob to turn it down on a couple of occasions, but we had Senator Tierney screaming at the top of his idiotic lungs in this chamber. Naturally, Senator Collins went straight over the top of him. So if Senator Newman can prevail on her colleague, we can let the level slide a bit.
—I cannot say any more than Senator Ray said. That was the problem. The general sound goes up as people interject and you ought to be aware of that.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts. Has the minister had the opportunity to examine the Telecom-News deal to build the Foxtel cable pay TV network? What safeguards, if any, are in place to prevent Telecom profits, which rightfully belong to the Australian taxpayer, from being diverted to the shareholders of News Ltd.? What process did the Telecom board follow in approving the deal and were board members unanimous in their support?
—I regret that I have no information on that question in the brief. I will refer Senator Bourne's question—
—Speak up; we can't hear you!

—I beg your pardon? What do you want me to do—speak up? That just goes to show that you can't please anybody in this business. In fact, on that basis, I might stop trying to please anybody and just please myself. I will seek an answer immediately for Senator Bourne. If I can get one before the end of question time, I will provide it immediately after question time.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer him to the Prime Minister's remarkable assertion yesterday that `the real problem remaining for Australia is the current account deficit'. Is Mr Keating so uncaring, so complacent and so out of touch that he has forgotten or wants to ignore the 800,000 Australians still out of work because of the recession we should never have had; the growing gap between the rich and poor and the development of a permanent underclass in this country; the breakdown of family life; the crisis in Aboriginal health; the $162 billion foreign debt; and the record high grindstone of interest rates that home owners and businesses are struggling to meet? Can the minister explain to all Australians concerned about the hardship and insecurity in their lives how the Prime Minister can make such a cruelly insensitive remark?
