—The view stated by the Prime Minister last night is a view widely shared by the kind of economic commentators that those opposite have been quoting with nauseous repetition over the last few weeks every time they have wanted to make a point about the current account deficit. They have not been able to say anything more about employment, because the government's record has been so dramatically good. There have been 570,000 new jobs created since February-March 1993. That is a dramatic reduction in the percentage. At the same time, participation rates are very much higher than they have historically been. At the moment, unemployment, with the participation rates prevailing in the early 1980s, would be less than five per cent. That is a very important factor to appreciate.

PARA.TAB: It is similarly the case with interest rates. They remain relatively low by comparison with historical levels. The official cash rate and the three-month bill rates are substantially lower now than their average levels over the past 20 years.

TALK.START.PARA: —How does it compare with other countries?

—It is not bad at all by comparison with most other countries. Australia has always been a bit above the others because of the capital shortage problem and our notoriously low savings ratio. That is part of the problem that feeds into the current account deficit problem and, as a result, is one of the problems that we are trying to address through the budgetary process—the fiscal process—to try to increase the level of savings in this country and reduce the call on overseas capital as a result.

PARA.TAB: It is very difficult in any modern economy to get every single one of these features of the economy working in absolute harmony. But when as many of them are working in harmony as the ones we have at the moment in terms of growth, low inflation, relatively low historic interest rates, very high levels of investment, continued high competitiveness and high productivity, a continued increase in exports and a capacity to sell those exports overseas, particularly to the markets in our environment, we have an economy that is as strong in all its basic fundamentals as it has ever been. It is one that we are absolutely determined to keep on that path.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Given that according to the Prime Minister the current account deficit has been the real problem since his days as Treasurer, when he made his infamous banana republic statement in 1986—that is, for over nine years—and has persisted despite record interest rates in 1989 and Mr Keating's deliberately induced recession to ameliorate the then equivalently large current account deficit, why have 12 years of the government's economic policies completely failed to overcome the recurring odium of this so-called real problem?

—Earlier on, I described the particular conjunction of circumstances that have contributed to this state of affairs so far as the character of the current account deficit is concerned. As a percentage of GDP, it is not historically high, although it is certainly higher than we find comfortable and we certainly want to do something about it.

PARA.TAB: I keep repeating the basic points: the fundamentals of this economy, particularly in terms of the inflation rate, which is the greatest single killer historically of the position and the capacity of ordinary working Australian men and women. We have not heard you rabbiting on about inflation for a long time, because you know the inflation problem has been licked. You were rabbiting on about growth, and we have the kind of growth that you can only dream about. It is sustainable growth that we have at the moment. You are rabbiting on about investment. A year ago, we could not possibly reach the 14, 15 or 16 per cent that we were predicting in the budget. We are now sitting on 24 per cent-plus investment, and it is moving ahead at a dramatic rate. We are sitting on an employment rate which is dramatically higher than it was. Again, it was against all your doomsaying predictions, with 570,000 jobs being created at a rate of 720 a day since we were re-elected. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I ask: has he seen the press release of the opposition spokesman for tourism of last night in which he maintained that, on his visit to Berlin, the Prime Minister neglected an important opportunity to help promote Australian tourism by failing to visit the international tourism fair where 117 Australian companies were represented? I ask you, Senator Evans, to lay to rest completely the falsehood contained in Senator Parer's statements relating to the Prime Minister's visit and his commitments in Berlin.

—The claims made yesterday by Senator Parer in question time were utterly and completely without foundation. The claims that he made in his press release last night, after I had put a detailed account and answer on the public record, were again utterly, completely and disgracefully without foundation. It is simply part of an ongoing opposition campaign designed to smear the Prime Minister and to mischaracterise the role that he played in Germany.

PARA.TAB: Let me make absolutely clear what happened. The Prime Minister began his program in Germany, in Bonn, on 7 March when he went straight into a series of high level meetings—the ones that I listed yesterday. He went after that to Hanover, where he met the Premier of Lower Saxony, and was there at the opening of the CeBIT information and technology fair. On the following morning, 8 March, he opened the Australian exhibition at CeBIT. He did all that was necessary and desirable in association with CeBIT and then flew to Berlin, arriving at 2.45 p.m..

Because of those commitments I have described, the Prime Minister could not have got there at any earlier time. That arrival did not enable him to advise the ITB for reasons I will now once again put on the record. Before his visit to Germany, his office made inquiries about him attending the International Tourism Bourse on 8 March. That is one of the reasons why he was scheduled to get in there at that time. The other appointments were concluded to enable him to get there, despite the very busy program he had.

The advice that was received from the Department of Tourism, the Tourist Commission and the Australian Consulate-General in Berlin was that he should not do so. They have confirmed that advice, completely repudiating Senator Parer's claims. The reason was as follows: the fair concluded at 6 o'clock on that day of 8 March—not, as you have claimed in your press release, the following day. It concluded at 6 o'clock on the day that he arrived at the airport at 2.45 p.m. Stands were being dismantled throughout the afternoon. The Australian Tourist Commission advised then, as again confirmed, that by 4 o'clock, which is the earliest possible time he could have got there, there were very few trade buyers still present at the show. Probably 50 per cent of exhibitors—

TALK.START.PARA: —Fifteen minutes away!

—Listen to this. Probably 50 per cent of exhibitors had commenced breaking down their displays. Ten per cent of the Australian sellers had already completely departed. ITB organisers actively discouraged all high level visits from any country on that afternoon because there was no show left to visit. In other words, your claims were completely false, completely misleading and part of an ongoing, disgraceful campaign of misrepresentation, and you ought to apologise for that.

—I listened carefully to the minister's response. In the light of the difficulty he has in getting the message through to Senator Parer, would he examine what he has just put on the record and perhaps consider translating it into cartoon form, forwarding it to Senator Parer in the hope that he will stop making a fool of himself in the future.
—Order! There is no supplementary question, but if you want to comment you can, Senator Evans.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. The minister will be aware of recent amendments to the Higher Education Funding Act and the States Grants Act whereby the federal government will take funds from state education funds to in turn fund student unions and associations—which, in some cases, now have voluntary membership. Is it true that student delegates and presidents from some of those associations and unions met with the minister and the Department of Employment, Education and Training to discuss funding? Furthermore, is it true that $4.5 million is to be removed from funds which would otherwise be provided for schools and universities in order to fund these student unions and associations? If the figure of $4.5 million is not correct, what is the amount?
—The coalition has had an ideological obsession against student unionism in Australia for decades.
—No, compulsory student unionism.
—The word `compulsory'.

—It has particularly attacked student unionism for an ideological reason on and off for decades. I think this is just another part of that campaign. You do not have any comprehension of the advantages of having students at universities participating in their student unions and negotiating with the management of the universities. You have never accepted any of that. You have never accepted the fact that overwhelmingly the students themselves support the government's policy on student unionism.
—You are wrong.
—Apart from a few ratbag Liberal student leaders like Senator Abetz when he was at university.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. That is a reflection on my colleague Senator Abetz and Senator Schacht should withdraw his comment.
—Senator Schacht, you should withdraw the comment.
—I withdraw `ratbag'—
—Unreservedly.

—I withdraw unreservedly, in deference to other ratbags being put in the same camp as Senator Abetz. I do not have details of the financial figures that Senator Ellison has now raised. I do not have the details in my brief. I do not have details of every meeting that Mr Crean may or may not have had. I will get the details for you. If I can get them before the end of question time, I will provide them. Irrespective of those details, this government will not back away from its support for student unionism in Australia.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction. I understand that today the minister released a report titled Linking Australia Globally, the report of the Committee of Inquiry into Australia's Standards and Conformance Infrastructure. Can the minister advise the Senate on the content of the report, his intentions with respect to the report and the significance of the report for Australian industry?

—This report will be released and tabled in parliament today. It is a major report on micro-economic reform that will assist Australian industry. I know that many people in the community may find the title `standards and conformance infrastructure' decidedly unexciting, and I don't blame them. However, when you talk to industry, you see that this is a very important issue. In the Working Nation statement of last year, we announced that we would have a major review as a result of industry concerns.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I ask whether this report is now on the Notice Paper, and therefore whether the minister is in order by referring to the document.
—Normally, a fairly wide discretion is accepted in this area. If you want to pick up on things like that, there are going to be an awful lot of questions ruled out of order.

—Industry requested that this review be conducted, and it was announced in the Working Nation statement that it would be. The review was chaired by Mr Bruce Kean, former chairman of Boral Australia and a respected industrialist in this country. The report makes significant recommendations on how to make the standards setting arrangements in this country advantage Australian industry, not only domestically but also for our export effort. The importance of the report is simple: in order to maximise opportunities for international trade, Australia's standards and conformance infrastructure must be operating at world best practice levels and must be seen to be in order.

PARA.TAB: The committee's recommendations are aimed at improving Australian standards setting processes and maintaining the excellence of Australia's measurement and testing facilities. It also clarifies the role of a number of bodies responsible in this area. The major recommendations include, most importantly, giving Australia a national weights and measures system instead of the current state based systems. This is a very important change. Industry will have to deal not with six different standards across Australia but with one national standard.

I will give an example of where we have a problem at the moment. We have waited five years for all the states to carry complementary legislation to the uniform trade measurement legislation. After five years three states still have not carried the complementary legislation. As a result, in some areas of industry our standards arrangements are not operating effectively. For example, there are 400 different water meter authorities in Australia. This means that in some areas people are looking to local government bodies to privatise water delivery, where you have to have a very accurate water meter. There is now no national standard set for water meters. This is a major issue for industry in Australia.

The committee has recommended that there be a full management review of Standards Australia undertaken to recommend management arrangements which would improve the performance of the organisation. It recommended that there be confirmation of the National Association of Testing Authorities, NATA, as the sole provider of laboratory accreditation services recognised by government. The committee recommended that Standards Australia and NATA divest controlling interest in their commercial certification activities, including quality assurance, to allow them to concentrate on their core activities of standards writing and laboratory accreditation respectively. It recommended that the charter of the Joint Accreditation System of Australia and New Zealand, JASANZ, be amended to remove accreditation of laboratory accreditation bodies from its activities.

The committee recommended that governments should adopt a more consistent, restrained and informed approach to requiring quality assurance in government purchasing. The committee also recommended that the Commonwealth government should establish a new system of conformance marks for the voluntary sector and that consideration be given to the introduction of a single mark for use on regulated products.

This is a very important report. There will be a lot of interest in it in industry across Australia. As a result, we are allowing industry and the community to respond over the next two months, until the end of May, because when we proceed with the policy on this issue we want it to be correct. (Time expired)

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Post-Mortem on Suspected Toxic Shock Victim

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Family Services. The minister might like to cease her tutorial and listen to the question. Minister, in your statement to the Senate yesterday you stated that a document containing confidential details of a post-mortem on a 13-year-old girl released without the consent of her parents was provided to `several specialist journalists who asked for it'. On Tuesday you advised `that the document had been given to anybody with a special interest, particularly those of the medical profession or journalists'. Can you give an assurance that none of the doctors or other persons who received the document passed that information on to Johnson and Johnson, which is an interested party in the forthcoming coronial inquiry? Do you acknowledge that those journalists included a features writer from the Adelaide Advertiser and a journalist at the ABC's 7.30 Report in Adelaide, neither of whom is a specialist in a particular field? Will you provide a full list of those who received the full report and will you acknowledge that they were not specialist journalists but merely people who had a special interest by virtue of being a journalist? (Time expired)

—In the statement I made to the Senate after question time yesterday concerning the release of the nine-page report I received from the TGA, I stated that I had made a copy of the full report available to several specialist journalists who asked for it. In my answer to Senator O'Chee on 28 March I said that I made this report available to the few people who sought it. I think it is quite clear we are not avoiding the issue that it was made available. As a result of that statement, further questions were asked in this place concerning the identity of the journalists to whom this report was made available.

PARA.TAB: My office has checked the records of that distribution. They show that the nine-page report was supplied to Trina Fely of the pharmacy trade; Sue Daniel, an ABC radio health reporter; Jan McLean, from Choice; Sheryl-Lee Kerr of the Adelaide Advertiser, who wrote a major feature about toxic shock and the public health concerns of this issue; Craig Skehan, from the Sydney Morning Herald under his responsibility to allocate stories to appropriate journalists—a piece was written by a woman writer; Angela Pippos of the 7.30 Report—the 7.30 Report broke this story in the first place and has had a continuing interest in the public health concern; and a reporter from Triple J ABC radio, which has regularly run stories concerning matters of health and safety, particularly to its very young audience. The recollection of my staff is that there was one other request from the press gallery—it was provided to a journalist, but my staff cannot remember or recall the name of that person.

As senators will note, the majority of these were health organisations, consumer magazines or media outlets that have consistently displayed a strong interest in women's health issues. I am not aware that any of these media outlets have used the precis of the post-mortem information contained in the TGA report. A number of copies were also made available to other interested persons, including Standards Australia, the Toxic Shock Information Service and the office of the shadow Minister for Social Security. After this matter was raised in the Senate, a copy was also provided to the Australian Democrats.

Yesterday I apologised to the family for causing them any further grief or anguish. There is nothing I can add to ease the family's distress. For that reason, I do not propose to say much more. I did not get down all the points that Senator Vanstone raised. I believe that she asked whether I can give an assurance that this information was not provided by those people or anyone else to Johnson and Johnson. I cannot give her that assurance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, are you actually asking this chamber and the family of this girl to believe that a proper description of a specialist journalist is anyone who has an interest in toxic shock?
—Of course.

—No, an interest in doing a report on it. Do you honestly say that a feature writer from the Adelaide Advertiser and a journalist from the 7.30 Report have an interest in that particular detail? Is that what you are honestly asking us to accept?
—What I said and what I conveyed on 28 March—and I have never resiled from this fact—is that we provided a full report to people who contacted my office. Many of those people—
—They are not specialist journalists.
—Those people were writing specialist articles about the information in that report. All of the evidence that I have been able to give you—
—You didn't say that.
—It is certainly not my intention to mislead, but to provide as much—
—You have been misleading again and you have resiled. You have ducked and weaved at every possible chance.

—No, Senator. I have tried as much as possible to provide you with the information you have sought. I have said before that the information being canvassed here will only add to that family's distress. It is not my intention to further add to the family's distress.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Justice. I refer to a recent report in the Age newspaper that the government is finally preparing a response to the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee's report on the Financial Transaction Reports Act 1988 Checking the cash. Is the minister aware that the Victorian police have begun to investigate 25 solicitors and one law firm on allegations of trust account fraud involving more than $54 million? Will the minister now accept the Democrats' proposal, as set out in my dissent to the report, that solicitors should be included in the list of financial institutions and intermediaries obliged to report to the Cash Transaction Agency on transactions above a certain sum? Is the minister considering any other measures that will increase the public accountability of the legal profession or improve the way in which lawyers deal with other people's money?

—I have seen newspaper reports in relation to the police investigation in Victoria of 25 solicitors and one law firm. It is a Victorian police matter. Speaking personally and also on the advice of the Minister for Justice, who I think is in the same position, I know no more about the investigation than I have read.

PARA.TAB: In relation to the rest of the question, the government is currently finalising its response to the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee report on the Financial Transaction Reports Act 1988, Checking the cash. As the government response has yet to go to cabinet, I am not in a position to detail our proposals. I can assure Senator Spindler, however, that the government has carefully considered the matters raised in his dissenting report, including his concerns about the accountability of the legal profession, and I hope he is satisfied accordingly with the response when it comes.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Did the Bureau of Resource Sciences, in its pest risk analysis relating to the proposed grain imports, find that the likely spillage of grain in the transport and handling process posed a significant weed risk? Did the BRS also find there was a good chance that this spillage would result in the establishment of at least some of the fungal diseases and viruses of quarantine concern to Australia and likely to be present even in grain imported from relatively clean parts of the US and Canada? Did the report further state that in most cases information about the pests in question was not available and, as a result, did the BRS urge caution in the interpretation of its pest risk analysis? Given the dearth of information and the clearly identified risks, will you rule out the up-country movement of imported grain, at least for use in intensive animal industries, unless it has first been heat treated?
—Mr President—by the way, where is `Senator Own Goal' today? Where is `Senator Escobar'?
—Who's that?
—Senator Baume.
—He's putting the ice pack on.

—He's got the ice pack on today, has he? I said yesterday that, as Senator Sandy Macdonald knows, there is no such thing as no risk. That is not the basis of any quarantine regime. It is a question of trying to determine what is acceptable risk and then adopting procedures to deal with that risk.

PARA.TAB: As I said to the Senate yesterday, and I cannot really add much more to what I have already told the Senate on this, we are in the unfortunate position of having got our hopes up, with significant falls of rain earlier this year, that there would be an easing off of the pressure to import grain to sustain—and I am sure Senator Macdonald would not disagree with this—what are vitally important primary industries in this country that have largely developed to the extent that they have over the past 10 years; that is, the intensive poultry industry, the pork industry and lot feeding.

I will give just one simple benchmark of how the face of Australian primary industry has changed dramatically. In the early 1980s there were around 100,000 cattle in Australia in feedlots; in a normal year there are now closer to 800,000 cattle in feedlots in Australia. What that means for policy makers and, I might add, the decision makers in the major peak industry groups in Australia—and they have acknowledged this—is that the effect of a drought and a decline in domestic grain supplies in Australia is now far more severe, irrespective of the nature of the weather, than it would ever have been before. I have made the point before, as Senator Macdonald knows, that that is why comparisons to earlier droughts in Australia are, to a large extent, meaningless because the structure of the industry has changed so dramatically.

Unfortunately, because of the deterioration currently in the weather situation, and I hope it changes on an hourly basis, Queensland farmers in many areas are now slipping back into the drought. A significant amount of summer sorghum crop has been lost already. As I said publicly on Channel 9 last weekend, if it does not rain within the next week to 10 days we can add significant further amounts of summer sorghum crops from Queensland on that list.

A number of areas have now formally slipped back into drought, as Senator Brownhill would know, in New South Wales and the current New South Wales minister has made a statement about that today. The situation is also continuing to deteriorate in places such as Victoria, which is why I have asked the Rural Adjustment Scheme Advisory Committee to expedite its review of the Victorian situation, and RASAC will be in Victoria doing that this weekend.

It is a question of managing the risk, Senator. I cannot rule in or out the measures that you have mentioned explicitly. I simply conclude by saying we have not done a thing in respect of this matter that has not been done without the closest consultation with all of the peak industry groups involved. I met a major delegation only yesterday from a lot feeders association in Australia to address the real concerns that its vital industry has with grain supplies. The matter will be handled carefully, I can assure you, Senator Macdonald, and no unacceptable risk will be engaged in in the importation, unfortunately, of further quantities of grain into Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology. The minister would be aware of certain negative perceptions that existed in the Australian community regarding the future of the textile, clothing and footwear industries. Given the restructuring that has occurred within the textile, clothing and footwear industries in recent years, are they now capable of competing internationally?

—Today we had a touch of style, glamour and class in parliament. Unfortunately, it did not occur in either the House of Representatives or the Senate, but rather in the Great Hall when the Council of Textile and Fashion Industries of Australia combined with the Textile, Clothing and Footwear Union of Australia to put on a fashion parade showcasing the talent of Australian fashion designers and manufacturers in the clothing, textiles and footwear area. Both Tim Todhunter, the committee chairman, for the authority and Anna Booth, the union secretary, deserve the commendation of the Senate because of the fine work they have done in promoting the Australian textile, clothing and footwear industry. It highlighted the new forward looking culture that is now permeating the TCF industry—a culture assisted by the government's transitional arrangements under the TCF plan begun in the 1980s.

PARA.TAB: It is true that old perceptions die hard and many commentators in the past, and perhaps some of the general public, have held the perception—a negative one, as Senator Chris Evans has referred to—that the industry is not an industry that is competitive. But I have to say that huge progress has been made. The people in the industry deserve the acknowledgment of the Australian community about that. The exports of Australian textile, clothing and footwear products are now valued at $600 million per annum. The industry has set itself what I think is a realisable target—others may regard it as ambitious—of $2 billion worth of exports from this industry per annum by the end of the century.

The government believes it does have a role in further advancing the interests of the TCF industry and, as a consequence, we commissioned the future strategies review, which worked together with the industry to assess what policy initiatives are required to achieve the targets that the industry has set itself. The review is currently being considered by the government but, as anyone who was at the exhibition this morning would testify and be an eyewitness to, there is a high degree of skill, flair, quality and competence in this industry. Indeed, it is a vibrant and exciting industry and, importantly, it is a growing industry.

Certainly barrier resistance measures are not the industry's prime concern any longer. The industry is now concentrating on world markets—focusing on international best practice and on such issues as training, benchmarking and, importantly, innovation. Australia's industry has undergone massive restructuring to date to meet the challenges and it is now the second fastest growing manufacturing exporter in Australia—quite an achievement, I think. Australian industries are now establishing themselves as major suppliers of textiles and other intermediate goods to the rapidly growing clothing market of Asia, and they have also established themselves as suppliers of high quality finished apparel to the consumer markets of America and Europe. Whereas people in the past were quick to write off the industry, I think it has shown a remarkable recovery.

I pay particular tribute to some of the names who exhibited their products today: Rip Curl, Balarinji, Coogi Morrissey and Edminston, Howe Leather, Textile Industries of Australia, Godfrey Hirst, Brintons, Pacific Brands, and so it goes. These are companies that are now world class, winning an excellent reputation for Australian quality and Australian price competitiveness overseas. It does demonstrate, given that this was jointly mounted by the union and the industry, that this industry is working together to secure a bigger market for Australia in the future.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Australian Labor Party: Preselection of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Status of Women. I refer to warnings on Tuesday by the federal Minister for the Status of Women, Carmen Lawrence, that the party would face an unholy scramble if it delayed preselecting women to fill winnable seats. I further refer to the statement by the ALP women's organiser president, Kerry Rea, that the ALP had no chance of implementing its policy for women. I ask: isn't it a fact that the ALP has totally misled the women of Australia as to its commitment to get more women into parliament?
—I am not sure whether that falls within your ministerial responsibility, but I will leave it to you as to whether you want to answer it.

—That is the first thing that needs to be said—it is not. The Labor Party, contrary to what Senator Troeth says, is absolutely up-front and clear to the women of Australia about what its policy is. It has a rule and a guarantee that after the year 2002 there will be 35 per cent of women at least preselected to winnable seats. So Senator Troeth may say what she likes, but the message is quite clear. As I understand it, polling shortly after that announcement showed that it was very well accepted by women of Australia. It is clear. I do not believe the conclusion that Senator Troeth draws is at all accurate.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to the Prime Minister's speech last night. Didn't the Prime Minister last night commit the government to imposing a superannuation tax of three per cent on workers? You have been denying all that. If that is the case, then how are the ordinary low income and middle income workers going to be protected? If one of the reasons for the imposition is that there will not be enough workers in the labour force paying tax to sustain a pension in later years, why discriminate against the working families who are nurturing those very taxpayers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not my understanding of what the Prime Minister said. We are in, as Senator Harradine knows, the immediate pre-budget period. In the immediate pre-budget period, as an observer of political life, people run gambits about what may or may not be in the budget. I will be an impartial observer for a minute and say that oppositions tend to try to rumourmonger and to scaremonger to attract superficial votes to their cause by frightening people about what budgets may contain. That is a comment on political life.

PARA.TAB: We are in a situation in which those features can be seen in the debate that has been growing around what the budget may or may not contain. Certainly what the government has said about the budget is that this will be a tough budget. We are going to apply ourselves to reducing the budget deficit and meet the targets of the Treasurer's fiscal consolidation program—that is, get the budget into surplus after two years.

In that context, there are from time to time remarks made about particular measures. At this stage, nothing is ruled in and nothing is ruled out. So the best thing, the most sensible thing and, indeed, the fairest thing is to wait for budget night and to take up the criticisms, if you have any, of what is actually in the budget rather than jump at rumour, or innuendo or political interpretations of what may have been thought by someone to have been contained in the budget.

Senator Gareth Evans—and I am pleased for this—has given me a copy of the Prime Minister's speech from last evening. On page 16 I think the relevant paragraph occurs. Perhaps I should take this opportunity to read into the record of the Senate what he actually said. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: Our policy commits us to increasing the overall level of Australian superannuation contributions to 9 per cent from employers and 3 per cent from employees by the year 2002/3.

So the Prime Minister has committed himself to this government's moving to enhance the superannuation entitlements of ordinary Australian workers. That is something that this government has stood up for during its period of office.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister last night said that we intend to see this program through; we intend to ensure that ordinary Australian workers are entitled to a decent level of superannuation cover; and because, left to the marketplace, that has not been able to be achieved, we will legislate for it. I might also say that this is in absolute contradistinction to the coalition's policy.

The coalition's policy, at the last election, was to remove the legislative requirement for a superannuation guarantee charge and require that the market determine it. We know that, when the market last determined it, those who were weakest in the market, those without bargaining power and those unable to secure gains from their employers, had no superannuation at all. So the coalition's proposal was to reduce the entitlement for the most vulnerable, most defenceless people in Australian society.

Senator Harradine and I are veterans of this debate not only inside this chamber but also outside of this chamber in our previous occupations as well. I say to Senator Harradine, with the greatest of respect, wait for budget night, but please recognise the landmark changes made to superannuation and the rights of ordinary Australian workers by this government in ensuring that legislation insists that they do have a superannuation entitlement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.
—During question time today Senator Bourne asked me a question relating to the Telecom news deal. The Minister for Communications and the Arts has provided me with the following response.

PARA.TAB: The Telstra-News Corporation cable television venture, Foxtel, announced on 9 March is welcome. It involves an accelerated improvement in communications infrastructure available to the Australian community. It indicates Telstra's preparedness to respond to the competition being provided by Optus, particularly the Optus vision proposal.

The minister is aware that negotiations for Telstra's involvement in this venture have been proceeding since last November. Undertakings of this nature are a matter for consideration and decision by the Telstra board. Consistent with the principles for GBE reporting established by this government, and Telstra's articles of association, Telstra has kept the government informed of its intentions. In terms of regulatory implications, the proposal must be consistent with the Telecommunications Act, particularly the draft ministerial direction on broadband services, the Broadcasting Services Act and the Trade Practices Act.

Arrangements for sharing of profits are governed by contract and partnership agreements which were negotiated by Telstra on a fully commercial basis, and the decision to commit to the joint venture proposal was properly a decision for the Telstra board. It is not appropriate for the minister to comment on the detail of the processes they may have followed and, like every other company, those matters are commercial-in-confidence.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have some further information for Senator Patterson, in response to her question without notice on 28 March 1995 regarding funding for HACC. The following information has been provided to me: Senator Patterson is not correct in her assertion that funding for the HACC program has been cut in real terms for three out of the last four budgets; in fact, that is opposite to the facts of the situation. The HACC program was introduced by this government in 1984-85, and each year has seen a real growth in the program. Since the inception of the program in 1984-85, the Commonwealth's contribution to the program has grown by 227 per cent in real terms. I can make no comment in respect of anything about the forthcoming budget.

—I have an answer following Senator Lees's question yesterday about the two per cent research allocation. The Prime Minister's election commitment was to work with researchers and the business sector to lift health and medical research funding to two per cent of total health expenditure by the year 2000. The latest data we have on research spending in the health and medical area is for 1990/91.

PARA.TAB: The data, taking into account the increases in funding research that this government has provided since that time, indicate that we are on track to meet the two per cent commitment. Funding has been provided directly by government to researchers through the NHMRC, with funding increases from $30 million in 1983 to $128 million in 1995. In addition, the government has provided substantial incentives for private sector investment in research through, for example, the Factor (f) pharmaceutical program as well as through taxation incentives. The government will continue its strong support for health and medical research and will be making decisions about further funding of the National Health and Medical Research Council in this year's budget.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek the leave of the Senate to incorporate in Hansard further information for Senator Lees about funding of hospitals in South Australia in response to her question to me of 27 March 1995.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—
Senator Lees asked the Minister representing the Minister for Human Services and Health, Senator Crowley, the following supplementary question without notice, on 27 March 1995:

Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for her answer. She has ignored several parts of the question. The figures given are quite misleading. A look at the total amount of money spent on health in South Australia, particularly on hospitals since 1983, and the percentage that the Commonwealth is contributing shows that it has declined. The states have made some very substantial cuts, particularly to the Flinders Medical Centre, where 20 per cent of its surgery has basically been cancelled for three years. When is the money due under the Medicare agreement? Forget about the reviews; we are talking about the money. When will the money be handed over to the states? When will the minister do something about the cost shifting? It is fine to say that she is running another review about it. But there is not just the cost shifting to the federal government; there is also the cost shifting to the consumers—the patients—and their families. Is the federal government going to act, or is it just going to keep blaming the States?
Senator Crowley—The Minister for Human Services and Health, Dr Lawrence, has provided the following answers to the Honourable Senator's questions:

ANSWER.PARA: Funding for South Australia

I have a chart which shows quite clearly that total Commonwealth health expenditure for South Australia has been increasing steadily since 1982-83. This growth applies to all major components of Commonwealth health expenditure—specific Purpose Payments (including Hospital Funding Grants), and Commonwealth own-purpose outlays on Medicare and Pharmaceutical Benefits.
Attachment 1—Commonwealth Health Outlays to South Australia
Since 1988-89, for instance, Commonwealth payments to SA have grown by 58%—from $880m to $1388m. (nominal terms)

On hospital funding, I have a very revealing graph which demonstrates quite clearly that while the Commonwealth has been consistently increasing its own funding, the State has in recent years been decreasing its contributions.
Over the period 1988-89 to 1994-95, the Hospital Funding Grant to South Australia has increased by 65% from $277m to $458m. (nominal terms)
When we look at the shares of total hospital funding, we find that over the period 1988-89 to 1993-94 the State share has gone from 53% to 45% while the Commonwealth share has gone from 47% to 55%.
Attachment 2—Commonwealth and State's Own Outlaws for Hospitals—South Australia 1988-89 to 1993-94
Review of Medicare Funding
A number of the figures that I have quoted above come out of the interim report by Commonwealth and State officials on the effects of the decline in private insurance coverage.
This review will do some additional work and report to Health Ministers in June.
No conclusions have yet been reached about the need to provide additional funding—and the Medicare Agreement does not oblige the Commonwealth to provide more funds if a strong case cannot be made.

Issues under consideration are the level of States' own contributions to hospital funding (which have generally been declining), cost shifting from the States to the Commonwealth (which automatically increases the Commonwealth contributions), and the extent of the demand shift from the private to the public sector.
Cost shifting
Senator Lees has asked when the Minister is going to do something about cost shifting.

As I pointed out in my response yesterday, Dr Lawrence has taken a number of steps to arrest cost shifting behaviour by the States. Her actions have taken account of the fact that costs are shifted, as Senator Lees has noted, not only to the Commonwealth but to the private insurance funds and to patients and their families.
I should also add that DHSH is investigating the need for changes to current legislation to address the cost shifting issue.

The Medicare Agreements have provision for penalties for States which engage in cost shifting—to any of the above parties. While it would be last resort, States have been warned that penalties may be applied.
Senator Lees also asked yesterday about the use of community based services to reduce the demand on the public hospital system. I can supply the following response:

The Government is aware of the potential to use non-inpatient care more effectively. It has therefore funded (and continues to fund) a range of programs over the years to encourage more effective discharge procedures, better links between hospitals and GPs, home-based palliative care, and post acute care (to name but a few).

There are also structural changes which can led to better outcomes in the use of community based care. The Commonwealth is investigating the use of funding mechanisms based on an "episode of care" which encompasses not only the in-hospital phase of care, but includes the preparation for admission and the recovery or post-discharge phases of care—much of which can be provided by community based carers.
This concept is also being explored by COAG and could potentially lead to changes in program boundaries between the Commonwealth and the States.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek the leave of the Senate to incorporate in Hansard further information for Senator Spindler on funding to hospitals in response to his question to me of 28 March 1995.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—
Senator Spindler asked the Minister representing the Minister for Human Services and Health, Senator Crowley, the following supplementary question without notice, on 28 March 1995:

Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for her answer, but I am no apologist for the Victorian government and I certainly know of the cuts undertaken in this area by the Victorian government. My question was, in part: what will the Minister for Health and the Commonwealth government do to stop state governments using increased Commonwealth funding, if and when they receive it, in this manner and off-loading the load on to the Commonwealth? The issue still remains that Victoria is entitled to an increased Commonwealth contribution and the minister might indicate, having said that there is a review partly in progress, when that increased funding could be identified and paid. But, more particularly, what will the minister do to ensure that this additional funding is not used by the states to shirk their responsibilities?
Senator Crowley—The Minister for Human Services and Health, Dr Lawrence, has provided the following further information in answer to the Honourable Senator's supplementary question:
There is unfortunately, little that we can do to prevent States reducing their own budgets in response to injections of Commonwealth funds.
However, such behaviour is certainly something that we are examining in the context of the present review of Medicare funding.
It would appear that the response of the States to increases in Commonwealth funding under the new Medicare Agreements has been to reduce their own funding.
To the extent that this has happened, it weakens the States' case that they should now get more money from the Commonwealth because private insurance coverage has decreased.
In relation to the timing of decisions on this matter, the review of funding will be considered by the Australian Health Ministers Council in June.
No additional payments have been made to Victoria or to any other State. The review is still in progress and no conclusions have yet been reached about the need to supplement States.

There is certainly no agreement about how much might be payable to any particular State and it is quite premature to claim, as Senator Spindler has done, that "Victoria is entitled to an increased Commonwealth contribution".

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek the leave of the Senate to incorporate in Hansard further information for Senator Lees regarding the drug and alcohol program in response to her question to me on 28 March 1995.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—
Senator Lees asked the Minister representing the Minister for Human Services and Health, Senator Crowley, the following questions without notice, on 28 March 1995:

I draw the minister's attention to the recent survey by the Alcohol and Other Drugs Council of Australia. Minister, do you agree with the survey's findings that the Commonwealth collected $3.8 billion in taxes on alcohol and tobacco in 1993-94 but spent only $36.4 million on specific drug and alcohol programs and services? If so, what is the explanation for that gap, considering that drug and alcohol abuse costs the Australian community at least $20 million a year? Finally, while the states and territories spend somewhere between 2.9 per cent and 24 per cent of what they collect for such programs and services on those services and the Commonwealth only manages one per cent, is it not about time for a considerable increase in the Commonwealth's financial commitment to education, intervention, treatment, research and other drug and alcohol related programs?

Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister, but that surely leaves open this question: does she believe the Commonwealth has any responsibility to put at least some money back? I am certainly not talking about all of it; we are looking at a realistic level in the states of putting four or five per cent back into drug and alcohol related programs. If the Commonwealth is not going to do that, those people will frequently end up in our hospital system, which is the most expensive end of our health service, as a whole range of services will be missing. I ask the minister: does the Commonwealth not have some responsibility? Is not the very small amount of money put back—it is about $2 per head; compare that with the Northern Territory, which is putting back $55 per head of what it raises in drug and alcohol taxes—only a fraction of what is needed.
Senator Crowley—The Minister for Human Services and Health, Dr Lawrence, has provided the following additional information in answer to the honourable Senator's questions:

I have no reason to dispute the collection of $3.8 billion from an excise on alcohol and tobacco quoted in the report by the Alcohol and Other Drugs Council of Australia (ADCA), nor do I doubt the levels of revenue from taxes and revenue per head figures at the State and Territory level provided in the report. I do, however, have concerns at the validity of making comparisons between the expenditures of the different governments.

The Northern Territory is shown for example as returning 24.3% of its alcohol and tobacco revenue to drug programs and services. However it should be noted the Northern Territory is the only State or Territory which has introduced a policy of hypothecating alcohol tax revenue to address the unique problems of alcohol use in that Territory. The other States and Territories all spend around 3-5% compared to the Commonwealth which is shown in the ADCA report as only expending 1%.

There is a valid reason for this apparent anomaly. The States are responsible for the direct provision of drug treatment and rehabilitation programs whereas the Commonwealth is not involved in direct service provision in this area. It should be pointed out that the figure of $36.4 million relates specifically to the additional funds provided by the Commonwealth to the National Drug Strategy. It does not include health services, income support and law enforcement activities. Based on a 1988 survey, the estimated aggregate outlays related to drug issues in current dollars is $1.594 billion of which the Commonwealth contributes $716 million. The figures in the ADCA report are therefore not necessarily a true reflection of the total level of commitment either by the Commonwealth or the States in this area.

As to whether or not the Commonwealth should be returning a greater percentage of the revenue raised by taxes on alcohol and tobacco to specific programs addressing the harms caused by the misuse of all drugs both licit and illicit, the Government believes that the appropriate approach is generally for tax revenue to go to consolidated revenue for the spending from that revenue to be determined on the basis of relative priorities, rather than a formula linked to specific tax collections.

The Commonwealth Government is concerned with the level of drug and alcohol use in Australia. The National Drug Strategy is a co-operative effort between all governments (including health and law enforcement jurisdictions) and the non-government sector with the common aim to minimise the harmful effects of drugs.

TALK.START.PARA: —During question time Senator Ellison asked me a question about student unionism in Australia. I gave a commitment to try to get more information before the end of question time. I have just been provided with information from Mr Crean's office. No, the Minister for Employment, Education and Training has not met with the students this year to discuss student unionism. The Department of Employment, Education and Training has met three times: mid-June 1994 with representatives from NUS and administrators from La Trobe, RMIT and Monash; on 1 February 1995 with the NUS national president, the Victorian president of NUS and business managers from WA guilds; and on 24 February with NUS WA and also WA guild presidents to consult on the guidelines for the student organisation support program. These guidelines were released on 14 March.

PARA.TAB: The student organisation program will provide assistance to student organisations to avoid the erosion of services and activities available to students below the level offered in 1994. The amount of funds required will be calculated on receipt of the detailed applications. Successful applicants will be required to provide to the minister a statement by a qualified auditor declaring the amount to be paid. Any funds determined to be payable by the minister to the institution and directed to the student organisation will be recovered from the states' general revenue assistance under section 15 of the States Grants (General Purposes) Act 1994, and in any subsequent states grants general purposes legislation.

—The minister is out of order as well. If he wants to interject, I suggest he sit down. I accept what he said, and I thank him for that. But it still has taken a hell of a long time to get what was a very simple answer.
