TALK.START.PARA: —Under the order of the Senate relating to questions on notice agreed to on 28 September 1988, I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Senator Faulkner, for an explanation as to why I have not received an answer to question No. 1984, which I put on notice on 10 February 1995 to the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs in relation to the supply of personal computers to the Daw Park Repatriation General Hospital in South Australia.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to this important question that has been raised by Senator Chapman in relation to Daw Park Repatriation General Hospital has been provided. I personally handed the answer to the clerk not very long ago. It is in the system. I will, however, as Senator Chapman has raised this issue in this manner, undertake to provide him with a further answer. I will not bother going to the Table Office to dig out the answer that is in the system. I will ask Mr Sciacca to provide Senator Chapman with a copy of that and do so in relatively short order.

PARA.TAB: I make the point that, if Senator Chapman had had the courtesy to raise this with me before, I could have had a copy of that answer well and truly in his hands by now. So he is doing nothing more than trying to make a political point. I indicate to Senator Chapman that that answer in fact is with the Table Office. But, regardless, I will provide a further copy to him, so it will be in his hands soon.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister for that response. I simply make the point in response to the minister's comments that his office was advised prior to question time that I would be raising this matter, so his comments there are absolutely false. More importantly, this question was asked on 10 February and therefore, under the standing orders, should have been answered by 10 or 12 March. It is now 30 March and the minister has only now provided an answer as a result of me taking this issue up with his office today.

—I have a question for Senator Schacht for which notice was given prior to question time today. Under the order of the Senate relating to questions on notice, agreed to on 29 September 1988, I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, Senator Schacht, for an explanation of why I have not received an answer to question No. 1964, which I put on notice on 6 February 1995 to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, in relation to the department's management information system in respect of various programs maintained in members' electorates.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will ensure that those remarks are brought to Senator Schacht's attention. We will do our best to give you an answer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the explanation.

SPEECH.PARA: I again point out the disgrace and the insult it is to the Senate that this matter, which was raised with the appropriate minister prior to question time today and which we were seeking a proper explanation in relation to, asked on 6 February, has not been addressed. It is important as it affects the information relating to the Department of Employment, Education and Training that is available to all 147 electorate offices in Australia. This question has a vital bearing on this year's budget. It is a disgrace that this information has not been provided. It ought to be publicly available. I am very concerned that in this matter the Senate has not been given the appropriate and due courtesy.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to Senator Crowley. I did advise her of this by 1.30 p.m. Under the order of the Senate relating to questions on notice, agreed to on 28 September 1988, I ask the Minister for Family Services, Senator Crowley, for an explanation of why I have not received an answer to question No. 2006, which I put on notice on 28 February 1995, in relation to child care centre mailing lists.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the answer will be provided this afternoon. I do apologise for the delay. I hope to be able to get that to you before the evening meal.

—I rise on a similar matter. Under the order of the Senate relating to questions on notice, agreed to on 28 September 1988, I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services for an explanation of why I have not received an answer to question No. 1997 and question No. 1998, which I put on notice on 21 February 1995, to the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services. The questions were in relation to the National Media Liaison Service.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just made a telephone inquiry about the status of that answer. Hopefully I will be in a position shortly to give Senator Kemp a response. In the meantime, he might like to take note of it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen C.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the explanation.

SPEECH.PARA: This issue was raised this morning with Senator McMullan's office. It was flagged fairly early in the piece. I have an interest in fondly receiving an answer to this overdue question. I also put on notice that quite a large number of questions are outstanding in relation to the National Media Liaison Service. Regrettably, estimates committee questions on notice do not come under the 30-day rule. I give notice today that, unless we can see some speedy responses to these questions, I intend to move in the Senate an amendment to the standing orders to ensure that questions on notice given to Senate committees also come under this 30-day rule. I will move it because of the tardiness of Mr Walker and others in supplying answers to estimates committees.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Under the order of the Senate relating to questions on notice, agreed to on 28 September 1988, I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Defence for an explanation as to why I have not received answers to question No. 1962, which I put on notice on 6 February this year, and question No. 1977, which was put on notice on 7 February this year. They relate to the use of the RAAF base at Curtin as a detention centre, and Blackhawk helicopters.
—They have already made decisions about half of that.

—Of course they have already made decisions. In addition, although my office has not been in touch with the minister's office this morning, it has been in touch with the minister's office a couple of times over the last couple of days.

PARA.TAB: While I am on my feet, I also ask under the same order of the Senate for an explanation as to why I have not received an answer to question No. 1888, which I put on notice to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel on 1 December 1994. My office has been in touch with Minister Punch's office in the last couple of weeks, yet we still do not have a response. It seems to me that the government has been getting a bit slack and complacent about questions on notice. I hope that the opposition's actions today will demonstrate to those responsible for answering questions that the Senate will not brook the backsliding that we have seen in recent times.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —It has certainly been demonstrated to me, because I am sick of being office boy. I have just checked with Senator Ray's office about the matters Senator Newman has raised. The answer on the Blackhawks is ready and will be faxed immediately to her office. The answer on the Curtin base is awaiting some input from the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs.
—I got the Immigration answer weeks ago.

—I am told that the Defence people are waiting for some input from Immigration. I have no idea what it is about. They are trying to expedite it. As soon as they get it, they will be equally delighted to help you.

PARA.TAB: While I am on my feet, I will deal with the question on notice from Senator Tambling addressed to Senator Schacht. Senator Schacht is aware that Senator Tambling has an overdue question on notice. He has advised that the response is in the minister's office and will be sent to Senator Tambling as soon as approved by Mr Crean.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not good enough. We asked for that a week ago.
—It might not be good enough, but that is the best I can do with as much grace as I can muster. I urge you to emulate me.

—I draw the minister's attention to the fact that I also referred to question No. 1888, which I put on notice on 1 December to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel. His office has been contacted in the last couple of weeks and the answer has still not arrived. Would the minister like to send his carrier pigeons in that direction?

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would be happy to do so.

—I have a question for the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, Senator Crowley, who is present; I am pleased that she is. Under the order of the Senate relating to questions on notice, agreed to on 28 September 1988, I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security for an explanation as to why I have not received an answer to question No. 1941, which I put on notice on 1 February 1995 and which relates to home equity conversion loans and the Advance Bank.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that that question includes matters which relate to a contract between the Commonwealth and the Advance Bank. Before the answer can be completed, it is necessary to seek legal advice on some aspects. An answer will be provided as soon as possible.

—Pursuant to the order of the Senate relating to questions on notice, agreed to on 28 September, I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts for an explanation of why I have not received an answer to question No. 1913, which I put on notice on 15 December 1994, to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts?

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will take that on notice, if I may.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the explanation.

SPEECH.PARA: I sympathise with Senator Evans. He does not even know what I asked. This is just an appalling way to run a government; it is an appalling way to run a parliament. It is just typical of a tired and arrogant government. My staff did the courtesy of telling the minister before question time that I would be asking about this.

TALK.START.PARA: —Spare me the rage. Which minister was it?
—The Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts. It has been outstanding since 15 December, more than three months ago now.
—What was the number of the question?

—I have done all this, Senator Evans. I do not blame you. All of your ministers were told that these things were happening, and what have they done? They have treated the Senate with absolute contempt. They have known that we wanted these answers, and they have just disappeared. They cannot get out of the joint quickly enough because they do not have answers. I feel sorry for you, Senator Evans. They have left you to bear the brunt of this.

PARA.TAB: This is not a laughing matter. It is a very serious matter. The standing orders of the Senate require that ministers shall answer these questions within 30 days. Those standing orders are not just there as play things or things that an arrogant government and an arrogant set of ministers might comply with if they feel like it. They are required to answer these questions by orders of the Senate. Not only did we ask them these questions three or four months ago but also we gave them notice before question time as a matter of courtesy, and they do not even have the courtesy to give an explanation. This is treating the Senate with absolute contempt.

I see that no Democrats or minor parties are here at the moment, but I do hope that they are listening. If the Senate is going to be treated with this sort of contempt by the government, we might as well all pack up and go home. That would be a tragedy for Australia because it is only this chamber that keeps this arrogant, tired, insensitive government anywhere on the track and on the rails.

TALK.START.PARA: —Your mob in the Reps are pretty hopeless, I acknowledge.

—They get guillotined or rolled simply because of the numbers, Senator Evans. This is simply not good enough. We are rising for five weeks now. We want the answers to these questions. That is why we asked them. If we did not want the answers, we would not ask the questions. We have asked the questions; we want the answers, which we are not going to get for another five weeks now. Your lot—those people who call themselves ministers of the Crown—just treat this Senate with absolute contempt. They walk out. They have not got the guts or the intestinal fortitude to even face the Senate. I think that is appalling.

PARA.TAB: If it were not the last day and if there were not such important legislation to be dealt with, I would very seriously move censure motions against every single one of those ministers for the way that they have handled this. It is appalling. You need to be put on notice, Senator Evans, as so-called leader of that so-called rabble that sits behind you on the frontbench, that we will not stand for this anymore. The Senate orders require that answers be given in 30 days and, if they are not given in 30 days, we will not be so generous in the future.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McGauran)—Following all that discussion, I am obliged to say that it really is incumbent upon those ministers who were given prior notice that these questions would be raised to come into the Senate as a matter of proper and orderly working of the Senate. Most ministers, if not all, were given prior notice. I do note that Senator Crowley was here to take up two particular questions. It is obvious that it is an order of the Senate. It could well have been stretched, if not breached. I am only in the acting capacity, so it is not for me to judge upon that. Nevertheless, I feel I am obliged to refer the matter to the President, who has raised this matter of ministers answering questions by the order of the Senate on many occasions. So I will be referring the matter to the President.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, you have made a very sensible comment. You handle the chair far better than the Speaker in the other place. Senator Alston also has two questions that are outstanding, and he desires an answer to those as well.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, two questions of mine have been outstanding for quite a considerable period of time. I was advised by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins) after question time that I could pick up copies of responses from the table office, but I did not think that that would be an adequate response in the circumstances. I join with my colleagues in deploring the way in which the government continually treats us.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McGauran)—I can only put the matter in the hands of the President.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave of the Senate to make a statement relating to a motion referring to me, which was passed in the House of Representatives earlier today.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I reject the dishonest motion passed in the House of Representatives against me. I do so on grounds that must concern every senator here. A matter of a most serious nature has emerged out of that censure motion. I want to record my disgust at what is either disgraceful collusion between the Second Commissioner of Taxation, Mr P.E. Simpson, and the Treasurer, Mr Willis, to blacken my name, or a dishonest action by the Treasurer, Mr Willis—or his office—to pass himself off as a spokesman for the tax commissioner.

PARA.TAB: I spoke this morning to the Commissioner of Taxation, Mr Michael Carmody, who denies absolutely the remarks attributed to him by the Sydney Morning Herald in an article which appeared in that newspaper on Saturday morning. The article, in part, read:

SPEECH.PARA: Yesterday, a tax office spokesman said the Tax Commissioner was considering referring Senator Baume's actions to the police, the Federal Director of Public Prosecutions and the Privacy Commissioner for investigation.

In simple terms, that is a lie. The commissioner himself told me today that he was overseas at the time, that he had not addressed the matter and he is not considering doing so. He told me that, as far as he can ascertain, no tax official made such a statement.

PARA.TAB: Who did? What shonky, crooked, dishonest person pretended to be speaking for the tax commissioner? This matter is being handled by the second commissioner, Mr Simpson. It is remarkable that the wording of paragraph 9 in his memorandum of Friday 24 March to Mr Willis is exactly the same as the statement that was incorporated in, and reported by, the Sydney Morning Herald. The statement in the confidential minute of 24 March read:

SPEECH.PARA: I am considering whether the matter will be referred to the Privacy Commissioner, Australian Federal Police or the Director of Public Prosecutions for further investigation.

Clearly, someone has some explaining to do about this political stunt, this attempt to politically hang me. I demand an explanation. Will Mr Willis come clean? Did he or anyone in his office pass himself or herself off as an officer of the taxation department in an attempt to damage me? If Mr Willis did not do so, did he authorise any member of his staff to pass himself or herself off as a representative of the taxation department. I demand an answer from Mr Willis. I remind whoever did that that they did so without the protection of the privileges of this parliament. I remind them that this kind of deception is simply and uncomplicatedly illegal. Mr Willis has a duty to reveal who performed this illegal act, passing himself or herself off to be an officer of the tax department.

PARA.TAB: It seems that Mr Willis may have been put up to this by the joint intelligence of the second commissioner and Mr Gear. It seems to me that the second commissioner has seriously transgressed across the boundary of proper behaviour into political intervention by advising Mr Gear of what is patently, totally and self-evidently false but very useful politically.

The second commissioner advised Mr Gear on 28 March in what is apparently a confidential minute—it is stamped `confidential', but it is only confidential until it can serve some political purpose—that the alleged breaches by me of section 8WB involved the holding, the maintenance, of the document that I tabled and its subsequent disclosure and the journalists who received it may also be in breach by holding it, whether they divulged it or not. This is absolute rubbish; it is politically designed to be hurled at me.

Firstly, the application of parliamentary privilege destroys this proposition totally. Journalists can take comfort from the fact that they are protected by section 16D of that act which provides that privilege applies to publications of documents published pursuant to an order of the house, as is the case on this occasion. Even worse, the second commissioner cannot even read his own act.

Section 8WB that he refers to is simply irrelevant. It does not apply in this situation. This section says that a person shall not record another person's tax file number or maintain such a record. I made no record of another person's tax file number and therefore could not be accused of maintaining a record. I did not make a record in the first place. I received the document and held it for a few hours until tabling. I did not record it or maintain it under any quaint or exotic interpretation of section 8WB.

This is yet another piece of politically oriented nonsense which represents a contemptible abuse of power by Mr Willis, Mr Gear and, regrettably, Mr Simpson, the second assistant tax commissioner. The most disgraceful part of all of this is that these non-offences—and they are known by Mr Willis to be non-offences—are being referred to the Australian Federal Police for further examination.

I will not stand idly by while this kind of charade continues, and that particularly applies to any threats to me indicated today by Mr Ted Mack on behalf of Dr Macdonald. The fact is that the improper behaviour of the Treasurer, Mr Willis, is clearly contemptuous of the parliament and totally dishonest. The fact is that he tabled a letter from the second commissioner, Mr Simpson, purporting to show that I may have committed a criminal act in simply possessing the tax file number of Dr Macdonald and that parliamentary privilege may not cover my actions, leaving open the possibility that I could face charges for breaching the Taxation Administration Act. That is a blatant lie, and Mr Willis knows it to be a lie. It is part of a dishonest beat-up aimed at grabbing a headline. I used to regard Mr Willis as decent but dull. I did not realise he had some other `d's—dumb and dishonest. He knows perfectly well that there is no such risk to me.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. I deliberately refrained from intervening before in the debate in respect of the language that Senator Baume was using because I believe that, when senators are making personal explanations going to their own integrity, they should be given almost full licence in which to defend themselves, although that was not a privilege extended to me the other day. I think in that last statement Senator Baume has transgressed to a point where I have to intervene to keep consistency in this chamber. I also note that Senator Baume has been heard in silence, another privilege that was not extended to me or anyone else the other day.

—I thank Senator Ray for his intervention. I acknowledge that my anger at Mr Willis's actions—which, as Senator Ray recognises, I find unacceptable—encouraged me to use words that should not be used in this place, and I withdraw them. I thank the Senate for the manner in which I am being heard on this matter today, which is in striking contrast to the way I was heard on a similar matter yesterday. I thank Senator Ray for his courtesy and, as he knows, I have a high regard for his recognition of the proper forms of the parliament.

PARA.TAB: I suppose I will have to think of some other `d' words to describe Mr Willis. He knows perfectly well that there is no such risk to me, that I have not committed any offence and that he is doing absolutely anything at the bidding of his master, Mr Keating, to get a cheap anti-Baume headline. Section 16(2) of his own government's Parliamentary Privileges Act 1987 makes it perfectly clear that proceedings in parliament attract parliamentary privilege. Mr Willis also knows that proceedings in parliament are specifically defined in the act to include:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . words spoken and acts done in the course of, or for purposes of or incidental to, the transacting of the business of a House or of a committee, and, without limiting the generality of the foregoing, includes:
(b) the presentation or submission of a document to a House—

`Incidental' means receiving and holding such a document. It is clear and uncomplicated. There is no escape route for the government. This is what the act clearly says, and Mr Willis knew that when he set off on this disgraceful scare campaign.

PARA.TAB: I want to make certain that this message is clearly received by the Senate. The totally false allegations that I have breached Commonwealth law and am at risk of prosecution are simply part of a dishonest, politically motivated campaign aimed at terrorising me into silence. It will not work. I reject today's censure in the House of Representatives as a dishonest political sham. I stress that the Commissioner of Taxation, Mr Carmody, has assured me that no tax official made the statement that was printed in the Sydney Morning Herald, and he denies that he had considered taking such action at that time.

I regret the performance of Mr Simpson and I demand an explanation from Mr Willis about who passed himself off as a representative of the tax office. I regret that Mr Willis today tabled a further document from Mr Simpson which is wrong in fact, incompetent in law and political in nature. That was the one in which he indicated he had decided to refer an alleged breach of section 8WB to the Australian Federal Police. I repeat there is no broach of the law and Mr Simpson and Mr Willis know it. This whole performance is a farce as the Parliamentary Privileges Act covers the whole matter. Journalists, as I said, are totally protected and the threat that they should be subject to some kind of prosecution for simply holding it is absolute nonsense.

I say in conclusion that the federal Treasurer, Mr Willis, who I say I used to hold in some esteem as a decent bloke, should cease using the tax office for disgraceful political purposes no matter what sort of pressure is brought on him by the Prime Minister, who simply cannot stomach the fact that I have scored so many direct points on him over his misleading this chamber, misleading this parliament and misleading the people about his ownership of the piggery and its continual breaches of laws ranging from Corporations Law to environment law to employment law. Not only should Mr Willis cease using the tax office for these disgraceful political purposes, but I regret that the second commissioner for taxation has conducted himself in a totally inappropriate manner.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Finance and Public Administration References Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Finance and Public Administration References Committee on the disclosure provisions for Prime Ministers and leaders of the opposition.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate will recall that on 8 November 1994 the Senate referred the following matter to the Finance and Public Administration References Committee for inquiry and report, at that stage by 1 December 1994: whether the existing disclosure provisions for Prime Ministers and leaders of the opposition are credible; whether Prime Ministers and leaders of the opposition should be accountable for their acquisition of assets and liabilities while in office and, if so, to whom; and whether the details to be revealed should be similar to those required of ministers under existing cabinet rules.

PARA.TAB: The Senate would be interested to know that this committee met on several occasions and was at great pains to arrive at some sort of consensus. The product of the eight meetings of this committee was five pages and three lines that honourable senators will find recorded in our report. The committee sought and received a submission from both the government and the opposition on this matter. These submissions are included in the five and bit pages as appendix 1 and 2. A further submission was received from Senator Baume and that is included in full as appendix 3. That makes at least a presentable number of pages. As a committee, we expended a great deal of energy in achieving the pages that we have here.

As chair of the committee, I must say that it was not an easy process, but in the end it was made a little easier when we arrived at the following paragraph on page 4 of the report. The paragraph reads:

SPEECH.PARA: However, having examined the current provisions in Australia, compared these with other countries and taken note of the limited evidence available, the Committee finds itself divided on the issue of the adequacy of the current disclosure provisions. The various views are set out in the following paragraphs.
That is, in essence, the tenor of the report. We actually set out the opposing views in the following paragraphs. I think honourable senators will be entertained to read those because they record—

PARA.TAB: Senator Watson interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I would do a lot better, Senator Watson, if I was not continually harangued from the side. I intend to do just what you want if only you will let me speak. As I indicated, those various views are representative and follow along the general lines of what I will now quote. The report continues:

SPEECH.PARA: Some members of the Committee regard it as a major problem for the head of the executive government not to be required to disclose any changes in the value of assets and liabilities because government decisions can have very important effects on personal wealth. These Senators favour changes in the current disclosure provisions for Prime Ministers and Leaders of the Opposition along the lines proposed in the Leader of the Opposition's submission—
The following paragraph points out:

Other members of the Committee, while recognising that differences do exist, point out that the obligation of ministers, who have to declare values as well as the nature of interests, is greater than for other senators and members, though such declarations of values are not made public. These Senators also point out that the Prime Minister, being aware of his/her own assets has no need to declare them to another person, since the purpose of ministerial declaration is to assist the Prime Minister to make judgments about the proper conduct of internal executive business. These Senators accept that it is not appropriate for the Parliament to involve itself in prescribing how Cabinet operates.

I again quote from what we agreed to in our report because, for those who want to see what this committee did and how it dealt with those opposing views, I think there are two matters of consensus which are important to illustrate. We found:

Notwithstanding that even the most stringent disclosure provisions cannot ensure the highest level of accountability and avoidance of conflict of interest in practice, the Committee believes that appropriate levels of accountability are essential in a modern democracy.

I think that as a truism is a little hard to avoid. Nevertheless, we were able as a committee, which was struggling to find agreement on anything, to find agreement on that point at least. As I said, the tenor of the report was mainly that we exposed the differing opinions and at least saw the value of having some disclosure in a modern democracy.

PARA.TAB: I found that one of the most important observations I could make was that we did not actually receive any evidence which demonstrated the value of adopting any overseas practice as a model for Australia, despite the fact that it has been contended in here and in other places that the concept of the United States, Japanese, Italian model or some other model might be worth following. We saw no evidence which demonstrated that, by following any of those models, we could ensure that there would be no conflict of interest in the parliamentary houses; in fact, quite the contrary. If senators would cast their minds to the situations that exist in any of those overseas countries, I am sure with any honesty one would have to admit that there is no capacity to demonstrate that the Japanese, Italian or United States models by themselves prevent any conflicts of interest. The report is brief; however, the appendices make interesting reading.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to make a few very brief comments on the report by the Finance and Public Administration References Committee. Senator Bell, the chairman of the committee, pointed out that this was a difficult report to prepare and there were considerable divisions on the committee. Although Senator Bell would be aware that I have sometimes been critical of the way he may conduct himself from time to time, he did an excellent job in making sure that we worked through this very difficult process to try to get a report which made a contribution to what is a very important debate.

PARA.TAB: I hold the view that the man or woman who holds the senior office in this country has a full-time job and has no business in business. That person has no business in borrowing, or lending, or selling or what have you and basically has to concentrate on the full-time job. The conflicts of interest are immense. If you are the Prime Minister of the country, there is no question that the decisions and appointments you make are extremely important and it would be a great pity if there were conflicts of interest. So that is the position I am coming from.

The second point the committee discovered—and this is very important—was that, although ministers are accountable to the Prime Minister for the value of their assets and transactions that they make in the selling of assets and borrowings and have to notify the Prime Minister of changes in the value of the assets they hold, no such requirement is made of the Prime Minister. The most powerful man or woman in the land is exempt from any form of disclosure along the lines which is required of ministers. People have started to focus on this issue because they are concerned about a Prime Minister who involves himself in very expensive business transactions.

It was pointed out in a submission by Mr Alexander Downer that there have been a number of case studies where the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has apparently involved himself in large scale transactions—whether it be the purchase of a $2.2 million home or the sale of a piggery. Apparently no-one is informed and there is no bit of paper around in which the Prime Minister is forced to disclose these transactions.

Importantly, what we came through with the committee was, at the very minimum, to try to look at an example of how the Prime Minister could be put in a similar position as the ministers. If Senator Robert Ray, who is in the chamber, spends up big and purchases shares and sells shares, he has to go along to the Prime Minister and say, `Paul, here is a bit of paper. I've made a million here, I've lost half a million here and I've borrowed $3 million there.' That is what Senator Ray has to do. But if Mr Keating does exactly the same thing as Senator Ray, he does not have to tell anybody. In fact, you can be absolutely assured that he will not tell anybody.

So how can we put Mr Keating in the same position as Senator Ray in relation to accountability and disclosure? I draw the Senate's attention to a few excellent sentences in this report. For example, when Mr Keating conducts one of his large scale transactions, it would be possible for him to disclose this to the presiding officers. Alternatively, the Prime Minister could be required to disclose it to the Deputy Prime Minister and the Leader of the Government in the Senate. This would put the Prime Minister in precisely the same position as Senator Ray is currently in.

As we could not reach a consensus majority view on this report, it will have to rely, as they say, on the court of public opinion. Hopefully, when interested people see this report, they will understand the enormous anomaly we have at the moment; that is, there is no effective disclosure or accountability by the Prime Minister—and, particularly, at present we seem to have a Prime Minister who is very active in business type transactions.

I commend this report to the Senate. I think it should be read. There is a diversity of views expressed in it. In the end, one of the strengths of the Senate committee system is that we can work through these issues and present a report which, even if somewhat difficult to read, at least makes a number of important points.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is a bit rich for those opposite to be holier than thou about the issue of pecuniary interests, given the way that they had to be brought kicking and screaming in this place to make declarations of the nature—not the value but merely the nature—of pecuniary interests. And, of course, they continued to oppose it to the end.
—Six years it took.

—At least six years, but I do not want to concentrate on that matter. I just mention in passing that it is a bit rich for them to be saying how important it is now, given their views on the record. Of course, the situation involving their views over the years about the ability—
—Who did Fraser report to?

—Exactly. In fairness, it was during the time of the Fraser government that they introduced the cabinet rules. But Mr Fraser, the former Prime Minister, reported to nobody. He was involved in business in a—
—Old money is fine.

—Yes, old money. There are different standards. I just make those comments in passing to point out that there is not a consistency of attitude in the opposition. The position that I took on this matter was simple: that the rules that apply to ministers, and which the opposition sought to want to vary in respect of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), were internal rules of the cabinet. Basically, I have accepted that that set of rules is an internal matter to the cabinet, and there is no precedent for the parliament purporting to involve itself in the way in which the cabinet operates. That, I think, is basic.

PARA.TAB: However, I have been strong for many years about the issue of revelation of pecuniary interests. The extent to which the revelation of pecuniary interests has gone up until now has been on the question of the nature of pecuniary interests. As we say in the report, on the public revelation of values, there are good arguments for and against. I can see both sides of that story.

But I take the position that, if the parliament is to consider extending its current pecuniary interest rules, it should do so only in a way in which they would apply consistently to all senators and members. That would mean that all those exercising significant power in their various ways should all be affected similarly by any rules which the parliament itself prescribes. And those exercising significant power would include the Prime Minister—and nobody suggests that the Prime Minister does not exercise significant power—the Treasurer (Mr Willis), other ministers, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), and shadow ministers. The leaders of the largest party in the Senate exercise very considerable powers. Those senators with the balance of power exercise considerable powers. Chairs and members of parliamentary committees, in their own way, exercise power. Particular members and senators, who might not have an office in here but who have special influence within their parties, exercise power.

There may be a reasonable expectation of the electorate that the value of interests be openly available so that judgments can be made as to whether or not decision making is affected by personal interests. That is just an extra step beyond the revelation of the nature of interests which occurs for all of us, including the Prime Minister now. But, if it is to be so, it would only be fair if all those making such decisions—which I think vary in their significance only by degree—were to be equally affected.

There is currently a review of the whole question of pecuniary interests by the committee of the Senate which has been appointed for that purpose. It is within that committee's jurisdiction to consider these issues. So, if there are people proposing that there should be now values revealed as well as nature, it is submissions to that committee which should deal with the matter and have us all affected.

As we say in the report, the Senate committee is permitted, by its terms of reference, to meet with its equivalent committee of the House of Representatives. It is firmly suggested by those of us who take this view that that committee should propose doing so, to ensure that there is a common approach in both houses and that a desired consistent level of disclosure affecting all of us should be achieved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The presentation of the report of the Finance and Public Administration References Committee is a timely reminder to this Senate of just how standards of propriety have dropped in the last few decades. I remind the Senate of the very high standards set under the Menzies regime, when ministers were required to divest themselves, for example, of all shares in public companies.

PARA.TAB: This came home very strongly to me when a former senator for Tasmania, who was a member of the Menzies ministry, the late Senator Henty, was required to divest himself of his very modest shareholdings. I would remind the Senate also that Mr Menzies himself did not enrich himself during his time in this place. In fact, as Prime Minister for very many years—in fact, the longest serving Prime Minister—he died a man of modest means.

Today we have a situation where ministers quite properly have to detail to the Prime Minister their interests in various assets—and I would have thought this is a minimum requirement. They also not only have to describe the nature of those assets but also the values that attach to them. But what is surprising is that, in turn, the Prime Minister is not required to reciprocate in any way whatsoever to his deputy leader, his cabinet, his ministers, or anybody. I am not necessarily asking that he divulge value details to the world at large. I would have thought that the most powerful person in this land, the Prime Minister, should have to report to someone. But this is not the case.

I also use this occasion to draw attention to my concern with what I believe is a great variation in the manner in which assets are disclosed. It does appear that, if members of parliament—whether a Prime Minister, a minister or a backbencher—put their assets in a trust form, they are somehow excluded from disclosing those assets behind that trust framework. For example, if a person holds assets individually, in a partnership or in a private company, the assets are required to spell out the investments in great detail behind the particular holding instrument. Yet, if a person holds the assets in the form of a trust—and there are people, including back benchers, ministers, and the Prime Minister, who hold them in the form of a trust—for the general disclosure register which is presented to this parliament and is available to the press that the interests behind those holdings do not appear to be mandated.

So I would have thought that there needs to be a great deal of tidying up in terms of the manner in which holdings have to be described. That applies from the Prime Minister right down to the most lowly person here. I also take this opportunity of acknowledging that the clerks of the

SPEECH.PARA: Senate in terms of their role in this place have taken on themselves voluntary disclosure. That is an acknowledgement of their professionalism.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a result of my request that this inquiry took place. There is enormous irony in that today this report—in my view a very poor majority report and a very sensible minority report—has come to us. It is an irony that it comes to us on a day when I have been censured by the House of Representatives for revealing the hidden truth about a parliamentarian's massive understatement of his tax. How ludicrous are the present revelation requirements anyway when it is a matter of such substance that when I revealed the understatement of income of $104,000 I should be censured for that and here we are talking about rejecting in this report any suggestion that one particular member of parliament, the Prime Minister, should be obliged to make any revelation at all about the state of his finances.

PARA.TAB: Given that irony, we have to recognise that a lack of public confidence in the integrity of Australian politicians has developed over recent years often as a result of their failure to disclose the reality of their position. For example, Dr Macdonald failed to disclose that he had understated his income, he says inadvertently, by $104,000. There was the failure to disclose his interest by the Prime Minister, for example, when he misled the chambers of this parliament by saying that he only had an interest in a company which had an interest in a piggery when, in fact, he owned half of a company which wholly owned a piggery.

When you get people misleading the chamber in that way because `an interest in' clearly does not indicate whole ownership, it cannot be stretched to mean whole ownership, the public of Australia naturally will feel they have been deceived by politicians who use that kind of device and that kind of language and a real need emerges for us to make certain exactly what we are about when we say there is disclosure.

We know perfectly well that the level of disclosure, for example, among ministers is much higher than that required of ordinary members of parliament. So it should be, because ministers have a particular responsibility. No minister has a greater responsibility than the Prime Minister because his responsibility extends over the whole range of government. So there is pressure on the Prime Minister to, if you like, be responsible to someone, to disclose to someone, what his or her assets are—and liabilities, particularly in view of some extraordinary debts we have seen to the Commonwealth Bank in relation to the piggery. It is vital that at least there should be a revelation to someone to ensure that the question of conflict of interest or the potential for conflict of interest is resolved. Whether it is resolved satisfactorily is another matter, but at least it is resolved within the cabinet because there are clear cabinet rules.

Ministers must reveal to their Prime Minister where they have an interest that may well be a conflict of interest and they also have to reveal the value of their assets and liabilities to the Prime Minister. That seems to me to be a sensible thing. That remains confidential within the cabinet. But at least the Prime Minister knows whether one of his ministers stands to gain or lose as a result of the decision of the cabinet or the decisions of that minister.

But what about this Prime Minister? When this Prime Minister was a member of Mr Hawke's cabinet he failed to reveal under the cabinet rules to Mr Hawke that he had acquired half ownership of a company for $413,000, a substantial amount, which totally owned a piggery group and a refrigeration group. Mr Hawke was never ever advised of that fact. Mr Keating was supposed to have advised him immediately, according to cabinet rules. It was only three or four weeks later when Mr Keating had resigned from the cabinet that eventually a normal statement of declaration was made as a backbencher to the parliament.

When you get people who break the rules you then have a special need to make certain that the rules are capable of being applied properly. The problem is that with the Prime Minister there are no rules. He does not have to report to anyone. That was the reason I raised this matter. If it had not been for the events of the last couple of years with the present Prime Minister, there would have been no pressure to change the situation which had existed. It appears on the face of it, at least, to have resulted in no misleading of the public ever since Federation. I do not know of anyone who has made any allegations of any previous Prime Minister having misled the people of Australia about his assets or liabilities, despite some incredibly vicious attacks on Mr Fraser by Mr Keating when he was in opposition about his ownership of a property in Victoria, which was well-known before Mr Fraser got elected to parliament. Changed circumstances means there is a need for change in the requirements.

The minority report does not accept any of my four recommendations—that the Prime Minister should make the same disclosure relating to new private interests required by ministers to him under the cabinet rules to the parliament in the public document or the Governor-General in a private document or the Auditor-General in a private document or the Deputy Prime Minister in a private document. The minority report has chosen some other alternatives. They are a decided improvement on the present situation and I strongly support and recommend the minority report contained in this report.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins), to a question without notice asked by Sentor West this day, relating to the drought in the Upper Hunter Valley region.

SPEECH.PARA: I have been in the Senate for four years and I have been involved with Senator Collins on a number of issues, including shipping and communications and now rural affairs. I note that when Senator Collins gets in a corner he has a tactic. The tactic is to take a small item in support of his case and then not give you the full story.

PARA.TAB: We had a classic example of that this afternoon. The minister's response to what I was saying about his abject failure to include in the extreme drought declared areas the Upper Hunter was that there has not been anything from the New South Wales government on this matter for four months. That illustrates the point I just made. On 16 November last year, 4 1/2 months ago, the Minister for Agriculture and Fisheries, Mr Causley, wrote to the minister and his reply was received on 16 December. So in a way Senator Collins has misled us because this matter was active four months ago. The minister's reply was received 3 1/2 months ago.

I tell the Senate and put on record what all this correspondence was about. The first letter came from the New South Wales Farmers Association. It is a letter to Minister Causley dated 11 November. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Following a survey of NSW Farmers' Association General Councillors, we request the following Rural Lands Protection Board areas be classified Exceptional Circumstance either in whole or in part . . .
He goes on to list 14 areas, including Gloucester, Maitland, Denman, Merriwa and Scone. That was the request on the 11th. On the 16th the minister wrote to Senator Collins. In part, he stated:

I would reiterate that the New South Wales' position continues to be that at the very least the six Rural Lands Protection Board areas which were previously proposed should now be declared as being in an exceptional drought (Grafton, Mudgee, Nyngan, Merriwa, Scone and Dubbo).

Merriwa and Scone are in the Upper Hunter. In other words, out of those 14 the New South Wales minister was putting those in the top six—yet the federal minister has ignored those areas and has included some of those other regions in extreme drought. They have been included since 1 December. Why? I have pointed it out to the Senate before: those areas were in marginal seats. Of course, poor old Merriwa, Denman and Scone are not in marginal seats. So it is bad luck for them—they have missed out. Minister Collins wrote back on 16 December to Minister Causley saying:
The Government has concluded that your request for support in the remaining Districts does not meet the . . . criteria and is therefore unable to agree to your request.

So Minister Collins knocked back that request 3 1/2 months ago. The minister is saying that the New South Wales government has been tardy on this. It got a request from the farmers, it responded a week later, the minister knocked it back a month later, the area is still in extreme drought—nothing has changed in the Upper Hunter except that the drought has got worse since that time—and this do-nothing minister has done nothing for the people of the Upper Hunter and continues to refuse to do anything for the people of the Upper Hunter.

PARA.TAB: It was most disingenuous of the minister to come in here this afternoon during question time while it was being broadcast and make out it was all the fault of the New South Wales government when clearly it is not. The guidelines, or lack of guidelines, he has put down for reapplying leaves this whole area very muddy about when and how states should reapply for this sort of grant. So we cannot blame the New South Wales government.

The minister's position this afternoon is even more inexcusable when we take into account that he misled the Scone delegation of farmers who took him at his word in his office to have RASAC consider the eligibility of the Upper Hunter. The exceptional circumstances relief drought package was supposed to give cash support relief and it continues to discriminate against those in need.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator West)—Senator Tierney, your time has expired.

TALK.START.PARA: —This minister should be—
—Senator Tierney, your time has expired.
—This minister should be condemned by the people of this country for his approach to drought.
—Senator Tierney! Would you, please, when I call you to order in future, come to order.
—Stop acting like a schoolteacher.
—And I would appreciate more respect being paid to the chair than that. I believe Senator Ellison wishes to have the call.
—Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. You might like to put the question that the Senate take note of the answer.
—It would be very helpful if people would tell me whether they are moving to a different matter.
—Before you put the question, I seek leave—I have sought the minister's leave to do this—to incorporate in Hansard the three letters I have referred to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction (Senator Schacht), to a question without notice asked by Senator Ellison this day, relating to funding for student unions.

SPEECH.PARA: My question related to the funding that the Commonwealth government will provide to those student unions and associations which now have voluntary membership. In particular I address my remarks to those institutions in Western Australia. What will happen is that, due to the shortfall in membership of those student unions and associations because they are now voluntary, the government will top up their income using taxpayers' money. That taxpayers' money will come from funding which was otherwise destined for schools, teachers, books and other expenses associated with educational matters in that state. I can tell the Senate that since voluntary membership came into being 30 per cent of students have enrolled in the student union at Murdoch—

TALK.START.PARA: —Only 30 per cent?

—Senator Abetz will be even more surprised to hear that only eight per cent enrolled at Edith Cowan University. At the University of Western Australia the figure is 24 per cent and at Curtin University, 12.5 per cent. Such low enrolment figures are certainly not a ringing endorsement of the various student bodies. These figures obviously mean that students, when given the choice, do not want to join their student union or student association. This is despite some of these bodies halving their annual fee. They are halving their annual fee, and that is all they can get. That is the sum total of membership.

PARA.TAB: The minister told us today that his department has had representations on two occasions from Western Australian student bodies and that guidelines were set down on 14 March this year in relation to the top-up funding of these student bodies. The problem is that they cannot get membership. They cannot get membership whilst they are voluntary, so the government will top them up with money taken out of the state's grants which were given to it for other educational expenditure.

The purpose of my question is that taxpayers of this country need to know that this government is subsidising student unions and associations which are incapable of maintaining or attracting anywhere near 100 per cent membership. In fact, we have figures showing that it is as low as 12.5 per cent and eight per cent. That tells the story. If these bodies cannot offer services, if they cannot offer any attraction to new students who are enrolling and those students who are re-enrolling, why should they be topped up with taxpayers' money? Why should they be subsidised? Why should other areas which need the money—education is an area which can never have too many dollars—go without and that money be used for subsidising student unions and associations? The Western Australian government, by bringing in voluntary student union membership, has demonstrated the very point that these bodies have been propped up over the years by compulsory membership. Senator Schacht says it is an ideological thing. It certainly is, and I do not shirk from that fact one bit. I stand by my belief that it should be voluntary association and I stand against compulsory membership of any association.

TALK.START.PARA: —Including the Bar Council?

—In this free society we should offer our citizens freedom of association—a basic right. That is recognised by the United Nations, for those who are interested in where that body stands. It is disgraceful that we are subsidising these bodies which are incapable of attracting membership to sustain their own movement.

—I wish to make a few remarks in relation to the answer of the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction (Senator Schacht) to Senator Ellison's very reasonable and proper question. The minister commenced his remarks by attacking the Liberal Party and continued by attacking me, being required to withdraw a certain description of me.
—What was that?

—I will not repeat it for the Hansard. I will not be baited by Senator Ray, but it was a very good attempt. The simple fact is—I make no apology for it—that I do have an ideological commitment to voluntary student unionism. What the minister was saying all the time was that the Liberal Party has got this fix against student unions and student associations. We do not. We have a fix against compulsory student unions and student associations.

PARA.TAB: Indeed, in my home state of Tasmania a prize winning student, a winner of prizes in physics and the sciences, was about to be denied the right to use the library and was about to have his marks and results denied to him for his refusal to join the student union. That comes from a society that allegedly prides itself on freedoms and personal rights.

The simple fact is that up until the legislation that Western Australia introduced, if students did not want to join this compulsory body, they would be denied their education. I find that to be obnoxious. If that makes me an ideologue in relation to that aspect of my views, so be it and I do not shy away from it at all.

It is very interesting that this government always talks about competition. It used to like Hilmer. I think it is backing away from Hilmer now because it is having a few concerns. But in general terms it says that it supports competition—except for its mates, its mates in the student unions who funded the Labor Party to a minimum of $100,000 at the last federal election. The students are now marching against the government and are absolutely disgusted with the leadership of the student union movement in this country for having betrayed their interests and having misled them into voting for the Labor Party at the last federal election.

It is no wonder that the Labor Party, desperate to retain the moneys that it has got from these student unions, had to manufacture a way to ensure that it could continue to receive that money. The Labor Party is a master at that. For example, the Australian Conservation Foundation had a shortfall of $500,000 in public donations in the past 12 months. With public support waning, what does the federal government do? It weighs in with an extra $600,000.

With student unions in the west, students are given a choice and they vote with their feet by walking out. The highest level of membership is 30 per cent. What a disgraceful record for the leadership of those student unions and student associations. They can attract only 30 per cent of their peers to be members, yet the federal government says, `We will top up that fund.'

The disgraceful thing about the federal government policy is that the student union that attracted the fewest members—that is, the one with eight per cent—will have the 92 per cent shortfall made up out of taxpayers' funds. So the more irresponsible the leadership of the student union is, the fewer members it has, the more money it will get from the federal government as an incentive to be less representative of the students.

If anything, the federal government ought to be providing an incentive to student unions and student organisations so that the more representative they are, the more members they get, the more support they get from the federal government. But in this case it is the reverse. The more unrepresentative you are, the fewer members you have got, the more money you are going to get from the taxpayer of Australia at the expense of the particular state. At the expense of the particular state means that state governments will not be able to match the federal government dollar for dollar on drought relief, on roadworks, on hospitals, on police and on all those other important infrastructure matters. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin Sen N.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans), to a question without notice asked by Senator Alston this day, relating to the economy.

SPEECH.PARA: It would be remiss of me not to take note of Senator Gareth Evans's inadequate answer to Senator Alston's question about the current account deficit. We have had released today the current account deficit for February showing another appalling figure of a deficit of $2,165 million. For the seventh time in the last eight months, we have had a current account deficit of over $2,000 million. This fits in with the government forecast because the government has had to increase the budget forecast for the current account deficit for 1994-95 by over 50 per cent to $26 billion for 1994-95. This disastrous February figure simply confirms that we are on track to probably the worst current account deficit outcome we have ever had.

PARA.TAB: I have just heard Treasurer Willis say in the House of Representatives that this is fine because it is consistent with this disastrous forecast for 1994-95. That really is like the owners of the Titanic saying, `It is okay that the ship sunk because we expected it to sink.' This is an utterly inadequate and irresponsible response from this government. We are dealing with a situation where our foreign debt is over $160,000 million. The figure is so large that it leaves ordinary Australians totally glazed over. This is the worst per capita result in the whole world. It is a surrender of Australian sovereignty to foreign bankers. That is the fundamental problem in Australia.

Nine years ago, then Treasurer Keating talked about the dangers of Australia becoming a banana republic because of this very problem. At that stage, the current account deficit was running at only—only!—$12 billion a year. He has been talking about the current account deficit problem for nine years. Mr Keating has acknowledged this as a major problem for nine years while he has been, effectively, running this country and he has done absolutely nothing about it in that nine years. The problem has simply got worse every year.

Finally, Mr Keating last night did acknowledge that the current account deficit was the real problem with the Australian economy. We think there are a number of real problems with the Australian economy, but we welcome that Mr Keating has at least acknowledged the depth, size and magnitude of this very significant issue.

Australians really want Mr Keating to focus on all the economic problems facing this country, and they are massive. Instead, Mr Keating runs around like the Australian version of Screaming Lord Sutch, yelling and screaming about a whole lot of subjects. He cannot get his focus off Mr Howard and the coalition—he is absolutely obsessed with that—and the people of Canberra told him last Saturday that they want him to focus on these real economic problems including, most obviously, this disastrous current account deficit.

The real point is that the current account deficit figures are a symptom of our real economic problems in this country. It is not the current account deficit as such. That is the symptom of all the problems we have. They are, of course, low productivity, the lack of competitiveness of the Australian economy, our disastrously low savings rates and very high taxes, compared with the taxes paid in our region. The government insists on comparing us to this region and in this region we have the highest tax rates extant. Government debt is a major problem and a major contributor to our very low savings rates.

TAB.TAB: Of course, the most fundamental problem of all that is contributing to Australia's current account deficit problem and our incapacity to deal with it is the fact that the trade unions in this country run the industrial relations system. The Industrial Relations Reform Act has celebrated one year of existence. It was designed for, of and by the trade union movement and it is a major impediment to Australia dealing with these fundamental problems. Mr Keating now does at least acknowledge what is our real problem—the size of the current account deficit.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Certain Aspects Of Foreign Ownership Decisions in Relation to the Print Media, I wish to make an oral presentation on its final report. The committee's first report, entitled Percentage players, was tabled on 9 June 1994 and was a comprehensive response to the committee's initial terms of reference.

PARA.TAB: The committee remained in existence after presenting its first report in order to monitor a number of important developments. Additional terms of reference required the committee to consider a report of the Committee of Privileges on the Parliamentary Privilege Amendment (Enforcement of Lawful Orders) Bill 1994. Senators will recall that it proposed a mechanism for adjudicating on claims of public interest immunity by reference to the Federal Court.

The Senate will recall that a key issue in the inquiry was the refusal of the government to provide the committee with documents based on an undemonstrated claim of public interest immunity. The deputy chair of the committee, Senator Kernot, introduced a private senator's bill, the Parliamentary Privileges Amendment (Enforcement of Lawful Orders) Bill 1994, proposing a judicial mechanism for resolving such conflicts. The bill was referred to the Privileges Committee, which concluded that the bill should not be proceeded with as it was unnecessary. The Senate and its committees, in the opinion of the Privileges Committee, already possessed the powers necessary to resolve such conflicts and needed only to use them.

The committee drew attention to the usefulness of an independent arbitrator in such cases. In a subsequent report, it noted that the Acting Auditor-General had performed this role in relation to the government's refusal to table information in the Senate relating to the lease of Casselden Place. In this context, Senator Kernot's proposal for a select committee of party leaders may be a useful device to consider when the inevitable happens and the government again attempts to withhold information from the Senate or its committees.

The committee was also required to review the government's response to Percentage players and to monitor any developments in the Federal Court in INP Consortium Ltd and others v John Fairfax Holdings Ltd, formerly Tourang Ltd, and others concerning the possible use in open court of documents supplied in confidence to named counsel in that case but denied to the committee by the government. That case is shaping up as one of the longest on record. It may be many months before questions arise on the disputed documents.

It is a great disappointment that more than nine months after the presentation of Percentage players the government has not responded to the recommendations in that report. These recommendations made important suggestions for the reform of the Foreign Investment Review Board to provide for greater accountability in its decision making processes. Calls for reform in this area were not limited to the majority report. The dissenting report by ALP senators also contained recommendations for the review of FIRB processes. Three months was the standard response time agreed to by this government when it came into office. I ask where that response is.

Finally, the committee received an instruction recently from the Senate to invite the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Mr Lee) to provide the committee with any evidence of allegations of a secret deal between the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) and Mr Kerry Packer. Not surprisingly, the committee has received no response to these invitations.

The committee has discharged its original terms of reference. In light of the circumstances I have outlined, particularly the absence of a government response, there is no further justification at this time for it to continue. There is no doubt that these issues will again arise, however, and that governments will again attempt to withhold information from the Senate and its committees. The print media committee has been instrumental in clarifying the powers of committees and will no doubt be an essential point of reference when these issues are inevitably revisited.

The chairman of the committee has asked me to draw to the attention of the Senate the fact that he sent a letter yesterday to the Labor members of the committee drawing their attention to his proposal to present the final report and giving them a copy of it. Only one of the ALP members of the committee acknowledged or responded to Senator Alston's letter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.PARA: This print media inquiry came about largely as a result of a comment in a book written by Conrad Black, where he mentioned a discussion with the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in relation to the increase in foreign ownership in the Fairfax group. The phrase `balanced coverage' was used. Conrad Black subsequently admitted that perhaps it was not a wise turn of phrase, because it gave rise to the strong inference in his discussion with the Prime Minister that, provided his coverage of the political matters at that time was balanced, the Prime Minister might be disposed to increase his foreign ownership.

PARA.TAB: The question is an important one. Along the way, this inquiry really raises some very important points. One of them is the operation of the Foreign Investment Review Board. The Senate Select Committee on Certain Aspects of Foreign Ownership Decisions in Relation to the Print Media recommended that there be legislation setting up an independent statutory authority to be known as the Foreign Investment Commission, which would replace the non-statutory Foreign Investment Review Board.

The question of the foreign ownership of our newspapers is a vexed and very important one. Since the interim report by the committee, we have recently seen this matter flare again. Kerry Packer and Conrad Black are again talking about increased holdings in the Fairfax empire. This matter just will not go away. I believe that this inquiry will stand for some time as a guide to any persons who want to acquaint themselves with this very complex area.

The litigation that Senator Minchin has mentioned, which is the largest commercial case in Australia's history, revolves around just how the local bidder for the Fairfax empire was kept out. In the minute from FIRB, its expertise and financial backing were discussed in its absence. In other words, the domestic bidder was criticised during the consideration process by the Foreign Investment Review Board without any input from it or reference to it. The Australian bidder was not aware that this was going on at the time. In effect, the foreign purchaser was allowed into the marketplace because an adverse decision had been made in relation to the local bidder. That was entirely unsatisfactory. That is what the committee really seized upon in its report. It is a most important aspect. The Foreign Investment Review Board would not provide to the committee full details of its process. We could only go on the leaked minute and come to conclusions from that.

The committee also recommended that there be guidelines in relation to foreign ownership. It also recommended that the whole process be more transparent and that the issue should not be dealt with by winks, nudges and nods. The people of Australia need a more transparent process by which they can know how the foreign ownership of their press is determined. That is a very important aspect.

Senator Minchin touched eloquently on the aspect of the government holding back documents from Senate committees. During this inquiry, the government placed a brick wall in the way of the committee. It would not provide the committee with information which was essential to its inquiry. I believe it is also for this reason that this inquiry will stand, perhaps for much longer than foreign media ownership, as a guide to the operation of Senate committees and just how the executive can get in the way of an inquiry on behalf of the people via a Senate inquiry.

In that report, a good deal of material touches on that issue. Senator Kernot's private senator's bill, which was introduced as a result of this situation, highlighted a problem which still exists today; that is, what do you do with the executive when it refuses to give information to a Senate committee which is properly sought and which is essential to the inquiry before it? That problem has not been resolved. It is a matter that will not go away. I venture to say that it will be visiting us again and again. In the future, we will be visiting this report again to look at this example of where a government could stand in the way of an inquiry. For those reasons, I believe this report is a very important one that will stand the test of time.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the print media inquiry, on which Senator Minchin, Senator Ellison and I served, two aspects were looked at. The first was the question of balanced coverage in response to Mr Black's request to the Keating government to increase the Black ownership of John Fairfax from 15 to 25 per cent. Mr Black admitted that it was probably an unfortunate or not very useful word to use in terms of the arrangements that he had come to with the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in his hope and expectation that he would be able to increase his ownership of John Fairfax after the election if the Keating government were to be returned in 1993. As the Keating government was returned after the 1993 election, it became quite legitimate for us to inquire into how this was possible and whether an arrangement had been entered into before the election which then came to pass afterwards.

PARA.TAB: The issue of whether there had been so-called balanced coverage in terms of the arrangement between Mr Black and Mr Keating was only part of the committee's findings. The committee report, entitled Percentage players, really dealt with the Foreign Investment Review Board, which was one of its most important aspects. We are a capital importing nation; we always have been. The operation of the Foreign Investment Review Board does have a great impact on our development, and will for a number of years.

I believe that any foreign investment review body, committee or commission must be intensely accountable. It must be transparent in its operation. The future recommendations that the committee made in connection with the operation of the Foreign Investment Review Board or the body that deals with foreign investment in the future will have a lasting benefit to a coalition government when it has the chance to look into the guidelines that should apply. As I said, it is a very transparent process that is determined for the future. In those major areas of investment, such as agriculture, banking and aviation, where a government should argue its case in the public arena if the normal expectations of the foreign investor as determined by precedent are not met, it is something that we will certainly adhere to.

I agree that, at the end of the day, what is in the national interest is something that is determined by the government. But the government, the Treasurer and the Prime Minister must be prepared to argue their case on behalf of the government in the public arena. That certainly has not been the case in this instance and it certainly has not been the case in the past.

Senator Minchin mentioned the question of public interest immunity that was claimed by the government in terms of public officers and members of the FIRB who did not come before us and would not answer questions. We felt that Senator Kernot's private senator's bill might have resolved the problem and might have been appropriate. As Senator Minchin said, her bill went to the Privileges Committee, but it was decided by the Privileges Committee that the bill was not necessary. It was a power that the Senate had already. The exercise of the power to decide what is public interest immunity is intensely political. That power is held by any court that determines what rights a potential witness has to withhold information and not to appear.

The final point I wish to make is that the government has had nine months to respond to this report, and it has not done so. As Senator Minchin said, normally the government is given three months. It is hoped that the government will respond to the Percentage players report. It is very much an example of the fact that at least the Senate committee can make the government accountable to the extent that it has and to respond to our recommendations. I look forward to the government's response.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
