The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: CUSTOMS, EXCISE AND BOUNTY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: This bill is an omnibus measure which proposes amendments to 6 pieces of legislation for which the Australian Customs Service ("the ACS") has functional and administrative responsibility: the Customs Act 1901, the Customs Administration Act 1985, the Excise Act 1901, the Distillation Act 1901, the Spirits Act 1906 and the Bounty (Fuel Ethanol) Act 1994.

SPEECH.PARA: The principal policy initiatives reflected in the provisions of the bill effect amendments to:

PARA.TAB: (i) the main pieces of Customs legislation, to give effect to the Government's response to the Review of the Australian Customs Service (the "Conroy Review") and
(ii) the Customs Act 1901, to extend the special rules of origin preference concessions to Papua New Guinea, Fiji, and the other Forum Island Countries.

SPEECH.PARA: (1) The Review of the Australian Customs Service

This bill marks the Government's legislative response to the recommendations by the Committee of Review of the Australian Customs Service, which was tabled in the Parliament on 8 February of last year. The Committee, which was chaired by Mr Frank Conroy, with Ms Susan Ryan and Mr Ian MacPhee as members, conducted a wide ranging examination of the organisation, operations and practices of the Australian Customs Service.

The review was commissioned in May 1993, to ensure the shortcomings identified in a number of Parliamentary inquiries (the most glaring of which was the Joint Committee of Public Accounts final report in December 1992 on the Midford-Paramount case) were corrected, and at the same time, the essential strengths of Customs were enhanced.

The Conroy Committee's Report, "The Turning Point", found that substantial change in the culture and operations of Customs was needed to address deficiencies in policies, priorities and structural arrangements.

In announcing the Government's strong support of the Report's recommendations on 26 April 1994, the Government highlighted its commitment to achieving a highly efficient Customs Service more closely attuned to the needs of its private and public sector clients. The need to change the thinking, culture and operational approaches of Customs, which have been dominated by an emphasis on revenue collection and law enforcement, was accepted.

This bill is a major step by the Government to bring about that significant change to the Service, through the operation of the Customs Act 1901. It will introduce standards of procedure and practice into this Act that will make it appropriate to Australia as a major international trading nation well into the 21st Century.

It is the Government's expectation that the implementation of the reforms proposed by the bill will further assist Customs in fulfilling Australia's expectation of a more appropriate balance between Customs' community and barrier protection roles, and its trade facilitation and industry assistance functions.

The Government proposes in this bill to place judicial control over the granting of powers to search for evidence of Customs offences and the power of Customs officers to seize goods suspected of being forfeited goods.

The scope of such powers, and their potential to harm the community, were regrettably made apparent in the Report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, "The Midford Paramount Case and Related Matters".

The bill proposes two substantive reforms in this area. It not only addresses present inadequacies, but it also improves the standard for the use of such enforcement provisions beyond that presently applicable to other Australian agencies with similar enforcement powers.

The first reform is to bring the power of seizure under judicial control by requiring seizures to be sanctioned by a judicial officer having regard to the appropriateness and necessity of seizure in all the circumstances, before the seizure can be effected. This appears as the new Subdivision D of Division 1 of Part XII of the Customs Act 1901. A similar extension of judicial control over the granting of search warrants for evidence of an offences under the Customs legislation is also proposed, and appears in Subdivision C of Division 1 of Part XII of the Act.

The second substantive reform proposed in this area governs activity post-seizure. The Government considered that the corollary to reform of seizure at the front end necessitated similar reform once a seizure was effected. Hence, the provisions in Subdivisions F and G of Division 1 of Part XII of the Customs Act 1901, to make clear that one's ability to retain that which has been seized is expressly dependent upon the bringing of the proceedings which justified the seizure in the first place.

Giving effect to these two major policy reforms has involved a substantial rewrite of Division 1 of Part XII of the Customs Act 1901. That in part was made necessary because it was considered current policy on the use of search warrants by Commonwealth officers, (including the contents of the warrants and their execution) which were contained in the Crimes (Search Warrants and Powers of Arrest) Amendment 1994 Act, passed by this Parliament last year, had to be reflected in these Customs Act 1901 provisions. The provisions contained in new subdivisions A-K of Division 1 of Part XII of the Customs Act 1901, inserted by Schedule 2 of this bill, have thus been modelled with strict adherence to that precedent.

The bill also includes the structural and organisational reforms to the Australian Customs Service which were recommended in the Conroy Report, to introduce the position of Chief Executive Officer with a 5 year term of appointment (Schedules 3 and 7 of the bill refer) and to provide the Minister with an ability to give written directions to the Chief Executive Officer with respect to the general policy to be pursued in relation to the administration of the Australian Customs Service (Schedule 3 to the bill refers).

The Government accepted the Conroy Report's view that for Customs to meet the Government's industry oriented policies, a structure was required to provide the Minister with clear power to communicate policy focused directions to Customs. The amendments proposed in Schedule 3 of the bill should meet this need.
Rules of Origin Amendments

The second major policy initiative reflected in the bill concerns the extension of certain administrative elements of the rules of origin preference concessions to Fiji, Papua New Guinea, and the other Forum Island Countries.

In April 1994, Australia implemented new rules of origin legislation to give effect to the agreement reached with New Zealand in the context of the 1992 Review of Closer Economic Relations (CER) and to extend to other preference countries the administrative and technical aspects of that agree ment.

Australia has now made commitments with Fiji in respect of the rules of origin arrangements applying to the Forum Island Countries. The Australian textile, clothing and footwear industry, which is the domestic sector with the predominant interest in rules of origin arrangements relating to the Forum Island Countries, was consulted during the negotiation phase.
This bill incorporates the legislative amendments required to give effect to the new arrangements for these countries, and corrects some errors and omissions in the existing legislation.

Papua New Guinea is mentioned separately but conjointly in each case where the Forum Island Countries are mentioned because, while it is party to the South Pacific Regional Trade and Economic Cooperation Agreement (SPARTECA) between Australia and the Forum Island Countries, for customs tariff purposes it is regarded as an entity independent of the Forum Island Countries, in recognition of its status under the Papua New Guinea—Australia Trade and Commercial Relations Agreement (PATCRA). In my following comments, reference to the Forum Island Countries should accordingly be taken to include Papua New Guinea.
The new provisions for the Forum Island Countries include:
Inland freight, from the port or airport where the materials are first landed in the preference country manufacturing the goods to the factory in that country, will become allowable expenditure.

PARA.TAB: Inland freight is already an allowable expenditure where it relates to materials which originate in the preference area. The legislation will in addition recognise as allowable expenditure the inland freight component applying to materials originating from outside the preference area.

The concession on inland freight will only be available to the Forum Island Countries. It will not apply to New Zealand, Canada, Malaysia or the Developing Countries. Inland freight on the foreign content of materials will not be eligible expenditure if it occurs in Australia or in a Forum Island Country other than that Forum Island Country manufacturing the preference goods.

SPEECH.PARA: The cost of materials for manufacture of the final product will be considered to be totally of allowable expenditure where the allowable expenditure on these materials which is contributed by Australia and the Forum Island Country where the last process of manufacture occurs is at least 50 per cent. A similar provision is already available in relation to trans-Tasman trade.

The bill will remove the requirement, where New Zealand content is involved, for the Forum Island Countries to achieve at least one half of the minimum 50 per cent of the total factory cost, with the balance made up from Australia and New Zealand. Prior to duty free trans-Tasman trade, it was necessary to ensure that the Forum Island Countries were not used as a means to get goods into Australia duty free which were essentially the manufacture of New Zealand, and as such subject to an import duty. Trans-Tasman trade became duty free in 1990, so this provision no longer serves any useful purpose.
The 2 per cent margin of tolerance on the 50 per cent qualifying content requirement as agreed with New Zealand will be extended to the Forum Island Countries. This means that:

PARA.TAB: where the percentage of allowable factory or works cost for a Forum Island Country shipment of particular goods would have been 50 per cent if it had not been for some unforeseen circumstance such as a fluctuation in exchange rates which is unlikely to continue; and
the allowable factory or works cost for those goods is not less than 48 per cent

SPEECH.PARA: then for the purpose of that shipment and subsequent shipments of similar goods, affected in the same way over a specified period, the allowable factory cost will be deemed to be 50 per cent. The intention of this provision is to allow a limited period of time for adjustment where goods fail temporarily to meet the requirements because of unforeseen circumstances. It is not intended to provide a long term or a generally applicable de-facto reduction from the 50 per cent of total factory cost requirement to 48 per cent.

The bill amends the legislation to allow manufactured materials sourced wholly within a qualifying area to be included in the allowable expenditure on materials. The omission of this facility was an unintended oversight when the rules or origin legislation was put in place.

In addition, the bill makes minor technical amendments to the provision requiring artificial elements of cost to be disregarded. The provision will now relate to preference claim goods rather than materials. It will allow the cost of material to be disregarded, where they are added or attached to the preference claim goods solely for the purpose of artificially raising the allowable factory cost of the goods. The revised legislation will more accurately reflect the 1992 CER agreement on this aspect.

Except for the new provision on inland freight for Forum Island Countries, the rules of origin provisions will apply from 1 April 1994. The inland freight provision will be implemented from Royal Assent.
In addition to the above two major policy initiatives, the bill also proposes amendments to:

PARA.TAB: the Customs Act 1901, to insert new provisions to govern the movement of goods where there has been a technical breakdown of the ACS computer entry system (COMPILE) for a prolonged period;
the Customs Act 1901, to specifically exclude the making of end use Tariff Concession Orders (TCOs) and to allow for the revocation of existing end use TCOs;
the Customs Act 1901 and the Excise Act 1901, to extend the provisions governing the sale of duty free goods to passengers departing Australia by sea;

the Excise Act 1901, to allow the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy to review and replace Excise by-laws which grant an excise duty exemption to the first 30 million barrels of crude oil recovered from certain onshore and offshore fields, for a period of up to 3 years; and
the Bounty (Fuel Ethanol) Act 1994, to clarify the amounts that are available under this Act for the payment of bounty.

SPEECH.PARA: All of these proposed amendments are dealt with in detail in the Explanatory Memorandum to the bill.
Financial Impact Statement
The amendments proposed in this bill have no direct financial implications.
I commend the bill to the Senate and present the Explanatory Memorandum to the bill.
TRADE MARKS BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: The Trade Marks Bill 1995 is the result of an extensive review of Australia's trade marks legislation that takes into account the significant public comment made on the proposed reforms and draft legislation. As well as repealing the Trade Marks Act 1955, it will repeal and replace the Trade Marks Act 1994, which has not yet come into force.

SPEECH.PARA: I should imagine that many honourable senators are wondering why the Government is proposing to repeal and replace legislation that has only recently been enacted. Let me briefly explain. To enable Australia to accept the Agreement Establishing the World Trade Organization, legislation that met Australia's obligations relating to trade marks under the WTO Agreement needed to be enacted. Rather than amend the existing Trade Marks Act 1955 to meet those obligations, the Government felt that the most expedient approach would be to introduce into the Parliament the Trade Marks Bill 1994, which had been released as an exposure draft early in 1994 and was essentially WTO-consistent. However, the Government was acutely aware of the signals that this course of action might send because it would preclude the 1994 bill from reflecting the results of public comment that had been sought on the exposure draft.

When the 1994 bill was introduced, the Government took the opportunity to reiterate its publicly stated commitment to take into account public comment by introducing at the earliest opportunity appropriate amending legislation. I emphasise that this Government has always been genuine in its commitment to take into account the views of interested parties and this is reflected in this bill. However, because of the extensive nature of the changes that would be required to be made to the Trade Marks Act 1994, the Government has decided that it would be simpler and more convenient for users of the trade marks system to repeal the 1994 Act and replace it with consolidated legislation that users would find more accessible and comprehensible. The bill currently before the Senate does this.

A trade mark serves to indicate the trade origin of goods or services. By granting the owner of a registered trade mark the exclusive right to use, or authorise others to use, their trade mark, Australia's trade marks law serves two complementary objectives—first, identification and protection of a business's products and, second, protection of the consumer.

In relation to the first objective, the value of a trade mark to its owner can be enormous in terms of the reputation and goodwill associated with the trade mark. For example, in its 1994 annual report, Pacific Dunlop valued its brands, including trade marks, at $319 million. Clearly, a registered trade mark, properly managed, can become a valuable asset of a business, an asset that can be sold, franchised out, licensed or used as security. As such, adequate protection of trade marks and other valuable intellectual property is vital for all innovative Australian enterprises. As part of its reforms to encourage innovation in Australian businesses, the Government has sought to improve the overall efficiency of Australia's trade mark registration system and to meet the contemporary and future needs of Australian business.

In terms of the second objective, trade marks also provide certainty to consumers by indicating the trade source of goods or services. Through use, consumers can also come to associate a trade mark with the quality of a particular good or service. For example, referring again to the Pacific Dunlop products, the "Chesty Bond" singlet has become an Australian icon because of people's experience over many years with that particular product. Because consumers make purchasing decisions based on the trade marks associated with goods or services, trade marks legislation, as well as trade practices and related legislation, provide appropriate checks and balances to ensure that use of trade marks do not deceive or confuse consumers. Quite obviously, trade marks are a vital link between the owner of the trade mark, the owner's products, and consumers.

As Australian firms become more export-oriented, in an increasingly globalised marketplace, this link is, perhaps, even more important. International developments relating to trade marks, such as the recently concluded WTO Agreement and the World Intellectual Property Organization (WIPO) Trademark Law Treaty, reinforce the significant role that trade marks play in international trade. Against this international backdrop, several countries, including New Zealand, the United Kingdom, Germany, Switzerland, Italy and South Africa, have recently undertaken major reviews of their national trade marks law. The Government has had due regard to these developments and has sought to harmonise Australia's trade marks system, as far as practicable, with similar systems of other industrialised countries.

Since the Commonwealth first legislated on trade mark matters in 1905, there have been two other significant reviews. They occurred in 1938 and 1954, and resulted in the current Trade Marks Act 1955. In many respects this bill represents an evolution from, rather than a revolutionary change of, the 1955 Act. It refines and streamlines the current trade marks system, and updates it to reflect recent international developments. The bill implements Australia's obligations under the WTO Agreement, but its main thrust is to implement the Government's response to the July 1992 report, Recommended Changes to the Australian Trade Marks Legislation, as modified by the consultation process I have already mentioned. That report was prepared by the Working Party to Review the Trade Marks Legislation which comprised representatives from the legal and patent attorney professions, industry and government. It was asked initially to review and streamline the trade marks legislation, but as the work progressed its objectives expanded to take into account the international developments already described.

The Working Party made 57 recommendations for change to Australia's trade marks system. Except for three recommendations, relating to the so-called "association" of trade marks and the structure of the Trade Marks Register, the Working Party's recommendations were unanimous. The Government accepted those unanimous recommendations. In regard to those recommendations on which the Working Party could not agree, the Government decided that it would accept the minority recommendations of the Working Party in the interests of harmonising the law with international trends.

The bill currently before the Senate is, in many respects, the same as the Trade Marks Act 1994. I will briefly outline some of the more noteworthy features of the trade marks system that have been carried over from the 1994 Act.

As a result of the review which produced the 1955 Act the Trade Marks Register was divided, mainly it would seem to conform with the British legislation then in force and to provide for registration of certain trade marks, in Part B, for which the rights given by registration would be limited. Unlike the 1955 Act, the bill does not divide the Trade Marks Register. Under the WTO Agreement there is no distinction between trade marks with respect to the rights they acquire on registration, rather they are to be afforded a level of protection equivalent to that of current Part A registration. Despite a minority of submissions expressing concern about the Register being undivided, the Government remains convinced that the undivided Register proposed in the bill will increase the efficiency of the registration process without adversely affecting the rights of trade mark owners. An undivided Register will also harmonise Australia's trade marks law with those of other OECD countries.

The bill is expressed in terms that make it clear that there is to be a presumption of registrability when an application for registration is being examined by the Registrar of Trade Marks. This means that if there is any doubt about whether a trade mark should be registered, that doubt will be resolved in favour of the applicant, rather than against the applicant as is now the case.

The bill widens the test available for infringement of a registered trade mark. In particular, action for infringement of a trade mark will be possible when the trade mark is used without the owner's authority in association with goods or services similar to those in respect of which the trade mark is registered. At present, infringement proceedings may only be brought where the trade mark has been used without authority in association with the same goods or services for which the trade mark is registered.

A new, broader definition of what may constitute a trade mark is introduced by the bill. As a result, it will now be possible to register sounds, smells and aspects of packaging as trade marks, provided that all the other requirements for registrability are met. This change is responsive to the contemporary and developing marketing needs of business.

The bill also streamlines existing procedures under the trade marks system. The bill introduces multi-class applications, which will obviate the need to file separate applications for each class of goods or services for which registration is sought; simplified provisions for recording the assignment of trade marks; and a more streamlined method for removing unused trade marks from the Trade Marks Register. These changes will benefit users of the trade marks system through the introduction of simpler procedures that eliminate unnecessary steps, improved efficiency in the Trade Marks Office and being in tune with the realities of modern marketing.
While this bill differs from the 1994 Act mostly in matters of clarity and technical detail, there are three changes that deserve specific mention.

First, a number of submissions on the exposure draft of the 1994 bill addressed the Government's proposals for streamlining the provisions relating to the "association" of trade marks. A business's trade marks are considered "associated" when they are substantially identical or deceptively similar and are used in relation to similar goods or services. The 1955 Act requires that associated trade marks be identified as such and prohibits a bundle of associated trade marks from being split up and assigned to different people. After considering this issue further the Government has decided that it would be better to do away altogether with the concept of associated trade marks rather than retain the scheme set out in the Trade Marks Act 1994. This is in line with views expressed in submissions and is consistent with the situation in most other industrialised nations. Should a change in ownership of a trade mark result in deception or confusion, the validity of the registration of the trade mark may be challenged under other provisions of the bill which could result in the trade mark being deregistered.

Second, the bill does not include provisions relating to registration of the use of a trade mark by a person other than the trade mark owner. The bill provides that where owners of trade marks exercise control over use of their trade marks by other persons, that use can be taken to be use by the owner. This is prescribed by the WTO Agreement and can be used by trade mark owners to defend an action to deregister their trade mark on the basis that they have not used it. The WTO Agreement does not require use under the control of the owner of the trade mark to be registered. Consequently, there is little benefit in retaining additional provisions for the registration of users. This change will simplify the new trade marks legislation significantly. Recent developments in Canada and the UK are consistent with this approach.

Third, the bill carries over the significantly increased penalties for counterfeiting and forging of trade marks introduced in 1992. Consistent with current criminal law policy, the bill also applies the fault element of knowledge or recklessness to these offences, rather than strict liability or the test of "ought reasonably to have known".

In keeping with modern legislative drafting practice, the bill sets out the guiding principles and general framework of the new trade marks system, with much of the detail devolved to the regulations.

The new legislation will come into force on 1 January 1996. This will allow time for the significant administrative and other changes required as a result of the legislation to be made by users of the trade marks system and the Trade Marks Office, and enable interested parties to become more familiar with the legislation in its final form.

Throughout the review of Australia's trade marks legislation that has resulted in the bill currently before the Senate, the Government has been committed to extensive public consultation with a view to having in place the best possible registered trade marks system for Australian industry. We have placed great emphasis on getting the legislation right. Consequently, there have been extensive opportunities for public comment on the Working Party's reports and the exposure drafts of the bill and subordinate regulations and I believe that people have welcomed the opportunity to be able to contribute. Significantly, 35 public information seminars were held around Australia to explain the draft bill and its expected impact, and to receive direct feedback on the draft bill.

Receiving comments on the draft bill and regulations has been particularly helpful to the Government in developing and refining the reforms to the trade marks system, as well as improving the specific structure and wording of the legislation itself. Mr President, I would sincerely like to thank all those organisations and individuals who have contributed to this review, especially the Law Council of Australia, the Institute of Patent Attorneys of Australia, the Australian Manufacturers' Patents, Industrial Designs, Copyright & Trade Mark Association (AMPICTA) and, in particular, the individuals concerned, for giving their time and for their devotion to the job.

The implementation of this new trade marks legislation requires revision of existing practices and procedures in the Trade Marks Office, as well as major changes to the comparatively large and complex Office computer system. The estimated cost to the Trade Marks Office, which is part of the Australian Industrial Property Organisation (AIPO), of the one-off implementation activity is estimated to be in the order of $4 million. This includes the modifications to the computer system and the training of Trade Marks Office staff with respect to the new practices and procedures.

AIPO is required to recover all its costs from its fees and charges. AIPO operates on a Group 2 Trust Account arrangement and is committed to containing costs for normal operations to within inflation and to achieving productivity gains at least equal to the efficiency dividend required for the Australian Public Service. The one-off costs of implementing the new trade marks system are budgeted for the next two years. Offsetting the one-off implementation costs will be benefits to the owners and users of trade marks in having a modern trade mark registration system that conforms with Australia's international commitments and is harmonised, as far as practicable, with similar systems of other OECD countries. In the longer term, there will be savings to the Trade Marks Office in the administration of a more streamlined system.

It has been nearly 40 years since the current trade marks legislation came into force; I believe that the bill now before the Senate is a worthy successor and one that will serve and protect the interests of trade mark owners and the public well into the 21st century.
I commend the bill to the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT (DROUGHT RELIEF MEASURES) BILL 1995

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before we broke for lunch, we were discussing the Taxation Laws Amendment (Drought Relief Measures) Bill 1995. The bill is to take effect on 1 July. The government brought it forward with the idea that it may help people in the present drought situation. It does not help people in this drought season whatsoever. It may help people in a future drought, but not in the drought that we have at the moment.

PARA.TAB: The measures that this bill allows—deductibility of items such as direct drilling implements and drought bonds—will affect farmers where they have got some funds coming through. As I said before lunch, the ones that are affected by drought will not be in a position to take advantage of this—I must say—very small measure, which I will address a bit later on. They will not be able to take advantage of the measure until they get into a profitable situation again, which probably will not be until two years down the track. Those badly affected by drought will not have a farm income this year, and losses will be carried forward to next year. I would say that it will be two years before any of these benefits flow through.

Let no-one be fooled by this bill. It does not help people in this season whatsoever, even though the government likes to think that it does. The people affected by the drought will not be able to put money into drought bonds. In the short time I have got left, I will address the areas in the bill that allow income deductions for tax purposes. As I say, this will only affect the future seasons. The bill addresses fodder storage facilities for buildings or silos, and facilities to improve water storage, such as earth tanks, underground tanks or above ground tanks. It would be good to get some sort of deductibility, or extra deductibility, for those items.

The bill says that capital expenditure on water tankers is not eligible. Why not? If you set up improved water storage or on-farm storage through dams, or put windmills on bores, then the water has got to be transported somehow. It may not always be able to be transported by water pipes or rising mains out of a pump. In some cases, it would have to be transported by water tankers. As you would probably know, Mr Acting Deputy President, water tankers are not an all-purpose vehicle. Most water tankers that I know of can move water, and that is about all. They cannot move fuel, otherwise you would have contaminated water. Those sorts of things will be eligible, except for water tankers.

To get the allowance to build water storages, such as dams or water catchments, you must have in writing from an Office of Water Conservation agency or an approved farm water resource consultant a total farm plan of water catchment. I will get back to that. This bill, which shows how generous the government is to the farmers of Australia, allows for a maximum total expenditure of $50,000. That gives a maximum deductible item of $5,000—that is all. If anyone can work out a better figure than that, I invite them to tell me.

Let us go back to what I was saying about the farm plan that you must have. What sort of total farm plan for water catchment can you get for under $5,000? Or was this provision made to simply give a few jobs to some neo-greenie groups that may be qualified in that area? I can tell you that, rather than have one of those eco-nuts come along to my property, I would forgo that $5,000, if it were available. But it is not available. You have got to spend more than $5,000 on your farm plan so that you qualify to receive a maximum of $5,000 from deductions. That is the catch. I can tell you that there will not be too many who will do that.

This package is nowhere near as generous as the government would like to think it is. I had a press release from the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear) telling us how good this package is. I want to point out to the farmers of Australia that they should look before they leap. When they are thinking of spending extra money on a deductible item, they should remember that the deduction they are entitled to is, effectively, a maximum of only $5,000.
I refer to minimum tillage equipment. The bill says:

SPEECH.PARA: Equipment is minimum tillage equipment if it is for use in planting or cultivation and involves:

PARA.TAB: (a) no tillage of the soil; or
(b) tillage of the soil that does not seriously affect soil structure and that retains a high degree of organic matter or surface cover.

SPEECH.PARA: I defy anyone to come to a suitable conclusion from that definition. If you have any tillage at all, it is tillage. I would like a better definition than that. Bearing in mind the $50,000 maximum expenditure allowable to get that $5,000, I do not know of any minimum tillage equipment that you can buy for under $30,000. That is minimum size. If you go to a reasonable size which can be pulled by a normal four-wheel drive tractor on a property these days, it is $1,000; for metricated people, it is $330 per metre. So you would be looking at $50,000. That is just for the bar; it does not include the seeding equipment that goes onto it. The seeding equipment would take you up to at least $120,000 to $130,000. I ask: where is the generosity of this government? It is not there.

PARA.TAB: In conclusion, I would like to address the issue of the drought management bonds. I believe they are an effective tool in farming and as one who is very involved in farming I can recommend them. The allowable interest rate on the drought bonds will rise from 80 to 100 per cent. I believe that that is a commonsense approach. The government is showing generosity again by increasing the maximum amount each farmer can have in a farm management bond from $80,000 to $150,000. The government is taking away the withholding tax component on withdrawals. I believe that is a very good move and it is something that the farmers, through their peak bodies, have been lobbying for for a long time.

I will go back to that figure of $150,000. That is the amount farmers can have—not to spend now but to drought proof their farm—in a management bond for when the next drought comes around. How far will $150,000 go towards planting a new crop or restocking after a massive drought like that experienced in New South Wales last year and which is continuing this year? I can tell you that, from my experience, it will not go very far. We have just gone through a drought and farmers will not have the money available to put into these drought bonds. If we get a few good seasons and farmers are able to build up that $150,000 it will not go very far if we have another drought.

I believe that each farmer should have enough money in a drought bond to cover costs. Farmers are building up the money in those bonds themselves. They are not asking the government to build up that $150,000, they have to save that money themselves. I believe a good management tool for a farm that is run properly is that it should be free from asking the government or the banks for help to carry on. In areas where drought is a one-off, I believe farmers should at least have enough money to plant a crop for the next year. Farmers will never be drought free. They expect a drought every five years, every seven years or every 10 years.

My good friend Senator Tierney has told us how bad things have been in the Upper Hunter Valley for the last two, three and four years. I believe in those areas where you are likely to cop two or three droughts in a row—and this is the principle that my farm management works on—you should have enough money stored away, not to use for just anything, to carry on for two years in case something goes wrong and then you do not have to rely on the banks or the government. That amounts to a lot more than $150,000.

I believe average farmers on average size farms where they get droughts should have at least $200,000 to $250,000 each year put away. This will enable them to carry on and to plant a crop. That is not to do anything else like changing plant or financing children in tertiary studies. To be completely independent of the government you would have to work at a figure somewhere in that range. If they are looking at having money to carry on for two years in case they cop droughts two years in a row then I believe they should have around half a million dollars.

The government is not giving away anything. The bonds will be taxed in time. The money that goes into drought bonds is tax free, but when the money comes out or the farmer sells out it will be taxed. They cannot carry drought bonds when they sell out. Those drought bonds will be taxed as normal income. That is the figure the government has to work towards. Certainly, when we are in government we will work to get the figure to $500,000 per farmer.

We support the bill even though it is a small measure. It is certainly no measure at all to the people who are in drought. The ones that have had a reasonable season, like those in Western Australia, can start building their drought bonds up from $80,000 to $150,000. We welcome the investment allowance, small as it is.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the measures announced last December in the $112 million drought assistance program which is aimed at helping farmers cope with drought in the long term. The package basically included two aspects. One was the five-year, 10 per cent taxation allowance for capital expenditure of up to $50,000 a year per taxpayer on livestock, water and fodder storage facilities, water transport facilities and minimum tillage equipment. The second was the enhancement of the farm management bond scheme and IEDs, with the investment component being raised to 100 per cent and a new maximum limit on deposits of $150,000.

PARA.TAB: It always seems to me that these important agricultural matters are left to the 11th hour when we do not have enough time to debate them. The other aspect of this particular legislation is that there is nothing in it, as my good friend Senator Panizza said, for the present drought affected farmers. We are entering, certainly in the north-west of New South Wales and the south-west of Queensland, our fifth year of drought and our fifth winter of drought.

The announcement yesterday by the New South Wales government that the drought declarations for April indicated seven areas slipping back into drought shows how serious the problem is. The announcement yesterday shows that two other rural land protection boards in New South Wales were removed from the list, resulting in the percentage of the state that is drought declared rising again from 58 per cent in March to 60 per cent in April.

Despite the rain in January, which gave a lot of people, especially in the north-west of New South Wales, some hope, almost two-thirds of the state remains in drought at this time. Unfortunately, some areas of the state which had previously shown signs of recovery, including parts of the Armidale, New England, Bathurst, Bega, Carcoar, Dubbo, Glen Innes, Holbrook, Inverell, Molong and Yass rural land protection boards, have been retrospectively declared in drought from 1 March.

A critical situation certainly exists now. In terms of the sort of problems that rural Australia faces, we are really looking at the situation of, more than ever, developing two Australias—rural and regional Australia and metropolitan Australia. To a certain extent, they are possibly getting some positive benefits from the five minutes of economic sunlight that we presently have. We are told that manufacturing exports are doing well.

I saw on the front page of the Australian Financial Review yesterday that the steel division of BHP has made record profits. Hopefully, those record profits will continue even though today's current account deficit was again over $2 billion. We are seeing the sort of unique qualities of rural Australia, the sort of qualities that make up our psyche and the way we think about ourselves. The sort of society that we have developed in regional and rural Australia over a century is changing and changing irreparably. Young people in rural Australia really see no future, even if they have nothing to do with farming, in making a career in agriculture.

It is inexplicable in a nation as rich as Australia that this is happening. It is inexplicable when you consider that the fabric, development and infrastructure of rural Australia were built on agriculture and it is suffering terribly at the moment. It is suffering because, even in the best of times, there is very little money in running a farm. I can tell you that, with the sorts of pressures farmers are working under now, there is very little hope for them.

We hear all sorts of anecdotal stories—and they have to be anecdotal to hide people's identity—about what is happening when the bank statement arrives, and the stories are absolutely true. People are desperate, and they are taking desperate measures with their lives and their families' lives. It is very sad. It is sad for those of us who live on the western side of the range to be involved with and try to represent those people in the federal parliament.

I would like to make a couple of points about two aspects of the legislation. The first aspect is the qualification for exceptional circumstances. When is an area in exceptional circumstances and when is it not? The government has moved the goalposts a couple of times as to when an area qualifies for exceptional circumstances help but, at the end of the day, it is very arbitrary. We have heard from Senator Tierney—both today and before—about the Upper Hunter, a normally abundant area of New South Wales not used to drought. The question of drought or severe drought has to be approached differently in the Upper Hunter than in other areas which are not so used to good rainfall.

In the early 1970s the situation was addressed by what I believe was a more practical rural adjustment scheme. It was a depression type scheme where local advisory boards determined which areas would qualify for rural assistance. There was supervision by local practising farmers, and those supervisory boards had the ability to address questions of bank debt and whether farmers should be helped off the land. They helped some farmers to buy more land, and they certainly helped to keep food on the table. I think it was a much more practical approach to drought aid.

In terms of the government's move down the road to a more scientific approach of determining exceptional circumstances, I do not care what approach the government takes. It does not matter how the government targets help and assistance, but that is what the government is there to do and it must be done. I know that there are certain areas in New South Wales which would certainly qualify for exceptional circumstances, but that has not happened lately.

The second aspect I would like to bring to the attention of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins) is the way the drought investment allowance works. The general investment allowance which applied to farmers should never have been removed. We are looking at a situation now where the 10 per cent investment allowance is being reintroduced for specific water and fodder conservation. It is something that is beneficial, but it is only marginally beneficial because very few farmers—especially those in drought affected areas—would have the sort of cash that would make it possible for them to be in a position to invest.

It always seems to me rather strange that, in a nation that is as dependent on water as Australia, water conservation is not tax deductible in the year of expenditure. It is presently tax deductible over three years, which seems ridiculous. The only way to encourage people to invest in water conservation is to make it tax deductible and give them the investment allowance as well. That would be very advantageous to people. If the government gives up the revenue when allowing deductions over three years, why not allow the deduction over one year for a start? The government has already given up the fact that it is going to give that cash to the farmers. It should give it up at the time that gives flexibility to the farmers or the small businessmen to make a decision when it is appropriate to them.

In terms of Senator Panizza's comments about the value of this investment allowance, there is value only if a farmer has the capacity to pay. I can tell you, from personal experience and from information from people I know in farming at the moment, that there is no way in the world farmers have any money for capital expenditure, regardless of the encouragement of the investment allowance on water and especially stockfeed storage.

The only way the government can encourage these sorts of things is by tax concessions, but it must make them real, make the infrastructure that is appropriate to fodder conservation tax deductible and certainly leave the investment allowance in place. I am not looking a gift horse in the mouth because any help that farmers get is something that I applaud, but the practical advantage of this legislation is pretty small.

The final aspect is the operation of the farm management bonds and the IEDs. The IED scheme was introduced in the late 1970s. It was very advantageous in terms of making plans for an economic downturn. Again, the government is not giving up the eventual taxability of the income that is raised; it just provides an avenue for farmers to put something away for a dry day and be in a position to help themselves. I think farmers at the end of the day want that capacity. They do not want handouts. They wish to be able to control their economic circumstances as best they might.

I would like to say a couple of things about the operation of the IEDs and farm management bonds. The first is that IEDs are not available to proprietary companies. The minister wrote to me and said to me privately that not a great number of farming operations in Australia were proprietary companies—I think he said about eight per cent. He said that, in terms of the way the process operated, the government felt that the availability of IEDs to proprietary companies would provide some access for tax avoidance that might be unsatisfactory and get out of hand.

I can say from my own point of view that the old scheme of IEDs was available to proprietary companies. I am from a small family pastoral company. It was very helpful to me and, without going into the details of the 1982-83 drought, I was able to come out of it, having put money aside previously, with my debt structure exactly the same as it was when I went into it. Between 1983 and 1992, when the drought in my area started again, I was not able to put anything away because of high interest rates, reasonably low commodity prices, the collapse in wool, certainly, and not very good seasons.

The other reason I have not put anything away is that my accountant told me that it was of no value at all under the present scheme. That is not to say that I would not use a scheme that was properly set up and available to me as a primary producer to put cash in when times turn around—which hopefully they will. I ask the government to reconsider the possibility that small proprietary companies might access IEDs. My learned colleague Senator Watson, who has a very good understanding of the accountancy profession, understands that they are of value.

The other thing I would like the government to consider is what Senator Panizza said: $150,000 does sound a lot to the man in the street as to the sort of money that could be put aside for difficult times in farming. But farming today is very capital intensive. You are dealing with very large costs. You have very large borrowings in the main and, of course, the debt that is overhanging rural Australia at the moment is absolutely unsustainable. That is something that this government will have to address—and when we are in government we will have to address—to look at some way of handling the level of debt that farming is presently labouring under.

In terms of the capacity to plan for the future, $150,000 is generally not enough for farmers to have. It does not provide the sort of assistance needed by small family farming companies, which are not as uncommon as the minister indicated to me. As I said, they probably make up eight or 10 per cent of farming operations.

I support these measures. It is interesting that a lot of the advantages and practical help that the farming community had before 1983 have been systematically taken away. This is a real recognition that the help that was provided, especially with IEDs, was absolutely essential. It is interesting that IEDs are now being reintroduced. I think that is pretty indicative of a government that is very uncountry and very unsympathetic to country people and their concerns. To be political, you only have to look at the New South Wales result to see that the National Party's vote in the north, the west and the central part of New South Wales held up very well because people in those areas are very concerned about the sorts of things that the National Party is concerned about.

Labor does not have people who come from the western side of the range. That does not just apply in New South Wales. Labor is not sympathetic to country people and country concerns. We must have measures introduced that provide farmers and rural communities with a capacity to survive. One thing that is very clear, unfortunately, is that they are not going to get that sort of help from a government that is headed by a Prime Minister who has the audacity to say that this has been the best year since the war.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe there was a request from Senator Gibson for some information about a matter. Senator, I hope I will be able to assist you with some information that has been given to me at this point.

PARA.TAB: Expenditure of $3,000 or more on a particular item will qualify for the drought investment allowance. The opposition was concerned about what might constitute an item for this purpose. The question of what constitutes a single unit of property is an old issue, not a new one raised by this bill. The courts have ruled on this question in the past in relation to other similar investment allowances. Those rulings apply to the words of this bill so farmers will have the benefit of many established rulings.

Those court decisions suggest that a unit of property in its own right is one that has functional completeness. They are the words of judges. I pass those words on to you because they are from the court ruling but I suspect that they can be understood to mean able to complete the function. For example, in Tully's case, a pumping station was held to be a single unit of property even though it was made up of an electric motor, starter and other parts.

That does not mean a whole project is always a single unit of property though. A farmer might plan a pumped bore, several dams and a system of pumps and lined channels to move water to where it is most needed. It is likely there will be several units of property in that case; that is, the pumped bore, each separate dam and the system of pumps and lined channels. It is likely that they would be separate units. But it is unlikely that the bore with its pump and windmill would be more than a single unit of property. I hope that assists you, senator.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.
Consideration resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the debate was interrupted for the lunch time debate, the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction (Senator Schacht) was explaining to the Senate the circumstances in which under these rules different classes of taxpayers could claim, in terms of the expense being incurred other than just being paid. I would appreciate it if the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley) would continue that presentation to facilitate our understanding of this issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Watson, I understand this is further to the question asked by Senator Harradine about the meaning of `incurred'. This bill does not deal with the timing of deductions, nor does it change the meaning of the word `incurred'. It uses exactly the same words as the current legislation. As indicated earlier, if, contrary to the drafter's intention, this bill results in a change on this point, we will correct the position. So the clear understanding is that there is no change to the meaning of `incurred'.

PARA.TAB: Senator, you specifically asked about whether an expense is deductible once a liability arises or only when it is paid. Your question related to a medical practitioner. As indicated earlier, for a medical practitioner, or indeed for any income which is returned on an accrual basis, the answer is beyond doubt. You can deduct the expense once you have a presently existing liability. However, the position for expenses which are related to income which is only included in assessable income once the income is received, known as cash basis income, is not so clear. It is commonly understood, and there is some judicial authority for the position, that in some cases the deduction has only been incurred and is only deductible once it has been paid.
In the English case of Inland Revenue Commissioners v. Morrison, Lord Clyde said:

SPEECH.PARA: The two alternative modes of computation are known as the `cash' basis mode and the `earnings' basis mode. According to the first, the profits of the business are estimated according to the excess of the actual cash receipts during the year over the cash outlays and expenses actually disbursed or paid during the year.

Similarly, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal decided last year in case 49/94 94 ATC 429 that a deduction was not available for telephone expenses relating to a bill paid on 4 July, after the relevant year of income, as the applicant had been taxed on a cash rather than an accrual basis.

PARA.TAB: However, in contrast to this position, it is also argued that `incurred' does not have a different meaning in this context and that such expenses can be claimed earlier; namely, when the liability arises. This issue is currently being looked at by the tax law improvement team responsible for rewriting the general deduction provisions, including section 51(1). Any changes will be likely to be before the parliament in November, but I am not in a position to say what, if any, changes will be made on this point.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a number of us who take a different view from that which has been submitted by the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley). My understanding has always been that section 51, which is the general deduction section, stands alone, irrespective of whether a person is in business or a professional person, or whether they return their income on a cash or accrual basis. However, I do acknowledge that there are certain circumstances in which the ability of various classes of people—particularly, for example, certain employees—to claim work expenses on an incurred basis may be restricted. Certainly in the case that I gave of the doctor, there is no doubt. It may help to clarify the position if the minister explained the class or occupation of the person who was involved in the particular case that she presented to substantiate her argument.

—I would be interested in the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley) referring to Australian High Court cases—she has given an example of a British case. May I suggest that she seeks advice and enlightens the Senate as to what High Court cases there may have been in Australia which define the question of when an expense is incurred. Maybe she should think of the New Zealand Flax Investments case, the Ronpibon Tin case or some other cases. But I concur with what Senator Watson said. We appear now to have a major departure from what has been considered to be the taxpayer's case; namely, that you have incurred expenses when you have a liability to pay them.
—That's what section 51 says.

—As Senator Watson says, that is what section 51 indicates. We have reached the stage where it is very interesting. The minister is saying that this legislation will not change the law. We are being told her interpretation of the law is different from what most accountants would consider to be the case.

—This is an important issue because it does have the potential to dramatically delay certain types of expenditure, depending on where you draw the line in terms of the classes of taxpayers you are going to regard as being eligible to deduct on the basis of incurred liability vis-a-vis those who are going to be allowed to deduct work related expenses in terms of the requirement of having to be paid. While section 51 may be subject to a further substantiation rewrite, I do think this issue should be clarified perhaps a little more before we move to November when the next tranche of the IAA rewrite is likely to be before the parliament.

PARA.TAB: May I also use this opportunity of requesting that the government, when it does rewrite section 51, takes cognisance of the fact that nowadays most income streams are subject to tax either on account of income or on account of capital gains. One of the reasons why Australian companies, for example, have a higher exposure to income tax than other companies around the world is the fact that Australian law denies quite a significant range of expenditure, particularly start-up type expenditure and certain environmental expenditure, deductibility on either the capital or current account.

Section 51, which is the general deduction section, was drawn up at a time before we had capital gains, so we do not appear to have a complementary section 51 which was drawn up in the environment of a tax on income regime, as applied to a regime for capital gains. So I urge the government to take these matters into consideration when it next focuses its attention on the rewrite of section 51 of the Income Tax Assessment Act general deduction provision.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —In answer to Senator Harradine's question, I am advised that there are no Australian High Court cases on deductibility for a cash basis taxpayer.
—That is not what I said.

—Can I just go on, Senator Harradine, because I would like to assist both of you as much as I can. More importantly, section 51 has not been reviewed as part of this bill. It is a matter that is relevant for discussion when the deduction provisions are rewritten. That is not relevant to this bill. I do want to advise you that the points you have both made will be very much considered as part of the rewrite of the deductions provisions.

—For completeness, I really do need to remind the Senate that I did not ask the Minister for Family Services to address her mind to the High Court cases which related to tax deductibility. Is there anyone around who would say that I did? What I did ask was that Senator Crowley turn her mind to the High Court cases which dealt with the question of when an expense is incurred. That is, I believe, relevant to this situation.

PARA.TAB: As I understand it, the gravamen of those decisions was that an expense is incurred when you have a liability to pay. If that is the case and if you have a liability to pay when that matter arises, that is a question which needs to be considered for the purpose of this discussion now. I am not suggesting that is something that we should accept necessarily. From what is being said here and now, I assume, unless I am corrected, that tax agents can continue what they have been doing for their clients until now—that is, to claim deductions for expenses incurred during the relevant financial year but not necessarily paid for. I assume that that is what the minister is saying. If that is the case, then we can revisit it again when the government rewrites section 51 in November.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, that is the case. I am advised that there is no change. Things will continue as they are at the moment. I would hate for Senator Harradine to think that there was any effort to misunderstand him or to get him wrong; I was simply reporting what the officers could be sure of. I can assure him that I cannot recall to mind recent or even distant rulings or matters on taxation from the High Court, but I think I have conveyed to the Senate that the points raised by both senators will certainly be part of the consideration by the officers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Schedule 1, page 51, proposed Schedule 2B to the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936, Division 5, Written Evidence, omit proposed subsections 5-4(2) and (3), substitute the following subsection:
"(2) The records that you may use to substantiate your claims for such expenses include the following:

TAB.TAB: (a)any documents that are relevant for the purpose of ascertaining your income and expenditure;

(b)documents containing the particulars of any election, estimate, determination or calculation made by you under this Act and, in the case of an estimate, determination or calculation, particulars showing the basis on which and the method by which, the estimate, determination or calculation was made.".

SPEECH.PARA: I guess it has been written in plain English from the kind of wording that existed in section 262A under the current Income Tax Assessment Act. It is basically aiming towards some sort of parity between ordinary taxpayers and corporations and companies in relation to what is currently required in record keeping.

PARA.TAB: As I noted in my speech during the second reading debate, we are putting up this amendment to put business and ordinary taxpayers on a more equal footing. It was only recently that the requirement for taxpayers to hold onto receipts was reduced to 3 1/2 years. The idea now is to extend the requirement for wage and salary earners to hang on to their receipts for five years. I disagree with cutting the time business has to save its documentation to five years. This equalisation goes in the wrong direction.

Wage earners move and many of them rent houses. It is not uncommon for them to lose receipts. It is not uncommon for them not to know that they have to save receipts or for how long they must save them. Most taxpayers are not cheats. Those who are will usually cheat each year. If a computer throws up a name as questionable and that person's last tax year is audited and found okay, it is more likely that their claim of two, three or five years ago was okay even if they do not have their receipts any more. It is unlikely that they have cheated a few years back, destroyed their receipts and now behave as angels as cover. This is the assumption of the tax office—an assumption that is being built into tax law with this legislation. It is a sort of guilty until proven innocent system and it is up to the taxpayer to prove that they are innocent for many years to come, unfortunately.

In addition, we see the case where all sorts of things are required of documents that are simply not provided on real documents really received in the real world. We do not ask this of business. The tax office accepts that normal documents in the form normally received are either good enough or not good enough to substantiate claims. The Australian Taxation Office does not require additional information on special forms not normally provided by sellers and will accept normal ordinary items, such as cancelled cheques and so on, for the purpose of substantiation.

Normal PAYE taxpayers, if they make claims, will have an idea that they have to substantiate the claims. But, realistically, how many will know that ordinary receipts, cancelled cheques and so on that would be standard accounting records, are good enough to substantiate business claims but are not good enough to substantiate the claims of potential horrible tax-cheating PAYE workers? How many will know the hoops they need to jump through to make it acceptable? Why is it that the letter of the law makes rationality and sanity disappear unless the ATO decides to use its discretion to ignore the law?

We see in the Tax Law Improvement (Substantiation) Bill no move to substantially improve tax law; it is just rewriting it to make the bad laws crystal clear. Yet we see an extension of the period which this bad substantiation law applies to ordinary PAYE workers. It is wrong. If our amendments are not accepted, we will not be able to support the bill.

I have mentioned before that our preference with taxation is that we ought to be reviewing our taxation system. The report the ACTU produced and then did not publish last year clearly said that our current tax system is aiding the growing gap between rich and poor in Australia. We would strongly support the review of our tax laws in Australia. But if we are simply clarifying the English of a very flawed law, and a law that not only creates a greater tax burden in reality for the people on the lower end of the scale but also requires them to substantiate it for years after, all we are doing is making it even tougher for us to then argue that we ought to look at the tax system again. Someone will say, `We spent all this time in 1995 and 1996 rewriting the tax law. Now you want to look at it again?' The answer is yes. We ought to be looking at the tax system in terms of its fairness, its ability to be implemented and its actual impact on the average person.

We see in this bill no move to substantially improve tax law; it is just rewriting it to make the bad laws crystal clear. Our amendment is simple: it eliminates the plain language requirement for documentation that is unlikely to be obtained by taxpayers from ordinary sellers in ordinary business. It uses the words from section 262A(2) to substitute the substantiation requirements business must meet. This seems a fair approach to us.

The Taxation Accountants Association, which has lobbied heavily for real reform, is delighted with the proposed change. We feel it is the minimum that should be done to eliminate the worst aspects of unreasonable compliance requirements for ordinary people. We had some examples given by the parliamentary secretary when he was in the duty minister's position earlier. He said that this will mean that there will be unsubstantiated areas. He gave an example of the air trip which we keep talking about. This is a very famous air trip by now.

But the reality is that substantiation would still be required. Nothing in section 262A says that people do not have to substantiate claims. If there were such a flawed way of substantiating claims, why is it that it is suitable to substantiate the claims of business? Where is this flaw in relation to business that is so gross in relation to ordinary taxpayers? If section 262A is a means by which business can avoid substantiating claims, or can falsify records or can do something that the average taxpayer cannot avoid doing, then there must be something wrong with that and perhaps we ought to address that.

To say that that is okay for business or that the tax office does not have the ability to consider whether documents used for substantiation are suitable to substantiate a claim and to make that decision creates a problem. Once again it is throwing back that blame onto the individual and that is the wrong way to go. We may well be saving money, supposedly, in the number of personnel who are required to administer the tax act—I am not sure what the personnel numbers are now—but we are leaving a whole lot of people terrorised at the possibility that they may have self-assessed incorrectly. There is a fair bet that that will impact on what people are prepared to claim, even if they are legitimate claims. This is and could well be interpreted by a reasonable person as a backdoor way of reducing people's legitimate claims and saving money in terms of legitimate tax rebates for the ordinary taxpayer.

This amendment does not support tax cheats. The onus of proof still remains on the taxpayers, who must substantiate their claims. It eliminates the requirement for documentation of sorts and in forms which are not normally received. Documentation still must be produced, but ordinary documentation—any documentation that supports the claim—becomes permissible. We feel that with this amendment this bill actually has some power to improve tax regulations and to make them much more rational. Ordinary taxpayers are certain to find that a welcome relief. Without it, it leaves the taxpayer in a worse situation with increased time for prosecution if unreasonable demands are not met.

If this is the vanguard of what we will see in a larger tax bill which deals with other aspects, then it would appear to have a certain attraction. Yes, it simplifies the language. But if this is the general principle, that self-assessment becomes more of the norm in the administration, and the possibility of computer-based auditing becomes more and more a part of our society, then I do not know whether it is the kind of society that I would like to live in. We have to look at the implications for ordinary Australians and whether or not the client—that is, the average taxpayer—will like this and feel that it is fair when it is presented to them as a fait accompli.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a great deal of sympathy with the comments of Senator Margetts, particularly her latter ones. However, the coalition has some difficulty in agreeing to her amendment. Unfortunately, the amendment does not include the whole of section 262A. For instance, section 262A(1) is also relevant. For the amendment to have any semblance of acceptance, that section really should have been included as part of your amendment. I consider the equivalent of section 262(1) to be a significant omission.

PARA.TAB: I note that Senator Margetts does have support from the National Tax Agents Association in terms of this amendment. But I am concerned that even in subsection (6) there is a reference to income, while this substantiation rewrite before the committee is essentially directed to work related expenses; it has no relevance to income at all.

Further, in subsection (6) I am concerned about the implications of the word `estimate'. If we were to accept documents which permit estimates, for example, for work related expenses, then the Senate would completely change the whole concept of substantiation. I think substantiation was introduced about seven to eight years ago to put, perhaps, a little more discipline into the deductibility process. Senator Margetts might recall that I had some particular problems with those original provisions. In fact, I think there is still a section there—the genesis of which came from my private member's bill. The Senate should note that that section has not been changed as a result of these substantiation requirements. In fact, it is still a central feature. But acceptance of a concept of documents that provide an estimate that are suitable to satisfy the substantiation requirements will effectively wipe out and negate what has been intended by this particular bill.

I also think it is opportune to refer to a press release issued by the National Tax Agents Association today, 30 March. I regret the timing of this particular release and regret the venom of the attack towards my leader, John Howard. Had perhaps Mr Ray Regan, who is the President of the National Tax Agents Association, withheld that press release until the conclusion of the debate today, he might have understood much more clearly the position of the opposition and the manner in which it has addressed these issues in this substantiation bill now before the committee.

Mr Regan has done a great job of marshalling resources and using those resources to focus attention on a number of very important tax issues. One always has to be careful when entering into the realms of politics since we do not always get our own way 100 per cent. Most of us would have left this place very early in our lives if we required 100 per cent acceptance of all our ideas. This place is a great forum for compromise, for the floating of ideas. I hope that in future the remarks will be less politically targeted and made at a time after the party has time to consider all the relevant issues—that time being, I believe, at the conclusion of this particular debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats were at first favourably disposed towards this amendment. Certainly the principle is right—that individual taxpayers should be treated in a similar way to the way corporations and other business taxpayers are treated.

PARA.TAB: However, we also take note of the points that Senator Watson has made. In particular, we are concerned about subsection (b) to clause 2 that is sought to be substituted for the existing clauses in the bill. I find it difficult to say that I would be prepared to accept `estimates', and I do not quite know what `election' means. `Any election, estimate, determination or calculation' seems to be a little bit tougher, a little bit more accurate and a little bit more rigorous. But I find it difficult to say that documents containing the particulars of an estimate should be admitted to substantiation.

I suppose one could argue that they could go some way towards substantiation and need not be the sole supporting document. But I cannot help feeling that it would loosen the system at this stage to an unacceptable degree. I believe that it would need further detailed consideration before this amendment could be supported. Accordingly, the Democrats will not be supporting this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know that Senator Harradine would like to add his voice to this debate, and I welcome that. But I would just explain, the reality is that Senator Watson has said it would be more useful if it included 262A(1), which is mainly about overseas banking—

—No. A person must keep records; subject to the section, a person carrying on a business must keep records that record and explain all transactions and other acts engaged in by that person that are relevant for any purpose of this act or for these particular sections. That is the matter that I was referring to.
—The point that I was going to make was that, in reality, the wording from our section (b) of the amendment was exactly from the act, which says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . documents containing the particulars of any election, estimate, determination or calculation made by the person . . .

This is in the existing act. The reality is that it would not weaken that. It is simply that this amendment does not take away anything else that is written in the current act. The only thing it does which is different is in relation to documents to be kept. Perhaps Senator Watson could enlighten us and tell us where that is actually written into the current act, and where this change that I am suggesting will write that out, that documents ought to be kept.

PARA.TAB: The reality is, by including this proposed amendment, I have not weakened the current act if it is not taking out that statement, `the documents need to be kept'. As far as I can see, it does not do that. It is simply using the words from the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936. So for Senator Spindler's point of view, that is nothing different from what exists already. If Senator Watson could point out to me, under the proposed act, where I have taken out that requirement, I will be happy to be advised.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to ask the government a question. I am attracted to Senator Margetts's proposition precisely because, as I read it, (b) is a straight take from the current legislation. We were told by the government—in fact, we were told in the second reading speech—that no taxpayer would be disadvantaged by this piece of legislation. We have been told that these are just plain language pieces of legislation which will make it easier for everybody.

PARA.TAB: We have already congratulated the government and the department for that consideration. I repeat: I congratulate the government for going along this line. A tremendous amount of work has been done by the government, by the ATO and by the committee along these lines. The reason I was inclined to support the proposition that has been put forward by Senator Margetts was precisely that it seems to me on the face of it that the plain words in 5-4 are more stringent upon taxpayers than the current provisions. I simply raise that with the government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Through you, Madam Chair, I was going to suggest that Senator Watson might be interested in adding the line, if that would make this acceptable, that he feels is left out, which actually is not in the current act from what I can see. If he would like to add that to make it stronger we would be happy to look at that and support it. I agree that we have not had enough time to look at the whole package and that we are dealing with something that may have big implications. If Senator Watson is worried about a line that means that people have an obligation to keep records, I cannot see it in the new act. If we add it in and he feels it makes it stronger, then we are happy to look at it.

—My comments were directed at the requirements under section 262A which involve the keeping of records. They involve sections 262A(1),(2),(3), (4), (4)A and 5. Senator Margetts has drawn from only part of those subsections and then only a portion of subsection (2). That, however, is not the main thrust of my criticism. My main criticism for rejecting the amendment is the emphasis that this shorthand version of section 262A(2) puts on the word `estimate'—`documents relating to an estimate or a determination of a calculation'.
