PARA.TAB: The WA Greens are applying that business concept to work related expenses, but in the context of a business, section 262A(2) is directed towards, for example, estimating the life of assets. One opinion might be that they will last for 20 years; another opinion could be 10 years. So the business has to keep documents which show the estimated life according to some engineering criteria or how long the plant is going to work those particular assets—say, a one, two or three shift operation which can have great relevance to the estimate of the working life. The claim for depreciation is then determined. The focus, however, that I believe is implied as a result of this wording by use of the word `estimate' is that all a taxpayer has to do is to estimate his work expenses. This is a different context in which section 262A is worded if you read section 262A as a whole.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true that this was taken from the business income assessment act. It says that `a person carrying on a business must keep records that record and explain all transactions and other acts engaged in by the person that are relevant for the purpose of this act'. So this has not changed either.
—That is not in yours.

—It is not in mine, no. What would you say? `Subject to this section a person who is a taxpayer must keep records that record and explain all transaction and other acts engaged in by the person that are relevant for the purposes of this act'? The tax department might be very pleased about this but is this what you would really want to see in terms of ordinary taxpayers? Is this the sort of general feeling that we are heading towards? Is this where you want people to be?

—Certainly that would go some way towards overcoming my objections. I appreciate your point of view, but the consequences of those words `estimate' and `determination' can be so interpreted as to completely overthrow the whole of the substantiation requirements that were set in concrete some eight years ago. Under these simplification proposals there has been an attempt to reduce compliance costs and to simplify the English. In that process there is a degree of unhappiness which has been expressed during the very long debate today. Some of those concerns hopefully will be further addressed when the task force rewrites section 51, particularly if the tax office and the government are good enough to take up the concerns that I have raised in this debate today. But I am still not in a position to be able to support the WA Green's amendment because of the consequences it may have overall for substantiation.

—Perhaps we might move some way towards a resolution, if a resolution is possible. In reality it would be difficult to expect any PAYE taxpayer to keep all records. It would be a total nightmare and a huge cost for society if we kept records of everything and if there might be a consequence for not keeping all records of everything. Maybe the wording is that a person wishing to make deductions must keep all relevant records of those proposed deductions or whatever. We understand that for a person running a business it is normal accounting procedure to keep records. But what you are saying concerns me—that perhaps the government would like to see PAYE tax become exactly like business tax and that it is fair and equitable to treat PAYE taxpayers in exactly the same way as business is treated, when in reality people are not there to make money, they are there just to earning a living and do the normal things people do.

PARA.TAB: If you start putting exactly the same requirements on PAYE taxpayers that you put on business it will be bizarre and unworkable. How would you ever enforce a requirement for everybody to keep records about every tax transaction? We either agree with the government that in the interests of so-called simplicity we build up a system of supposed equity between business and PAYE taxpayers or we accept the reality that this may not be a fair thing to do to average people, whose main role in life is earning a living for themselves and their family or perhaps doing other more interesting things with their life.

They do not want to spend their entire life being in terror of the tax department for every record it keeps. It is reasonable to expect them to keep records of those things for which they expect to gain a deduction. It is reasonable for them to pay tax and it is reasonable for them to be required to substantiate those claims for which they claim a deduction, but I personally do not think it is reasonable to require a PAYE taxpayer to keep all records of all transactions because there are not enough cardboard boxes in Australia to do that. It is ridiculous to expect all taxpayers to carry on in that way.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened for some time as the issue has been debated across the end of the chamber between representatives of the various parties. Senator Watson has shown a pretty good grasp of this issue. On the general issues being raised by Senator Margetts, we want to put on the record the government's attitude to her suggestions and amendments. She asserts that the requirement of keeping records on salary and wage earners is more onerous than it is for business. This is nonsense. Senator Margetts has quoted from section 262(2)A1 of the Income Tax Assessment Act, apparently without appreciating its significance. That subsection sets out the basic record-keeping requirements for business. It requires a person carrying on business to keep records that record and explain all transactions and other acts engaged in by the person that are relevant for any purpose of the act.

PARA.TAB: This is a very comprehensive obligation—far more comprehensive than for ordinary taxpayers—and recognises that businesses, as a matter of course, need to keep detailed and adequate records as a matter of good business practice. That is quite different from the limited record-keeping requirements that the bill will impose on salary and wage earners in respect of some but not all of their claims for deductions.

Senator Margetts also appears not to understand the importance to taxpayers of the specific written evidence requirements contained in the substantiation rules. Under this bill and the existing law, taxpayers know what evidence will be accepted by the commissioner as a matter of course and without argument as to adequacy. That is very important because it gives taxpayers the certainty they need to be able to conclude their tax affairs.

However, the government recognises that it is not possible to comprehensibly prescribe an absolute rule that will cover all situations. The government understands that suppliers do not alway give taxpayers adequate receipts. The government understands that documents are sometimes lost. That is why the government amended the substantiation provisions in 1991: to give the commissioner discretion to look at other evidence to establish that an expense has been incurred and is deductible. The government is further amending that discretion by this bill to remove any restriction on taxpayers accessing that discretion.

Senator Margetts wants to remove that first limb of the substantiation rules so that taxpayers and the commissioner of taxation will have no clear statement of what evidence should be accepted without challenge to its adequacy. The Greens would get no thanks from Australian taxpayers for that change if it were carried. Taxpayers would be thrown into using their own resources to establish the adequacy of their evidence. No doubt the commissioner would be required to issue rulings about what evidence would be accepted without challenge. I suspect they would be in the same terms as the requirements in the bill.

Senator Margetts should realise also that by converting very clear evidentiary rules to fuzzy law statements greater reliance is thrown on the courts to interpret the rules. Going to tribunals and courts is an expensive matter. It would no doubt be welcomed in spades by the legal profession, but I do not think it would be welcome by the rest of us Australians as it would serve to only increase taxpayer compliance costs.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot believe what I heard from Senator Margetts during her last delivery about the way we should treat PAYE people and others in business. It is not only nonsense, as the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction (Senator Schacht) said; it is totally ridiculous. Basically, whether we are in business or pay PAYE tax, at the end of the day we are all taxpayers. Starting with big business, big business has shareholders. Small companies have shareholders. Small businesses have partners. In the final analysis we are all taxpayers, so substantiation, I believe, should be treated the same.

PARA.TAB: One of Senator Margetts's conclusions is that there would not be enough cardboard boxes. What a ridiculous suggestion that is. I think virtually every home has a computer. That can store whatever evidence or records people may need, and they can do a print-out when they need one. Senator Harradine is shaking his head, but I do not know of too many households that do not have some sort of computer. Kids' computers can be used—

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the poor people?
—I can tell Senator Margetts that a lot people richer or poorer than me have computers. I have seen that.
—Your definition and theirs of `poor' is quite different.

—Senator West has commented on this, too. If people do not have a computer, they can use ordinary exercise books. Has Senator Margetts heard of those? Ordinary cash books are available and will last 20 years. They might cost $25. They are around. Do not be so stupid when making those interjections.
—That is a bit unparliamentary.
—Being stupid is not unparliamentary. Senator Spindler does it every day.
—Can we just get back to the bill?
—Yes, I am getting back to the bill.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Reynolds)—Senator Panizza, I think it would be preferable not to use that kind of inflammatory language about honourable senators in this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Temporary Chair, I take your ruling. Generally, it is easy and simple to keep records. Anyone can do it. Furthermore, I believe that ordinary PAYE taxpayers have more time on their hands than people in business, especially in relation to small business. Let no-one argue with that point: PAYE taxpayers have more time on their hands. Senator Schacht, I do not think, has been in business of any kind, so he would not know. Generally small businesses do not have as much time. I am referring to the very smallest of businesses at present—the sort of business run by a husband and wife with the kids helping out on Saturday mornings. It is not all rosy. The minister is shaking his head, but I can tell him that—
—I am not shaking my head about that. I just wish you would finish.

—I will finish when I am ready to finish, Minister. I, having been in business for most of my life, cannot sit here and listen to the rubbish coming from the other side. Being in small business is not all that rosy. I will say it again: PAYE taxpayers have more time on their hands to deal with this sort of thing. A husband and wife running a small business with their kids helping them on Saturday mornings work far longer hours than anyone on PAYE.

PARA.TAB: Senator Margetts has also never been in business. All she has done with her green movement in WA, especially amongst the foresters, is bring down business. That is what she has done. The unfortunate thing is that she was elected to this place with the help of our preferences. Hopefully, next time round it will be different.

I am telling the Senate that those types of businesses have far less time to keep records. The government has imposed heavy substantiation and reporting rules on small business. So Senator Margetts should not come in here and give us that sort of stupid argument. It is totally wrong. I am certainly happy that the government is not listening to it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Temporary Chair, I raise a point of order. I suggest you ask Senator Panizza to withdraw `stupid'. I feel offended by it.

—I was listening very carefully. Senator Panizza did refer to a `stupid argument'. I made the point earlier to Senator Panizza that it would be preferable not to use inflammatory language and to get on with the debate, which I think the minister has indicated he is anxious to see.

—There are a few issues here. Senator Panizza's definition of `poor' is certainly different from mine. We are talking about a whole lot of people. We have a growing number of working poor in Australia. We have not just the unemployed; we have a growing number of working poor. Statistics certainly show that more and more people are scraping to survive. Some of them have two part-time jobs, which means they have to do things like substantiate travel claims between one part-time job and another. It is not as easy as Senator Panizza suggests. People in the rest of the world are not sitting back on their rear ends using tax as their new family hobby. I am sure people have other things they would prefer to do with their lives.

PARA.TAB: There is another point here. A lot of people in Australia have a computer, but under these new rules, the tax office would not accept claims on computer. The reality is that you would still have to have these documents. The question I ask both the government and Senator Panizza, if he knows, is: what will be the actual compliance cost for small business? We all say that we are concerned about costs for small business when there will be this extra concern by PAYE taxpayers to make sure that all this information is available for those businesses which normally do not provide receipts which have a lot of this information.

Has anybody done some sort of analysis, has the government done some sort of costing, of what the compliance cost for small business will be? We have talked about tiny changes in greenhouse gas and we have heard the opposition has been jumping up and down very vociferously. But this is going to have a very large impact, I would say, on the compliance costs for small business. We have had various debates about tiny increases in taxes, but in reality, if PAYE taxpayers have to require this kind of detailed substantiation to be written in, they are going to be asking for it at the point of sale in most cases. If anyone can give me information that shows me how much small businesses will be required to pay to comply with the extra requests that are going to be made to try to get all of this information at the point of sale, perhaps I might be more relieved about the implications.
Amendment negatived.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to the key principles at section 2-1 of division 2. Under these new substantiation requirements, for some expenses of travel you need to keep travel records, et cetera. If the only work expenses claimed total $300 or less, does that imply that people who are engaged as, say, welders or carpenters automatically can claim $300 without substantiation, or does one have to have some other proof? For some people, it could read that there is an automatic work related expense. Providing you do not receive $300, then you can claim automatically $300.

PARA.TAB: Furthermore, we note that certain transport payments do not have to be substantiated. I believe this is unfortunate. Depending on your occupation, some people do not have to substantiate at all whereas others have to substantiate in great detail. Can the minister tell me, if at the present time I was preparing a tax return, what would be the rate of expense I could claim under the transport award payment, because there is some doubt about the amount.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —You cannot automatically claim up to $300. I believe there is a note on page 38 of the bill that makes that clear. In answer to your second question, I have got as far as that it depends under which award.

—I understand that a number of these awards have not been updated, so there is some doubt, so far as taxpayers are concerned, as to what amount they should actually be claiming. I am asking the tax office if it could, for example, give me a selection of awards it is familiar with as to what amount a person can claim in the year 1994-95 in relation to a transport award payment. There is some doubt because these figures have not been updated as to the accepted deduction amount.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that taxpayers can only claim what was payable in 1986. If taxpayers are uncertain of the award rate, they can contact their employer or union for the relevant details. I cannot give you any information that you just asked for, Senator.

—Has the tax office, in its attempt to assist taxpayers correctly claim for expenses, prepared a list of deduction items under the various transport awards? These entitlements do not appear to have been indexed. The amount that the tax office tells us we can claim as a deduction under this particular provision is the amount that was set in 1986. Given that a lot of people would have entered vocations after that date, would it be possible for the tax office to provide a schedule outlining the various deductible items that people can claim under this particular provision?

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that it is not possible to provide that list. I believe the tax office has forwarded a list of the top 50 awards, but there are very many more than that, so a comprehensive list is not available.
—Would it be possible to table that list in the committee?
—I am advised that nobody has such a list with them, but we would certainly be able to get one and provide it to you as soon as possible.

—I refer to section 4-4. This relates to the five-year period for the retention of records. This time period does tend to favour the taxpayer who lodges late as opposed to a taxpayer who lodges his return earlier. I am concerned about the fairness or logic of such a concession going to taxpayers who have an ability to delay the lodgement of their return as compared with a taxpayer who lodges before or on time for that particular status of taxpayer. It may be that a more suitable time is one month after the end of the financial year.

PARA.TAB: Can the minister explain the rationale behind this particular provision that favours a person in terms of late lodging, in relation to a particular year as opposed to an earlier lodger? It refers to the date of lodgment rather than, say, the end of a relevant particular financial year. To me, that seems just a little inequitable. The five years starts on the due date for lodging your income tax return for the income year. If you lodge your return late, the five years starts on the day you lodge it. That is the matter that I have some concern about, or have I incorrectly interpreted the legislation?

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that Senator Watson has interpreted it correctly. The five years start on the day people lodge their income tax return.

—During my speech on the second reading, I addressed a concern which to date has not been responded to by the minister. That concern is that the tax loss issues are being reviewed by the Australian Taxation Office. If they are being reviewed in the light of the contentious draft rulings TR94/D26 and D42, will the completion of the current review be held up pending a clarification of the current law before the rewrite is progressed? Otherwise, I believe that there could be further confusion.

PARA.TAB: An issue that was addressed by the Taxation Institute of Australia concerns the proposed numbering system and the arrangements made for definitions. The duplicate section numbers in the two new schedules, for example, section 1-1 of schedule 2A and section 1-1 of schedule 2B, will create inconvenience in searching for sections in electronic publications and databases.

Definitions are included in the bill to help the taxpayer. The way the definitions are scattered all over the place is definitely confusing. For example, the phrase `motor vehicle' is defined in schedule 2A section 11-13, although the phrase is used in other sections, such as schedule 2B section 2-3(6). Does the definition in schedule 2A section 11-1(3) also apply to schedule 2B section 2-3(6)? May I be bold enough to suggest that it would be more helpful to provide the definition at the front of the act and supply any definitions specific to a section at the end of that section. I acknowledge that it is too late to do it now, but these are important principles that should be noted in a further rewriting of the Income Tax Assessment Act.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a response to Senator Watson's previous point. The rewriting will not in any way cut across the ruling processes. The basic concepts being examined in the draft rulings are not being put in different language or are fundamentally disturbed in the rewrite. I note his comments on the last point about definitions. I am sure that the officers will take note of them, too.

PARA.TAB: Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.
Bill (on motion by Senator Crowley) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: HEALTH LEGISLATION (PRIVATE HEALTH INSURANCE REFORM) AMENDMENT BILL 1994PRIVATE HEALTH INSURANCE COMPLAINTS LEVY BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 28 February, on motion by Senator Sherry:
That these bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Robin Cook, an American novelist, has just released his latest book. The Senate will recall that he has written 14 other books, one of which, Coma, became a popular movie. His current book is entitled Fatal Cure. The subtitle says `His terrifying new medical chiller'. Some would think this an appropriate title for this legislation. The dedication for this book is also appropriate:

PARA.TAB: This book is dedicated to the spirit of health-care reform and the sanctity of the doctor-patient relationship.

SPEECH.PARA: It is my fervent hope that they need not be mutually exclusive.
However, some dialogue clarifies this legislation even further. I quote from page 17:

"Oh, bullcrap!" Traynor snapped, losing a bit of control. "You old docs have to wake up to a new reality. It's not easy running a hospital in the current environment of cost-cutting, managed care, and government intervention. It isn't cost-plus anymore like you had it. Times have changed, demanding new adaptations and new strategies for survival. Washington is mandating it."
Hodges laughed derisively: "Washington sure isn't mandating what you and your cohorts are doing."
"The hell they aren't," Traynor argued. "It's called competition, Dennis. Survival of the fittest and the leanest. No more sleight-of-hand cost-shifting like you used to get away with."
The legislation is the brain child of the department and is influenced by the Australian Health Insurance Association. One can understand the motives of the bureaucracy. It extends its power.

PARA.TAB: The encroachment of bureaucratic organisation into almost every area of health has become increasingly apparent over the last 40 years. Bureaucracy today is the mechanism through which social control can be exercised while the public is totally unaware of it. The catchcry is `accountability', `cost containment' and `casemix' while the bogies are `over-servicing' and `fraud'. All are designed to undermine the credibility of the health professionals and increase the influence of the bureaucracy. The effect has been that our older faith in basic values, such as trust, service and quality, have been devalued or even replaced.

The objective of all these initiatives is not just to allow insurance carriers to question bills from providers instead of simply paying them, as they have in the past. Rather, it is to use insurance reimbursement policies to determine what medical treatment providers could render. The new reimbursement policies are designed to achieve two goals simultaneously: to ration the services that providers deliver to patients; and to undermine the authority of doctors by creating new definitions of what constitutes good medical practice.

In general, the process works like this. First, either government regulation or utilisation review by private insurers forces providers to reduce the services they deliver to patients. In the process, new utilisation data are generated upon which to base new definitions of good medical practice. These definitions provide a comparative base to show that providers must have been delivering unnecessary services to patients all along. At that point, many services can be eliminated without arousing much political or professional opposition.

Second, the over-utilisation that is bound to be unmasked when this technique is used can then be explained as the result of ignorance or greed on the part of providers. Thus, the entire process undermines medical authority, debunking both the professional knowledge base and its service ethic. All of these developments then legitimate initiatives to make providers accountable; that is, to subject them to bureaucratic management techniques.

In the process, a new elite has emerged. This elite is made up of health care statisticians, health economists, administrators and consultants. The authority of these new experts increasingly competes with and weakens that of providers. This is an excellent example of the process in which knowledge emerges out of the exercise of power. In this case, while the new experts created, collected and interpreted data which undermined medical authority, they simultaneously created a new knowledge base which supports their own claims to occupational power. If this just sounds like rhetoric, I refer you to what is occurring in the former Repatriation General Hospital in Brisbane today.

I would now like to turn to the supposed aims of this legislation. Will this legislation lower the cost of private health insurance? The answer is a resounding no. In her second reading speech, the minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: The reforms will place the health insurance industry in a position to achieve efficiency gains and pass on the benefit of these gains to their members in the form of lower premiums and better controlled costs.

Let us analyse that. What does the industry say? Mr Schneider, the Chief Executive Officer of the Australian Health Insurance Association, said on 3 March before the Senate Community Affairs Legislation Committee:
It is a very brave man—
I stress that he said `man', and not `man or woman'; I am sure the minister would enjoy the sexism in that remark—
who predicts that the price of any commodity will go down. I believe two things will happen. Firstly, the rate of growth of premiums will slow. I think it will be beneficial.

He said that `the rate of growth of premiums will slow'. Big deal! Premiums have increased by 100 per cent in the last five years, and Mr Schneider hopes it will slow as a result of this legislation. I quote him again:

If we can get it closer to C.P.I. I think it will help people to stay in private health insurance. Secondly, I believe there will be niche products. It may be possible to buy into health insurance for more limited coverage than they can get today at a lower price. That could be very attractive to some section of the market. As I said, it is a very brave man who predicts that the price of any commodity will go down.

Let us not just rely on the Health Insurance Association. Let us rely on Dr Duckett, the secretary to the department. At the Senate Community Affairs Legislation Committee on 6 March, Dr Duckett said:

If there are efficiency gains in private hospitals, they can be extracted by increased profits for the private hospitals, or they can be extracted in terms of increased reserves for the private health insurance funds, or they can be extracted in terms of reduced premiums in private health insurance funds.

I do not think the government could say, if improved efficiency took place, whether it would end up as reduced premiums, increased reserves or increased products. I would not like to guarantee that there would necessarily be an X per cent reduction in premiums, when this bill still leaves a lot of power in the hands of private hospitals and health insurers.
That is what the secretary to the department says in contradistinction to the minister. Also, the secretary is supported by the Executive Director of the Australian Health Insurance Association.

PARA.TAB: Let us turn to the question of choice in relation to insurance products. The minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: Consumers will be able to purchase a product that best suits their needs, at a price that suits their budget.
Let us turn to see what Mr Schneider, the man who is responsible for the industry association, said:

A cheaper product would probably be one which limited the choice of hospitals and doctors and possibly even the value of the benefits paid. The price of the products depends on what you pay on benefits.

That should be self-evident to everybody, but it is not to the minister. Let us turn to what the secretary to the department said. At the Senate Community Affairs Legislation Committee on 6 March, Dr Duckett said in reply to a question from me:
Is what you are saying that, if health insurance funds can now cover something that they cannot cover, it will cost more money?
I replied:
Yes.
Dr Duckett said:
You are quite right. It will.
Let us turn to casemix. I again quote the minister:

Casemix is the most significant Commonwealth health financing initiative developed in Australia. The implementation of casemix payments will improve efficiency within hospitals and improve the quality and quantity of the information available on what takes place in hospitals and hence improve quality and outcome of health care.

The first point to make is that casemix is not an Australian initiative. Casemix was developed in the United States in the 1970s and legislated in 1983 in amendments to the American Social Security Act. The department brought in two Americans to develop the casemix program here, as they said there were no Australians with their expertise. You will recall that the department said that $162,000 was paid for a consultancy. Like you, minister, the department made the error, which it had to correct later. Originally, it had said it was $550,000. But the point that I make is that two Americans had to be brought into this consultancy because no Australians were available, according to the department.

PARA.TAB: The second point is that the minister is contradicted by the secretary to her own department yet again. I again quote from the Senate Community Affairs Legislation Committee Hansard of 16 February. I asked:

SPEECH.PARA: Because we still do not know—and you have said this in an earlier answer—what is going to be the outcome in terms of quality patient care at the end.
Dr Duckett said:

That is right. I agree with you there, I think the monitoring of quality is very poor and we do not know whether the quality of care in New South Wales now without casemix is better or worse than Victoria, with casemix.
I rest my case. Let me turn to the privacy considerations and the collection of data. On 10 March, a senior departmental officer said:

So the situation could arise in the future whereby some of the modelling results that we are obtaining might indicate that some products are overpriced. In such a circumstance it might be that the minister and the department may wish to use their powers in relation to approving products. But at the end of the day there is power in the legislation now and in the future to refuse premium increases.

Under the legislation, the department has the authority to do whatever it likes with modelling evaluation and research. The same mantra was chanted in the US at the time of its introduction. It provided the administrative mechanism for subjecting doctors and hospitals to bureaucratic surveillance and manipulation and it legitimised an attack on the credibility of doctors in general by calling into question both their professional knowledge base and their ethics. As I said previously, the objective of these measures is to use insurance reimbursement policies to determine what medical treatment providers could render. Again, I refer you to what is occurring today in my own state of Queensland in this regard.

PARA.TAB: This legislation is complex. It is almost certainly unworkable. It fails to address consumer concerns. Price will not be lower and it is adding cost to the industry. Consumers have not been consulted. It is obvious that they are voting with their feet in relation to private health insurance, in that they are only 36.3 per cent now and less than 30 per cent in our state of Queensland. It is restricting freedom. It is aimed at producing uniform mediocrity. It affects public hospitals as well, both in the restriction of private patient access and the added burden of coping with the extra numbers who have dropped their private health insurance. If you consult any public hospital in Australia, they will tell you this. I had a phone call today from Tasmania. I had a phone call yesterday from Queensland. We have had government members complaining about the states of Victoria and New South Wales. We also know that it exists in the other states of Australia.
What protection is there for hospitals from the funds? The minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Trade Practices Act provides protection against anti-competitive action by any funds.
Bob Baxt, former Chairman of the Trade Practices Commission, said in a letter on 27 March:

My major concern with the proposed changes to the Health Act is the blind acceptance of the proposition that the commission, by using the Trade Practices Act, will be able to overcome any unfair or improper conduct on the part of powerful health funds, powerful hospitals or other powerful players in the health industry, acting either alone or together.
Who is right?

PARA.EMPHASIS: Sitting suspended from 6.59 p.m. to 8.00 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Our major amendment is designed to allow a benefit to be given to hospitals where there is no contract between a hospital and an insurance company. This is designed to protect small rural and specialist hospitals. Even if the cost to be in a hospital is $200 a day, hospitals will still go broke. Currently, hospitals with less than 40 beds cost $340 a day. At this rate, it will take them about one or two months to go broke. Small hospitals have very little power to negotiate with a health fund. Other amendments protect psychiatric rehabilitation and palliative care.

PARA.TAB: The provision of an adequate level of default benefit is vital for two reasons. By taking away the safety net, we are taking away the true raison d'etre of private health insurance as a guarantee for patient, doctor and hospital. Just as importantly, a token or inadequate benefit makes the financial pressure for providers to work under purchaser-provider agreements almost irresistible. For these reasons, we note the amendments which take the proposed default sunset out of the legislation. We see this as a step in the right direction. Ensuring that defaults are ongoing will remove the financial pressure and preserve the voluntary nature of agreements. Without this reassurance, it will be hard for us to do anything but to continue to oppose the legislation as a whole. Our amendments to the provisions of purchaser-provider agreements will ensure a more level playing field between insurers and providers, with the complaints commissioner will act as a watchdog for negotiating processes and practices.

We are aware that there is considerable debate between provider and insurer groups about what data should be provided and for whom it should be provided. Clearly, insurers need to have patient data relating to the episodes for which claims are being made. It is not as clear why the department or the Private Health Insurance Agency Commission needs anything but that aggregated data. We have an objection in principle to the central role of the department in the data collection and dissemination process. We were interested to note from committee hearings and other sources that it has not been made clear what it actually wants to do with it. Our amendments propose an arms-length data agency, not unlike PHIAC, which would allow the parties to get together first to talk the problem through.

We also believe there should be adequate protection of patient privacy and there should be controls over the use of aggregated data. Our amendments will go a considerable way towards addressing these concerns, while making constructive proposals which would give some balance to the negotiating process and enable agreements to be implemented. We have consulted widely with key industry and professional groups, including AHIA, and have approached the government legislation in a constructive manner. We are not targeting health insurers or any other industry group. Nor are we opposed to the negotiation of contracts between funds and practitioners. We are interested in patients.

This legislation is a classic example of legislation on the run. We have 17 pages of government amendments. We have 54 amendments already, all introduced at the last minute without consultation. If ever there was a case for referral to a Senate references committee, this is it. In all her protestations about consultation, the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) left out consultation with the most important people of all—those most affected. Where were the consultations with national seniors, the pensioners league, the members of the Medical Benefits Fund and the millions of contributors to private insurance?

The bottom line is that this legislation is unworkable. The Council of Procedural Specialists and the Australian Private Hospitals Association have already notified their complete opposition to the proposals. We believe there needs to be reform of the industry. Our amendments are designed to achieve that. We believe there needs to be more community involvement in the process of this legislation because it will affect us all—one day, one time, unfortunately, but inevitably, nearly all of us will be patients.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to disclose my pecuniary interest in this debate. I am a member of the Health and Research Employees Association and a member of the New South Wales College of Nursing. I also have a current nurse practise certificate for the ACT. I would hope that all other members of the Senate who are going to speak on this will disclose their membership of professional organisations and their interest in health bodies.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I regard that as a reflection on me. It is well known that I am a surgeon. I have been a surgeon for over 35 years. If the implication of that is a reflection on me, I expect it to be noted.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Reynolds)—There is no point of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not mentioning anybody by name. I was drawing people's attention to the pecuniary interest register. If it hurts people, so be it. This legislation has been deemed necessary because there has been a decline in the number of people with private health insurance. At the same time, there has not been a decline in the number of bed days occupied in private hospitals. That is because people are choosing to self-insure.

PARA.TAB: Why are people giving up their private health insurance? The most common complaint from people with private health insurance and who use private hospitals is that they get a bill at the end which causes them to have out-of-pocket expenses. Some of those expenses are quite significant. They do not feel that they are getting value for money.

With this legislation, people will have the opportunity to know what out-of-pocket expenses, if any, will be incurred when in a private hospital because their fund may have come to an arrangement with that hospital. They will know the details before they agree to having a procedure. They will be able to give informed consent, because they will know and understand the whole regime that is going to take place and will be aware of the cost involved to them as well.

Some of the evidence given showed that the out-of-pocket expenses average $79 for doctors and $239-odd dollars for hospitals—in excess of $300. The majority of older people who have health insurance are not giving it up. They are keeping it. They are pensioners. They are people on lower incomes and they will find the average of $300 quite significant. I have figures from a practice in Brisbane which show that the surgeons are charging something like 75 per cent to 80 per cent as an average over the scheduled fee. That sort of thing is happening and is distorting the figures.

It is important that people know the cost of health services prior to going into hospital. As I said before, it is part of the issue of informed consent. It also gives hospitals, insurance companies and doctors—if they care to be involved—an opportunity to offer a range of products to people, to tailor services to people's needs. That is very important. A complaints mechanism will also be set up in this legislation. That is something that Medibank Private is already subject to with the Ombudsman. They have no problems with it; they find that it works very well. They think that, if they are subjected to that mechanism, why shouldn't other private health insurance companies be subjected to it?

We have talked about the issues of casemix data collection and privacy. I suggest that it is very important that the casemix data collection remains within the purview and the control of the Commonwealth departments. It will be de-identified documentation and material. In our report, we refer to the privacy restraints and constraints that the departments will be subject to—the Health Insurance Act, the National Health Insurance Act, the Crimes Act and the Privacy Act. You cannot bring private organisations under that umbrella. They are independent. Therefore, they are not subject to monitoring by this body, the parliament, and controlling of how much information can be given or what they do with that information. That is very important. Casemix also means that they will be able to measure apples with apples. They will be able to have greater standardisation of their measuring, which is vitally important.

People have concerns about giving information to the government despite all those controls. I draw the attention of the Senate to the information required by the government when the government gave private hospitals a subsidy. They had to list the patient's surname, their given names, their Medibank number, their address and their date of birth. They had to list all those things that are far greater identifiers than the de-identified material that they would be required to produce. They were also required to list the patient's health insurance number. The industry was happy to forward those sorts of details to the department prior to this legislation. Now the industry is saying, `Lets not do that.'

I think it is important that we look at some of the solutions that have been suggested. The Australian Association of Surgeons—I think Senator Doctor Herron knows that association quite well—suggested that we remove the means test on free public hospital admission. That is a direct attack on Medicare. That goes back to the conditions that existed prior to 1972 and the introduction of Medicare. One of the reasons I am actually here is because of what it was like working in a public hospital then. After you had your admissions, the next morning the assessment officer came around and classified all of your patients as either private, public or intermediate. The number of people who signed themselves out of hospital because they were means tested into a category that meant they had to pay is nothing short of appalling.

COTA made a very good point in its submission. It talked about the research that is being done which has found that if people are forced to pay for services that they have difficulty affording then they will choose to seek medical attention and assistance later in that episode of illness and possibly to the detriment of their own lives.

It was also pointed out by the Australian Association of Surgeons that it wants to allow private insurance funds to cover health costs up to the AMA recommended schedule. That would mean that there would be no constraints on the AMA, doctors could charge what they like and everybody else would get constrained. It has also suggested that we should allow some tax relief for private health insurance premiums. That is fine for those on our incomes because anything that reduces our taxable income is good. I finally draw the attention of the Senate to an article that appeared in the Canberra Times on 1 March in which Dr Wooldridge said:
They have had hospital contracts in place in Victoria for four years and it has worked well. . .
I am assured that the proposal for the contracts with doctors to be entirely voluntary. If it were not completely voluntary I would not support it.

SPEECH.PARA: He goes on to say:

Well I support what has happened in the Victoria . . . it works and I think it has been good for consumers and good for doctors. Victoria has one of the highest rates of health insurance in the country.
Victoria is the place that started off contracts with private hospitals. I rest my case.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —After listening to Senator Herron's speech I was wondering which piece of legislation it is we are speaking about. I do not think that in my five years in this place I have ever seen a piece of legislation where there has been so much nonsense and so many myths perpetuated and running amok. It has reached epic proportions. The phone calls to my office have been most disturbing.

PARA.TAB: Perhaps one of the most disturbing was when a woman phoned to say that she had just taken her mother to the orthopaedic specialist. He had told her mother that he could not see her and he could not put her on a waiting list because he may not be allowed to operate when the Health Legislation (Private Health Insurance Reform) Amendment Bill is in place. That is a misinterpretation and a total misunderstanding of where we are. It has got to the point of being absolutely ridiculous.

There are some genuine concerns about this legislation and there were certainly many when we first saw it back in December. We have reached a stage now after the Senate committee hearings, and the ongoing negotiations and debate with people outside and inside parliament as well as on the phone, where, I believe, we have a package that is workable—not perfect but even though I expect that the monitoring processes we are putting in place are going to throw up some problems—but nevertheless is worth putting into place tonight.

Wherever in the world there has been a move by a government to put any restrictions on what doctors can charge, there has been the sort of campaign that we have here. I think the huge outcry that we are seeing is quite out of place in that we will not see any compulsion at all in this legislation. That is one key point that seems to be ignored.

This package of reforms is designed, according to the government, to give the private health insurance industry an opportunity to reduce premiums and eliminate out-of-pocket expenses and open up insurance funds and hospitals to greater competition. I am sceptical about the capacity of these reforms to reduce premiums in the short term. I believe that we are looking at a longer term reduction in some of the packages offered or certainly holding the line. Perhaps one of the biggest wins in this legislation is that some packages offered will not include any gaps. When I have spoken to different retiree groups, that is one of the major issues they have raised. Self-funded retirees struggle to keep up with their premiums and then they are hit with not just a few dollars but perhaps hundreds if not thousands of dollars should they require hospital treatment.

I believe it also gives the health insurance industry the impetus and scope to develop more flexible products. The original bill gave far too much power to the health insurance industry. What the Australian Democrats have tried to do in their amendments—and I believe we have achieved this—is swing that power base back towards the consumer by putting in a range of different amendments and putting a consumer focus on the legislation.

That is the general thrust of this legislation in terms of what the government hopes to achieve and where I think we are now. But, right from the start, the Democrats had a whole range of major concerns. I will only briefly touch on those as I do not want to spend too much time on this.

The reform package basically has five parts. For those who might read the Hansard later or for those who heard Senator Herron's speech I will put clearly on the record what is actually being done in this legislation. We are replacing the current arrangements under which the benefits are paid to hospitals with the casemix payments system which is based on the cost of the entire episode of care. We are replacing the requirements that private health insurance funds pay hospital benefits as determined by the Commonwealth with arrangements which allow the funds to enter into contracts or purchaser-provider agreements with private and public hospitals. It allows funds to enter into agreements with medical practitioners for the provision of professional services in hospitals. These agreements may eliminate out-of-pocket expenses. It establishes an independent Private Health Insurance Complaints Commission to deal with complaints about the private health insurance industry. Finally, it brings all employer based or corporate health insurance schemes within the operation of the Health Insurance Act.

The Democrats had a list of major concerns right from the beginning. In particular we were very concerned with the level of power handed over to the private health insurance industry in the original bill. We were also concerned from the initial discussions and looking at the bill that there could be some impact on doctor choice and hospital choice. As we listened through the committee hearings we found that those concerns were simply not able to be justified and some of the rather strange comments from the witnesses led us to believe that a lot of the hype and a lot of the very exaggerated comments that have been made are based on misconceptions as to what this legislation is in fact doing. We had a major concern that there would be an adverse impact on the smaller private hospitals and, in particular, we looked at the lack of a default payment.

After negotiations with the government, the Democrats have reached a package of amendments which, if accepted by the Senate, will deliver a far better piece of legislation. At the end of the day, we will have vastly improved legislation which protects the most vulnerable of patients as well as ensuring a better deal for both public and private hospitals. We have secured a default benefit which will be paid to all hospitals whether or not they have a contract with the insurer. That benefit will be initially set at the same level as the existing basic table.

From 1997, the default benefit may be directly linked to quality of service and the minister will have the power to reduce or cancel the default benefit should the hospital fail to meet recognised standards of care and treatment. That link will encourage hospitals to seek and gain accreditation. It will not be just a ministerial decision, however, it will be a disallowable instrument which will have to come before both houses of parliament. There would be a very extensive appeal process and one that is open and public for all those who are involved in the industry to participate in.

We have protected hospitals from arbitrary decisions by insurance funds not to enter into purchaser-provider agreements. There is an amendment which ensures that insurers cannot refuse to enter into agreements with hospitals on a number of grounds, including the size of the hospital, who owns it and the range of services it offers. There is an amendment which enables the new Complaints Commissioner to refer a matter to the TPC, and a clause will be inserted into the legislation to ensure it does not conflict with the Trade Practices Act.

We have ensured that hospitals and doctors must inform contributors of the amount a patient will be liable to pay the hospital and doctor for treatment. This is an important amendment for consumers. I for one continue to have complaints from people who are privately insured yet face huge out-of-pocket expenses after their treatment. This amendment does not go as far as we would like, but it is well along the way to where we should be going.

We have protected the interests of vulnerable classes of patients by ensuring that all insurance products covering hospital treatment must include coverage for psychiatric, rehabilitation and palliative care. In addition, a default benefit will be paid by the insurers for treatment in these areas. These issues must be covered in all packages offered by the insurers.

We have provided for a patient's charter of rights within the legislation. That charter will be formally introduced and subjected to parliamentary scrutiny at a later date. We have deferred the implementation date for compulsory agreements with private hospitals from 1 July to 1 September. Even though the need for this delay is not as important as it was—this is because we have got the default benefit—there will still be a need for administrative arrangements in hospitals, in particular I am advised that some of the forms will need to be changed.

We have ensured that hospitals and medical purchaser-provider agreements will not be subject to any stamp duty or state and federal charges. We have looked at the whole issue surrounding the employee schemes and have made some changes. The schemes have known for some time now that they will have to cease operation. Having seen this bill in December, they have no doubt been preparing for those changes and making some decisions as to where their fund will go. We still believe that it was right to have pushed the date for the end of the schemes back to September. We have secured an exemption for top up schemes and schemes which are part of an approved enterprise agreement registered with the Industrial Relations Commission.

I think those amendments offer a very good outcome for these schemes given the circumstances. However, I still have one concern in this area and that is for those people who are currently members of self-funded schemes who have pre-existing conditions. I have been advised that, based on the decisions in the Federal Court case involving ESSO, the self-funded schemes can continue to meet their liabilities to people with pre-existing conditions even after they have been wound up. I would like the minister to confirm that advice, if possible.

I believe that the Democrats have delivered on all of our major concerns. We have maintained a consistent line on this legislation, and we have held our ground. As I have said, we will see a vastly improved piece of legislation if our amendments are successful and as a result of all the negotiations. I will deal in more detail with the monitoring processes that we have set in place as we move through the committee stages but, at this stage, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At the end of the motion, add: "and, on and from the day the bill has been agreed to by each House, that the following matter stand referred to the Community Affairs Legislation Committee, for inquiry and report on or before 1 July 1996:

The ongoing monitoring of the implementation and operation of the Health Legislation (Private Health Insurance Reform) Amendment Act 1995 during the first 12 months after its enactment, with particular reference to the collection of data under the legislation and its provision to the Department of Human Services and Health and the Private Health Insurance Advisory Council.".

This will set up one of the processes for ongoing monitoring of this legislation by referring the matter to the Community Affairs Legislation Committee for inquiry and report on or before 1 July 1996.

PARA.TAB: We will not just be monitoring the specific contracts and issues directly related, affected or impacted on by this legislation. We also want to put on notice that the Democrats will be monitoring very closely what the funds decide to do. We have been very concerned in the last couple of days after hearing from the people who are currently working in community care in the private sector and with the funds.

Previously when I have criticised the funds, I have been very general and have not mentioned a particular fund, but I will mention one tonight. It is Mutual in my home state. Currently, under its supplementary table, it allows 20 home visits for surgical patients following surgery. It has informed the nurses working for it that, after this legislation passes, it will not continue this benefit. Mutual wants to simply work with hospitals. It seems to be looking for an excuse to go back to a casemix basis. This is of great concern when we look at the range of services that these nurses provide. One of the nurses who phoned me last night gave me a whole list of these services, and I am happy to show that to any senators who are interested.

I want to place on notice the fact that we will be watching very carefully the funds' response to this. We hope that they will increase the number of different packages that are viable for the 1990s, rather than cutting back and simply looking at funding the casemix system in the hospitals. I reserve my further comments for the committee stages. (Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —(8.28 p.m.)—I rise to speak on the Health Legislation (Private Health Insurance Reform) Amendment Bill 1994. I will not speak on the Private Health Insurance Complaints Levy Bill 1994. One of the reasons I will not speak on that bill is that, instead of having 20 minutes to speak, I have now been asked to speak for 10 minutes. I was also asked if I would speak over the dinner break, and I said no.

PARA.TAB: The government cannot get its business organised in time. It has no consideration for the people in this building—the clerks, the staff of the chamber and everyone else involved. They actually need a dinner break. We went through lunch; we have been here since early this morning and we will be here until late tonight. This government is so disorganised that it wants to have people speaking over the dinner break. I had to put that on the record because I think it is totally unacceptable.

Senator Herron, you of all people should be interested in this because you have been pushing for occupational health and safety standards in this place to improve. Here we have the very example where we went through lunch yesterday and lunch today and we were going to go through dinner tonight.

Having vented my spleen and having had a dinner break, I now feel much better. There is no doubt about it—the private health insurance system and the health system in general in Australia needs reform. At a time when the beleaguered Clinton administration was looking to our health for inspiration in resuscitating its own ailing system, our minister is inclined to introduce a US style managed care system supported by preferred provider agreements between insurance funds on the one hand and hospitals or medical practitioners on the other.

The prime object of this legislation is to stem the mass exodus of the population out of private insurance funds. Senator Crowley, with repeated questions from you, Mr Acting Deputy President, about the problem of the haemorrhaging of people out of private health insurance funds, stood across the chamber time after time telling us it was not a problem—they were only young people who were not going to place demands on the public health system.

Obviously Senator Richardson and Minister Lawrence had a very different view. The facts speak for themselves. The proportion of Australians covered by private health insurance has fallen from 59 per cent in February 1984 to an all-time low of 36.3 per cent at the end of last year. During 1994, more than 300,000 Australians dropped out of the private health insurance system. This, as I said, leaves 36.3 per cent of the population with private health insurance cover. That is below the critical figure of 40 per cent that Senator Richardson gave as the critical flashpoint for real problems and disasters in the private health insurance system. Despite what Senator Crowley says, a resultant demand and pressure is being brought to bear on public hospital systems and that cannot be sustained.

I do not know where Senator Crowley goes when we are not here. People say to you, `Oh, you're having a holiday now the Senate has risen.' Let me tell you that people on this side do not have holidays. If you go through rural Victoria as I do and speak to CEOs of small rural hospitals throughout Victoria, they will tell you one of the things that has affected their operation is the number of people who have left private health insurance and are no longer covered and the depletion in their funding because they do not have those privately insured patients. I do not know where Senator Crowley goes during the break but it is obviously not to small hospitals in South Australia.

In the seven years to 1994, private health insurance premiums have grown by over 100 per cent. This rise in premiums has significantly outstripped the growth in CPI. There is no question that one of the predominant reasons for the mammoth dropout rate is the cost of insurance. We have seen that in the literature, in the research and I also see it in my office. I have pensioner after pensioner coming in saying, `I have done everything—I have gone without things, I have gone without repairs in my house, I have gone without necessary things—to pay my health insurance. I can no longer do it.' Many of them have put themselves at risk by dropping out of the private health insurance system.

Of the 41,000 who dropped their cover in the last quarter of 1994, half were Victorians. That demonstrates that the states are bearing the brunt of the federal government's ineptitude on this issue. Dr Lawrence believes that her reforms, amongst other things, will reduce private health insurance premiums. I want to know where the evidence for this is. It seems to me a quantum leap in faith. She was not backed up by her senior bureaucrats in this, nor was she backed up by other people who gave evidence at the committee. They did not say that it was a foregone conclusion that we were going to see any change in private health insurance premiums.

There is nothing self-evident in this bill to show that this will be achieved. There is no certainty that the increased efficiencies or increases in membership hoped for will translate into reduced premiums. Even the AHIA, a major proponent of these reforms, says that at best the rate of increase in premiums might slow down. I believe we will see premiums increasing but at a slower rate.

What incentive is there for health insurance funds to channel efficiencies into reduced premiums rather than increased profits? What is there to ensure that the increased administrative and compliance costs and levies will not contribute to the very premiums the minister hopes will fall? Basically this legislation is a great package of wishful thinking on the part of the minister.

Under purchaser-provider agreements, health funds will acquire a range of hospital facilities and professional medical services at agreed prices and fees to support a range of health cover products at different premium cost levels. It is hoped that the total cost of an episode of care will be met by insurance but only where treatment is by a doctor and in a hospital contracted to the health fund. The first casualty will of course be choice.

Taxpayers in their capacity as patients of our health system will be the ultimate judges of these reforms. It is by reference to their expectations and demands that the success or failure of these reforms will be measured, not by reference to the bottom line of balance sheets of health insurance funds, or indeed those of hospitals or medical practitioners. It is proper that industry bodies have an input but let us not overlook the patient. I do not know how many people have discussed the patient tonight but that is really the end of the line. The patients ought to be the group we are concentrating on.

The Australian Council of Procedural Specialists has already indicated that it will not enter into any such contractual relations under these reforms as such relations would offend one of its own resolutions made in 1993 as well as facilitate insurance companies in seeking to exert their influence upon the nature and manner of treatment given to patients by their doctors. The council says that now. I can remember general practitioner after general practitioner who said they would never become vocationally registered. But when the dollars start flapping people change their minds. With all the best will in the world, I am not sure that the proceduralists will not be influenced in the same way as the general practitioners were to conform with the government demands.

The government scoffs at suggestions that this legislation might facilitate interference in the manner in which a doctor treats a patient. Yet this is very much a valid concern. The duration of an episode of care for a given diagnosis will be determined. To the extent that actual duration deviates from the regulated duration, practitioners may obviously encounter difficulty in maintaining different levels of fees for the care they are required to give.

Issues of market distortion arise, which may well be beyond the auspices of the TPC. We euphemistically speak of negotiating purchaser-provider agreements when the market features large funds that can bargain from a position of strength as compared with smaller funds likely to be pushed to the wall or taken over. We need to consider, too, the smaller hospitals, particularly in rural areas, which lack the muscle of their larger city counterparts. The reality may well amount to compelling agreements upon pain of possible financial ruin or at least financial loss.

Whether trade practices protections and remedies are available to aggrieved market players is by no means a clear-cut matter. The TPC says that the `context of a situation' is an important factor in deciding such an issue and that the purpose of the particular conduct needs to be considered.

The government really did not do its homework on these reforms. In setting up a start-up date of 1 April, no thought appears to have been given to the logistical difficulties involved in adapting existing arrangements to the new regime. The Victorian government in its submission to the Community Affairs Committee described the `timeliness for the introduction of these reforms as totally unrealistic'. The government has now been forced to extend this start-up date to September and the coalition believes that this is not sufficient and it should be extended to January.

The government prescribed no minimum amount which a health fund would be required to pay for treatment of a patient in a hospital with which it has no contract. The government, again, was forced to concede it got this wrong. It is no doubt a good idea to provide the consumer with more information about the cost of treatment and the government said it intended this. However, it was not borne out by the terms of the legislation. Again, the government has been forced to address it.

As has become de rigueur with so much of the government's legislation, the failure to consult prior to the formulation of what is very comprehensive legislative reform has once again, in the case of this bill, necessitated wholesale amendments without which this legislation would be totally unpalatable and unworkable.

Maybe it is a Western Australian disease that Minister Lawrence has because when her former colleague Mr Dawkins when he was Minister for Employment, Education and Training undertook reforms of the higher education system—I do not know that you would call them reforms, disastrous reforms—he had what was called a purple circle. If you were not in the purple circle, forget it; you were not part of the consultation. That is how former Minister Dawkins brought in his reforms to education. They have proved to be an absolute disaster. If anybody can show me one bit of cost saving resulting from the forced amalgamations of universities, then I would be surprised.

If you were not in Minister Carmen Lawrence's purple circle in these reforms, forget it. It is the Western Australian disease—you have to be in the minister's purple circle. If you were not, you were out. You only have to read what she said in her speech. She said:

SPEECH.PARA: As a responsible minister, I want to make it very clear that I am delighted with the opposition we are getting from the private hospitals and the doctors. That signals to me that we have the recipe pretty well right.

That is staggering. She is also like her boss. She has taken over, not just from the ministers from the west, having purple circles, but also from her boss. He is the doyen of division, and she is the duchess of division now. Mr Keating has divided this nation on many issues, and what Carmen Lawrence has succeeded in doing in health is dividing the groups. She has said it. She is delighted to have opposition from hospitals and doctors. She said that we must have the recipe pretty well right.

PARA.TAB: If I were the minister, I would be hoping that the groups would be saying to me, `Minister, we know the problems. We have worked around it. We have not all got our way, but we have all been part of the decision. We believe the health system in Australia will be better because we have all made a contribution. We have got it as right as we can achieve.' You should not be proud that you have got opposition from the doctors and the private hospitals. I would not get up and boast about that in the House of Representatives if I were a minister. She ought to be ashamed of that. It was repeated time and time again in that committee. Group after group came to us and said, `We were not consulted.'

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not true.

—It is not true, says Senator Neal from across the chamber. It is true that they came and told us that. You might believe they were consulted, but group after group came in. You can go and look at the Hansard, Senator Neal. You might have had your ears blocked when we were in that committee, but group after group told us they were not consulted.

PARA.TAB: Carmen Lawrence gave us a list of 124 people who had been `consulted'. When we talked to those people, we found out that `consulted' meant there had been some discussions on the periphery for some of them—maybe about some of these legislative changes or some meetings they had had with the previous minister, Minister Richardson. That is not consultation. If I were minister, I would like to see cooperation and consultation going together—not having a lecture about what the minister thought ought to happen, not being told some peripheral aspects of it and not being involved in the whole thing.

Let me say, with all due respect, the opposition has also been out in the cold, too. Senator Lees has been part of this purple circle. She is in there. But had the minister really wanted to change health for all Australians, not some system that she wants to dream up with a few of her purple circle, and if she had wanted to get the best health system, then she would have done everything in her power to make sure all the major players who were involved made a contribution. As I said, they would not all be winners but at least they would have felt that they had made a contribution and that it was the best that they could all do together. That is what it ought to be—a cooperative effort; not the duchess of division dividing the health groups. It is hopeless if you have the procedural specialists saying they are not going to be part of it. It is hopeless if you have the private hospitals not feeling that they have been adequately consulted and involved. You only have to read the journal of the Australian Private Hospitals Association to see how it feels about this legislation. As I said, time after time we were told that the groups were not consulted.

The Senate Community Affairs Legislation Committee, which recently looked at this legislation, found that there had been a mixed reaction to the various reforms contained in it. Senator Herron and I would have agreed to that report with some concerns, but to describe it as a mixed reaction was something of an understatement. There was quite significant reaction to it.

That we are sitting here with amendment after amendment on a major piece of legislation that will affect every Australian is a disgrace to this minister. We ought to have had more time to look at it. We asked for that. Senator Herron and I suggested that the legislation should go back. We are now rushing through in the 11th hour very serious legislation which will affect every Australian, and all you can do over there is laugh. I'll tell you what, in a few months time when the legislation comes back, you will say, `Oh, we didn't mean this. There's an error. We didn't mean this amendment. We've got to have an amendment to fix this,' and we will have a swag of amendments on the health bill. I will say to you, `I told you so.' We will remind every Australian of the inappropriate way that this legislation has been formed, has been amended and will be, let me assure you, amended again.

TALK.START.PARA: —The government has introduced the Health Legislation (Private Health Insurance Reform) Amendment Bill 1994 because it wishes to give the people of Australia the best possible health system available. The foundation of the health care system in Australia is Medicare. The guarantee of universal health is supported by an overwhelming number of Australians; in fact, 87 per cent.

PARA.TAB: The government is committed to a proper level of funding to allow the high level of health service that Australians enjoy to be provided through the states. In light of this, it is a disgrace to see the states of New South Wales and Victoria underspending their budgets for health services funded by the Commonwealth by $300 million and $370 million respectively for the 1993-94 year. Further, the government is committed to diversity and to providing the choice of seeking private health care through the mechanism of private health insurance.

It is a truth universally acknowledged that in recent years there has been a decline in the level of participation in private health insurance. The fact is that private health insurance is just not worth the money, and that is what this piece of legislation intends to address. Consumers pay a substantial premium, usually on a weekly basis. They think their medical needs are covered. When they require dental treatment or go into hospital for an operation, they discover that this is not the case. Yes, insurance funds pay some of the cost, but a substantial amount of those costs still comes out of the person who has been paying premiums until that time. This is a problem for the health industry and it is a problem for the public health system. The government and the Minister for Human Services and Health, Dr Lawrence, are well aware of this problem, and that is why they have attempted to deal with it through this bill.

The main thrust of the bill is to increase participation in private health insurance, and it is going to be done in two ways: to make health insurance more attractive by making it more responsive to consumer needs and to increase the capacity of the health insurance industry to provide an efficient and competitive product by contracting with the medical providers. The most important area of reform is the provision of more choices for the consumer and, in fact, an empowerment of the consumer that to date they have not had.

This bill puts the consumer in the driver's seat. This legislation gives consumers protection that they did not have. They will know in advance what they are being charged for medical services or a hospital stay. They will know how much their fund will cover and, if they are required to pay anything out of their own pockets, how much. Further, consumers will know in advance which medical providers their fund has contracted with. The consumer will have real choice. They will have all the information to make an intelligent choice and they will be able to weigh up the cost of that choice.

Presently, this is not the situation. Presently, consumers go to a doctor who refers them to a specialist and then in turn suggests a hospital. They go along to the hospital and they do not know how much the hospital is going to charge, and they do not know how much the fund will reimburse them. They just go into hospital and pray that they will not have to pay too much at the end of it.

Further, consumers under this legislation will be able to choose a package with lower premiums, if they are happy with the medical practitioners and hospitals with which the funds have contracted. They will be able to choose a package that covers 100 per cent of all cost, which they are not able to do now. They will have a real choice because they will have all the information available to them. The fact is that at the present time the power is all in the hands of the medical providers who hold the information that consumers need to make a real choice. This bill changes that.
I do not have a great deal of time, but I have to say that this constant allegation that there has been insufficient consultation is quite preposterous. I really want to quickly address that issue.

The development of the health insurance reforms has been going on for a long time. In fact, the reforms first began in December 1993, with the release of a press release and a discussion paper. Eight and a half thousand copies of the discussion paper were distributed, and 200 submissions were received in response. Those responses were drawn from 77 individual consumers, six public hospitals, 20 health service providers, 11 private hospitals, 25 funds and representatives, 22 doctors, and many others.
