On the basis of these submissions, a working party was set up to make a report on the reforms plus prepare a number of specialist reports—in connection with which, again, there was constant consultation.

In December 1994 the legislation was introduced—and that is now almost six months ago. As well as these steps, the government consulted, between December 1993 and February 1995, on a further 61 occasions with both groups and individuals. Further, the Senate community affairs committee, of which I am a member, received 83 submissions, heard 13 hours of evidence and subsequently prepared a report that is before us. The fact is, this bill has been a model of consultation. To say otherwise is a fallacy. I draw to a conclusion and commend this bill and the reforms contained within it to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woods Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I feel constrained by the time limits that have been put upon this debate. The health insurance bill is such an important piece of legislation that I am somewhat frustrated I cannot address all the problems faced in it. Let me say at the beginning, we support the basic principles involved in this legislation. It is an attempt, albeit a failed attempt, to try to redress the imbalance which has developed between the public systems and the private systems. That is something which even the Labor Party recognised. Senator Richardson said:

SPEECH.PARA: I think my primary role is to administer Medicare and that means public access and public hospitals. That has to be the thrust of all that I do. But you cannot do it properly unless there is a vibrant private sector, and I think that is what has been missed over the course of the last few years.
He went on to say:
One of the reasons why waiting lists are so long, why it is such a difficulty is that we have let private health insurance numbers get too low.
This is an attempt to redress that problem—however, it is an attempt which is not going to work.

PARA.TAB: Why do people not take out private health insurance? There are a number of reasons. The most important reason I guess is cost. When you think about it, as a privately insured patient, you are potentially paying four times over: you are paying your private health insurance premium, you are paying your general taxes, you are paying your Medicare levy and, at the end of the day, when you have had your treatment, you will pay more either to the doctor or sometimes to the hospital.

I think Senator Neal asked the question: why do they have to pay? The answer, particularly relating to the gap, is: they have to pay because this government has made it illegal to cover for the gap. So there is a simple reason why they have to pay: they have to pay because of the Labor government.

Sadly, these reforms will not improve the number of people with private health insurance; witness after witness at the committee inquiry reaffirmed that. `At best, we may get a slowing down in the rate of decline'—and that was evidence which was given by my good friend Russell Schneider who I see sitting in the gallery paying close attention to the matters at hand. If we are lucky, we will slow down the rate of deterioration—and that is not much of an aim for a piece of legislation which is as important as this is.

There are a number of other problems which this legislation will actually introduce and make worse. Let me address, first of all, the problem that this will have on hospitals, one of the two keystones of our health system. Effectively, this bill abandons small rural and specialist hospitals—`specialist' including things like psychiatric and rehabilitation hospitals. This is not just private hospitals but public ones as well.

After this legislation is in place, hospitals will have to have a contract with insurers if they are to survive. They will suffer a default payment if they do not have a contract, but that default payment will be set by the minister, and nobody really knows what it will be. It may be tied to the basic payment; it may not be. But, even if it is, it will cease in 1988. If it is set, as has been suggested, at $200 a day, essentially the hospitals will go broke. Smaller hospitals—that is, hospitals of around 40 and 50 beds—currently generate around $340 to $350 a day in revenue. On that basis, it will take most of those hospitals between one and two months to go broke.

Those hospitals really do not have any power to negotiate with a monopolistic health fund, which may be a giant in that particular state, and it is unfair to expect the hospitals to negotiate on their own, but they have to because the TPA usually will not let hospitals negotiate in groups. What the government has said here and elsewhere is that those hospitals can get authorisation and negotiate together. Apparently, the government seems to think that is an easy process. But Bob Baxt, the Chairman for the Trade Practices Commission, has said:

SPEECH.PARA: The authorisation process is also a costly and time consuming one. It could take six to nine months and in some situations the whole process takes over 2 1/2 years.
That is fine. So, in that six months or maybe years, the hospital has to go into bat for itself, and it faces bankruptcy.

PARA.TAB: What protection does the bill offer if a larger insurer does not make a reasonable offer or if it makes no offer at all? Apparently, a hospital can complain to the Complaints Commissioner, although there is some doubt about that if there is no contract. The Complaints Commissioner can then refer the matter to the TPC. The TPC has a month to say whether or not it is going to investigate. If it does investigate, it then reports its terms.

But what happens if there is no attempt made to contract with the hospital? The TPC is then not even applicable and cannot do anything. If the hospital does not receive a phone call or a letter, there is no compulsion to deal in any industry. That is the advice, again from Bob Baxt. But, if it can investigate, we have been told by Professor Baxt that it will be almost impossible for the TPC to prove that a fund had misused its market power. That, I think, was illustrated by Bob Baxt when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: It would be very difficult for a private hospital or the TPC to establish the purpose behind the health fund's refusal . . .
And, again, when he said:

In conclusion, we believe that a private hospital would not have recourse against a health fund as a result of unfair treatment by that fund. It is impossible to prove that there is a misuse of power.

So what can the Complaints Commissioner do then? He can make recommendations. So what? In effect, the Complaints Commissioner can go right back to the hospital and say, `Sorry, I can't do much'. What can the hospitals do now a couple of months on? They can apply to the Federal Court for an injunction. But there is a wealth of evidence to indicate, firstly, that that is a slow process; secondly, that it has very little guarantee of success; and, thirdly, that it is also a very expensive process. Application can be made to the TPC for help. But, again, Bob Baxt has commented about the likelihood of that succeeding. He said:

The commission has limited resources and will be unable, in my view, to deal effectively with what has been described to me as a typical case of a powerful health fund or a group of funds refusing to deal with a small hospital.

So hospitals may have spent a lot of time on this process but in the end they go broke. It does not matter whether the hospital is one of really high quality, a specialist hospital or a longstanding community asset. It still goes broke because this government has not put into place any sensible legislation to give it any power over its own destiny. When hospitals start to go broke in this country because of this legislation, the coalition will remind them of this day and of the government and, indeed, the Democrats who made it happen.

PARA.TAB: There are other problems with the legislation as well. One of the reasons for taking out private health insurance is to ensure choice—that is, essentially, choice of doctor and choice of hospital. Under this process there will be a diminution of choice; there is no question about that. There will still be some choice, but the freedom of choice, the breadth of that choice will be undermined by this legislation. That is something which I think all of us will decry. We have differing views about the extent of that, but it is going to happen.

We actually have no real problems with the fact that there is a Complaints Commissioner; it may be of some advantage. The problem with this, of course, is that it is going to be paid for by the consumer which, indeed, means that health costs will increase to the consumer. Also, there seems to be no appeal to the Complaints Commissioner. Indeed, it seems that the Complaints Commissioner can only make recommendations; the Complaints Commissioner has no power. That is a two-edged sword, but it does seem to undermine some of the reasons for having a Complaints Commissioner.

There is, again, the problem of an undermining of the basic principles of community rating. It seems that there will be an increased freedom for health funds to offer packages which exclude specific diseases. I know that most of the original current health funds will offer the same tables as an option. But, clearly, in this situation, they will be pushing the tables which more suit them. It seems to me that they will, for example, exclude hip replacements, something we heard of a couple of years ago from Medibank Private with its `select and save' process. At that time, the Australian Health Insurance Association, as I remember, was very critical of Medibank Private because it did undermine community rating. So I guess the question we have to ask is: what has happened to that view about offering packages which exclude specific diseases which may relate to particular age groups, for example?

So we finish up with a situation where this legislation will not put costs down. Not only has Russell Schneider indicated that would happen but John Loy from the department has also indicated that costs will not fall as a result of this. Choice will fall. We will be moving towards an American system where a HMO-type approach will predominate. I have no problems with HMOs if it is a matter of choice. What I am concerned about is that there will not be a real choice in this matter. Total cover will be available. That is something which we welcome. It was part of our policy in the last election campaign to allow people to cover for the costs which they faced. Although the approach taken was a slightly different approach, the essence of it was the same thing: that you should not be out of pocket. We had no particular problem with that. The difficulty with that is that there are no real barriers now to offering total cover. Indeed, in some states, certainly in Victoria and I think in your own state, Senator Crowley, it is possible to get pretty well total cover as a result of deals which have been done between purchasers and providers.

One of the other outstanding features which was touched upon by Senator Neal in her discussion was the consultations. She went to great lengths to say how extensive the consultation process had been. But the facts of the matter are very simple. In the evidence given to the Senate committee, I think 65 out of 66 people were critical of the process undergone either as a result of the legislation itself or as a result of the consultation process. Time and time again we had criticism from groups which had not been consulted. Senator Neal pointed out incorrectly that this legislation has been there for six months. It was introduced in December. We are now in March. That is 3 1/2, perhaps four months at most. Her time scale is obviously different to mine. It just seems like six months when you listen to Senator Neal speak. However, it has not been offered for wide consultation and a number of important groups, professional and non-professional, consumer and non-consumer, are very concerned about the lack of consultation which has occurred about this legislation. It is vital legislation; it is important.

In terms of the contracting out of services, of pushing doctors into contracts, this is again something which we have concerns about because although the contracts will not be obligatory, in essence as time goes on they will become obligatory. The new doctor setting up a new practice will not be able to set up a viable practice unless he has entered into a contract with a health fund or a group of health funds. So, de facto the issue will become one of compulsion for doctors to enter into contracts. Those at present who have large viable practices may choose not to enter into that particular contract but with the passage of time it will become impossible for a doctor to have a viable practice unless he has a contract, which essentially is another example of the restriction of choice which will occur as a result of this legislation.

So in essence I have concerns that this will not lower costs. It will not increase the number of people with private health insurance. It will not relieve the strain and pressure on the public hospitals by encouraging people to take out private health insurance. It will remove or at least reduce the choice of doctor and the choice of hospital. The Complaints Commissioner will have no powers. There will be no appeal against it and there will be an increased cost. It will also as a result of this legislation give unusual powers to the minister, powers which may relate to intrusion of privacy, and power for the minister to decide what is a quality hospital. We have a very good system in the hospital sector of accreditation. The accreditation is a voluntary process but one which works very well. If you are not an accredited hospital, then most health funds will not pay you a top rate of return.

It is a system that works well. There is no need for the minister to be given this extra power to say to a hospital `You are not meeting the standards'. I have terrible fears that the minister might start using this power in the same way that it has been used in the nursing home industry. The nursing home industry is moving away from that, yet it seems here in the hospital sector that we are moving towards that. We have a system which works very well at no cost to the consumer or to the government or to the taxpayer. Why would we want to move away from a system which works so well?

The last problem which I have time to touch upon today is that problem again of consultation. It is vitally important in legislation as crucial as this that people are consulted when they have an interest in the issue. That has not been done with this legislation. I have grave fears that this will not improve the system but will make the system worse.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —We all understand the pressures of time tonight so I will not be elaborating points or refuting argument at this stage of the debate. I thank all senators who have contributed. There clearly are a lot of issues to be considered. They are probably best dealt with if we now move into the committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand the amendment, the collection of data under the legislation and its provision to the Department of Human Services and Health in the private health insurance advisory council does not clarify the use of that data. It does not satisfy the arguments that I used in debate as to the use and de-aggregation of the data. So we cannot support that part of the amendment. Of course we support a watching brief. I believe it should be extended even beyond that. So we have no difficulty with the monitoring of the implementation and operation of the Health Legislation Amendment Act, but we are concerned about reference of the collection of data under the legislation under the provisions of this amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: HEALTH LEGISLATION (PRIVATE HEALTH INSURANCE REFORM) AMENDMENT BILL 1994

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to the amendments to be moved to this bill jointly by the government and the Australian Democrats.

PARA.TAB: Clause 1.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to briefly explain to the committee that there had been a problem, as I see it, with the second reading stage. I had noted a list of persons on the second reading stage speakers list and that dwindled considerably. I feel I should explain that my preference would have been to see the amendments that have been circulated go off to the committee for consideration.

PARA.TAB: There is a substantial number of amendments, including those by Senator Lees and the government. We are now presented with the explanatory memorandum for those amendments. It is a little difficult for persons like me to absorb, as it were, the details of the explanatory memorandum as it has just been submitted.

I do appreciate the notification I have been given by the Democrats and the indications by the government of assistance, but to my way of thinking the best method would have been to send the amendments to the committee. That not having taken place, I suppose the best we can do is examine them now, together with the information we have received about them from the various people submitting amendments, including Senator Herron. I just thought I should explain that that is the reason I voted against the motion for the bill to be read a second time. I felt that if I did that and it was successful, then the matter could have been reinvented in May.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are 54 amendments moved by the Democrats and the government. I have 42 amendments. The Democrats have now introduced another three amendments. I have complete sympathy with Senator Harradine's statement. This is legislation on the run. If ever there was legislation on the run, this is it. I say to Senator Harradine that I completely understand. How he is expected to even comprehend what the amendments are when the explanatory memorandum has just been tabled is even beyond the wit, I would suggest, of Senator Crowley.

—I will not hold the matter up, but I will certainly be interested to hear any propositions in support of the amendments. I have those in my office with notations on them. Again, I indicate that I am, in general terms, over a number of the amendments, with notations thereon. I will be following that with some interest with an adviser. Hopefully I will be able to judge the matters on their merits, not that my vote is going to make any difference one way or the other.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

SPEECH.PARA: 3.Clause 2, page 2, line 5, omit "1 July 1995", substitute "1 January 1996".

The reason I moved that amendment was to defer it until 1 January. That gives a pre-contract period of eight months. I do not believe, as Senator Lees apparently does, that that is sufficient time for the government's amendments to be dealt with. This would also minimise any advantage to those funds and hospitals which have already started to negotiate or seek to negotiate unofficially, and gives smaller hospitals and funds a reasonable opportunity to be competitive in the negotiating area. That was the reason behind my amendment. It is all very well to say that that will happen within a few short months, but I believe that this is such a major change to the structure of the whole health care industry in the private sector that more time is needed.

TALK.START.PARA: —In respect of my amendment No. 5, I thought this would be better clarified if it applied to some or all hospital treatment provided by a hospital or a day hospital facility. SPEECH.PARA: These amendments recognise that there is a need to set a maximum time for the provision of hospital casemix protocol data from the hospitals to the funds and from the funds to the department. The amendments to proposed section 73AB of the act require hospitals to submit the hospital casemix protocol data to funds within six weeks of the discharge of the patient and for the funds to send the data on to the Department of Human Services and Health within a one-week period three months after the date of discharge. The times are structured to provide sufficient time for the data to be collected but will limit any delays.

TALK.START.PARA: —I strongly oppose this amendment because this is the very point that I was making previously about the use of data. It relates to the casemix protocol data collection. We believe that we have not got an assurance, and I would question the minister as to the use of this data and the restrictions put upon it. We have heard verbally on a number of occasions that it will not be misused and that there are certain restrictions on it. I would like to know what those restrictions are.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —The restrictions to this data are the restrictions of the Privacy Act, the Crimes Act and the National Health Act. They are the very provisions that govern the control and protection of data at the moment.
—To what use will the data be put?
—I am advised that that data is going to be necessary for adequate research, for monitoring and particularly for the evaluation of casemix and its effect on hospital costs and so on.
—Research into what?
—This research will be particularly important for measuring the efficiency and the effectiveness of the reforms.
—What do you mean by `the effectiveness of the reforms'?

—I am advised that these reforms go particularly to efficiencies within hospitals, the effective management or good patient care and the effectiveness from the patient's point of view. If you like, it could be called customer satisfaction. I think it is how the practice under these proposed changes in private hospitals does affect the efficiency and the effectiveness of the treatment that is provided.
—Is that done in public hospitals now?
—I think the answer is that, as casemix is implemented into the public hospital system, yes.
—I said now, minister.
—I guess that depends on how effectively or how far casemix is. I will seek an answer on that.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —If I could add some other reasons that the Democrats are interested in these amendments. They are linked with a later amendment, No. 15, which requires hospitals to forward the data to funds within six weeks of discharge. But they are also linked with another amendment, No. 38, which says that the particular data provided to PHIAC must be determined in writing by the minister, and that determination is a disallowable instrument.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to your question about public hospitals and casemix, Senator Herron. I am advised that casemix is now operating in Victoria, South Australia and Queensland. I cannot assure you that they are all operating to the same level. I understand that it is further established in Victoria and that some of that data is emerging.

—I appreciate that, minister. But your statement was that it was customer satisfaction. You have told me that, in essence, it is not occurring now in public hospitals in Australia. It may be occurring in some. But my question is: how will this data and the material that goes through the department be implemented to determine the quality of care? I suppose that is a generic term that could be applied. You have mentioned that it was for research, evaluation and monitoring. I wanted to know what the research was. As I understand it from your previous statement, it is research into the quality of care. How is that going to be determined?

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —It will assist us to compare hospitals and assist us to define best practice.

—The point I am making—and it does not seem to be understood—is that we have no assurance about the detail of the data that is going to be provided. Admittedly, it will be controlled by the various legislative acts, but we do not know the use that the department will put it to. We do know—and it has been said during our committee hearings—that it was ultimately at the discretion of the minister as to what would be available and how it would be used; but we still do not know the detail of the information that will be provided. My question is: can you give us the detail of the information that is required under this legislation?

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that Senator Lees has fairly much explained this already. The hospital casemix protocol is something that is being developed with the industry. Once that detail is available, it will certainly be available to the Senate committee, and I believe it is also to be introduced by regulation. Of course, it would then be a disallowable instrument.

—In the legislation it says `casemix or another system'. It does not refer solely to casemix, and that is why it is essential that we know the detail of the information that is required. Casemix is what is being aimed at, but within the committee stage we heard that any system could be used; and that is mentioned in the legislation. Why will you not give us the detail? Admittedly, it might be disallowable, but I think we are entitled to know the detail that is required.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I can only reiterate what I have said, that the process and the exact details of the protocol in casemix are being discussed almost, I suppose you could say, at this moment. The detail of that and the variations on it will be provided to the Senate once it is—I am not sure whether you would even say concluded. But when there is some reasonable decision made, that will certainly come to the Senate committee, as I say, protected by regulation.

PARA.TAB: Casemix episodic payments are defined in the bill. Casemix must be used as a classification, but any agreed payment structure can be used. So it is going to that word `agreed' that is negotiated between the funds and the hospitals.

TALK.START.PARA: —What you are saying, Minister, is, `Trust me, I am from the government.' We have no difficulty with the data going to the insurance companies to which they are entitled. But we do have a difficulty with that data going to the government and the use that it will be put to. I suggest that you accept my amendment No. 7, which will deal with this problem in a better fashion.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not fair to say,`Trust me, I am from the government.' It is about saying, `Trust that the industry and the hospitals will properly negotiate.' I think it is important to understand that distinction and the protections that will be provided with it and the possibilities that, when those arrangements are further finalised, you, along with other senators, will certainly be able to examine them closely.

—All this does is to ensure that dental practitioners who are carrying out work in a hospital can also enter into an agreement if they so wish.

—That was the question that I was asking. You are referring to oral surgeons who do not have a medical degree; that is, oral surgeons who are dentally qualified—such as the illustrious Senator David MacGibbon, who is an oral surgeon. He is a Fellow of the Royal College of Dental Surgery in England, but he is not a medical practitioner. Is that the intent of what you are proposing? TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

My understanding is that we are not trying to be in any way prescriptive in terms of putting any requirement on hospitals, if that is what you are getting at.

—Perhaps I am not explaining myself clearly enough, or I am not understood. Perhaps I am explaining myself and it is not understood. It is one or the other. There are certain dental practitioners who are oral surgeons who work full time within hospitals, dental hospitals in particular, who have the right of private practice and who treat private patients. There are dental practitioners who work in private hospitals who are not oral surgeons, and also dental practitioners who work in public dental hospitals treating private patients who have the right of private practice. TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

" `(5) Subject to Part VIC of this Act, an individual or a body corporate in a relationship of agency to an individual hospital or a group of hospitals may negotiate with a registered organisation on behalf of one or more hospitals in relation to the provision of a hospital purchaser-provider agreement, but a hospital is not to be taken to be a party to such an agreement unless it has expressly entered into it.
`(6) For the purposes of subsection (5) an "individual hospital" includes a group of hospitals under the management of a company incorporated under a law of a State or Territory.

`(7) While the details of an agreement or provisions of an agreement should be treated as being confidential between the parties, the Complaints Commissioner may review, in confidence, and recommend to the Minister the disclosure of any of those provisions in the public interest.

PARA.TAB: `(8) A party to an agreement, or a member of a class of persons or organisations described in subsection 82ZS(1) of Part VIC who can reasonably expect to be affected by the agreement may refer a request the Complaints Commissioner for a determination in accordance with subsection (7).

SPEECH.PARA: `(9) The Minister may, following a recommendation by the Complaints Commissioner, direct a registered organisation or a hospital to enter into a specified hospital purchaser-provider agreement or a negotiation for a specified hospital purchaser-provider agreement, provided that a refusal to negotiate or to enter into an agreement has been found to be unreasonable by the Complaints Commissioner.

`(10) For the avoidance of doubt, it is declared that a hospital purchaser-provider agreement may be the subject of relief under an Act or under a law of a State or Territory (as agreed by the parties to the hospital purchaser-provider agreement) that provides for relief in respect of contracts on the grounds of harshness, unconscionability or unfairness.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate to Senator Herron that we would like to support subsection (12) of amendment 10. Could you put subsections (5) to (11) together and subsection (12) separately, Madam Chair?

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Reynolds)—There being no objection, I put the question that subsections (5) to (11) of amendment 10 be agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Both the hospitals and the doctors are concerned about the possibility of individuals and groups of providers being picked off by the funds in the negotiating process, particularly in states where Medibank Private and one or two other funds dominate the market. For instance, in Western Australia we heard that 70 per cent of coverage was by one fund.

PARA.TAB: Not all providers would necessarily be disadvantaged. Specialists in numerically small specialities could actually be in a very strong position. There are certain specialties where there are very small numbers of people and they would obviously be in a much stronger position. After seeking advice from the shadow Treasurer on the trade practice implications of fostering group arrangements, we have decided against the Australian Private Hospitals Association and the Australian Medical Association preference for group negotiations to be completely removed from the Trade Practices Act.

New subsection 73BD(5) would instead allow hospitals and practitioners to appoint agents to negotiate on their behalf if they so desire. These agents could be an individual or an organisation such as the Australian Private Hospitals Association or the AMA. The agency negotiation would then need to be ratified by the individual practitioner or hospital by signing the negotiated agreement on its own behalf. We believe this would minimise the legal perception of such group negotiations being seen as anti-competitive or even cartel forming and we believe it is important that they be highlighted. We believe that they are making it more fair and competitive.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Herron understands that the government will not be accepting subsection (5).

—Why not? It certainly seems to us as if it is making it more fair and competitive. I am happy to hear debate from you as to why you do not believe that to be so. I do not think it is sufficient just to say that you are not going to accept it. That is what we are in committee for.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate that, but I am also given to understand that there has been very extensive discussion. If this was not something covered I am happy to explain. In short, subsections (5) to (11) try to replace the provision of the Trade Practices Act. The issue is comprehensively covered under the trade practices legislation which permits groups to collectively negotiate provided they do not represent an undue market share.

PARA.TAB: The opposition's amendment has the potential to contradict the principles of the Trade Practices Commission and its legislation by permitting a single, monopolistic organisation like the federal AMA or the APHA with market dominance to constrain and circumvent the competitive reforms designed to benefit consumers. This item constitutes hospitals trying to have it both ways. They want the power of group negotiation, but they do not want to be bound by it. The negotiations would merely set a floor price for contracts.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —We looked very hard and long at the whole area of the Trade Practices Act. Its implications for this legislation were a great cause of concern right from the beginning for us. It needs to be clearly understood that there is nothing in the Trade Practices Act as it stands now that prevents people from working together, as long as their actions are not anti-competitive.
—We will agree to dis agree.

TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will just give Senator Herron some information on government amendment No. 17. This is a disclosure provision for medical practitioners. It requires doctors to inform privately insured patients of any out-of-pocket amounts the patients will have to pay. We believe that this is a very important amendment for consumers. I know that lots of doctors already do this—they have been assuring us that they do so—but, unfortunately, a few doctors do not realise the importance of providing that information.

—I have no problem with the intent of the amendment, but I do have a problem with its wording. The sentence on the second last line begins `rendered of any amounts that the eligible contributor will be liable to pay'. I respectfully suggest that that end phrase should be amended to `could reasonably be expected to pay'. When the word `liable' is used, it implies legal obligation. By inserting the words `could reasonably be expected to pay', no legal liability is implied. There are many occasions when the patient is certainly liable by implication. As senators know, the bill may be sent to a debt collector, but that is very uncommon. If we remove `will be liable' and make it `could reasonably be expected', it removes that liability to pay the professional service. Therefore, I move:

PARA.TAB: "Subparagraph 73BDA(2), omit "will be liable", substitute "can reasonably be expected"

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure whether it makes a huge amount of difference. Is Senator Herron suggesting that the doctor may not require some people to pay and there is no contractual arrangement? I would expect that what we are really talking about is an agreed fee that the doctor is going to charge and that fee has to be made very clear to the patient. Senator Herron, are you suggesting that the doctor may decide to not ask for some of the payment?
—Yes, that happens all the time.

—Therefore, the patient is not liable for whatever the practitioner decides to take off the bill. We are talking only about the amount that the person is expected or liable to pay. I cannot see the difference, but I am very interested that Senator Herron suggests that doctors may issue one bill and, if some agreement is not reached, issue a second one. Is that what you mean?

—Yes. In practice, an account may be sent, then some circumstance may occur that is of a major nature to the financial structure of the patient. They might suffer a bankruptcy or something. Under the wording here, they have been notified that it will cost them and they are liable to make that payment. Circumstances vary so much—as Senator Crowley and Senator West well know—in relation to what happens to patients in a clinical situation.

PARA.TAB: The government is defining that the patient will be liable to pay, but I could give the Senate many circumstances when a patient goes into a hospital with a ruptured subarachnoid haemorrhage. If they are unconscious, how can that be defined? They are not in a situation where they are even aware of what is going on. That is not uncommon if they have had some medication prior to admission. The government is asking under this clause to inform the eligible contributor in respect of whom the professional services will be rendered of any amount liable to be paid in respect of the professional service.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators will be aware that for some period of time now I have been pursuing a tale of misconduct in the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service. The matters in question were examined at an estimates hearing of the rural and regional affairs committee on 15 February at which time various undertakings were given to the committee that information would be provided to questions taken on notice.

PARA.TAB: At a meeting of the committee this morning, I indicated my dissatisfaction that in fact none of the answers to the questions which were taken on notice had been provided to the committee. I was very grateful to Senator Murphy for contacting the office of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins) and providing an undertaking from the minister that those questions would be answered. At around 5.15 or 5.30 this afternoon we did receive a large number of answers to questions which had been taken on notice and I am very grateful for that.

There is one problem, however; that is, the question I most wanted answered in relation to charges under the Public Service Act against a senior executive service officer in relation to six items of misconduct was not answered. No explanation was provided at the time the answers came back from the committee as to why that question had not been answered. It was very clearly shown that an undertaking was given at page 87 of the Hansard. Yet that undertaking was not met in so much as the information was not provided this afternoon.

At 6.15 p.m., I indicated to the government whip that I intended to call a quorum and would continue to call for quorums until that information was provided. That resulted in further discussions with Senator Collins's office and, ultimately, with Senator Collins, the result of which was that Senator Collins believed we had an agreement that the information would be provided to me tomorrow morning. I distinctly remember—and I do not want to get into a long discussion about it—saying to Senator Collins that was not satisfactory as far as I was concerned because it precluded me from making a comment about the information in as full and as wide ranging a fashion as I would want. Although the information would obtain privilege by virtue of its being presented to the committee when the Senate was not sitting, I would not in fact be able to speak on it to the full extent because parliament would not be in session.

That is why at 8.30 p.m., two hours having elapsed, no answers having come back and then being told by Senator Collins's staffer that he intended to provide the information to me tomorrow, I called a quorum. Subsequent to that, I had a long discussion with Senator Collins and we sorted the matter out on the following basis: that Senator Collins would provide that information to me or to the committee for my benefit tomorrow morning; that is, he would provide the full report of the investigation officer who was appointed under section 62 of the Public Service Act; and that Senator Collins would further provide, if possible, before 10 April, which is the sitting of the rural and regional affairs committee in relation to AQIS in Melbourne, an answer to the issue of whether any officers of AQIS had provided references to Mr Corrigan to enable him to take up a job with the Meat Hygiene Service in the United Kingdom. On that basis, I would be happy not to call for a quorum again tonight. That agreement, I think, will see an amicable solution to the problem.

I want to make a couple of points. First, it is absolutely ludicrous that questions taken on notice should take over a month, in this case almost six weeks, to come back to a committee. I think Senator Robert Ray, on the other side, is fairly reasonable and would recognise that six weeks is a long time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Depends on the question.

—Some of those questions are fairly obvious, Senator Ray. But to get nothing back in six weeks is unsatisfactory, especially as this is the last sitting day of this sitting. We will go into the budget sittings still without answers to questions from the supplementary estimates. The hearings of 15 February were a continuation of hearings that had been set down for 29 November. At that rate we would not get any satisfaction at all. I think it is absolutely unsatisfactory that it should take so long.

PARA.TAB: I also think it is ridiculous that senators from the opposition should be put in a situation where they cannot do anything to get the information they request and have to wait another six weeks before we get another sitting day. If that is to be the case, then obviously the estimates process will become a farce. Senator Collins tells me, and I accept the fact, that was not his intention. Obviously when that committee examines further estimates I will be hoping to progress some more.

I do want to make one other comment in relation to Mr Corrigan; that is, to place on record one very important fact which must be understood. I am certainly of the belief that AQIS officers provided references for Mr Corrigan at the time at which he was under investigation. I also know that the UK government was advised that Mr Corrigan was under investigation at the time at which he was appointed. I am yet to precisely establish when he was appointed, but we now know that Mr Corrigan was granted extended leave of absence on 7 September 1994. In spite of that being granted on 7 September 1994, none of the senior executive service officers of AQIS thought it a relevant fact to add to the evidence they were providing to the committee on 29 November.

Mr Corrigan's leave of absence had been approved at the beginning of September and some 2 1/2 months later, knowing that he was about to take up his leave of absence, officers did not draw it to my attention or to the attention of any other senator at the estimates hearings when Mr Corrigan's investigation was discussed. I believe—and I have said it before but I will say it in the chamber—that material information was withheld from the estimates committee. I am not saying that Senator Collins was part of that because I do not believe Senator Collins knew the arrangements, but I do believe that senior officers withheld information from the estimates committee. It is very clear that the leave of absence was approved.

Although the secretary of the department, who approved the leave of absence, was not there, other officers who knew all about it were there. They knew we were examining the whole case in the context of a long delay in finalising the investigation and, for that information to have slipped their mind, I find totally and utterly unbelievable. I place on record my dissatisfaction that the process has developed in this fashion. I do not think that is the proper way for estimates questions to be dealt with, and I hope we will see some improvement.

I place the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service on notice that I will be continuing to pursue this. I look forward to the minister's answers. We are slowly extracting the full story about Mr Phillip Corrigan. That story will be revealed, whether departmental officers like it or not. I think the best way for all concerned is for departmental officers to start to cooperate more fully in the whole process so that, whatever the result, it is arrived at speedily rather than slowly because, the more drawn out this becomes, the more painful it is for all concerned.

On that basis, I look forward to receiving the answer to the committee which Senator Collins has undertaken to give to me tomorrow. I also look forward to the answer to the question of what AQIS officers, if any, provided references for Mr Corrigan. Certainly the answer that was given to a question in the House of Commons by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries indicates that the UK government was certainly of the belief that Mr Corrigan was coming with references from the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to comment further on the motion of censure of me that was passed in the House of Representatives today. In Erskine May's Parliamentary Practice, with relation to the House of Representatives, I notice that it says:

PARA.TAB: A motion of censure of a private Member has been moved on only one occasion—

SPEECH.PARA: I am under the impression never on a senator. It goes on to say:

On a number of occasions a motion of censure of the Leader of the Opposition, or an amendment expressing censure in the form of an alternative proposition, has been agreed to. These are considered to be bad precedents. Such resolutions, as distinct from a resolution of the House suspending or expelling a Member, are of no substantive effect and are only regarded as an expression of opinion by the House.
I must say I would never take the House of Representatives' opinion even vaguely seriously at the moment, and I certainly do not take this political stunt seriously. It continues:

A motion in the form of a censure of a Member, such as the Leader of the Opposition, not being a member of the Executive Government, is not consistent with the parliamentary convention that the purpose of a vote of censure is to question or bring to account a Minister's responsibility to the House.

I mention this to show not only that it was a political stunt in the other chamber but also that it demeaned the party and the minister who introduced it, who was acting as the puppet of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), who just cannot stand me because I keep scoring points against him in the sense that I keep revealing the facts of his extraordinary financial investments. They are extraordinary in the sense that he has only been earning, or at least seen to have been earning, the income of a parliamentarian ever since he was a young man, and certainly has apparently had no access to large riches.

PARA.TAB: So here we have a situation where, if you like, to satisfy the fury, to expiate the rage of this Prime Minister, this absurd resolution was passed in the House of Representatives today, which Erskine May's Parliamentary Practice clearly indicates to be a bad precedent and, of course, a bit of political stupidity. On top of that, as I indicated earlier today, the Treasurer (Mr Willis) behaved in a disgraceful way in the House of Representatives by being party to an arrangement to deceive the chamber about the basis of a statement attributed to a spokesman for the taxation commissioner, when the taxation commissioner has denied to me—and I believe him—that any spokesman for the tax office made such a statement.

As a result of that, I advise the Senate that, when we next meet, I will be giving the following notice of motion: That the Senate notes that the Commissioner for Taxation, Mr Michael Carmody, has stated today that no tax official made a statement on which the Sydney Morning Herald's report of the 25 March 1995 is based to the effect that yesterday a tax office spokesman said the tax commissioner was considering referring Senator Baume's action to the police, the Federal Director of Public Prosecutions and the Privacy Commissioner for investigation; and notes that the Sydney Morning Herald report is similar to paragraph 9 of the confidential minute of 24 March 1995 from the second tax commissioner, Mr P. E. Simpson, to the Treasurer, Mr Willis, which says: `I am considering whether the matter will be referred to the Privacy Commissioner, the Australian Federal Police or the Director of Public Prosecutions for further investigation'—isn't it remarkably similar—calls on the Treasurer to assure the parliament that he did not authorise or request anyone to commit the offence of holding themselves out to be a tax office spokesman; and requires the Treasurer to introduce a police inquiry into who in his office committed this offence.

This was a confidential minute from the tax office to the Treasurer. It was not to be sprayed around, and it was not to be available to people widely. The tax commissioner has assured me that no officer of the tax department made this statement to the newspaper. The onus is on Mr Willis to demonstrate that he has clean hands in this matter and if any one of his staff behaved in this illegal way, they should be exposed and investigated.

The government is massively keen to get the Federal Police to investigate things. It claims that I am going to be investigated. What absolute nonsense! There is no way such an investigation can or will proceed. Such an investigation cannot properly be constituted as a police inquiry. The proposal is absurd. It is a political stunt. I will say this: I will not cooperate with such a stunt if I am asked to because it is improper and illegal and is in breach of two statutes of this parliament.

I simply want to conclude by saying that I did hear some disgraceful speeches in the House of Representatives today—one by Mr Hollis, which was beneath contempt. I am very tempted to respond in kind to Mr Hollis because he is in a glasshouse and should be the last person to throw any stones. I advise him to apologise to me before my patience with him runs out.

As for Mr Mack, I can say this about him. He has, in fact, made some kind of standover threat to me that I will be dealt with in the Federal Court. I just notice that the Independents and the Greens in this chamber had the good sense to vote on this censure motion, which turned out not to be a censure motion, on merit. Mr Mack, I am afraid, revealed once again that he is simply a puppet of the Labor Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today the leader of the Labor Party in New South Wales declared victory. His election will mark the resurrection of the New South Wales economy and the opportunity for the populous state to return to being the best governed. Most senators will be aware of the details of that campaign and how effectively it was run. It was, as usual, a well-run campaign that has brought victory to the Labor Party. This is in contrast to that of our opponents in New South Wales, whose cynical attitude to the electorate ended up causing this defeat.
—Is this all your own work or did your hubbie write it?

—I think the sorts of comments made by Senator Macdonald display his attitude to women in general, his failure to understand that women have progressed a little way further and that the sorts of views they express are their own. I think maybe you should examine your own conscience, and maybe the women in your party should examine your conscience—because obviously you lack one—and in future maybe you should reflect attitudes that accord with mainstream Australia rather than those that accord with your own backward views.
—Order! You are best ignoring interjections, Senator.
—I think it is sometimes worthwhile putting on record the sort of cynical attitude towards women that the Liberal Party displays.

PARA.TAB: Given that the results have been declared in every seat, I would like to address the topic of women's participation in parliament. This topic was raised earlier by Senator Troeth in question time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who is the general secretary of the New South Wales Labor Party?
—And a very good job he has done too, thank you, Senator Macdonald. I did not feel I could mention him, but since you have—
—Order!

—The question of women's participation was raised earlier in question time. I think every senator would agree that there are barriers to women participating in parliament, as has been displayed by the attitude of Senator Macdonald. They have increased family responsibilities, the long hours that parliament sits are a difficulty, and there is a residual belief that somehow women are just not up to the job or—as Senator Macdonald has displayed—a residual attitude that somehow they do not have their own views and that their views are determined by the views of their male relatives or influential males.

PARA.TAB: These barriers have caused harm to the representative nature of parliament. They mean that women, who make up 50 per cent of the population, make up less than 10 per cent of parliamentarians. The New South Wales Labor Party has worked hard since the national conference last year to help women overcome these barriers—

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you fix that up in Queensland?

—Senator Macdonald only displays his own ignorance—and to make parliament more representative. In this election the Labor Party ran a record number of women candidates in winnable seats. Labor women were elected in the lower house seats of Badgerys Creek, Penrith, Cabramatta, Parramatta, Peats, Heffron, Blacktown, Port Jackson and Swansea. One other woman candidate was narrowly defeated in Sutherland. Five more Labor women have been elected to the upper house. An important point to note about these women, with the exception of Badgerys Creek, is that they all hold safe Labor seats. That fact is proof in New South Wales that the Labor Party membership has committed itself to giving women the best possible chance to hold the positions and to make the parliament truly representative.

PARA.TAB: Contrast this with the New South Wales Liberal Party—a very sorry record. The only high profile woman in state parliament, the deputy leader, Kerry Chikarovski, has once again been shouldered aside, with a deal being done between the boys as they fight over Fahey's leadership spot. In the upper house the hard right of the Liberal Party went so far as to force the hardest working woman, Beryl Evans, out of the party's ranks. Ms Evans has since retired from public life, bitterly hurt by her treatment at the hands of her Liberal colleagues.

I would also compare this with the situation in this chamber. The Labor Party in New South Wales has six senators, including two women; that is 33 per cent of positions. The New South Wales Liberal Party has three senators, none of whom are women—that is nil. The New South Wales National Party has two senators, neither of whom are women—that is nil. There should be no more pious rubbish in this place about the Labor Party's commitment to women and women's participation in Parliament House, because there certainly is a commitment there.

I would like to mention briefly some of the candidates who have been elected to parliament in the last election, because they certainly are fine women of great quality. The newest party member, Diane Beamer, who was only elected last night, is a woman of great energy, who is very vocal and an outstanding advocate for her area. She left school, married young and, whilst raising a family, also undertook a university degree. She subsequently went on to work for members of parliament, to represent her community and local government, and her commitment to the community has been acknowledged in this result today. I am very pleased to congratulate her very heartily.

Also there is Reba Meagher, who is a young woman who was elected in the by-election. Reba Meagher hailed from Young Labor. She was twice elected president of the 4,000 strong member organisation. Young Labor in New South Wales is a very strong party organisation. During her term young Labor was revitalised, taking a much higher public profile in the issues of youth employment, law reform and education issues. She was tertiary educated—one of the generation of young people who gained access to higher education under the massive university expansion initiated by this government.

Reba Meagher has also worked extremely effectively for some years as industrial advocate for the Transport Workers Union, before winning her preselection for the seat of Cabramatta. The Cabramatta by-election saw a 22 per cent primary swing to Ms Meagher, and the general election last weekend saw a further 16 per cent, making Cabramatta one of the safest seats in the state.

There is also Marie Andrews who was elected to the safe seat of Peats on the central coast—someone for whom I personally have great admiration. She has had a very long career. After having served the transport officers union for many years and the public service, she decided to make a contribution in the public sphere by running for the seat of Peats. She also has been successfully elected to that seat and, again, with an increased majority—a swing of almost five per cent.

I cannot conclude my remarks without mentioning another candidate, now member: the member for Parramatta, Gabrielle Harrison. I had the pleasure of meeting Gabrielle Harrison some time ago when we were both at university, where she was the President of the Macquarie University students representative group. Gabrielle has continued to participate at that level. She proceeded to complete her arts degree and also to complete part of a law degree before working in the area of law in New South Wales. During that time, her husband unfortunately passed away and she was left a widow. But in spite of all that, and with Tristan her young son, she took on the challenge and successfully won the seat of Parramatta.

I conclude by saying I am very proud of what the Labor Party has achieved in New South Wales by winning government. I also say that I am very proud of the women who have now formed part of that government. I urge the Labor Party to continue with what it is doing; and I urge the Liberal Party to take on the challenge as well and promote the fine women I am sure it also has.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw Sen M.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to also record a tribute to Bob Carr and his team on their great victory in the New South Wales elections which were held last Saturday. Bob Carr has demonstrated that hard work, commitment, integrity and the right policies will succeed—
—Did the general secretary write this for you?
—Senator Macdonald, you remind me of one of those figures they used to have at Luna Park that people used to drop ping-pong balls down. That is about the use of your mouth.

PARA.TAB: As I was saying, Bob Carr has demonstrated that hard work, commitment, integrity and the right policies will succeed. Bob Carr has led the rebuilding of the New South Wales Labor Party after what we acknowledge was a devastating defeat in 1988. Over the past seven years Bob Carr has devoted himself to restoring the Labor Party to its rightful position as the government in New South Wales.

He went extremely close in 1991, when everybody in the polls and in the media wrote him off. He has succeeded in March 1995, and he has succeeded notwithstanding the polls and notwithstanding the biased editorials of the Sydney press. Bob Carr will succeed as premier. He has the policies. He has the team. He has the determination to implement those policies and restore New South Wales as the premier state.

Bob was supported by many people in this great victory, particularly his wife Helena. Also he had the great support of all those hardworking, dedicated loyal branch members throughout New South Wales who get out and do the unheralded work in campaigns and on polling day. But tonight I want specifically to pay tribute to three other people. Firstly, I pay tribute to Diane Beamer, who achieved that wonderful victory at Badgerys Creek. My colleague Senator Neal has already highlighted the significance of Diane's victory and the hard work and determination that she demonstrated to achieve that.

Secondly, I want to pay tribute to Mike Egan, a close friend of mine and a colleague from the Cronulla branch of the ALP, a person with whom I spent many years in my formative years within the ALP. Mike has certainly earned his position as a senior minister in the Bob Carr Labor government and will play a most important role in restoring the finances and the economy of New South Wales to prosperity.

Finally, and most importantly, I want to pay tribute to John Della Bosca, the general secretary of the New South Wales branch of the Australian Labor Party. This has been a particularly tough campaign. I have not seen a campaign with as much mud thrown in it for a long time in New South Wales. A lot of that mud was thrown at the New South Wales ALP head office and the New South Wales right. As general secretary of the New South Wales branch and as the campaign director for that campaign, John Della Bosca had to bear the brunt of that attack. He bore the brunt of that attack with integrity and with decency, something clearly not demonstrated, not even known, by those who attacked him, particularly those who attacked him in this chamber.

We in the party know the pressure that John was under in this campaign. We know how hard he has worked towards his victory, and we appreciate his efforts. I have to say that when I heard the snide interjections from Senator Macdonald this evening, when he made that most disgraceful statement about John, I started to wonder if there is any semblance of decency and respect on the other side. I ask particularly the female senators on the other side of the chamber to go out of this chamber and have a look at what Senator Macdonald said in the Hansard. But you all know what he said, so think about it. Think about whether you really believe that is an appropriate comment to make. The people of New South Wales—

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you just keep quiet?
—You are a paternalistic patroniser.

—I also happen to be a member of the winning team in New South Wales. The people of New South Wales can look forward to their health services being restored. They can look forward to the end of hospital waiting lists, that great promise made by the Liberals when they entered government in 1988. I well recall it. They campaigned on a slogan of ending hospital waiting lists and now the hospital waiting lists are longer and longer. Some of the hospitals are being closed. The people of New South Wales can look—

—What's that, Morticia?

They can look forward to a restored state economy, to improved employment and to the retention of key government services in public ownership. Most of all, the people of New South Wales can look forward to honesty and integrity in government.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 2 February 1995:

PARA.TAB: What are the monthly cash flow implications for revenue arising from the changed procedures in relation to provisional tax, whereby any refund entitlement is remitted to the taxpayer, following assessment with a separate bill subsequently charged for provisional tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Assistant Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: In past years, provisional taxpayers who were not subject to the quarterly system were notified of their provisional tax on their notice of assessment. From this year, provisional tax is being notified separately. This means that taxpayers who pay provisional tax and who have excess credits at the time of their assessment will get a refund. A refund arises where there is an excess of credits (including provisional credit, prescribed payments system credits, and tax instalment deductions) over the taxpayer's primary tax assessed. Previously, this refund would have been automatically credited against provisional tax notified to the taxpayer that was not yet due and payable. Taxpayers who are due a refund will now have use of that money until any provisional tax debt is due and payable.

The implications for the revenue cash flow are that the refunds will be issued when the income tax returns are assessed and payments of the provisional tax will be due no earlier than 31 March 1995. Previously the two amounts were combined and any amount still payable was due no earlier than 31 March.

These particular refunds and payments are not separately identified, the refunds paid are included in Individuals Refunds and the payments are included in Gross Other Individuals collections. As stated in Budget Paper No.1 of the Budget Statements 1994-95, the full year impact of this change is estimated to increase both gross collections for other individuals and refunds for individuals by around $550 million in 1994-95.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology upon notice, on 6 February 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) What services were provided to the Department of Industry, Science and Technology by Wunderman, Cato, Johnson, South Melbourne, at a cost of $626,500, described as marketing and distribution.
(2) What was the purpose of these services.
(3) Over what length of time were these services provided.
(4) What was the total cost of these services.
(5) What was distributed.
(6) To whom was it distributed.
(7) When did the distribution occur.
(8) What marketing services were involved.
(9) What other costs were involved in this purchase by the department.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) What services were provided to the Department of Industry, Science and Technology by Wunderman, Cato, Johnson, South Melbourne, at a cost of $626,500, described as marketing and distribution.
Following a limited tender process, Wunderman, Cato, Johnson (WCJ) was contracted by the Office of AusIndustry to provide marketing, communication and distribution services for BizLink products.

BizLink is a family of information products, the first of which is BizHelp, a database directory of government business assistance programs and services. BizHelp was developed by Human Solutions Pty Ltd, a high technology software development business located in Glenorchy, Tasmania.
The main tasks identified in the tender process, and the estimated costs for fulfilment are :

ANSWER.PARA: marketing and communication fees (see table below)—$245,000
promotional tasks—$47,500
distribution of kits and quarterly upgrades—$90,000
management of customer enquiries and orders—$22,000
management of BizHelp stock—$97,500
management of revenue, financial records, and reporting—$45,000
creation, management and maintenance of an electronic database of clients—$37,000
ancillary items—printing, photography, couriers, travel etc—$42,500

PARA.TAB: It was not possible initially to put a fixed price or a fixed delivery date on some of these tasks as by their nature they will vary in complexity and scope, depending on demand for the product and other variables.

Government purchasing requirements dictate the need for allocation of a budget against specified tasks, so an indicative amount was included in tender documents. This amount is a best estimate using the professional judgment of the tenderer. The uncertainty applies in particular to promotional tasks such as production of promotional flyers.

In a contract of this nature, it is not possible to determine exact costs since exact numbers of subscribers are not known in advance of the marketing activities. Costs will vary in accordance with the number of subscribers, which in turn determines the number of times the marketing and distribution services are used. Estimates have been made using a subscriber base of 10,000, and the total figures in each component rounded up.

ANSWER.PARA: Payment of Fees

PARA.TAB: AusIndustry has agreed to pay the contractor a flat rate management fee in return for marketing communication and promotion services. The payment schedule for these services is as follows:

The contract with WCJ provides for this arrangement to be reviewed by both parties and a new agreement reached by close of business Monday 17 April 1995. The annual amount allocated, $245,000, is indicative only, as it assumes continuation of a similar arrangement past March 1995.
(2) What was the purpose of these services.
The purpose of these services is to ensure an efficient and professional delivery of BizLink products to government and other subscribers.
(3) Over what length of time were these services provided.
The contract is current until November 1995. The monthly retainer is in place until March and will be reviewed in terms of value for money at that date.
(4) What was the total cost of these services.
This is not known as the contract is not yet complete.
(5) What was distributed.

The BizHelp kit comprises: an A4 two ring binder containing two 3.5" floppy disks; installation documentation; training and tutorial documentation; a licence agreement; a newsletter; an AusIndustry mouse mat.
In addition WCJ distributed promotional material and brochures.
(6) To whom was it distributed
The directory contains information on government assistance programs and services provided from both State and Commonwealth agencies.
Over 1,000 copies of BizHelp have been distributed to date. Copies of the directory were sent to all agencies which provided information for inclusion in it.
It was also sent as a matter of course to the electoral offices of all Federal Members of Parliament and Senators, including Senator Calvert's office.
The value of this service has been recognised by the private sector and feedback from subscribers has been extremely positive.
The system is updated every quarter, with the next upgrade due in March 1995.
(7) When did the distribution occur
The major distribution occurred immediately following the launch of the product on 18 November 1994.
The distribution service is provided on an ongoing basis via a dedicated 1-800 toll free number.
(8) What marketing services were involved
WCJ have provided input into the overall marketing plan for BizLink products.
They provide a quarterly newsletter, copy, layout and design of magazine and newspaper articles.
They have developed an enquiry pack for callers to the 1-800 number.
They provide research and advice on the applicability of advertising offers for BizLink products.
They are currently working with the professional accounting bodies with the objective of promoting the use of BizHelp by all public practitioners.

WCJ provide other services to AusIndustry, for example acting as the distribution point for public tender documents, providing advice on AusIndustry marketing activity, and other hands-on involvement such as designing advertisements, writing advertising copy, and preparing case studies.
This marketing and promotion activity has resulted in subscription income to AusIndustry in excess of $40,000, so far. These, and future funds, will be used to offset program development costs.
(9) What other costs were involved in this purchase by the department.
There are no other costs involved with this purchase.

The current base rent in the Melbourne CBD is estimated at $175 per m2, which would be the notional rent charged to the Review if it sought a similar standard of accommodation at the present time.
