(3) The Review was originally allocated space on the 5th Floor of Casselden Place, 2 Lonsdale Street, of up to 185 m2. The maximum amount of space the Review would have used was approximately 85 m2. It presently occupies approximately 62 m2.
(4) There is no lease for the Review. It is proposed, however, that the Review will vacate its accommodation in Melbourne around March 1995.
(5) Lease of space in Casselden Place by the former Department of Health, Housing and Community Services was on commercial tenancy arrangements agreed with Australian Estate Management.
(6) No, this was not required as the Review was given accommodation within its portfolio department's lease of Casselden Place.
(7) There are currently two Review staff at the premises.

(8) A space of 52.3 m2 is currently made available for three Review staff on the 4th floor, Cosmopolitan Building in Woden, Canberra. The Review does not pay rent directly for this space; the space forms part of the area tenanted by the Department of Housing and Regional Development. All other resource costs are met from the Review's budget.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 7 February 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Which Rangelands areas has the Land and Water Resources Research and Development Corporation identified as being unviable for pastoral production as currently practised.
(2) Which Rangeland areas does the Department regard as being economically or environmentally unviable for pastoral production as currently practised.
(3) How much funding has been allocated and is proposed for the South West Queensland Rural Adjustment Scheme.
(4) How much would it cost to undertake regional adjustment in the areas the Department has identified as being unviable.
(5) How much is the portfolio seeking for regional adjustment in the next 3 years.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Land and Water Resources Research and Development Corporation (LWRRDC) has not identified areas of Australia's rangelands as being unviable for pastoral production. LWRRDC Occasional Paper 06/93 "R&D for Sustainable Use and Management of Australia's Rangelands", however, sets out the proceedings of a national workshop involving representatives of the grazing industries, Aboriginal and conservation organisations, researchers and policy makers to identify opportunities and priorities for rangelands research and development.

This included a report by D Wilcox and G Cunningham on the "Economic and Ecological Sustainability of Current Land Use in Australia's Rangelands". Financial data in this paper showed the strong performance of much of the northern beef industry, and the difficult situation faced by many wool producers in southern pastoral areas. While these results supported earlier reviews undertaken by State governments, it should be noted that there is wide variability in financial performance between producers within any one region. Since that report there has been a lift in wool prices, but high debt levels continue to be a significant factor in the economic performance of some wool enterprises in the rangelands.
(2) The Department of Primary Industries and Energy has been involved in a number of studies examining conditions in Australia's rangelands.

A National Rangelands Strategy is being developed that could provide a strategic basis for the assessment and adjustment process in the sensitive arid areas of the country. The Strategy is being developed jointly by the Agriculture and Resource Management Council of Australia and New Zealand and the Australian and New Zealand Environment and Conservation Council. The Joint Working Group of the above two Ministerial Councils which has government, grazier, Aboriginal, environmental and CSIRO representation has undertaken a public consultation process and is currently developing rangeland goals. The Strategy will be completed in 1995.

In 1993 the Bureau of Resource Sciences completed a report `Opportunities for Regional Rural Adjustment' which provided an overview of the range of needs of rural industries across Australia in areas identified by the States/Territories that may require a regional approach to achieving adjustment goals. Rangeland regions reviewed included South West Queensland, The Western Division of New South Wales, the Far West Coast of South Australia and the Gascoyne Pastoral Region of Western Australia.

The Commonwealth also collects physical and financial information on the farm sector to enable it to undertake economic research to support government policy and program development and implementation.

This information is collected by the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics, ABARE, in a national annual survey of broadacre farms throughout Australia. The annual survey does not provide detailed analysis of the economic and environmental viability of specific regions.

In 1994, however, ABARE did increase its sample of farms in a number of regions including the Burdekin and South West Queensland. The additional data from these regions are being used to analyse aspects of the national dryland salinity program and the national bore rehabilitation scheme.

The Government's approach to rural regional adjustment involves the community in identifying problems and developing solutions to facilitate agriculture moving to a more economically viable and ecologically sustainable basis. The Commonwealth does not, however, declare regions as unviable in either economic or environmental terms.

(3) The estimated Commonwealth contribution to the South-West Queensland Strategy under the Rural Adjustment Scheme (RAS) is $5.8 million over the years 1994-95 to 1996-97 comprising $2.5 million from the RAS reserve (matched by Queensland) and $3.3 million allocated from normal RAS. A further $0.4 million has been provided by Queensland under the 90:10 RAS cost sharing arrangements.

As part of the South West Queensland Strategy the Commonwealth is also contributing to improved natural resource management through the National Landcare Program with funding of $2.8m to be matched by the Queensland government.
(4) As indicated under (2) above, the Commonwealth has made no specific assessment of areas of Australia which are unviable.

(5) Funding for the Rural Adjustment Scheme regional initiatives will be drawn from the Commonwealth Rural Adjustment Scheme reserve. The reserve was established in the 1994-95 Budget context to provide funding for RAS regional initiatives and as a basis for smoothing between year (and between State) variations in demand for assistance and/or fund specific productivity improvement measures. Funding for the reserve is derived from underspends from normal RAS. The government announced a further $10 million over two years for adjustment in drought prone regions as part of the 8 December Drought Package.

I have proposed to the States/Territories my intention to establish a competitive bidding process for community based projects which make the greatest contribution to structural adjustment and related needs. In the meantime specific proposals including the South West Queensland Strategy are being funded on a pilot basis.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 6 February 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) What is the reason for undertaking a million dollar capital expense project of outfitting the Repatriation General Hospital, Daw Park, South Australia with personal computers.
(2) Why was such a project commenced when the transfer to State control was planned for the Hospital.
(3) Will details be released about the tender/quote of $292 000 for personal computers bought late last year by the hospital.
(4) Who was responsible for the placement of the order.
(5) Who won the tender/quote and, on what basis was the order given to the successful company.
(6) Were the order details recorded in the Commonwealth Government Purchasing and Disposal Gazette; if not, why not.

(7) (a) Was this project a joint effort with the South Australian State Government; if so, how much is the department funding and how much is the State funding, (b) what role did the State play in the process.
(8) Where did the funding for this project come from.
(9) Did the hospital transfer funding designated for medical and surgical specialised equipment use, to fund this project.
(10) Will an assurance be given that the proper guidelines concerning the purchase of this tender/quote were adhered to.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The existing mainframe computers were proving to be expensive, complex to run and maintain and hospital management initiated an outfitting project to remedy this situation. The Acting Chief Executive of Daw Park has advised that savings in excess of $250,000 were realised.

(2) The project was undertaken to accommodate significant staff reductions, reduce overall cost structures, prepare for reduced funding under the casemix-funded arrangements, and to allow the development of necessary billing and statistical systems which would provide improved electronic access to critical information relating to the health care of veterans post integration of RGH Daw Park.

(b) The State did not play any active role in the project. However, all known State Information Technology standards were taken into account during the formulation of the strategy.
(8) Funding for the project was derived from several internal sources, none of which required any additional Commonwealth funding.
(10) Period contract and general purchasing guidelines were followed in respect of the purchasing activities associated with this project.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, upon notice, on 13 February 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) What action is being taken to implement the Labor Party policy to protect the Ramsar listed wetlands as national parks or nature reserves.
(2) Is the Minister aware that in Tasmania the Minister for Parks and Wildlife encourages the shooting of native and migratory waterfowl in Ramsar listed wetlands.

(3) Is the Minister aware that serious lead contamination has been identified at Moulting Lagoon and the Apsley Marshes (both listed under the Ramsar Convention); if so, what action will be taken to protect these areas and other listed places from future degradation from recreation hunting.

(4) Is it the intent of the Ramsar Convention and other international treaties to which Australia is a signatory to provide safe refuge and passage to migratory species of birds; if so, how is this reconciled with allowing the indiscriminate shooting of these birds.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) There has been no specific action to implement the Labor Party policy to protect the Ramsar listed wetlands as national parks and nature reserves. The Federal Government continues to work co-operatively with the State and Territory Governments to ensure better management of Ramsar sites and other wetlands. For example, through the National Wetlands Program in 1994-95, the Federal Government has allocated a total of $585 000 to assist with wetland management issues, including the development of management plans for Ramsar sites.

(2) I am aware that on 13 February 1995 the Tasmanian Minister for Parks and Wildlife announced that the 1995 duck season would proceed from 4 March to 7 May 1995. I have been advised that the majority of Ramsar sites in Tasmania that provide suitable habitat for waterfowl, including Logan Lagoon, Moulting Lagoon and Orielton Lagoon are closed or partly closed to shooting on a permanent basis. Other Tasmanian Ramsar sites are privately owned and shooting is often prohibited or at least restricted by the owners.

(3) I am aware that lead contamination has been identified at Moulting Lagoon Game Reserve and the Apsley Marshes. The Tasmanian Government prepared a status report on Ramsar sites within its jurisdiction for inclusion in the National Report for the Fifth Conference of Contracting Parties to the Ramsar Convention in 1993. The report outlined action undertaken by the Tasmanian Government to rehabilitate Moulting Lagoon. Tasmania also advised that a study into the occurrence and uptake of lead shot within Ramsar sites is being carried out. Results from this study are yet to be finalised.

During 1994-95, the National Wetlands Program is providing funds ($24,760) to the Tasmanian Parks and Wildlife Service to prepare management plans for all ten Ramsar sites in Tasmania. The plans will consider management guidelines identified by the Ramsar Convention and will address the management implications associated with the hunting of waterfowl.

The Australian Nature Conservation Agency within my Portfolio is currently working with the State and Territory wildlife authorities under the auspices of the Australia and New Zealand Environment and Conservation Council to address the management problems associated with lead contamination. Currently South Australia has prohibited the use of lead shot in duck shooting and the Northern Territory and Victoria are considering adopting a similar policy. Tasmania is considering prohibiting the use of lead shot in some areas.

(4) Under the Ramsar Convention the Federal Government has obligations to ensure that listed wetlands are managed so as to maintain their ecological character. Where listed wetlands occur within the jurisdiction of a State or Territory Government, that Government is responsible for ensuring Australia's obligations are met under the Ramsar Convention. Such an arrangement is consistent with the Intergovernmental Agreement on the Environment.

As with land and resource management, primary responsibility for wildlife management lies with the State and Territory Governments. Accordingly, in Australia hunting of wildlife is controlled by the relevant State or Territory wildlife authorities which closely monitor waterfowl populations and, where appropriate, take steps to protect certain species, reduce bag limits, restrict or declare open seasons.

Australia is signatory to a number of other international treaties and agreements concerned with the protection of migratory species of birds. The Convention on the Conservation of Migratory Species of Wild Animals (also known as CMS or as the Bonn Convention) aims to secure the conservation of endangered or threatened species which undergo cyclic and predictable migrations across one or more national boundaries. As with the Ramsar Convention, implementation of CMS in Australia is the purview of the State and Territory Governments, consistent with the Intergovernmental Agreement on the Environment.

CMS takes two approaches to protect migratory species, each reflected in a separate Appendix to the Convention text:—Appendix I lists those migratory species which are in danger of extinction throughout all or significant portions of their ranges. The taking of any species listed on Appendix I is prohibited. Australia does not have any migratory birds listed on Appendix I. Appendix II lists species which would benefit from international co-operation. Australia has some 64 species of migratory birds listed on Appendix II. Most of these species are shorebirds and are not subject to hunting in Australia. Only one species of duck is listed; the Radjah Shelduck, Tadorna radjah. The distribution of this species is limited to northern Australia. It is not hunted in either the Northern Territory or Queensland and duck hunting is banned altogether in Western Australia .

Australia has bilateral Migratory Bird Agreements with the Governments of Japan and the People's Republic of China respectively. Article II of both Agreements, makes provision for the establishment of hunting seasons within sustainable limits, for birds protected by the Agreement. Only two species of duck are listed under both Agreements, the Northern Shoveler, Anas clypeata and the Garganey, Anas querquedula. Both species are protected and are not hunted.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Telecommunications: Optus Vision and Moco Joint Venture

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 27 February 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) What are the significant differences between the Optus Vision and Moco joint venture proposals which were presented to and examined by Austel during 1994.

(2) Which, if any, of these significant differences are considered to have potential consequences for the competitiveness of the telecommunications, broadband or subscription television sectors, and what would be those consequences.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) On 6 December 1994 the Minister for Communications and the Arts tabled a report by AUSTEL on the Optus Vision and Telstra ("MOCO") broadband joint venture proposals.

AUSTEL found that, in principle, the two proposals were similar, in that the cable network would be installed by a licensed carrier but would be owned and operated by a service provider who would in turn provide pay television carriage to a licensed broadcaster and telephony carriage back to the licensed carrier.

However, AUSTEL found that the two proposals differed in the provision of broadband services. Optus Vision intended to exclusively provide broadband telecommunications services (for example, multimedia) directly to customers. Under the MOCO proposal, broadband services were to be provided by both Telstra and MOCO itself: Telstra would provide broadband services which were interactive multimedia or non-entertainment home and business services and MOCO would provide broadband services with limited interactivity (such as home shopping, betting and games).

AUSTEL reported that there would be an asymmetric regulatory arrangement between Optus Networks and Telstra for broadband services under the Optus Vision proposal. If Telstra were to offer such services, it would be obliged to offer interconnection to Optus Networks and hence to Optus Vision customers. However, Telstra would have no right to interconnect to the Optus Vision network and hence such access could be denied.

The report also identified a potential difference in the provision of pay television services. While Optus Vision intended to provide pay television carriage exclusively to Multicom (a pay television licensee under the Broadcasting Services Act 1992), MOCO had, at the time of finalising the report, yet to confirm whether it intended to offer similar exclusivity to PAYCO (also a pay television licensee)—that is, there was a possibility that MOCO could offer carriage to other licensed broadcasters as service providers under Part 10 of the Telecommunications Act 1991.

(2) AUSTEL found that the different arrangements in regard to provision of broadband services had the potential to impact adversely on competition. It supported the view that equitable interconnection arrangements are necessary for the development of broadband services and considered it essential that the Government's policy commitment to equitable interconnection arrangements should apply in this newly developing sector of the industry.

On 24 November 1994, the Minister announced that the Government would act to ensure that broadband services are subject to the relevant access provisions of the Telecommunications Act 1991. He said that he would issue a direction to AUSTEL to ensure that service providers would have access to broadband cable for the provision of telephony and broadband services. For pay television use of cable, there would be an exemption from this access regime until at least 1 July 1997. The Department of Communications and the Arts is currently undertaking public consultation on a draft direction.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 1 March 1995:

PARA.TAB: With reference to assurances given by officials of the department in the Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Legislation Committee Estimates hearing of 15 February 1995 that all contact between the department and the consultant Mr Laurens Fluitman had ceased:
(1) Did a senior officer of the department, Mr Adrian Fielding, meet with Mr Fluitman on at least three occasions over the past three months, including one meeting in February 1995.
(2) Why did Mr Fielding travel, at taxpayers' expense, to meet Mr Fluitman at a private house on the Gold Coast on 30 November 1994 and on 28 January 1995.
(3) Why was the Defence Export Program's desk officer, Ms Anitra Kenny, also present at the January 1995 meeting, at taxpayers' expense.
(4) What was the purpose of these meetings, who approved them and why.
(5) Was Mr Sutadi Suparlan, a director of the Indonesian Government Agency BPIS, also present at this January meeting.
(6) Following this meeting, did the department give approval for Mr Fielding to travel to Indonesia in February at taxpayers' expense.
(7) What was the purpose of Mr Fielding's trip to Indonesia, who authorised it, and why.

(8) Was Mr Fielding accompanied to Indonesia by a representative of a large Australian public company on the basis that Mr Fielding would arrange a meeting with BPIS to discuss a Government-led venture.

(9) Rather than meet with BPIS, did Mr Fielding instead introduce the representative of the Australian firm to Mr Suparlan and Mr Fluitman in their role of representatives of the company `Australin', of which they are the owners.

(10) Is it acceptable for a member of the Australian public service travelling to Indonesia at Australian taxpayers' expense to act as a broker for the private business interests of Mr Suparlan and Mr Fluitman.
(11) During this visit to Indonesia, did Mr Fielding hold discussions relating to the Inspector General's inquiry into the Fluitman affair with Jakarta-based representatives of the department.
(12) Had these Jakarta based officials of the department been questioned by the Inspector General about the Fluitman affair prior to Mr Fielding's most recent visit to Indonesia.
(13) If no such questioning had taken place prior to Mr Fielding's visit, why was Mr Fielding allowed to conduct such discussions.
(14) Is the department intending to fly a senior official of the Indonesian agency BPIS, Mr Suparlan, to Melbourne for a program of industry briefings at taxpayers' expense in March 1995.

(15) Had the department been advised that Mr Suparlan is shortly to leave his post within BPIS and that a number of Defence personnel, including the Defence Exports Program's Indonesian desk officer, are aware that a replacement for Mr Suparlan has already been named.
(16) Why was an invitation not extended instead to Mr Suparlan's replacement at BPIS.
(17) Will all these matters be considered in the Inspector General's inquiry into the Fluitman affair.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) to (17) I have referred all matters raised in the question to the Inspector-General for investigation in conjunction with the current investigation into the Fluitman contract arrangements. The Inspector-General's findings will be made available to Senator Baume after I have received them and had time to consider any consequential action that may need to be taken. Until that time, it would be inappropriate for me to comment on the issues raised.
